title: Fix for basic auth vs. url escaped passwords.
body: Failure case is something like user:p@ssword: node s url.parse expects this to be escaped in the URL string   user:p 40ssword   but they must be unescaped before base64 encoding for basic auth.  testing @mikeal

title: Connects to the same host when redirected to another host
body: When request gets a redirect to another host  it will keep the same underlying Agent which will connect to the same host as the first request. E.g.:      request  uri:  http://graph.facebook.com/yesbabyyes/picture    function     console.log arguments    ;      It will get a 302 to Location http://profile.ak.fbcdn.net/hprofile ak snc4/48812_548215162_1269_q.jpg but it will still connect to graph.facebook.com the next time.

title: Fixes issue  14  following redirects to another host.
body: As previously reported in issue  14  when following redirects to another host request will still connect to the original host. This is a fix for that.

title: Add body as a property to response?
body: Hey there   How do you feel about adding  body  as a property to  response ? That would simplify callbacks to be just  function  error  response  .  I ve become a big fan of [Streamline.js] https://github.com/Sage/streamlinejs   which lets you write async code as if it was sync  really awesome <3 . It makes the  admittedly not robust  assumption that async callbacks are of the form   error  result    which lets you do stuff like:      try       var result = someAsyncTask foo  bar  _ ;    // the _ is the callback placeholder     // do something with result   catch  error        // do something with error        Which would otherwise be:      someAsyncTask foo  bar  function  error  result        if  error            // do something with error       else           // do something with result         ;      The reason that s awesome is because this totally removes crazy indentation levels and makes code generally so much easier to follow and reason about  especially when it comes to error handling .  But of course  since JS as a language doesn t have a notion of multiple return values  any callback arguments beyond the first two are lost by Streamline. Hence my request. =   In parallel  I m working with the Streamline author to see if we can add a feature that automatically detects and  packs  multiple return values into an array:      var results = someAsyncTask foo  bar  _ ; // if someAsyncTask calls the callback w/ multiple values: var a = results[0]  b = results[1]  c = results[3];      So the pattern for using request would look like:      var result = request.get opts  _ ; var response = result[0]; var body = result[1];      Which is reasonable. But I figure I d ask    would you be open to adding  body  as a property onto the  response  object to _streamline_ this? ;   Thanks in advance

title: Redirects w/ POST on HTTP 302/303/308: Found
body: BACKGROUND    [rfc1945 HTTP 1.0] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1945          302 Moved Temporarily     The requested resource resides temporarily under a different URL.    Since the redirection may be altered on occasion  the client should    continue to use the Request URI for future requests.     The URL must be given by the Location field in the response. Unless    it was a HEAD request  the Entity Body of the response should    contain a short note with a hyperlink to the new URI s .     If the 302 status code is received in response to a request using    the POST method  the user agent must not automatically redirect the    request unless it can be confirmed by the user  since this might    change the conditions under which the request was issued.         Note: When automatically redirecting a POST request after        receiving a 302 status code  some existing user agents will        erroneously change it into a GET request.        [rfc2616 HTTP 1.1] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616       10.3.3 302 Found     The requested resource resides temporarily under a different URI.    Since the redirection might be altered on occasion  the client SHOULD    continue to use the Request URI for future requests.  This response    is only cacheable if indicated by a Cache Control or Expires header    field.     The temporary URI SHOULD be given by the Location field in the    response. Unless the request method was HEAD  the entity of the    response SHOULD contain a short hypertext note with a hyperlink to    the new URI s .      If the 302 status code is received in response to a request other    than GET or HEAD  the user agent MUST NOT automatically redirect the    request unless it can be confirmed by the user  since this might    change the conditions under which the request was issued.        Note: RFC 1945 and RFC 2068 specify that the client is not allowed       to change the method on the redirected request.  However  most       existing user agent implementations treat 302 as if it were a 303       response  performing a GET on the Location field value regardless       of the original request method. The status codes 303 and 307 have       been added for servers that wish to make unambiguously clear which       kind of reaction is expected of the client.      So what happened is after the release of HTTP 1.0  prior to the advent of HTTP 1.1 which brought codes  303   and  307  the spec read that the client MUST NOT redirect  POST  verbs temporarily. Unfortunately  there was no mechanism in the spec to redirect  POST  verbs    slight oversight    and the browsers were redirecting solely on the basis of  Location  header. It is not common place for  HTTP 302  to be legacy for the more explicit  HTTP 303 . This functionality should be permitted in Request too.  Both  302   and  303  require user approval. But  because Request won t be able to easily get that I suggest we support a feature to auto approve on behalf of the user.  In essence  if there is a  Location  header the client should reissue the request as a  GET  rather than a  POST . I m going to create an option for this functionality and default it to enabled  per the expected behaviors. I m also going to amend HTTP 308 to redirect with the POST verb  per the explicit word of the HTTP 1.1 spec.

title: SSL fails with Request@1.9.5   Node@0.4.8
body: I have some code that relies on Request to make SSL requests  and upon upgrading to Node 0.4.8 those calls began to silently fail.  I noticed there was a test ssl.js file in my ./Request/tests directory  doesn t appear to be in git?   I ran it  and that also failed.  I then cloned Request s git repo  @1.9.6  484afc  into my code  and my calls began to work. So  some changes w/ Node 0.4.8 appears to have broken SSL support in Request <= 1.9.5.  Luckily whatever the issue is has been fixed with the unreleased  on npm  1.9.6 code.  I m not sure what the timeframe is to post 1.9.6 to npm  if this is an unintended bug introduced into Node  or if there s anything that can be done about older versions. But  I at least figured I d post an issue to make it known in case someone else runs into a similar problem.

title: Infinite loop with 303
body: I recently had a problem where my app is getting into an infinite loop. I am doing a simple get on a page that returns a 303 redirect. Due to some other bug  the redirect redirects to itself. This leads to an infinite loop and error that doesn t go away and will eventually bring the server down    .  We are going to fix the bad redirects  but in the meantime we need a way to guard against this. I don t know anything about the way request handles redirects   is there a way to stop it from following the redirect? Initially I thought it must be an error in our code but going through the loop in the debugger was jumping between the error and a line in request that was doing callback if options.callback was set with error. That callback keeps getting set and I can t stop it   I just want to return when I encounter an issue like this.  Here s the error:  Error: Exceeded maxRedirects. Probably stuck in a redirect loop.    at ClientRequest.<anonymous>   .. node_modules/request/main.js:215:31     at ClientRequest.g  events.js:143:14     at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:64:17     at HTTPParser.onIncoming  http.js:1349:9     at HTTPParser.onHeadersComplete  http.js:108:31     at Socket.ondata  http.js:1226:22     at Socket._onReadable  net.js:683:27     at IOWatcher.onReadable [as callback] net.js:177:10

title: The  end  event isn t emitted for some responses

I encountered this problem when trying to fetch https://profiles.google.com/VoxPelli through JSDom. I tracked it down to being that the response object in this file only emitted  data  events and no  end  events. The change here fixed that.   I hope the bonus spelling correction of  because  is okay as well :

title: Misc. cleanup and fixes
parse option
body: What do you think about having a parse option that parses the response before calling the callback? So you could get something like this going:      var couch = require  request  .defaults  headers:   content type : application/json    accept type : application/json   parse: true  ; couch.get  http://localhost:5984/pages/_design/pages   function req  resp  body    console.log body.views ;   ;      I think if parse is set to true  I think it should set the body to undefined if the response is empty  rather than throwing a parse error  at least when the response has an error code. It should be OK to return an empty response in a 404 even if accept type is application/json.

title: Parse json: Issue  51
body: Here s a fix for  51. It parses the JSON if the following conditions are met:   the json option is truth   the response content type is  application/json    the response body isn t empty  Both response.body and the body parameter in the callback are set to the parsed JSON. I wasn t sure if I should leave response.body unparsed and only parse the body that s passed to the function. I chose to make them both parsed. The raw JSON can be obtained by setting the request header and body manually instead of using the JSON option.  Another thing to consider is passing on a JSON parse exception to the callback if the JSON doesn t parse  instead of letting the exception be thrown. Should I be doing that?

title: Add abort   method
body: We have a running request to check some version compatibility to prompt users if they should upgrade  but we run the commands even if the version is out of date. Since we are receiving JSON it is buffered  but even if the request fails we ignore errors since this is a somewhat optional nicety. Being able to abort a buffered request would be a great boon.

title: Why isn t  url.query  accounted for?
body: In the case that a pre parsed url object is passed in for the  uri  option  is there a reason that the  query  object and/or string are never accounted for?  Essentially  I m trying to append a query param to GET requests  before shipping off the HTTP request with  request . Something like this does not work: https://gist.github.com/1148093  Looking deeper into the code  it looks like node core is the one who drops the ball on handling  query . So the real question is  should  request  pre process a passed in  query  option when present? I say yes

title: gunzip if necessary
use Buffer for the body
body: Here s my patch for gh 57  I used the    2 buffer size technique in the end as it was simpler  it s a good heuristic.  I made it so that the  body  in the callback is only set to be a  Buffer  if  encoding: null  is set  otherwise a  string  is returned so not to break existing code.

title: Add request/response times to response object

title: Should content type default to  application/x www form urlencoded  for POST requests?
body: Here s the backstory: I was trying to use request to make a POST request to a server running express. I kept on getting 500s  but it would work when I used curl. After four hours of trying to figure out wtf is wrong  I find out the server is using express.bodyParser and assuming req.body would exist  however the bodyParser middleware only populates body on POST and only if the application/x www form urlencoded content type is set  which curl sets automatically when you POST .   So  this patch sets the content type to be application/x www form urlencoded if the user hasn t already set one. It s not perfect  because it detects if it s set only by the one particular capitalization scheme  but it is consist with the rest of the code in that way.

title: Strict SSL behavior
body: I d like to add two options: 1.  strictSSL  flag: Validate the server s certificate  and treat it as an error if there are any problems with it.   This includes self signed certificates.  2.  ca    key    cert : Just pass through to the same fields in node s request options.  I m envisioning something like this:      javascript if  options.strictSSL     res.connection.pair.cleartext.authorized      var er = new Error res.connection.pair.cleartext.authorizationError    // abort the request  call cb with the error   // do not upload any bytes.  this is now a security risk.   // maybe should happen even before headers are sent    // since they might include Authorization info?

title: progression callbacks
body: For wiring up to progress bars  it d be nice to have insight into: 1. How much of the total expected request body has been uploaded. 2. How much of the total expected response body has been downloaded.  HTTP requests can look at the Content Length  and fs streams can stat the file and check the size.  This will make it much easier to integrate with things like https://github.com/substack/node multimeter

title: Handle cookies
body: I stumbled upon a page that set cookies in the redirection. I don t know if it is part of the http spec or not  but I had to change the redirection code within request to handle this.   Since request does not handle cookies itself  it might make sense to build a generic callback where the caller can play with the headers etc.  Thanks  Julien.  _Mikeal changed the title to add more generic support for cookies._

title: POST Redirects
body: Line 251 of main.js has  self.method  ==  POST      as a condition to the redirect.    Unfortunately  the increasingly common Post/Redirect/Get  PRG  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post/Redirect/Get pattern  where a redirect will be returned from a post to avoid the risk of POST duplication doesn t work.    In this case  the redirect should use a GET as usual after the POST has returned the redirect.  Would you consider  perhaps  a flag to override this default behavior?

title: Document strictSSL option
Can t do multipart requests that contain  frontier
body: request uses  frontier  as the static multipart boundary  which means that it s impossible to create requests that contain that word. request should auto generate a long random string.

title: Can t post binary to multipart requests
body: request tries to concatenate text to the  body  part of a multipart request  which stringifies the buffer object. Instead  it should write the buffer to the socket as is.

title: Error handling with .pipe  ?
body: I m attempting to refactor some code that currently uses node get:      javascript          new get url  .toDisk dl  function err  file                pool.release obj ;             if  err                    downloads[url].emit  done   err ;                 delete downloads[url];                 return callback err ;                           fs.rename dl  filepath  function err                    downloads[url].emit  done   err  filepath ;                 delete downloads[url];                 return callback err  filepath ;               ;           ;      Into request  and having some trouble. My current  blue sky code  is      javascript         var req_dl = request url .on  error   function err                pool.release obj ;             downloads[url].emit  done   err ;             delete downloads[url];             return callback err ;                    .on  end   function                 pool.release obj ;             fs.rename dl  filepath  function err                    downloads[url].emit  done   err  filepath ;                 delete downloads[url];                 return callback err  filepath ;               ;                    .pipe fs.createWriteStream dl  ;      Which fails  because there is no eventemitter to bind the  .on   s on. It seems like there are two ways to use request: simple chaining with  .pipe    and providing a callback. Earlier I was doing something else: allowing one to stream the file but also catch errors. I don t see an exposed way to both use  .pipe    and grab errors or success from request. Is there one  that just isn t documented or obvious? Thanks

title: Refresh http header is not followed
body: Some websites still send the non standard Netscape era Refresh HTTP header. This header is supported by all browsers IE Firefox Chrome etc eg: Webkit s implementation can be found here: http://trac.webkit.org/browser/trunk/Source/WebCore/platform/network/HTTPParsers.cpp L106 The websites which send this Refresh HTTP header are not obscure sites which can be ignored. For example I ve received the refresh header from microsoft.com: Trying 207.46.19.254... connected Connected to www.microsoft.com 207.46.19.254 port 80 0 > GET / HTTP/1.1 > User Agent: curl/7.19.7 x86_64 pc linux gnu libcurl/7.19.7 OpenSSL/0.9.8k zlib/1.2.3.3 libidn/1.15 > Host: www.microsoft.com > Accept: / > HTTP 1.0 assume close after body < HTTP/1.0 200 OK < Connection: Close < Pragma: no cache < cache control: no cache < Refresh: 0.1 < Content Type: text/html; charset=iso 8859 1 < < DOCTYPE html PUBLIC //W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN http://www.w3.org/TR/1999/REC html401 19991224/strict.dtd > < < DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC //W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd > >

title: Typo in previous pull causes TypeError in non 0.5.11 versions
Inline port numbers in URLs cause request to spawn multiple callback chains which loop  endlessly
body: I ve been using request for a small project where we crawl some pages on a site I work on.  We noticed an issue where request was entering an  endless  loop when attempting to follow a redirect.  Further investigation showed that   request wasn t just looping until it hit options.maxRedirects.  Instead it was looping until it hits options.maxRedirects  _options.maxRedirects   1 times over _   The issue occurs at the point when request fetches http://app.compete.com/login from our server and receives a 301 response redirecting it to https://app.compete.com:443/login     It s this second url  with an inline port which is actually confusing request.  In fact  you don t even need to follow the redirect in order to observe the behavior    you can just try to request https://app.compete.com:443/login directly.  I ve attached some code demonstrating this behavior here:  https://gist.github.com/1316008  I ve also attached a sketch of a patch.  It appeared that by passing the same object around everywhere as options to callbacks that various callbacks were being run multiple times and that multiple chains of processing were running.  Stopping that behavior by copying only the necessary properties into a new Object of properties given to the _http_ or _https_ module caused the problem to cease    even when the same Agent is passed through.  To be honest  I m submitting this in a gist not in a pull request because I don t really have a thorough enough understanding of _why_ this fixes things.  That means I view it as a piece of diagnostic information not a viable fix in its own right.

title: auto parse application/json
body: Is there a reason why request doesn t  or isn t  automatically JSON.parsing the body if it detects the application/json   content type header  or perhaps if the url ends in .json?    my current json header is:    Content Type: application/json; charset=utf 8   eg:      javascript  request  http://localhost:4000/datas.json    function error  response  body        console.log typeof body  // = string  but the server returned JSON            javascript request  url:  http://localhost:4000/datas.json   json: true   function error  response  body        console.log typeof body  // = object. great  but the json:true could be inferred.

title: EMFILE  Too many open files
body: I realize this may not be a request specific issue  but I have am getting two errors from trying to utilize the module.  The first was      FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_2 Allocation failed   process out of memory      So I changed the request options to      pool :  maxSockets : 10       and then started getting the title error      EMFILE  Too many open files      Here is the little app making all the problems: https://gist.github.com/0f496e2ba2ab12786de0  Basically what happens is one call is made which returns an array of values  each of which require a new call. That is why I set an interval between calls. tho it didn t help :   I looked into using node pool to help  but did not understand how to stick request in it. Can somebody gist a simple node pooling of requests?  https://github.com/coopernurse/node pool

title: Request does not fire requests in parallel?
body: I have an app that uses request to grab API data from an internal API.  I was doing some tests  and it seemed that our app was scaling poorly under heavy load  and API responses were getting incrementally slower.  I deduced this down to the request call we re using  and it looks like request is probably firing these in a queue  not all at once. Here s a test script that shows this behavior:      javascript    /usr/bin/env node var request = require  request        logger = require  ./logger.js        argv = require  optimist  .argv; var numRequests = argv.requests    argv.r      requestsMade = 0      wait = argv.wait    argv.w    0      url = argv.url    argv.u     http://www.google.com       requestApi = function url callback           var requestTime = new Date  .getTime  ;         request                   method:  GET                   uri: url               function err  response  body                   var totalTime =  new Date  .getTime      requestTime;                 callback err  response  body  totalTime ;           ;            doRequest = function            requestsMade  ;         if requestsMade==numRequests  clearInterval requestMaker ;         var thisRequest = requestsMade;         logger.info  Firing Request    thisRequest ;         requestApi url function err  response  body  totalTime               if err                   logger.error  error contacting API    err   trying to request   reqUrl   after    totalTime   ms  ;               else                   logger.info  Api responded to request    thisRequest   after    totalTime   ms  ;                         ;      ; logger.info  Starting Test with     numRequests     Requests.  ; var requestMaker = setInterval doRequest wait ;       logger.js is just a logging tool to print timestamps   set up log levels .  And  a simple test of google shows the incremental slowdown:       node requestTester.js  r 20 [Wed 2011 11 2 11:2:24.575 GMT7] INF: Starting Test with 20 Requests. [Wed 2011 11 2 11:2:24.580 GMT7] INF: Firing Request  1 [Wed 2011 11 2 11:2:24.654 GMT7] INF: Firing Request  2 [Wed 2011 11 2 11:2:24.661 GMT7] INF: Firing Request  3 [Wed 2011 11 2 11:2:24.664 GMT7] title: ECONNREFUSED when connecting locally

When attempting to use request to access a data serving endpoint on my local machine on  say  port 3000  I get a ECONNREFUSED.  Yet if I use a simple function using the http module  it processes normally.  Perhaps there is something wrong with my server code that would deny some header or agent set by this module  but I m just not sure.  I m using Connect  which is pretty standard out of the box... any insight?

title: parseError with certain requests
body: Haven t had time to really dig in and figure out what s really going on here but I noticed when making certain HEAD requests the httpClient will emit a parseError and there doesn t seem to be anything you can do to stop it from crashing the thread.  Could be a node bug? It s 0.6.2.  It s also possible I have no idea what I m doing and the problem is me.  Changing it to a GET request fixes the issue though.   Here s a small sample program to recreate the issue:  var request = require  request  ;  var options =               url:  http://www.aa.com/content/images/footer/footer_email.gif               method:  HEAD               headers:                    Accept :  text/html application/xhtml xml application/xml;q=0.9 _/_;q=0.8                        Accept Charset :  ISO 8859 1 utf 8;q=0.7  ;q=0.7                        Connection :  keep alive                        Accept Language :  en us en;q=0.5                        User Agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Windows NT 6.1; rv:6.0  Gecko/20110814 Firefox/6.0                             followRedirect: true              maxRedirects: 10              jar: false              timeout: 10000              encoding:  utf8               strictSSL: false   ;  request options function error response body       if error           console.log  and we re dead  ;         ;

title: Update to Iris Couch URL
body: Besides updating the branding :  this change goes to a different IP address instead of the legacy one.

title: Avoid buffer.toString   utf 8 encoding problems...
body: If the request get a buffer  it should send a buffer. Converting a buffer into a string could generate the following problem: you cannot regain the buffer from its string representation  b = new Buffer ...   s = b.toString    b  = new Buffer s   for example:   gt; var buffer = new Buffer 1 ;  gt; buffer[0] = 0x89;  137  gt; buffer   lt;Buffer 89 gt;  gt; var string = buffer.toString  ;  gt; string       gt; new Buffer      // problem   lt;Buffer ef bf bd gt;

title: Support using a custom http like module
body: Some people may have an API compatible module that works like http  with custom behavior or a monkey patch or whatever.  This one liner allows the caller to provide that module in the options.      javascript var my_http = require  ./my_http_module    request  uri: http://example.com/   httpModule:my_http   function er  resp  body      // ...         This strikes me as an obscure or advanced feature  so I skipped documentation and tests :  Let me know if you want some and I ll slog through it.

title: Events are fired before listeners are added
body: To listen to and respond to events  one has to setup listeners as follows:      var r = request.post postOptions ;  r.on  close   function         // Do something   ;  r.on  data   function data        // Do something   ;  r.on  end   function         // Do something   ;      To configure listeners  you have to initiate the request in order to get a Request object. If the request is running  isn t it entirely possible for one or more events to be fired before the corresponding listener is added? To solve this there should be a way retrieve the Request object  add listeners and then initiate the request.

title: headers.cookie shouldn t be replaced
body: I had some old code that pre dates request s cookie jar support:      request       headers:           cookie:  foo=bar             // ...   ;      However  after I updated request it stopped working because now  headers.cookie  is always overwritten unless  jar: false  is specified:      if  self.jar === false      // disable cookies   var cookies = false;   self._disableCookies = true;   else if  self.jar      // fetch cookie from the user defined cookie jar   var cookies = self.jar.get   url: self.uri.href      else     // fetch cookie from the global cookie jar   var cookies = cookieJar.get   url: self.uri.href      if  cookies        var cookieString = cookies.map function  c            return c.name    =    c.value;       .join  ;   ;      self.headers.Cookie = cookieString;        The fix was trivial  but I m reporting it anyway because I think it s a wtf. In my opinion there should be a check for whether  self.headers.cookie  already exists  and if so  append to it. Or at least it shouldn t do anything if the global cookie jar is empty.  My guess is that the current behavior breaks a bunch of proxying use cases where cookies are involved.  I can whip up a pull request  but it would be nice to hear if everyone else is on board with this?

title: Cookie issue with uppercase names
body: I found an issue in [vendor/cookie/index.js] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/vendor/cookie/index.js :      javascript // First key is the name this.name = str.substr 0  str.indexOf  =   ;  // Map the key/val pairs str.split /  ;  / .reduce function obj  pair     pair = pair.split /  =  / ;   obj[pair[0].toLowerCase  ] = pair[1]    true;   return obj;    this ;  // Assign value this.value = this[this.name];      Commit [b2a4ad1e7d] https://github.com/mikeal/request/commit/b2a4ad1e7d7553230e932ea093d7f77f38147ef9  is noted  Force all cookie keys into lower case as suggested by LinusU . I don t understand why this is necessary. It introduces a bug since  this.name = str.substr 0  str.indexOf  =   ;  is not assigned a lowercase string. This results in  this.value = this[this.name];  assigning  undefined  in cases where  Set Cookie  for example is  ES=4da3d6b4c946b189 .  I don t see why  .toLowerCase    originally was introduced  but from my point of view I think it can safely be removed.    Edit:   Just saw the pull request  [Fixed cookies parsing] https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/133   by afanasy. This will solve this  and some related  problems.

title: Error Handling for Building HTTP Clients on Request
body: I ve been giving this a lot of thought lately.   One of my favorite things in  request  is the way it handles requests. If there is a callback  stuff gets put in my callback. If there s no callback  request  returns a stream I can pipe or do whatever I want with.  One of my least favorite parts of  request  as someone that has build multiple HTTP clients on it is exception handling. Handling things in  try catch  when I have specified a callback annoys me a little  but having no predictability when I don t specify a callback is worse.  The way I fixed this in my apis is by introducing the following error handling code  and placing every call to  request  in a  try catch :      js var EventEmitter = require  events  .EventEmitter;  exports= function err error  callback      if typeof error ===  string         error = new Error error ;       if callback        return callback error ;     else       var em = new EventEmitter  ;     process.nextTick function     em.emit  error   error ;   ;     return em;      ;      This way when you are using a HTTP client I made you can be ensured that:   If you specified a callback any error will be returned in the first argument on that callback. No exceptions.   If you didn t specify a callback you can still intercept the error event in the stream you are probably trying to pipe. If you don t attach an error handler to your steam  you will get an  uncaughtException .   It maintains the same important characteristic that if your node application isn t expecting an error and doesn t know how to handle it your process will crash.  I would like to make a case for this to be the default behavior in request. It s a pretty easy fix  replacing  throws  with  err error  callback   and introducing some try catches in places that can potentially throw. Would like to get some feedback from others using request to validate this idea first.  For the sake of the conversation here is how exceptions are handled in request today:      js var request = require  request  ;  // Good Request with a Callback request.get  http://writings.nunojob.com   function err res bod      console.log res.statusCode ; // OK   ;  // Good Request without a Callback var stream = request.get  http://writings.nunojob.com  ; stream.on  response   function res      console.log res.statusCode ; // OK   ;  // Bad Params with a Callback // Throws // Opinion: Should return it in the first arg of the callback. request.get  mailto:duh   function err res bod      console.log  Not here  ; // Never gets here   ;  // Bad Params without a Callback // Throws // Opinion: Should log Not here. var stream = request.get  mailto:duh  ; stream.on  error   function err      console.log  Not here  ; // Never gets here   ;  // Timeout Request with a Callback request.get  http://ithinkimighttimeout.su   function err res bod      console.log err ; // Error here   ;  // Timeout Request without a Callback // Throws // Opinion: Should log the error var stream = request.get  http://ithinkimighttimeout.su  ; stream.on  error   function err      console.log err ; // throws? was expecting this to catch  but ok   ;  // Timeout Request without a callback and error handling // Throws // Opinion: it should throw request.get  http://ithinkimighttimeout.su  ;

title: Querystring option
body: 172  Took a stab at adding support for passing in a querystring option parameter. First contribution to the project and I am still pretty new to Node  so happy to talk over any problems in code.  It got a bit interesting with oAuth  the oAuth code supports pulling its parameters from the body or the querystring  with the querystring taking preference with a basic truthy test. This looked wrong to me  but the change I have made would cause a change in functionality in certain circumstances.  Also included is a js based test runner if you want to point the npm test script at it. Running windows here  so needed something platform agnostic.

title: Issue  173 Support uri as first and optional config as second argument
body: Implemented uri as first and optional config functionality for Issue  173  Would be great if this format was supported:      request.get uri      ...        so we don t have to put uri in the options config.  Makes it more clear what uri we are trying to connect to.  Also since the uri is mandatory to provide  it makes sense that the options config is for optional config only.       Also added a test and called test params.js to test this new feature  may not be the best name. :   Thx

title: Modified the post  put  head and del shortcuts to support uri optional param
body: Now you should be able to do the following:      javascript request.post  http://example.com/widgets   function e r b    console.log b    ; //or request.post  http://example.com/widgets     body:  foo=bar    function e r b    console.log b    ; //and still do request.post   uri:  http://example.com/widgets   body:  foo=bar    function e r b    console.log b    ;      created a new function called initParams to reduce duplication:      javascript function initParams uri  options  callback      if   typeof options ===  function       callback  callback = options;   if  typeof options ===  object         options.uri = uri;     else if  typeof uri ===  string         options =  uri:uri ;     else       options = uri;     uri = options.uri;       return   uri: uri  options: options  callback: callback  ;        and each shortcut method calls this method to organize the method params      javascript request.post = function  uri  options  callback      var params = initParams uri  options  callback ;   params.options.method =  POST ;   return request params.uri  params.options  params.callback

title: Make json default
body: Suggestion 1:  At the moment setting json to true will generate Content Type: application/json header but not Accept: application/json. This ends up me having to do:      request.post url      json: true    headers:        Accept :  application/json    body:       foo:  bar          callback ;      Could the  accept: application/json  header be generated as well since often you wanna both send and retrieve json. If someone wants to send json but retrieve another format they could just override the default with specifically setting the Accept header. I think this is better than being forced to always have to specify Accept header for json even though we already set  json: true .  Suggestion 2:  Could json be made default so we can eliminate the  json: true  line:      request.post url      json: true    body:       foo:  bar          callback ;      This looks more clean and since you often send in json I think it s reasonable for it to be default unless you specify something else:      request.post url      body:       foo:  bar          callback ;      What do you think?

I have not added any tests to the pull request  because I wanted to get feedback first  but I will before it is merged.

title: Occasional errors piping CouchDB via node.js
body: I apologize for not having a better bug report  but I am noticing an occasional error using  the  x.pipe y   pattern to push couchdb data out in response to web requests.  The version of request that I am using is request@2.9.152  The error has two facets:  a crash with an error report  and a silent fail with no further activity from Request.  The crashing error is as follows  but I think this is just a symptom of the silent fail  not the actual problem:      Error: This request has been piped before http.request   was called.     at Request.resume  /home/james/repos/jem/carbserver/node_modules/tracker_rewriter/node_modules/request/main.js:702:29      at ServerResponse.ondrain  stream.js:48:14      at ServerResponse.emit  events.js:64:17      at Socket.ondrain  http.js:1322:27      at Object.afterWrite [as oncomplete]  net.js:488:28       The code that triggers this error is  as follows.  BTW  the code is borrowed shamelessly  but with attribution  from maxogden/rewriter  so it should be easy to reproduce.       javascript var couch =  http://127.0.0.1:5984 ; exports.rewriter = function req res next       var to = couch    /vdsdata 2ftracking/  req.params.id;     if req.params.attachment  == undefined           to  =  /  req.params.attachment;           request to .pipe res ;        My app does two things.  First it asks for a document  and then pulls out all of the document s attachments  png files  and displays them.  that part of the app uses the above service and when it crashes produces the above error.  The app also gets a list of the 5 000 or so document ids in a separate request  asking for 1000 docs at a time.  This part of the app is the part that triggers the silent fail  Request freezes up .  It uses the following service  very similar to the above .      javascript exports.vdsdetectors = function req res next       var to = couch    /vdsdata 2ftracking/_design/vdsml/_view/mainline ;     var query = req.query     if query          to  =  ?    toQuery query      request to .pipe res ;        As I said  the bug seems to have two manifestations.  The most obvious one is the crash  and I have found that it only happens _after_ calling the listing service  but it also only happens from the one at a time service  get a doc or get the doc s attachments .  I _cannot_ get that crash to happen by holding down control r on a stripped down version of my app that just gets one document and its attachments.  The silent fail  in which Request freezes and refuses to work anymore  couchdb is fine  only occurs when triggering the request to get 1000 documents a bunch of times  I hold down control r in ffox .  I can get that one to happen every time  and it will usually fail after working only about 6 times  it varies .  If I hit refresh at a more modest pace  the crash doesn t happen.    In case it is relevant  I am using these services within the connect framework  with a bunch of other things turned on...logging requests  session cookies  etc.  I hope this bug report makes sense  but if it doesn t or if you have any suggestions on what else to try  please let me know.

title: [Feature request] Multiple requests at once
body: I m using it to mashup different APIs on a single request call  and it s quite handy. I ve wrapped it into a function  but I don t think its the best way to do it: https://gist.github.com/2001487  The sintaxis I m using is:   __request  [ http://foo    http://bar ]  function response    ...   ;   The response argument is an object that group all the responses by url:          http://foo :   error: ..   body: ...   response: ...         http://bar :   error: ..   body: ...   response: ...

title: HTTPS Tunneling requires node >=0.6.11
body: When trying to use the new tunneling code with a pre 0.6.11 version of node  an error should probably be thrown in createSecureSocket   in tunnel.js that lets the user know that node >=0.6.11 is required to do httpsOverHttp or httpsOverHttps.  To do tunneling in pre 0.6.11 node  you can also try: https://github.com/milewise/node https proxied

title: Fix cookie and redirect bugs and add auth support for HTTPS tunnel
body: Fixed  : The  proxy.auth  option wasn t being passed through to the https tunnel.  This prevented the https tunnel from being used with proxy servers that require authentication.    Fixed  : Due to a bug in the composable jar code  cookies weren t being set properly in redirects.    Fixed  : Cookie attributes should be case insensitive.  For example  the cookie parser fails when  Path=/  is used instead of  path=/     Fixed  : When following non GET redirects  remove any content in the body of the request.  Otherwise  servers will complain about the GET request being malformed.

title: Allow streaming only the body to http.ServerResponse

title: Always forcing redirects to GET causes HEAD requests to become GET
body: Hi there   I m currently using request  which on the whole is great  to resolve various URLs   many of them shortened  t.co  bit.ly . All I m interested in is the ultimate destiation URL  so naturally I need to follow redirects etc. So far so good.  However  I ve noticed this on line 449 of main.js: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L449   just curious as to why all redirects are changed to GET? I can t quite follow the history of that line but I m guessing it was to follow Post / Redirect / Get style submissions   is that right?  Unfortunately when all you re trying to do is resolve URLs by issuing HEAD requests  this means you end up spidering the entire contents of the target URL   I only discovered this when one such URL turned out to be a huge mp4 file.  I ve noticed setting onResponse to true seems to solve this issue but I can t help wondering what s happening to the rest of the response body   is it aborted if onResponse is true?  I ve temporarily worked around this by simply commenting that line out  as I know I ll always be issuing HEAD requests  but am interested in a more robust and more  correct  solution.  Thanks   Nick

I m not sure if any other oauth providers break on this or not.  not sure what the policy is on lowercase vs. titlecase headers though. my change seems quite arbitrary and confusing unless it s somehow applied to all headers or made case insensitively somehow.  any guidance?

title: Uncatchable exception when follow redirect to an invalid url
body: When a page redirect to an invalid location  we stuck with an uncatchable exception. This is an example: http://achau.edu.vn/goto.php?redirect=bWFpbHRvOmFuaG52LmZhQGdtYWlsLmNvbQ==  I also managed to fix it. In main.js  look for      javascript if   isUrl.test response.headers.location       response.headers.location = url.resolve self.uri.href  response.headers.location         Then replace      javascript if   isUrl.test response.headers.location       response.headers.location = url.resolve self.uri.href  response.headers.location     //Double check redirect location if   isUrl.test response.headers.location       self.emit  error   new Error  Invalid redirected url.   ;   return;        Now the error is passed to callback itself and we can safely handle it.

title: defaults mode breaks jar function
Multipart content type change
body: I am currently using request to do some multipart work and I notice that there are some parsers that don t like the way request formats it multipart headers. I especially think of Ruby  but it might be a coincidence.  The changes here are small and shouldn t break compatibility. 1. In [RFC1341] http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc1341/7_2_Multipart.html  the quotes are omitted in all cases but one  when there was a space in the identifier. Let s remove that as some sucky parsers fall over it  it won t make a difference because according to [RFC2045] http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2045.txt  the quotes are optional. 2. I have no clue whether the the space after the  ;  is mandatory  I can t really find anything in the RFC s  but then again  I m a sloppy reader   but I have noticed that some parsers  like CloudFoundry  break over this if the space is omitted.

title: POST request with extended response hangs when Internet connection is disrupted
body: I have a script that uses request to access the Twitter Streaming API. If  while receiving a response  the network connection is disrupted request hangs without emitting any events. I m forced to kill the process and run the script again.  Is there something I should be doing to detect a network disruption and restart the request?    Steps to Reproduce   1. Run the example code 2. Disable the network connection 3. No events occur and Twitter stream output stalls. 4. Wait a few seconds 5. Enable the network connection 6. Twitter stream output remains stalled.    Example        var request = require  request  ;  var oauth =       consumer_key:  CONSUMER_KEY       consumer_secret:  CONSUMER_SECRET       token:  TOKEN       token_secret:  TOKEN_SECRET   ;  var requestOptions =       method:  POST       url:  https://stream.twitter.com/1/statuses/filter.json       oauth: oauth      form:   track:  baseball     ;  var httpRequest = request.post requestOptions ;  httpRequest.on  abort   function         console.log  Request aborted.  ;   ;  httpRequest.on  close   function         console.log  Request closed.  ;   ;  httpRequest.on  complete   function         console.log  Request completed.  ;   ;  httpRequest.on  data   function data         console.log data.toString  utf8   ;   ;  httpRequest.on  end   function         console.log  Request ended.  ;   ;  httpRequest.on  error   function error        console.log  Request error:     error ;   ;  httpRequest.on  response   function aResponse        console.log  Request responded.  ;   ;

title: Opening and not releasing connections to CouchDB
body: Related to the silent fail I reported  in  195.  I am using request to pipe output from CouchDB to an incoming  query.    If the requests are long  and I send in multiple  almost simultaneous requests from different machines  it seems that Request opens up connections to CouchDB and then doesn t close them properly.  Output from lsof:      lsof  p 30393 COMMAND   PID   USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF      NODE NAME ... node    30393 nobody    5u  IPv4 512692      0t0       TCP  :http  LISTEN  node    30393 nobody    6u  IPv4 517444      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:35285 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:6379  ESTABLISHED  node    30393 nobody    7u  IPv4 515460      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:49355 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:6379  ESTABLISHED  node    30393 nobody    9u  IPv4 518295      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:47326 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:5984  ESTABLISHED  node    30393 nobody   10u  IPv4 514485      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:47327 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:5984  ESTABLISHED  node    30393 nobody   12u  IPv4 514486      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:47328 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:5984  ESTABLISHED  node    30393 nobody   13u  IPv4 517443      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:47340 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:5984  ESTABLISHED  node    30393 nobody   14u  IPv4 516541      0t0       TCP lysithia.its.uci.edu:47341 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:5984  ESTABLISHED       When the pipe works properly  I only see one connection in lsof  and it appears to be closed:      ...   lysithia.its.uci.edu:38350 >lysithia.its.uci.edu:5984  CLOSE_WAIT       With smallish data piped  and low volume usage  the bug doesn t happen.   I will try to work on an automated crash trigger  but so far I ve just been using screen and curl.

title: Problem with Forever Agent
body: There is the code in forever.js  function createConnectionSSL  port  host  options      options.port = port   options.host = host   return tls.connect options     But   tls.connect options  seems to be 0.7.X tls API. current production node is 0.6.15:  // TODO:  make port  host part of options  exports.connect = function port /   host  options  cb  /     Forever and HTTPS are incompatible with production node. Can you please make 0.6.X working?

title: Connection reuse with Forever
body: I am not sure this is bug or not yet. Let s call it an issue.  I use forever agent to send HTTPS POST requests. I failed to requse connections untill I did following  In the code:  foreverAgent.prototype.addRequest = function req  host  port      var name = host    :    port   if  this.freeSockets[name]    this.freeSockets[name].length > 0     req.useChunkedEncodingByDefault        var idleSocket = this.freeSockets[name].pop    I inserted  req.useChunkedEncodingByDefault = false;  Everything started to work exellent  Unfortunately  setting content length of post request does not fix the problem. Setting req.useChunkedEncodingByDefault = false; before req.end   does not help either.  Is there a way to reset useChunkedEncodingByDefault for POST requests without patching forever.js?

title: Request method composability
body: This is really more of a question of intent and clarification. But if you like these ideas  I can work up some PRs  @mikeal you ve talked about building composable apis with javascript and I ve been trying things out with an eye to composability. One thing I tend to do is wrap an existing module to form a new one that re uses the exact same api. It just wraps some methods; to provide some more sophisticated defaults for example.  request  already provides a nice built in mechanism for this with  request.defaults . But here s the scenario I m looking at.  I m creating a request client with some defaults. But I also want to do some munging to the options at request time. Here s an example of maintaining an oauth2 token that might change.      var authToken     _request = request.defaults   /  some defaults  /   ;     myRequest = function opts  callback        if  opts.headers    opts.headers =           opts.headers[ Authorization ] =  Bearer     authToken;      return _request opts  callback ;      mixin myRequest  _request ;  var setAuthToken = function token      authToken = token;    module.exports = myRequest; exports.setAuthToken = setAuthToken;      This is fine for most cases  but there are a few limitations.  It s harder to use the full range of method signatures for request. If the user wants to pass   uri  options  callback    or just   uri  callback    I have to handle that myself so I can manipulate the right options hash. I think the right thing to do here might be to expose the  initParams  method. That way I could interpret the args in the recommended way first. Or I could wrap initParams and implement my request time logic there. That would avoid double calls to initParams.  I m trying to reuse the convenience methods like  post    head   etc with the mixin line above. But this doesn t work the way I intend. Because these reference these always reference the internal  request  function. I can t make them use my wrapped version. Making my own version of these methods would be easy enough  but I would lose the bits of error checking. For instance  head  checks if there is a body and throws if there isn t.  This isn t ideal  but one idea is to have those methods use  this  as the underlying requester. I m positive you hate that idea though. Another idea is to allow  request.defaults  to take a new request function as the optional second parameter. It would require a bit of refactoring.  Here s an example using some of these ideas      var authToken     _request = request.defaults   /  some defaults  /   ;     myRequest = function uri  opts  callback        var params = request.initParams uri  opts  callback ;      opts = params.opts;     if  opts.headers    opts.headers =           opts.headers[ Authorization ] =  Bearer     authToken;      return _request params.uri  params.opts  params.callback ;      mixin myRequest  _request ;  var setAuthToken = function token      authToken = token;    module.exports = myRequest; exports.setAuthToken = setAuthToken;

title: don t error when null is passed for options
Composability updates suggested by issue  239
body: I took a stab at the updates I suggested in  239. Pretty simple and includes tests. I don t really like adding custom stuff to the options hash. But couldn t think of a cleaner way to do it off hand.

title: Allow option to set throttle limit
body: Couldn t find this in the documentation  but it looks like request is throttling the number of outbound requests. This makes sense due to ulimit restrictions  but right now it appears to be throttling to 5 at a time.  Is it possible to add the ability to increase this when necessary?  Let me know if I m just missing something  here s a quick script to reproduce this issue:      // Create an http server to respond to pings slowly var http = require  http        url = require  url        i=0 http.createServer function request  response      response.writeHead 200    Content Type :  text/plain      var pathname = url.parse request.url .pathname   console.log  Request for  s received.  pathname    setTimeout function          i         response.write i.toString          response.end         500    .listen 8888  // ping method var request = require  request   var ping = function val     console.log  ping   d started  val    request   uri :  http://localhost:8888/  val   method :  POST   function err res       console.log  call   d complete  val         // ping 200 times for var n=0;n<=200;n       ping n         If you run that script  you ll see this:      ping  0 started ping  1 started ping  2 started ping  3 started ping  4 started ping  5 started ping  6 started <snip> ping  198 started ping  199 started ping  200 started Request for /4 received. Request for /2 received. Request for /3 received. Request for /1 received. Request for /0 received. call  0 complete call  1 complete call  3 complete call  2 complete call  4 complete Request for /9 received. Request for /8 received. Request for /7 received. Request for /6 received. Request for /5 received. call  5 complete call  6 complete call  7 complete call  8 complete call  9 complete Request for /14 received. Request for /13 received. Request for /12 received. Request for /11 received. Request for /10 received. <snip>      If this is expected behavior  I d like to increase the limit.

title: maxRedirects throws error on 301
body: Have been trying to extract header information from a sequence of redirects using http.get and request using the code below:  USING HTTP.GET  var http = require  http  ;    var options =         host:  t.co         port: 80        path:  /UFUG0GzF       ;  var req = http.get options  function res              console.log res.statusCode ;         console.log res.headers.location ;     var loc = res.headers.location;       var str = loc.split  /  ;       var strpath =  /    str[3];       var opt =           host: str[2]          port:80          path: strpath      ;     http.get opt  function response               console.log res.statusCode ;         console.log res.headers.location ;   ;   ;  OUTPUT  1st redirect Statuscode: 301 location:  http://bit.ly/Hwhiyt  server:  hi   2nd redirect Statuscode: 301 location:  http://www.scoop.it/t/nodejs code/p/1573117519/is node better  server:  nginx   USING REQUEST  var request = require  request  ;  request        uri:  http://t.co/UFUG0GzF            maxRedirects:  2            followRedirect: true              function  error  response  body         if   error       console.log response.statusCode ;     console.log response.headers ;           else      console.log error ;           OUTPUT  Using followRedirect: false Statuscode: 301 location:  http://bit.ly/Hwhiyt  server:  hi   Using maxRedirects:  1    followRedirect: true  default  [Error: Exceeded maxRedirects. Probably stuck in a redirect loop.]  So  if it cannot get a response with Statuscode:200 within the specified number of redirects it throws and error. It s is getting a 301  but that is ignored.  Using maxRedirects:  2   followRedirect: true  default  Statuscode: 200 location: undefined server:  Jetty 7.5.4.v20111024    Redirects on the same host are not considered in the count of maxRedirects  else it should have returned 301 as in http.get above. Note the server in each case. The one using http.get has an nginx server. So there is an internal redirect taking place.  So we can use  request  only to get the first redirect  using followRedirect: false  or the final response. Not sure if the maxRedirects parameter was intended to work this way.

title: Fix for the fix of your  closed  issue  89 where self.headers[content length] is set to 0 for all methods
body: turns out that setting content length to 0 for GETs to some servers causes them to respond with status 403.  For example  try out http://govwin.com.  The request:  GET / HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/html application/xhtml xml application/xml;q=0.9 _/_;q=0.8 Accept Charset: ISO 8859 1 utf 8;q=0.7  ;q=0.3 Accept Language: en US en;q=0.8 Cache Control: max age=0 host: govwin.com Accept Encoding: gzip deflate sdch Connection: keep alive User Agent: Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8  AppleWebKit/535.19  KHTML  like Gecko  Chrome/18.0.1025.151 Safari/535.19 content length: 0  The response:  HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden Date: Fri  04 May 2012 22:53:43 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.8  CentOS  Accept Ranges: bytes Vary: Accept Encoding Content Encoding: gzip Content Length: 2021 Connection: close Content Type: text/html; charset=UTF 8 Set Cookie: BIGipServerdeltek_govwin.com_p=409138605.20480.0000; expires=Fri  04 May 2012 23:08:43 GMT; path=/  This commit checks self.method before setting content length:0 and only sets this value if the method is not a GET and not undefined  which resolves to GET .

title: content type header should be  application/x www form urlencoded  as default on any POST requests
body: Today I wasn t unable to parse data sent from your module because the server I was using wasn t parsing the  body  of the POST request since it only supports two  content type  headers:  application/x www form urlencoded  and  application/json   And this is an expected behavior  since if you do a  curl  to any website with   d  param  POST   you will find that they also send the  application/x www form urlencoded  content type header by default.

title: strictSSL  must default to true
body: Without enforcing strictSSL by default  this code running on a compromised network can be tricked into sending confidential information over TLS to the wrong server. Let people make an explicit choice to turn a security feature off.

title: Inconsistent JSON handling in 2.9.202
body: Here you say that auto parsing is JSON response is dangerous: https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/99 so it should not be done. I understand that and can parse response myself when needed.  However  if you issue request with  json  option set to some object  then parsing is still forcibly done for the response  and the  Accept  header is automatically set to  application/json  . Why assume that when I make a request with a JSON body then I certanly expect JSON response and want to auto parse it?  Relevant code:  Lines 643 ... in main.js:      Request.prototype.json = function  val      this.setHeader  content type    application/json     this.setHeader  accept    application/json     this._json = true   if  typeof val ===  boolean         if  typeof this.body ===  object   this.body = JSON.stringify this.body      else       this.body = JSON.stringify val        return this        And line 555 ... in main.js:                if  self._json                try                 response.body = JSON.parse response.body                catch  e                      The culprit is  self._json  which can indicate whether I want JSON parsing  or not  OR the object used for request body. This cannot express case where I want JSON body in the request but not auto parsed response body  or that  Accept  header . The fix would be to separate it into two separate properties? I have no idea about common usage patterns so such fix could cause backwards incompatibility?

title: No charset in Content Type header when posting JSON
body: Currently  when you set a json body using the  json  property the following headers are added to your request.        this.setHeader  content type    application/json     this.setHeader  accept    application/json        The content type lacks a charset  which I believe the http rfc says should be treated as ISO 8859 1.  Thoughts on either adding a charset=utf 8 like on the form bodies or opening up some way to set the charset? Happy to do a PR for you  just wanted to know your thoughts on the best approach.

title: multipart allow body ===      the empty string
body: Hi  When sending POST request  with empty fields  multipart/form data    request  fails with the message  Body attribute missing in multipart. .   body === null  and  body === undefined  should be avoided   but not  body === 0  or  body ===      Here is a dump of what I want to send  done with chrome  :            WebKitFormBoundaryya1smvvViLvINIOb  Content Disposition: form data; name= title             WebKitFormBoundaryya1smvvViLvINIOb  Content Disposition: form data; name= upload ; filename=    Content Type: application/octet stream            WebKitFormBoundaryya1smvvViLvINIOb

title: request.abort   should clear timeoutTimer
body: When sending request to a slow server with a short timeout value  before the server returns back anything  calling request.abort does not clear timeoutTimer. The ETIMEDOUT error will still be reported.  e.g.      javascript var r = request.get  http://slowserver   request.defaults   timeout : 10000     ;  r.on  error   function  error      //We should not see ETIMEDOUT error here   console.log error ;   ;  r.pipe ... ;  process.nextTick function        r.abort  ;   ;

title: request.defaults could support headers better.
body: request.defaults could support headers better.  version:  2.9.202    For example var req = request.defaults     headers:        user agent :  some user agent          ;  req.get uri   headers:   if modified since:  Tue  29 May 2012 19:30:57 GMT    ...  Curently  we see the following headers on the wire   if modified since:  Tue  29 May 2012 19:30:57 GMT    What we would like to see is   user agent :  some user agent    if modified since:  Tue  29 May 2012 19:30:57 GMT

title: return byte stream directly if self.encoding is undefined or null.
body: without this update  we have to write something like request.get  url:url    encoding: null     function e  resp     ; to get byte stream in response.body

title: pool:false being ignored
body: There seems to be an issue where   pool:false   does not disable the core http pool.      js var request = require  request  ; var http = require  http  ;  http.createServer function         console.error  just hanging...  ;   .listen 8888  function         for  var i = 0; i < 10; i              request  http://localhost:8888    pool:false  ;              ;      In the above example I would expect the program to print out  just hanging  10 times as I pass   pool:false   to request. It however still seems to use the core global pool and only prints out  just hanging  5 times.

title: fixed just another leak of  i
body: See change.

title: Setting  pool  to  false  does NOT disable Agent pooling
body: An incorrect check of  if   self.pool ..  caused the  globalPool  overwrite  self.pool  before a check later in the code  if  self.pool === false  ...  which is intended to turn off pooling  but is never triggered. The result was that the typical  http.Agent  is used  with it s default max connections of 5.    Tim Shadel github@timshadel.com

title: JSON test should check for equality
body: assert    by itself only looks to see that the first argument is a value of some kind. This uses  assert.equal    instead.    Tim Shadel github@timshadel.com

title: Bug in OAuth key generation for sha1
body: Per spec  http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5849 section 3.4.2  the consumer_secret  client shared secret  and token_secret should be encoded before being used as part of the key for sha1.

title: uncaughtException when redirected to invalid URI
body: We recently faced a case of uncaught exception: when a website redirects  using  Location  header  to a syntactically invalid URI  we end up with an ugly  Uncaught Exception TypeError: Cannot call method  indexOf  of undefined .  Here is the stack trace:      TypeError: Cannot call method  indexOf  of undefined     at / /node_modules/request/vendor/cookie/jar.js:51:19     at Array.filter  native      at CookieJar.get  / /node_modules/request/vendor/cookie/jar.js:50:23      at Request.request  / /node_modules/request/main.js:156:29      at request  / /node_modules/request/main.js:570:5      at ClientRequest.<anonymous>  / /node_modules/request/main.js:385:9      at ClientRequest.g  events.js:156:14      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:67:17      at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient [as onIncoming]  http.js:1256:7      at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete [as onHeadersComplete]  http.js:91:29       And the real life case:        curl  i  http://indicecorporativo.com/component/flexbanner/?task=click bannerid=1    Location: http://        Boom.  This PR will check the URI before going further  and if it s invalid it will emit an  error  event  which will make it catchable.

title: chunks of html missing from request body
body: I ve spent about 8 hours trying to figure out what I might be doing wrong  and finally I ve isolated it. I ve saved my cookies as a text file and tried an identical request with cURL and it works. I open a node console and make the request with the same set of cookies and it s missing a huge chunk of data.      javascript var request = require  request   var cookie =  ClrOSSID=1337385593623 6464; ClrSCD=1376398593623; browser_id=150992397523; mt.v=2.1480660823.1337228590123; SessionId=801066220120523155337507318223; SRCCODE=WEB1205; plushContainerWidth=100 25; plushNoTopMenu=0; ClrSSID=1337638593602 6464; JSESSIONID=Bj9vPQ3Kr20nxhNpdG4KQR2SCH9x9h8tyDY25ysxQf0gYCn1SYJr  1017646277  request       uri: https://www.dollargeneral.com/checkout/index.jsp?process=address       headers: cookie:cookie     function e r b        console.log b          the result is missing most of the page  it ends abruptly with:  <div class= wrap >   curl  on the other hand  returns what i expect  and matches a browser :      bash curl   cookie  ClrOSSID=1337385593623 6464; ClrSCD=1376398593623; browser_id=150992397523; mt.v=2.1480660823.1337228590123; SessionId=801066220120523155337507318223; SRCCODE=WEB1205; plushContainerWidth=100 25; plushNoTopMenu=0; ClrSSID=1337638593602 6464; JSESSIONID=Bj9vPQ3Kr20nxhNpdG4KQR2SCH9x9h8tyDY25ysxQf0gYCn1SYJr  1017646277   https://www.dollargeneral.com/checkout/index.jsp?process=address       You ll need to establish your own cookies for this to work    what I did was start an order  pay with paypal  go back to the site ... you dont have to actually complete/authorize any purchases.  this is the   ONLY   page I ve had this problem with

title: Proper way to stream a response
body: I ve been trying to track down what appears to be a memory leak with some code I have that is making a secondary HTTP request to another host and then streaming the response to the original request.  Is there any functional difference between these snippets?   req and res represent my original request and response variables and callback should be called when the response has finished.      var proxy = request options ;  proxy.on  error   function  err        console.log err ;   ;  proxy.once  response   function  response        response.once  end   function              return callback  ;       ;      res.writeHead response.statusCode  response.headers ;     response.pipe res ;   ;      versus      var proxy = request options ;  proxy.on  error   function  err        console.log err ;   ;  proxy.once  end   function          return callback  ;     proxy.pipe res ;      The proxy response could be rather large  so I want to do a minimal amount of buffer  if any .  Functionally both work  but the top one seems to be leaking somewhere and I ve been having trouble tracing down exactly where.  I wanted to first confirm I m doing the piping using the preferred method first.  Thanks for your help.  This is a great library.

title: How to POST JSON data
body: Hello  I am having issues posting data with your Request module.  I am trying to POST JSON data to a locally running Bugzilla server. Using PHP curl works no problem but when I use the following code:      var request = require  request  ; request.post  url          json:                email:  email            hash:  hash           ;      I get no data being passed on we checked it with a script . what is the proper format for a post? On this support page I have seen people use the json map to be a True/False value and use form or body to hold the data  but then I have seen even more people place the data straight into  the json map. Which is the proper method? The documentation is very vague on the options so I am very confused. Help would be greatly appreciated  thanks

title: Boundary begins with CRLF?
body: A  .NET  server I was working with was missing the first part of my multipart  i.e. it recognized the boundary of the second section I was sending  and thought it was the first section  but missed the existence of the first section entirely   until I added a CRLF at the beginning of my boundary as in the code in this pull request.  Reading the RFC it looks like it _might_ be required to be like that?       _Note that the  encapsulation  boundary  must  occur  at  the             beginning  of  a line  i.e.  following a CRLF  and that that             initial CRLF is considered to be part of  the  encapsulation             boundary  rather  than  part  of  the preceding part.    The             boundary must be followed immediately either by another CRLF             and the header fields for the next part  or by two CRLFs  in             which case there are no header fields for the next part  and             it is therefore assumed to be of Content Type text/plain ._  from [http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1341.txt] http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1341.txt        I thought I d share this pull request just in case there s something to it.

title: Pipe back pressure issue
body: Currently request doesn t return a boolean from write to indicate whether or not the write was flushed nor does it emit a drain event.  This can result in a large memory overhead when piping large files to request because of back pressure. Consider:      js fs.createReadStream  i_am_large.file  .pipe request.put  http://...  ;      If the above readstream reads faster than request can write we ll end up having most of the file in memory. This patch fixes this issue by adding the  drain  event and returning the boolean from  req.write .

title: Get request with body does not returns complete response.body
body: This happened accidentally in a utility function that was able to send GET/PUT/POST  etc based on options passed to it. It took me 2 days of debugging to figure out what was causing it . My utility function was creating following GET request      javascript var opts =                   url:  http://hgilani.iriscouch.com/memento/8be0467d6c3981db55428129934c28c9                   method:  GET                   headers :                        Content Type  :  application/json                                           body:               ;          request opts  function error  response  body                if   error    response.statusCode == 200                    console.log body ;                 done  ;                         ;      In this request opts has   body:        which does not make sense as this is a GET request. But this results in GET request to return body that is of different length  i.e. it gets truncated at the end and JSON is malformed   On doing curl following command fails with error     error : bad_request   reason : Referer header required.          curl   d      http://hgilani.iriscouch.com/memento/8be0467d6c3981db55428129934c28c9      but following command works      curl  X GET  d       http://hgilani.iriscouch.com/memento/8be0467d6c3981db55428129934c28c9      I am not sure if this is a defect in request module or in couchDB or a combination but something worth checking.

title: fix tests with boundary by injecting boundry from header
body: This is in response to  277. I traced the error and found that it was due to a change that made the request text contain a randomly generated UUID. This made it so that it couldn t be compared with a static piece of text. I added a token to it and made it find the boundary in the header and put the boundary into the text. All tests pass now. More info is in my comments on  277.  I also clarified what happens when Squid isn t installed  so the person running the test knows that all tests that ran passed  that the test was skipped  and that squid needs to be installed to test tunneling.

title: filed  some/file  .pipe request options   fails on node@0.8
body: I m honestly not sure if this is related to a change in how node handles  process.nextTick   or a mismatch in compatible versions of  filed  and  request   but what I m seeing suggests it is the latter:      js   require  filed    some/file  .pipe request options  ;     1.  filed  immediately starts an  fs.stat  operation [here] https://github.com/mikeal/filed/blob/master/main.js L43  2.  request  immediately calls  Request.prototype.init  [here] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L106  which beings the http request 3. The  File  instance is piped to the  Request  instance setting  this.dest  [here] https://github.com/mikeal/filed/blob/master/main.js L177  4. Before the  fs.stat  operation in  1  completes   process.nextTick  fires and  self.ntick  is set to true [here] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L366  5. When the  fs.stat  operation completes  a new  ReadStream  is created and piped to the  Request  instance [here] https://github.com/mikeal/filed/blob/master/main.js L149  6. Since  this.ntick  is true on the  Request  instance it throws:      /path/to/project/node_modules/request/main.js:322     if  self.ntick  throw new Error  You cannot pipe to this stream after the                            ^ Error: You cannot pipe to this stream after the first nextTick   after creation of the request stream.     at Request.init.process.nextTick.self.headers.content length  /path/to/project/node_modules/request/main.js:322:27      at Request.g  events.js:185:14      at Request.EventEmitter.emit  events.js:88:17      at Request.vows.describe.options.Emitter.emit  /path/to/project/node_modules/vows/lib/vows.js:236:24      at Stream.pipe  stream.js:112:8      at fs.stat.finish  /path/to/project/node_modules/filed/main.js:147:40      at /path/to/project/node_modules/filed/main.js:156:7     at Object.oncomplete  fs.js:297:15

title: Specify servername when creating secureSocket over tunneling proxy
body: This makes the https over http proxy work when strictSSL is turned on.  In v0.8.4  we fixed a security bug where an otherwise valid cert would be accepted for a host that was not listed in the CN or subjectaltnames sections of the certificate.  However  this breaks proxying  because you want to accept the cert if it comes from the origin server  not tested against the proxy s hostname.  This fixes isaacs/npm 2719

title: gzip support for HTTP responses
body: I ve found that having to wrap every  HTTP response in a zlib wrapper is annoying and clutters my code.  This patch supports gzip automatically  without overwriting people s headers or breaking code running on older node versions.  It does 3 things: 1. checks if zlib support is present in node  and if so adds it. 2. if zlib is present  and self.headers does not contain an Accept Encoding header  it adds one  with the value set to  gzip  3. after the request body is received  if zlib is present  and the Content Encoding header is present  and if that header s value contains  gzip   gunzip the body.
