title: Exception thrown on request time out
body: There is the potential for an exception to be thrown when a request times out and the timeout property has been set in the request options. Node  v0.6.17  will still exit even if the exception is caught.  Potential source of the callback error is at https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L654  In the call that caused the problem  the options are:      javascript var pageRequest =       method:  GET       url: url      timeout: 10000      followRedirect: false      jar: request.jar        headers:    user agent :  GoInstantCrawler/1.0      ;      And the call itself was done as follows:      javascript   var fetchRequest = request.get pageRequest  function err  resp  body        try         if  err  return logFetchFailure err  pageRequest  cb ;       if   resp  return logFetchFailure new Error  No response body from fetch page request    pageRequest  cb ;        var contentType = resp.headers[ content type ];       DBG  DBG  page fetched   pageRequest.url                   status code   resp.statusCode                   content type   contentType                   body length   body ? body.length :  n/a  ;        // Handle a redirected page       if  resp.statusCode === 301    resp.statusCode === 302    resp.statusCode === 303            return handleUrlRedirect pageRequest  resp.headers.location  cb ;        // Handle a normaly returned page         else if  resp.statusCode === 200            if   body    body.length === 0  return logFetchFailure new Error  URL fetch returned an empty body.    pageRequest  cb ;          // This is the  success  condition where a body is returned and needs to be processed.         cb null  pageRequest  contentType  body ;        // All other status codes  unhandled .         else           return logFetchFailure new Error  URL fetch returned an unprocessable return code:     resp.statusCode   pageRequest  cb ;                catch e          DBG  DBG  Unhandled exception caught in fetchPage                   Fetching URL:    pageRequest.url                  Exception:    e ;        return logFetchFailure e  pageRequest  cb ;           ;      The pattern of failure typically has one URL fail with the ETIMEOUT error and then the next URL fail with the ESOCKETTIMEDOUT error. A typical dump from the program is as follows  the initial text comes from the logFetchFailure method referenced in the above code snippet :      Page fetch failed http://mentaltrackmarks.com/?tag=enniscrone  with error:   [Error: ETIMEDOUT] code:  ETIMEDOUT    Page fetch failed http://mentaltrackmarks.com/?tag=dublin  with error:   [Error: ESOCKETTIMEDOUT] code:  ESOCKETTIMEDOUT     node.js:201         throw e; // process.nextTick error  or  error  event on first tick               ^ Error: timeout     at ClientRequest.emitTimeout  http.js:1346:18      at ClientRequest.g  events.js:156:14      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:88:20      at Socket.emitTimeout  http.js:1345:10      at Socket.g  events.js:156:14      at Socket.emit  events.js:64:17      at Socket._onTimeout  net.js:153:8      at Timer.ontimeout  timers.js:94:19

title: Nested requests are blocking
body: I am relatively new to nodejs. I ve been recently pooling all of the collective knowledge i ve gathered through the past couple of months into an project. I believe I ve ran into my first  blocking  issue in nodejs.  I have a page that loads two  request    calls they are async and nested accordingly. The innermost one uses data from the innermost to redirect the user.        request parameters  function error  response  data         //the first request passes a token         request newParamters  function error  response  data             //the second request passes a url           res.redirect data.info.url ;         ;     ;      The error is that when I open this up in many browser tabs it ends up breaking after the first couple then the server says  data.info.url  is undefined.  My question to you is: Should I only be performing one request at a time? I could save the token from the first  request    and redirect the user to the second  request    would this help? I ve been very conscience about async and not blocking and I m shocked that this is happening. Any feedback would be great

title: consuming twitter api using request
body: I m having a hell of a time trying to figure out what the problem is here.  I m using everyauth to authenticate and grab the necessary access token and secret. I store this information and then consume the twitter api to do the following  get the timeline and post a tweet. I m having no problem with getting the timeline. However  I can t seem to post a tweet. Here is my code:  For getting the timeline  this works :       var oauth =        consumer_key: ss.twitterKey      consumer_secret: ss.twitterSecret      token: req.session.auth.twitter.accessToken      token_secret: req.session.auth.twitter.accessTokenSecret    ;     var url =  http://api.twitter.com/1/statuses/home_timeline.json ;   ss.request  url: url  oauth: oauth   function error  response  data        res null  JSON.parse data  ;      ;       For posting a tweet.  this doesn t work          var url =  https://api.twitter.com/1/statuses/update.json ;   var test =  status: message ;   ss.request.post  url: url  oauth: oauth  body:  include_entities=true status=thissucks    function error  response  data        res null  data ;      ;      When performing the above  I get:      error : Could not authenticate with OAuth.   request :  /1 /statuses /update.json    This seems odd  because I just performed the get timeline request and it worked. title: Manual  piping
body: I had to override the  process.nextTick  function call in  request.prototype.init  to perform manual  piping .  I had to break the response body of a get request into multiple chunks and perform put requests with those chunks. The server that I was posting to did not allow  Transfer Coding: Chunked .  So all I did was create a new option  endOnTick: true in  request . When this option is  true   nothing s different. When  false   whatever the state of the request  the code in the  process.nextTick  call is not executed.

title: request assumes lowercase headers
body: This in our experience has been a source of errors.  e.g.  trying to set the  Content Type  on a multipart request will get overwritten if its not lowercase.  Seems like request should normalize those when coming in.  I can write a pull if desired.

title: Twitter Oauth Stuff Out of Date; Now Updated
body: Updated the twitter oauth dance. The comments weren t clear. Also removed token_key. No longer needed with twitter oauth.

title: Invalid URI error emitted before handlers can listen
body: versions:      javascript   http_parser:  1.0     node:  0.8.8     v8:  3.11.10.19     ares:  1.7.5 DEV     uv:  0.8     zlib:  1.2.3     openssl:  1.0.1c          main.js:169       javascript self.emit  error   new Error message        This error event is emitted before any handlers get a chance to listen to it  thus making it throw. Obviously you can  url.parse  before calling  request   but it appears the intention here is not to throw.  How to reproduce: https://gist.github.com/3520431 Quick fix: Wrap this line  or whole  request.prototype.init  inside  process.nextTick

title: Workaround for  313
Pass servername to tunneling secure socket creation
body: This makes the https over http proxy work when strictSSL is turned on.  In v0.8.4  we fixed a bug where an otherwise valid cert would be accepted for a host that was not listed in the CN or subjectaltnames sections of the certificate.  However  this breaks proxying  because you want to accept the cert if it comes from the origin server  not tested against the proxy s hostname.  This fixes isaacs/npm 2719

title: swap out node s querystring lib for visionmedia s
body: visionmedia s querystring parser handles nested attributes and puts them into a common format  common among node express  ruby on rails  etc       javascript qs.stringify   user:   name:  Tobi   email:  tobi@learnboost.com      // => user[name]=Tobi user[email]=tobi 40learnboost.com      this makes it much easier to interact with such servers using node request

title: Piped into request hangs on 3xx response.
body: Piped into request waits for _src_ stream _end_ event to start  and when server returns redirect  3xx  it re inits request and waits for _end_ event again  which is never happens.

title: Fix   test for piped into request bumped into redirect.  321
body: When server returns redirect code  there is no need to keep source stream  and it s existence signals request to wait for end event  which is already gone.  So just removing it helps to normalize the flow.

I ve made it so that responses will always be parsed as JSON if the response  Content type  header is  application/json .  Do we need more options here? However  when running the test  we see that s1 s  /original  endpoint is actually called twice:  1  with the /original url  and  2  with /original?[...].  Is this a bug?

title: Cookies are stored and set across domains  security issue
body: The cookie jar implementation  apparently taken directly from [LearnBoost/tobi] https://github.com/LearnBoost/tobi/tree/master/lib/cookie ?  only differentiates cookies by path  so cookies are being stored and set across domains.  https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/vendor/cookie/jar.js L46 55      js CookieJar.prototype.get = function req     var path = url.parse req.url .pathname       now = new Date       specificity =   ;   return this.cookies.filter function cookie       if  0 == path.indexOf cookie.path     now < cookie.expires          cookie.path.length >  specificity[cookie.name]    0         return specificity[cookie.name] = cookie.path.length;     ;  ;      This is a major security issue  as well as causing all kinds of problems for long running processes that hit multiple domains.  Cookies build up over time and since every cookie is being sent to every domain  requests fail when the cookie size exceeds server limits.  Since [LearnBoost/tobi] https://github.com/LearnBoost/tobi  is a functional testing library  its cookie jar implementation was never intended to be used across multiple domains. The fix here would be to either find a library that handles cookies properly  I haven t found one that s any good yet   write a new cookie jar implementation  or at least fix the current one to respect domains and possibly even limit the number of cookies that can be set per domain as most browsers do.  I d be happy to work on a pull request for this  but I wanted to report it first due to its severity.  Additionally  I found it surprising that cookies were enabled by default for a server side library. Most use cases probably don t need cookies  so it only makes sense that the cookie jar should be disabled by default. Just a thought.

title: Allow AWS to work in more situations  added a note in the README on its usage
body: The AWS function was modified to make sure the method is uppercase  since it breaks AWS signing if it s not.   I also wrapped the resource definition with some if statements to make sure the string is built correctly in most cases  as well as added a short note to the README on how to use the AWS signing.

title: Make AWS auth signing find headers correctly
body: The AWS function was using  content type  as the header name  which causes access denied errors if the header is actually set as  Content Type  since it is an important part of the signing process.  To resolve it  I wrapped the header in a short case insensitive getter to make sure they are always correctly set for the auth signing.

It d be nice of the example showed the form being submitted and capturing the results.   I ve been left really confused on how to submit the form once I populate it.

On this [line] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L212 :      javascript if  self.setHost  delete self.headers.host      the host header is being deleted  and actually commenting out that line resolves my issues. My question is  why is this needed? Can we get rid of it or move it below this conditional:      javascript  if  self.req._reusedSocket    error.code ===  ECONNRESET     self.agent.addRequestNoreuse

Basically  when we setup request to follow the redirects  and the redirect url has this pattern feed://... an  Invalid protocol  is raised. Which is quite a problem  because it s really hard to catch. Oddly enough  other types of url patterns do not have that issue.  Let us know if you need more things to debug that.      javascript var express = require  express  ;  var request = require  request  ;   http = express  ;  http.get  /redirect   function request  response      response.redirect 301   feed://tumblr.superfeedr.com/rss  ;   ; http.listen 8989 ;  request  http://0.0.0.0:8989/redirect   function  error  response  body      console.log error      console.log body    ;

title: setting a querystring breaks redirecting
body: [At the beginning of init] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L129   if self.url exists  it sets self.uri to self.url and deletes self.url.  Later  if there s a query string option present  init [calls the qs function to parse it] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L259 .  The qs function [sets self.url to the current uri again] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L748   Then  when the request is actually made  if it needs to redirect  based on the response status code  [it sets self.uri to the new uri from the headers] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L569  and calls self.init  .  Now  going in to self.init  self.uri is set with the new url that we need to redirect to from the response headers prior. Additionally  self.url IS ALSO SET to the ORIGINAL uri that was passed in when we first made the request. So now [init clobbers the proper uri with the old one] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L129 .

title: stop sending erroneous headers on redirected requests
body: if you delete the body  you should also delete any existing content type and content length  otherwise you re sending erroneous values: e.g. content type form encoded  content length 1415  empty body

The callback for the first request  the  HEAD  request  gets called when the response of the 2nd request   the  GET  request  is piped  which causes an infinite loop.  This gist https://gist.github.com/3991044 illustrates the issue: the expected output from running the program is       HEAD request returned status 200 Received end      ...the actual output  as testet with the latest  2.11.4  is       HEAD request returned status 200 Received end HEAD request returned status 200 Received end HEAD request returned status 200 Received end HEAD request returned status 200 Received end HEAD request returned status 200 Received end HEAD request returned status 200 Received end etc..

title: Use Date.now   instead of  new Date   .getTime
body: Date.now   is shown to be faster than  new Date   .getTime    http://jsperf.com/date now vs new date gettime

title: Delete self._form along with everything else on redirect
body: When posting a file to a url that does a redirect I was getting this error from request:      You have already piped to this stream. Pipeing twice is likely to break the request.      The post callback would never get fired.  When I deleted self._form it fixed the issue and I think it makes sense since its already deleting self.body etc.

title: Don t create a Content Length header if we already have it set
body: We ve had issues where we need to send Content Length as a header  rather than content length; when content length lowercase is in the request  the request fails.  I ve put some more checks around content length so that request doesn t do this if we ve already worked out Content Length  I thought it was part of the HTTP spec that headers we in fact uppercase? According to RFC2616?  http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616 sec14.html

title: Running  rfc3986  on  base_uri  in  oauth.hmacsign  instead of just  encodeURIComponent
body: All I ve changed in terms of output is that the base_uri is encoded with the rfc3986 function before being included in the sha1 base. I was getting 401 errors with the LinkedIn API because my signatures were wrong when I used [field selectors] https://developer.linkedin.com/documents/field selectors  in an api call.

title: rfc3986 on base_uri  now passes tests

title: Fix uncatchable errors. Update tests/test errors.js for coverage.
body: Request init has two places where it will emit an  error  event  but listeners have not had a chance to attach yet. So any emitted errors actually throw.  Tests included.  Example:      js request  /invalid  .on  error   function  e     console.error  Hey... I should have been caught   ;    // Throws Error: Invalid URI  /invalid

title: Cookie Header Caching
body: I m attempting to make requests to CouchDB from inside an Express app.  I m seeing a cached cookie header get sent to Couch on every request  regardless of the actual initial request from the client.  For example  I log in to my app on one machine and I see the correct response from CouchDB.  Another user visits the same app on another machine and is instantly recognized as being logged in as me because CouchDB is somehow receiving my session cookie.  If they then choose to force a new login on their machine  then my app now thinks I m logged in as them.  Here s a snippet where I am attempting to pull the cookie from the Express request object and pass it along to CouchDB:      javascript exports.currentUser = function req  res  next      var headers =     cookie = req.cookies.AuthSession  auth = req.get  authorization  ;   if  cookie  headers.Cookie =  AuthSession=    cookie;   if  auth  headers.Authorization = auth;   request  url:  http://127.0.0.1:5984/_session   json:     headers: headers   function error  resp  body        console.log body ;     next  ;  ;      Any thoughts on why this is happening or what I m missing? I m using version 2.11.4 from npm.

title: HTTPS does not work through Proxy
body: I had originally reported this against npm  but it looks like the issue is in request. Here s the npm ticket: https://github.com/isaacs/npm/issues/2866  I have set up my  .npmrc  file to have settings for our corporate proxy:      proxy = http://user:password@proxy:8080/ https proxy = http://user:password@proxy:8080/      Running any npm command using these settings fails. As a workaround  I had to change the registry to HTTP instead of HTTPS:      registry = http://registry.npmjs.org/      Most things seem to work fine with this  except if I try to install something that has dependencies listed using HTTPS. One example for this is Yeoman  https://github.com/yeoman/yeoman   which lists two dependencies in package.json using HTTPS:      https://nodeload.github.com/cowboy/grunt/tarball/0ba6d4b529 https://nodeload.github.com/yeoman/generators/tarball/282b0b4c51      Downloading these fails miserably with the following error:      npm ERR  fetch failed https://nodeload.github.com/cowboy/grunt/tarball/0ba6d4b529 npm ERR  fetch failed https://nodeload.github.com/yeoman/generators/tarball/282b0b4c51 npm ERR  Error: tunneling socket could not be established  sutatusCode=403 npm ERR      at ClientRequest.onConnect  /usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/request/tunnel.js:148:19  npm ERR      at ClientRequest.g  events.js:193:14  npm ERR      at ClientRequest.EventEmitter.emit  events.js:123:20  npm ERR      at Socket.socketOnData  http.js:1393:11  npm ERR      at TCP.onread  net.js:403:27  npm ERR  If you need help  you may report this log at: npm ERR      <http://github.com/isaacs/npm/issues> npm ERR  or email it to: npm ERR      <npm @googlegroups.com>  npm ERR  System Darwin 10.8.0 npm ERR  command  node   /usr/local/bin/npm   install   yeoman  npm ERR  cwd /Users/Nils.Winkler npm ERR  node  v v0.8.11 npm ERR  npm  v 1.1.62 npm ERR  code ECONNRESET      It seems like HTTPS does not work through some proxies. Could you please look into getting this supported in npm  as it looks like a major shortcoming for people behind a corporate proxy.

title: fixing neverending redirect loop
body: issue  311. looks like Host header is transmitted on the wire as lowercast  host  which confuses some servers. RFC does state the host header as uppercase  Host   so I amended all instances of headers.host to headers.Host.  Hope this helps.

title: Don t remove x_auth_mode for Twitter reverse auth
body: Twitter s reverse auth requires passing an x_auth_mode parameter.  See more: https://dev.twitter.com/docs/ios/using reverse auth.

title: Twitter reverse auth uses x_auth_mode not x_auth_type
body: Sorry.

title: Strip out the UTF8 BOM when encoding is  utf8
body: Some frameworks  such as .NET in my case  often emit the UTF8 byte order mark in the HTTP response.  This commit strips out the BOM when the encoding is set to  utf8  and improves compatibility with external services.

title: Correct Host header for proxy tunnel CONNECT
body: As per [RFC 2817] http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2817.txt   section _5.2 Requesting a Tunnel with CONNECT_  there is a  Host  header to be set. The examples in the RFC use the same example host/port which is confusing  but logically  it makes no sense to use the same hostname in  CONNECT  statement and in the  Host  header. The  Host  header is meant to be set to the actual host to be proxied/tunelled to  and it looks like at least some of the proxies out there work that way.  I believe this also closes  367.  Notes: 1. it would probably be ideal if the tunnel options were overridable from the main api  e.g. via  opts =   tunnelOptions:   ..      2. it would probably be better if the Host header for the tunnel was set after the logic for resolving the target hostname/port/protocol  which is below the tunnel config code  but it contains a few references to self.tunnel  so I m not sure on that.

title: Fix for missing oauth_timestamp parameter
body: If one of the request parameters is called  timestamp   the  oauth_timestamp  OAuth parameter will get removed during the parameter cleanup loop.

title: Headers lost on redirect
body: When piping request into another stream  which supports setHeader  the headers aren t included if a redirect occurres. It s because the  self.dests  in the  init   [linie 114 in main.js] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L114   method is reset to an empty array on every redirect. I think this also fixes issue [ 348] https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/348 .

title: How does pooling work?
body: Hello   We have completely disabled pooling in our application  or at least we think we did by passing pool:false  when calling request. Now  however  we re trying to understand how it works because we re seeing an odd behavior.  Basically  we use request to fetch a lot of different files  from different hosts mostly  in our  fetcher . We have set our fetcher so that it does not fetch more than X files at any given time  it will start fetching the next when one is done . We also measure how much time is spend between an item enters our fetcher and exits it  after its being fetched .  We ve noted that when we increase the X number to say 2X  it looks like we re not fetching more items per second. Similarly  we observed that the process time for each item increases. This leads us to think that even though we have set pool to false  request is still throttling our fetcher. Could this be? How can we check that?  Also  if I understand correctly  pooling will just keep a fixed  maxSocket  number of sockets and request will try to find the best one to use  using the host information  if one is already open. Is that the case? If not  can someone explain better?

title: add  charset=utf 8  to content type  application/json
body: The  Request.prototype.json  function sets  Content Type  headers to  application/json .  utf 8 really should be the default imo  and this lead me to several hours of debugging hell to realize that the API I was working with rejects all but UTF 8 json.  I made these changes:  main.js  Line  803:      this.setHeader  content type    application/json; charset=utf 8        main.js  Line  807:      this.setHeader  content type    application/json; charset=utf 8        Is there anything wrong with this?  Any thoughts?

title: Destroy the response if present when destroying the request
body: Right now calling  req.destroy  does nothing when the response is present and the request will continue to emit data.  This makes sure to call  response.destroy  if there is a response present which ensures that the stream will stop emitting data when destroy is called.

title: Use latest form data 0.0.5
body: The [form data] https://github.com/felixge/node form data  module has recently merged some very useful improvements to [working with multipart forms] https://github.com/felixge/node form data/pull/17 issuecomment 10047904   used by request. The latest release is 0.0.5  but request is still using 0.0.3. This bumps it up.

Connection :  close             followRedirect : false      function  err  res  body        var json = JSON.stringify res ;     process.nextTick hambulance ;     ;     ;      This does not crash:      javascript var request = require  request       util = require  util     ;   function hambulance       var req = request.head       url            :  http://short.co/97k9       headers        :          User Agent :  AppleWebKit/525.13  KHTML  like Gecko  Safari/525.13. Something in  getSafe  is doing something it shouldn t be doing to the Socket s underlying events listeners  and it s causing a  close  event to be emitted incorrectly to boot.  Breaking cycles is hard

title: Ensure  safe  toJSON doesn t break EventEmitters
body: V8 and / or the JS spec are apparently extremely wily about interpreting values as potential indexes for arrays    even hex strings can be converted internally back to numbers when passed to Object.defineProperty  . This should fix mikeal/request 387.  None of the tests break with this change  but as the bug is sort of a race condition  I couldn t easily come up with a new test case. The breaking test code on mikeal/request 387 no longer crashes when left running for a decent length of time  at least.

title: Memory leak from Node with request.setTimeout
body: Hi   There is a memory leak happening here ... https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L682  ... with older versions of node. I can confirm it s happening with node 0.8.4 but not 0.8.14 and it was probably fixed in one of these: https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/3076 https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/3068 https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/3788  It s of course not an issue with request but maybe you should disable this 2nd timeout feature for older versions of node  it is already not supported before 0.6?   because request users stuck with older versions of node will have to either use a patched request or disable timeouts altogether.  You can test this by running npm test on crawler: https://github.com/sylvinus/node crawler/blob/master/test/units/leaks.js  Thanks

title: node v0.9.x  compatibility
body: This isn t ready to merge yet  merely heads up for everyone wanting to use  request  with unstable version of  node .  Right now   streams2  compatibility is included.  rejectUnauthorized  in tests should still be changed.

title: remove nextTick delay for GET  HEAD  DELETE
body: Since GET  HEAD  and DELETE requests do not have a body  we can remove the process.nextTick delay before starting the request.  The delay is there to allow content to be piped in  but is not necessary for these types of requests  This improves performance by roughly  20  in some simple benchmarks.

title: Chunked encoding   forever   working?
body: I ve been looking at request for the last couple of days and am now stuck with it.  I m looking for some pointers with the below issues  and also wanted to confirm that the features I m trying to get working are not broken .  First  if I set headers like so:   headers:      Transfer Encoding :  chunked      I get nothing back  the response callback is never called .  The web service I m trying to talk to only accepts chunked connections  so I have to have it set  without  transfer encoding: chunked  header the service returns an error  Monitor request must be done on a chunked encoding connection.    So  does request handle chunked connections?  If so  are there any special considerations getting it to work?  I can get a  chunked  connection working against the API I m working with using https.request  but the whole point I m looking at request instead is that I d like to keep the TCP connection open and multiplex multiple requests over it  it s the recommended way the web service in question should be accessed .  https.request shuts down the socket right away  and so request s  forever    might solve the problem.  The second question is about forever  .  How do I enable it?  I saw a suggestion [in Google Groups] https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=  topic/nodejs/ZI6WnDgwwV0  to access forever like so:    var request = require  request  .forever  ;   But when I do that  node exits with:   /usr/local/lib/node_modules/request/forever.js:100   options.port = port   Thanks for any insights on this

title: Check for Host header should be case insensitive
body: Currently  request checks that if the  Host  header is present in the options but only checks the lowercase version: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/b85bf633fe8197dc38855f10016a0a76a8ab600a/main.js L187  What I see is that I can t set the  Host  header with capitalization because it is ultimately overwritten by  host . I would like to  for the sake of agreement with standard protocol   set  Host  instead of  host   but I m unable to. Can the check on the line I linked to be made case insensitive? I can provide a patch if necessary.  Ideally  I d love for the header that request sets itself to also be capitalized so that I don t have to override the capitalization  but at least the check should be case insensitive.

title: Add noproxy configuration
body: When using request with noproxy  check if the url requested must use a proxy  if present  or not. This allows requests on lan without having to change/disable the proxy parameter each time.   noproxy  is a string containing hostnames. When using request with an url matching one of these hostnames  the specifed proxy won t be used.  So  this add a way to specify a list of hostnames that will not ever go through a proxy.

title: Need a way to not escape querystrings

This causes a problem when using this library because all of the query strings are escaped prior to the request. Bing  of course  doesn t understand the parameters when they are escaped  when   top   >   24top  .   Pretty lame that Bing requires this but I think it could be a useful feature.

title: tests/googledoodle.png is actually a JPEG

It turns out that https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/tests/googledoodle.png is actually a JPEG   see http://regex.info/exif.cgi?imgurl=https 3A 2F 2Fraw.github.com 2Fmikeal 2Frequest 2Fmaster 2Ftests 2Fgoogledoodle.png for confirmation.

title: When response content length is 0  callback receives undefined as body parameter
body: When request receives a response where the response body has a content length of 0  request calls the callback and passes undefined as the body parameter to the callback.  I believe that passing the empty string is more correct behavior.

title: Increment major version due to API change.
body: The new auth API changes are not backwards compatible  which I discovered trying to use the current master README against the 2.12 release.  [Semantic Versioning] http://semver.org/  demains that backwards incompatible changes result in a new major version. You might not be currently applying semantic versioning to this project  but I would strongly recommend it.  Alternatively  you could patch the code to continue to accept  user:pass  string as auth parameters. In this case you would only need to increment the minor version to 2.13  to indicate the presence of the new  auth  api.

title: Copy options before adding callback.
body: Prevents a reference to the callback function being added to the original options object.  I discovered this by making a request with a callback  then reusing the options object I made the request with to make a  streaming request  which called the callback a second time.

title: Respect specified  Host host  headers  not just  host
Remove bundleDepdendencies from package.json to pull in latest versions of form data and mime  also bump major version.
body: So I ve been trying to fix a bug with request when using the multi part forms where a form value of empty string will cause the everything to fail.  So one by one I ve been moving from package to package putting all the bits in to fix this.   The bug originated in node combined stream which is required by node form data which is required by request.   Bug in node combined stream: https://github.com/felixge/node combined stream/pull/4  Bug in node form data https://github.com/felixge/node form data/issues/25  And due to an issue with the package.json node form data needed to be updated as well. Now this bug has propagated all the way up to request being the next dependency in line :   The fix to finally resolve this issue is to remove the line:      javascript    bundleDependencies :[ form data   mime ]      And to bump the package version for request up a major version as request will use much newer versions of form data and mime.   If this is done I believe the following bugs in request will be resolved   385  424  And the following issues may be resolved  394  316

title: Fix issue  160  remove auth header on redirect
body: This fix removes the authorization header when the host that s being redirected to is different than the host that s redirecting  if the hosts are the same then the auth header remains the same.  Tests included.  This is try 2  I don t think the first pull request sent successfully.

title: Added support for HTTPS cert   key
body: Currently  request  does not support some of the options from node core  https.request . _This pull request adds support for  key    cert   and  rejectUnauthorized  options._  Including full list from [nodejs.org/api] http://nodejs.org/api/https.html https_https_request_options_callback  for reference  > The following options from tls.connect   can also be specified. However  a globalAgent silently ignores these. >   pfx: Certificate  Private key and CA certificates to use for SSL. Default null. >   key: Private key to use for SSL. Default null. >   passphrase: A string of passphrase for the private key or pfx. Default null. >   ca: An authority certificate or array of authority certificates to check the remote host against. >   cert: Public x509 certificate to use. Default null. >   ciphers: A string describing the ciphers to use or exclude. Consult http://www.openssl.org/docs/apps/ciphers.html CIPHER_LIST_FORMAT for details on the format. >   rejectUnauthorized: If true  the server certificate is verified against the list of supplied CAs. An  error  event is emitted if verification fails. Verification happens at the connection level  before the HTTP request is sent. Default false.

title: How to know if JSON auto parsing failed?
body: Currently  request try catches its JSON parsing:  https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/v2.33.1/request.js L879 L883      js           if  self._json                try                 response.body = JSON.parse response.body                catch  e                      As you mention in https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/99 issuecomment 14016174  this was intentional  and I understand why.  But it has one problem: I as a caller have no way of knowing whether the JSON has been successfully parsed or not. Specifically  if the response is malformed JSON   response.body  remains a string  but if it s valid JSON representing a string   response.body  is also a string.  This isn t just a theoretical problem; I ran into this recently when an API server started returning malformed JSON  with a 200 error code  because it s a streaming API  due to an out of memory error.  What do you suggest? Thanks again for the help    Edited to fix and pin link.

title: protect against double callbacks on error path
body: In the case that the client callback passed into request throws an error  the request callback may get called twice. Setting request s _callbackCalled flag before invoking the callback protects against this.   See here for some background: https://github.com/visionmedia/mocha/issues/755 https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/330  Here is a simple mocha testcase that shows one example of this happening. In this case  i m forcing the issue by using a url that request will fail to fetch  and then throwing an error in the callback.       var request = require  request  ;  function testFunction requestOptions  onCompletion         var hasBeenCalled = false;      request requestOptions  function  error            if  hasBeenCalled                console.log  WARNING multiple callback  ;                   hasBeenCalled = true;          throw new Error  whoops  ;          onCompletion error ;       ;    describe  testFunction   function          it  should not invoke the request callback twice   function  done            testFunction  url: http://localhost:6789    done ;       ;   ;

title: Not specifying callback can result in unhandled error
body: I m using the convenience methods for making a request without specifying a callback. If that request fails for some reason it will throw an unhandled error. I m not really interested in whether the request makes it or not in this particular case  hence the missing callback  but the unhandled error exits my process. Just adding a callback or even doing  request  http://localhost:1/  .on  error   function      ;  works but I would expect the library to handle any errors when using a convenience method. Perhaps this should be noted in the documentation somewhere?  Example code that triggers the error  make sure you re not running anything on port 1  .      javascript var request = require  request  ;  request  http://localhost:1/  ;          events.js:71         throw arguments[1]; // Unhandled  error  event                        ^ Error: connect ECONNREFUSED     at errnoException  net.js:770:11      at Object.afterConnect [as oncomplete]  net.js:761:19

title: Content length issue with form data and streams
body: Saw a bug similar to this which is now closed  for some reason  but if you think this is a dupe go ahead and close it.  Anyhow  the following:      javascript var upload = request       url:  http://example.com/       method:  POST      function err  resp  body        console.log body ;   ; var form = upload.form  ; form.append  test    somestring  ; form.append  test2    anotherstring  ; form.append  Filedata   fs.createReadStream  1M.data   ; form.getLength function err  len        upload.setHeader  Content Length   len ;   ;      This results in a 411 response from a standard nginx server. Using getLengthSync makes no difference  removing the last 3 lines makes no difference. Also resp.request.headers does contain a content length with a value which seems correct.   So why is it that it still fails? Why do I have to do any of this in the first place? Your examples should work as is  and this is almost a direct copy of your example in the readme  except the last 3 lines and changing request.post   to request   .

title: Convenience method for PATCH
body: This adds a convenience method for the PATCH HTTP method defined in [RFC 5789] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5789 .

title: Exclamation in status update causes Twitter OAuth to fail
body: Posting to twitter works fine until you use any of these characters:      looks like a common problem: https://dev.twitter.com/discussions/12378   When I post something to Twitter with an exclamation mark I get the following error: status_code=401  body=[message=Could not authenticate you  code=32]  Looks like https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/main.js L865 is not escaping some chars that Twitter wants escaped.

title: Authorization header shouldn t be forwarded across redirects
body: Authorization headers are getting preserved even after redirects to a different server  which breaks if the target of the redirect isn t expecting Authorization  e.g. Amazon S3 throws a 400 error .  Ideally the behaviour would be the same as in curl or requesting the URL in a browser  For example:      js var app = require  express    ;  app.get      function req  res     res.redirect  http://aws lightbox.s3.amazonaws.com/source/jquery.fancybox.css  ;   ;  app.listen 5678   require  request    http://foo:bar@localhost:5678/   function err resp     console.log  Request   resp.statusCode ;   ;  require  child_process  .exec  curl  L  w    http_code    o /dev/null http://foo:bar@localhost:5678/   function err  resp     console.log  Curl   resp    ;      Outputs:      Request 400 Curl 200      This is currently breaking NPM with links to GitHub private repo tarballs using basic auth  as they redirect to S3

title: Use Error.name to easen error handling
body: It would be nice if Error.name[1] could be used to make it easier to distinguish different types or Errors and handle them. For example  HTTP problems vs. max redirects.  [1] https://developer.mozilla.org/en US/docs/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Error/name

title: Increment major version due to API change.
body: New version of  424 that tracks the changes to master.  The new auth API changes are not backwards compatible  which I discovered trying to use the current master README against the 2.12 release.  Semantic Versioning demains that backwards incompatible changes result in a new major version. You might not be currently applying semantic versioning to this project  but I would strongly recommend it.  Alternatively  you could patch the code to continue to accept  user:pass  string as auth parameters. In this case you would only need to increment the minor version to 2.13  to indicate the presence of the new  auth  api.

title: Use Date.now   instead of  new Date   .getTime
body: Date.now   is shown to be faster than  new Date   .getTime    http://jsperf.com/date now vs new date gettime

title: Destroy the response if present when destroying the request  clean merge

title: browserify support
body: While working on tilgovi/chromify last month I ran into an issue where the mime types file couldn t be read by request  because it wasn t included . At the time I hacked around it hard by bundling the mime types file through emscripten and a readFileSync that read from that.  With the  browser  attribute of either request or the mime types module I bet we can preload the data so that it just works.  I ll look into it and come back with a PR over the weekend.

title: addCookie needs to pass a request object to the Cookie constructor
body: When  addCookie  calls  new Cookie  it should be passing an object that has a  url  member as the second argument as the cookie constructor will expect to be able to use that if the cookie attributes don t include a path.

title: hawk 0.10.0
Strip the UTF8 BOM from a UTF encoded response
body: Some frameworks  such as .NET  often emit the UTF8 byte order mark in the HTTP response.  This commit strips out the BOM when the encoding is set to  utf8  and improves compatibility with external services.   This is a copy of a previous commit for issue  371  which no longer cleanly applies and requires a refresh .

title: if query params are empty  then request path shouldn t end with a  ?   merges cleanly now
body: If you do this:      javascript req = request.get   uri:  http://www.google.com   qs:            Then req.path equates to /?  which only makes sense if there are some query parameters.  Opening a new PR since issue https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/436 wasn t merging cleanly.

body: Add gzip support for request:      js request.get  uri:  http://code.jquery.com/jquery 1.9.1.js   gzip: true   function err  res  body      assert.equal res.headers[ content encoding ]   gzip     assert.ok body.indexOf  jQuery   > 0

title: default pooling behavior is fundamentally incompatible with composibility
body: The current default behavior in request and core s http.request   is just about the most insidious kind of bug riddled behavior possible. Once you have 5 or more extant open connections  any additional outgoing connections will just HANG FOREVER until one of the other connections finally dies. Now the behavior of your program is dependent on what other pieces of code in your program are doing and might hang inexplicably at ANY TIME.  More ranting: https://github.com/substack/hyperquest pooling is evil  @isaacs is fixing most of my objections in node 0.10 but it would be great if we didn t have to wait as long for request to do the right thing here.  Until this issue is fixed I ll ripping out every instance of request in all of my modules to use [hyperquest] https://github.com/substack/hyperquest  because the current behavior of request s horrible connection pooling behavior is fundamentally incompatible with composing behavior from lots of tiny pieces.

title: not immediately request

title: Replace core pooling entirely?
body: @substack raised some good points in recent rants.   https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/259 issuecomment 14607516 https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/465 https://github.com/substack/hyperquest  The current behavior isn t what anyone wants. Request has traditionally tried to offer a simpler API to the pooling in core and also straddle compatibility between versions of pooling in core.  These issues won t be fixed in core until 0.12  it may be prudent to move request  tunnel agent and forever agent  or possibly deprecate entirely  to the new pooling structure being discussed for 0.12.  As discussed here  https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/4769  something like require  net  .createPool   will go in to 0.12. Could we begin this as a standalone library that will work in 0.8  and integrate it in to request prior to 0.12?  @isaacs

It s not a big deal    I m just doing this to debug  and I can turn off pooling for this task    but I wonder if this is a bug.  Thanks

title: NoProxy configuration
body: When using request with noproxy  check if the url requested must use a proxy  if present  or not. This allows requests on lan without having to change/disable the proxy parameter each time.   noproxy  is a string containing hostnames. When using request with an url matching one of these hostnames  the specifed proxy won t be used.  So  this add a way to specify a list of hostnames that will not ever go through a proxy.

title: Request fails when response is > 1GB and a callback is assigned
body: Request fails when the response is larger than 1 GB and there is a callback function  e.g.:  request  http://www.host.com/largeimage.jpg   function  error  response  body        ...     Here is the stack trace in the node console:  buffer.js:243       this.parent = new SlowBuffer this.length ;                     ^ RangeError: length > kMaxLength     at new Buffer  buffer.js:243:21      at Request.onResponse  /home/fmahnke/src/node_modules/request/index.js:790:22      at Request.EventEmitter.emit  events.js:126:20      at IncomingMessage.Request.onResponse.buffer  /home/fmahnke/src/node_modules/request/index.js:773:12      at IncomingMessage.EventEmitter.emit  events.js:126:20      at IncomingMessage._emitEnd  http.js:366:10      at HTTPParser.parserOnMessageComplete [as onMessageComplete] http.js:149:23      at Socket.socketOnData [as ondata] http.js:1485:20      at TCP.onread  net.js:404:27   It looks like the problem happens when request is given a callback function. Line index.js:790 is when the Buffer object is allocated that will be used to hold the response body.  The problem appears to be because the data exceeds the maximum length of node s buffer: https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/src/node_buffer.h L69

title: Changing so if Accept header is explicitly set  sending json does not ov...
body: This change handles a case where the user has set the Accept header  other than application/json  for the request and wants to send JSON. Accept header is not overwritten. A valid use case for this is a REST API where the API expects a custom Accept header for versioning reasons  i.e. application/vnd.custom.v1 json

title: Check hasOwnProperty in prototype.qs
body: Hi   I m working on a project where some functions get added to Object s prototype.  When request.prototype.qs copied over params into  base  this meant it also added these functions  and so all my requests with qs options had  extraFunctionName anotherExtra... on the end  which made some APIs we were using very unhappy.  This fix just adds a hasOwnProperty check inside the for loop.  Thanks  Thomas

title: Broken querystring encoding
body: Your module here depends on the node querystring module right now  which was recently updated. The recent update broke querystring encoding for parameters with  null  values. See my report here: https://github.com/visionmedia/node querystring/issues/52  My question is  why use the node querystring module when you could use the built in querystring module? By switching it would avoid the recent breakage.      js var qs = require  querystring  ; qs.stringify ... ;

title: Limit Request Body Size
body: Is it possible to limit the request body size similar to the express.limit 250kb function in Express? Thanks much Chris

title: Inconsistent Transfer Encoding for form urlencoded post requests
body: Calling  Request.prototype.form  with an object doesn t set the  content length  header. So the request gets sent with  Transfer Encoding: chunked :      javascript request.post url  callback .form   // Transfer Encoding: chunked     user: username      pass: password   ;      But when you already specify the form data in the options argument the content length gets set correctly and the request is not chunked:      javascript request.post url        form:   // not chunked         user: username          pass: password          callback ;

title: Empty response body  3 rd argument  must be passed to callback as an empty string
body: Docs sates:  The callback argument gets 3 arguments. ... The third is the response body String or Buffer.  If response has an empty body  Content length is 0  third argument is  undefined   not  String  nor  Buffer .  The  edge case  is JSON response. Empty body can t be parsed to something convinient  so  this case still results in  undefined   may be it must be handled different way? .

title: Requesting Engadget RSS feed at one second intervals causes request to freeze.
body: Using setInterval to make requests to Engadget RSS feed  http://www.engadget.com/rss.xml  causes Request to freeze after about 30 minutes of requesting every second.  I took the example from the Readme and modified it to show what is going on:      var request = require  request  ;  function makeRequest         request  http://www.engadget.com/rss.xml   function  error  response  body            console.log  callback getting called  ;       ;    setInterval makeRequest  1000 ;      For about 30 minutes this runs just fine. Every second the callback prints  callback getting called . Then suddenly the printing of new lines just freezes. No new lines are printed. No errors are getting printed as well  in case I change to code to print error variable. In that case null gets printed until the freeze  then nothing. If I make the application to request other url as well  tested with this: http://yle.fi/uutiset/rss/paauutiset.rss  using for example an array and a loop  the other url gets requested just fine.  When the application is in the frozen state  I can use the same computer to refresh the Engadget RSS feed in browser just fine.  Seems that Request does not request the url after a while for some reason or Engadget stops responding because of the one second interval but Request does not handle the timeout. The latter seems unlikely as I can load the url using a browser.

However  the following breaks the output in the terminal pretty badly:      javascript headers =                      User Agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Windows NT 6.1; WOW64  AppleWebKit/537.17  KHTML  like Gecko  Chrome/24.0.1312.60 Safari/537.17                     Accept:  text/html application/xhtml xml application/xml;q=0.9  / ;q=0.8                      Accept Language :  en us                      Accept Encoding :  gzip  deflate                     Connection:  keep alive       ;        httprequest                   headers: headers                  url:  http://www.google.com    function  error  response  body                        console.log body ;                  ;         ;      I am also attaching here a screen shot of my terminal after running the second example. Also  this didn t use to happen in an earlier version of the module    2 months ago .    [Screen Shot 2013 03 27 at 09 38 14] https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2144830/307440/1bd20e6c 96c2 11e2 85b4 e76e33a644b4.png

title: Allow not forwarding certain headers
body: I m using request to pipe a stream between a remote Web host and a file upload API. The API in question uses ETag as an MD5 hash  and when using request to pipe directly to the API endpint  the automatically forwarded Etag causes the API to fail.  One possible solution  I m very open to discussion  is to allow explicitly opting out forwarded headers. That s what I ve implemented here.  You could also do wholesale disallow  except for content length  type  etc  or some other solution  whitelist?   Thoughts?  Sample code:      Javascript request  http://my.server.with.etag.com/foo.jpg  .pipe request       method:  PUT       uri:  http://somewhere.else       forwardedHeaderBlacklist:           etag: true          callback ;

body: Just a heads up. With request.jar set to true  which is default  I could not complete linkedin s oAuth2 flow. Everything worked fine until I sent a request to the api after receiving a users authorization.   I guess linkedIn set the cookie when the user authorizes the app:  leo_auth_token=  GST:8g9dFmC06EEeQmi4M        9fFmm_J779E1amHEULfLM6xsEsTmb46_sy4s:1364515371:463a8c904e50f8be059fd99b12dd443b373695bb    When making an api request it seems to send this cookie with it which couse an exception:    id :  errorCode :0  message : [invalid.auth.token.type]. Authentication token type  GST  is not valid here.   requestId : 6XYP7FPIGR   status :401  timestamp :1364501128399    The fix: set request.jar to false.  An explanation would be cool as I dont quite get why its doing that

title: Add a NEWS file summarizing changes between releases
body: See http://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/NEWS File.html

title: Added transformRedirects option
body: This option allows you to alter redirects before they are executed.  This would mostly be used when you don t know the final url you are trying to hit  but want to append query parameters onto it.  Using this function has the advantage over catching each individual request and appending the query yourself in both ease of use and taking advantage of any optimizations/error handling request already has in place for redirects.  Example usage:      javascript var search= ?query=somedata ; request     url:  http://www.test.com  search    followRedirect: true    transformRedirects: function url        return url search;       function error response body      res.send body ;   ;      For comparison  this is the current alternative I am using:      javascript function requestTransform options transform callback      request options function error response body        var redirect=response.headers.location;     if redirect ==undefined          options.url=transform redirect ;       requestTransform options transform callback ;           else         callback error response body ;

title: Added redirect event
body: Similar to this pull request: https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/496  This instead emits an event which includes a function that allows altering the redirect.  Example usage:      javascript var search= ?query=somedata ; request     url:  http://www.test.com  search    followRedirect: true    function error response body      res.send body ;   .on  redirect  function redirect updateRedirect        updateRedirect url search ;   ;

title: Moving response emit above setHeaders on destination streams
body: This change proposes moving  self.emit  response   response ;  above the loop that ultimately calls self.pipeDest   on each of the destination streams.  This is to allow modifying the response headers before they are cloned to the destination Requests.

title: OAuth: Requires the  content type  header to be _exactly_ as is
body: Not sure if this is intentional  but this caused me a major headache:      js // Build reqOptions  reqOptions.headers[ Content Type ] = req.params.contentType; request.post reqOptions  callback ;      This fails because   Content Type   ==  content type   and [therefore] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/4d63a042553c90718bf0b90652921b26c52dcb31/index.js L1049  the POST body is ignored when building the OAuth signature.

title: Hawk 0.11
body: You can just change package.json to use 0.11.x. The APIs you are using did not change.

title: Is there away to know what the last URI is when dealing with redirected links?
body: I m writing a program to trace to the actual target of an URL. There are some URLs contain redirection  is there away to get the last request object in order to find out the final URL?

title: Fix POST  and probably other  requests that are retried after 401 Unauthorized
body: These commits fix a regression and a bug that were preventing POST requests from working when the initial request fails with  401 Unauthorized  and a  WWW Authenticate  header  and the client retries with a proper  Authorization  header.  Also add tests to catch these problems in the future.

Creating a request to one page works fine  however once that s finished and another request is made  it ll look like it s working for a couple of minutes then crash out with:      events.js:72         throw er; // Unhandled  error  event               ^ Error: connect ECONNREFUSED     at errnoException  net.js:878:11      at Object.afterConnect [as oncomplete]  net.js:869:19       I m now running my application as  sudo node app  and see where that takes me. Have I missed anything though?

title: Nesting GET objects does not work
body: Lets say I wan t to get to the following address:      http://google.com?awesome[key]=12345      This is what I tried to do and it failed:            url:  http://google.com      qs:           awesome:                key :  12345                         This fails as well:            url:  http://google.com      qs:            awesome[key] :  12345               In the  response  object I found something that looks like this:      http://google.com?awesome 5Bkey 5D=12345      So I just ran            url:  http://google.com?awesome[key]=12345         And this worked.

title: Temporary Streams2 support
body: Not sure how to test this since you need node 0.10 to really try the stream. But fully tested within hapi.

title: Honor the .strictSSL option when using proxies  tunnel agent
body: Using a proxy makes Request use its own agent. Therefore  Request must give the agent the appropriate  rejectUnauthorized  value.  Thanks  Isaac Schlueter for a hint of where to look for this bug.

title: Blocking timing out a GET request if content length is bigger than X
body: When sending GET requests  if the URL refers to a huge sized file  like a zip file of 600mb   the process hangs if it is not streamed to a file.  Is there a way to get the  content length before getting the full body and abort the connection is it exceeds a given size.  Or  what is the best way to manage such issues?

title: Add HTTP Signature support.
body: Add options  docs  and tests for HTTP Signature Scheme[1] support using Joyent s library[2].  [1] https://github.com/joyent/node http signature/blob/master/http_signing.md [2] https://github.com/joyent/node http signature

title: Piped responses truncated when running under node 0.8.x
body: I m using this module to forward certain incoming requests to a backend server:      var dbReq = request  uri:dbURL  jar:false  pool:foreverPool  ; req.pipe dbReq .pipe res ;  // debugging code dbReq.on  data   function  d    console.warn  DATA FROM API REQUEST   d.toString   ;   ;      However  when the  dbReq  returns a large amount of data the response often gets truncated running under node 0.8.x. I ve confirmed that the upstream server is returning valid data  but the debugging logs on the  data  events show only what the client is seeing: a bunch of output during the the first part of the  dbReq  response but then suddenly stopping.  Running under node.js 0.10.x seems to fix  or at least mask  the problem.

title: Make password optional to support the format: http://username@hostname/

title: Port 80 is included in the  Host  request field  instead of defaulted  when it isn t with other popular HTTP clients
body:
Hi So we encountered an interesting problem today less so a bug with request but more of a incongruent behavior from request when compared against other browsers and client s we ve tested. When working with cloudfoundry.com we found that their proxy did not consider a request to port 80 the same if the port was explicitly specified in the Host header field. So a request to http://foo.cloudfoundry.com:80/ and http://foo.cloudfoundry.com/ behaved differently. We narrowed it down to the difference in the Host field. Request included the port when explicitly specifying it but not when it wasn t. http://foo.cloudfoundry.com:80/ has a Host header of Host: foo.cloudfoundry.com:80 http://foo.cloudfoundry.com/ has a Host header of Host: foo.cloudfoundry.com No big deal right? Well so everyone else strips port 80 because it is the default : Curl strips port 80 from the Host header wget strips port 80 from the Host header Safari strips port 80 from the Host header Firefox strips port 80 from the Host header Chrome strips port 80 from the Host header You can test the behavior using http://helloworld ng.cloudify.com:80/ and http://helloworld ng.cloudify.com/ notice that both URLs work the same in all of the above listed browsers In curl we can see the failure case shell pair@foo: pair/ curl http://helloworld ng.cloudfoundry.com:80/ H Host: helloworld ng.cloudfoundry.com:80 404 Not Found

404 Not Found

nginx
pair@foo: pair/ curl http://helloworld ng.cloudfoundry.com:80/ H Host: helloworld ng.cloudfoundry.com Hello from Cloud Foundry Now let s try it with request javascript request=require request ; request.get http://helloworld ng.cloudfoundry.com:80/ function err req body console.log this will fail with port 80 body ; ; request.get http://helloworld ng.cloudfoundry.com/ function err req body console.log this will not fail without port 80 body ; ; We ve asked cloudfoundry to fix this issue but to be clear this is incongruent with every other client and browser we ve tested So then the question becomes should request do the same? Sadly it seems like this shouldn t be an issue but it is an unexpected behavior and no one else does it hence why I think request should strip port 80 from the Header field if it is specified. On that note node http proxy suffers form the same problem and a nice bit of logic that it uses some places to address it: javascript var host=host port 80===0? : : port

title: UNIX Socket URL Support
body: Added support for http requests over unix sockets via the  unix://  protocol name.  Uses  net.connect  to discover the listening socket inside a full url and sends the remaining path using existing  request  methods.  Summary for use is added to  README.md   The asynchronous socket listener discovery loop fails with an  Error  after 1000 ticks to prevent hangs  successful connections appear to happen within a couple of ticks.

title: Fix custom request handler to work with other request methods  put  post  etc
body: The custom handler implementation was only partially finished. When creating a custom handler such as:  var req = request.defaults     customHandler ;  Only req    req.get    req.del   would use the custom handler. req.put    req.post    req.patch    and req.head   would not. This fixes the problem using the same solution that existed  only filling in the other methods that were missed.

title: Best practices for conditional gzip/deflate support
body: I m curious about the best way to decode requests returned with gzip or deflate content encoding.  Using stream piping seems like the most elegant way when you re sure a response will be gzip encoded  see http://stackoverflow.com/a/14739453/566197 . However  that will fail if the response isn t encoded  as sometimes happens with custom 5xx error messages  etc . I m looking for the best way to support conditional decoding based on the server s Content Encoding header.   Here s an example of this behavior with Node s built in http module: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10207762/how to use request or http module to read gzip page into a string. I tried something similar but it didn t work: https://gist.github.com/nickfishman/5499713. My guess is stream piping doesn t work if you use the  request options  function err  res  body    ...     constructor.  Here s the solution I ended up with: https://gist.github.com/nickfishman/5499763. Is there a better way to do to this? Additionally  would it be possible to add gzip/deflate support directly into your library?

title: Update http signature version.
body: Going from the 0.9 to 0.10 series includes a protocol incompatible change. The change was made by me in the spec and node code due to a security issue: https://github.com/joyent/node http signature/issues/10. Considering how new HTTP Signature support is and the limited use of this spec I think it s safe to potentially cause breakage for any limited users of this feature.

title: oAuth querystring params with square bracket characters
body: Background:   Magento REST APIs use querystring parameters that have square brackets.    Problem:   Unfortunately  Request throws  [TypeError: Cannot convert object to primitive value]  when using params with square bracket characters.    Example:    var queryString =   ; queryString[ filter[1][attribute] ] =  entity_id ; queryString[ filter[1][neq] ] =  2 ;  request.get           url: configHelper.magento.urlRootApi    products           qs: queryString          oauth: oauth          json: true        function e  r  body       Notes:   1. These Magento APIs themselves have been tested and work on the same request using the Chrome Advanced REST client. 2. I ve tried using encodeURIComponent on the queryString params before they go to Request  but I believe Request ends up double encoding them.

title: Set  total time  for request  like cURL s CURLINFO_TOTAL_TIME

However  this time value is not super accurate  especially if I perform many asynchronous requests.

title: Fix redirections
body: The problem  Request  module was ignoring the new location   Why:  when there are a new redirection  self.uri is set  to the new location      javascript self.uri = url.parse redirectTo       after that again   call  the init function with this      javascript if  self.url         // People use this property instead all the time so why not just support it.     self.uri = self.url     delete self.url          so the location is ignored  have not effect  and the second request is done to the original url   solution      javascript if  self.url     self.uri        // People use this property instead all the time so why not just support it.     self.uri = self.url     delete self.url          Regards

Using vanilla node:  var agent = new  require  https  .Agent ; agent.options.secureProtocol =  SSLv3_method ;  then set  options.agent = agent;  when doing request.  I realize it s probably kind of corner casey  but it might look good in the docs if you have a technique already in place.

title: agentOptions not applied in all cases
body: Hi   I m having the same HTTPS certificate encryption trouble experienced by @umutm in https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/530 and @cybo42 ni https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/5360. To solve my troubles  I need to specify certain encryption related agentOptions fields when using the request lib. However  I believe that the request lib does not always apply agentOptions.  Here is the repro case:      javascript var agentOptions =           secureOptions: require  constants  .SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1_2          ciphers:  ECDHE RSA AES256 SHA:AES256 SHA:RC4 SHA:RC4:HIGH: MD5: aNULL: EDH: AESGCM           honorCipherOrder: true  ; require  request    https://admin.pearsonopenclass.com/service/status     agentOptions: agentOptions    function      console.log  this is the callback. response:    this.response    this.response.body ;         I can get the request to go through by manually creating an agent using the same agentOptions:      javascript var agentOptions =           secureOptions: require  constants  .SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1_2          ciphers:  ECDHE RSA AES256 SHA:AES256 SHA:RC4 SHA:RC4:HIGH: MD5: aNULL: EDH: AESGCM           honorCipherOrder: true  ; var https = require  https  ; agent = new https.Agent agentOptions ; require  request    https://admin.pearsonopenclass.com/service/status     agent: agent    function      console.log  this is the callback. response:    this.response    this.response.body ;   ;      The actual response is not important  only that a response is received in the second case and not in the first case.  I narrowed down the problem in the source code to this line: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/index.js L556  I inserted a logging statement at that line and verified that the agentOptions are being ignored in my repro case. I m not terribly familiar with the inner workings of the requestLib  but I think if the poolKey generation was modified to include details of the agentOptions that would fix my particular problem. Would that be an issue for other users?  Thanks Sam

title: Issue  556: apply agentOptions in all cases
body: Hi Mikeal   I made a change to the agentOptions handling as we discussed in https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/566. AgentOptions are now applied regardless of the value of poolKey. In addition  I added some commonly used HTTPS agent options to the poolKey.  Thanks Sam

title: use agentOptions to create agent when specified in request
body: Hi   This changeset includes the changes we discussed in https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/566 regarding agentOptions  now with some basic tests.  Thanks Sam

title: Please remove the default  global cookie jar  feature
body: I love the Request package for Node.js  but it s default  global cookie jar  feature almost drove me insane. When using the Request package inside my node.js webserver  for making authenticated webservice calls   globally storing cookies turned out to be a very bad idea because every internal request was sharing the same authentication cookies.  Please turn off the  global cookie jar  feature by default  so developers are aware of the implications when they enable this feature. The jar option in Request already works perfectly for conscious cookie sharing between multiple requests.

title: Caching with pluggable cache
body: I have been working on adding cache support to request. It currently lives in https://github.com/aslakhellesoy/request caching which is a fork of @kevinswiber  s repo with some additions.  I recently discovered the now obsolete  20 PR by @mwhooke which essentially does the same thing.   Some stuff  20 does that my code doesn t do:   Delete old stuff from the cache   Caches more properties from the response  I only do headers and body .   More through  Cache Control  handling  Some stuff my code does that  20 doesn t do:   Supports caching of private responses   Default cache implementations for Redis and in memory LRU  without declaring runtime dependencies in package.json   My first plan is to incorporate the work by @mwhooker in my request caching repo  aslakhellesoy/request caching 1  to add the stuff I m missing.  If there is interest I might work on a PR to incorporate all of this into request itself  aslakhellesoy/request caching 2 .  Comments and suggestions welcome.

title: duplicate escaped characters

title: Complete  event only triggered when there is a callback
body: Is there any reason for emitting  complete  event only for the requests with callback function passed? It s quite contrary to how the events oriented lib/code should work I believe.  complete  event should be always triggered when the requests is successfully ended and the callback argument should be just a shorthand  registered on initialization to listen  complete  event  which is how you do it at the moment .

title: request module provokes  Maximum call stack size exceeded  error if events are emitted inside event handler
body: The code below triggers a  Maximum call stack size exceeded  error whereas node s generic http module does not  can be simulated by setting  useRequest  to false . This has something to do with the error emitted inside the response callback. If the  req.abort    statement is removed the error is still triggered after  10s. Note that the error is not emitted on the request itself but on the encapsulating  Loader  object.  Environment: node.js v0.10.12 request v2.21.0      var request = require  request  ; var events = require  events  ; var util = require  util  ; var stream = require  stream  ; var domain = require  domain  ; var url = require  url  ; var http = require  http  ;   var useRequest = true;   process.on  uncaughtException   function err      if  err.stack        console.log  Unaught error:     err.stack ;     else       console.log  Unaught error:     err ;       ;   function Loader      util.inherits Loader  events.EventEmitter ;   Loader.prototype.loadRessource = function resourceUrl      var self = this;   var targetStream = new stream.PassThrough  ;    var req;    if  useRequest        req = request.get         url : resourceUrl       ;     else       var resourceUrlParts = url.parse resourceUrl ;     req = http.get         hostname : resourceUrlParts.hostname        port : resourceUrlParts.port        path : resourceUrlParts.path       ;        req.on  response   function response        if  response.statusCode  = 200          req.abort  ;        self.emit  error   new Error  Got response with HTTP code     response.statusCode  ;       else         response.pipe targetStream ;           ;  ;    var loader = new Loader  ;  function doLoad url      var d = domain.create  ;   d.on  error   function err        console.error  Loading failed:     err ;     d.dispose  ;     ;    d.run function         loader.loadRessource url ;     ;     doLoad  http://localhost/foo  ; // some URL that triggers HTTP 404      Output:      Loading failed: Error: Got response with HTTP code 404 Unaught error: RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded

title: Emit complete event when there is no callback
body: Following issue  575  a simple fix so that request emit a  complete  event even if there is no callback. However it has come to my attention that the number of parameters has to be different when doing so  since we are streaming  we do not pass a body to the event receiver.

title: support HTTP S _PROXY env vars by default
body: Other popular request libraries such as python s  requests  support automatically configuring proxies based on the standard HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY env vars: http://docs.python requests.org/en/latest/user/advanced.html proxies  It makes sense to me to deal with these variables in the library rather than making _all_ clients that want to operate seamlessly with globally configured proxies pass in the proxy values.  Is there any reason request doesn t do this already? I d be happy to hash this out and send a pull request.

title: Global agent is being used when pool is specified
body: When making a request of the form      request     uri:  http://localhost:4000     pool:       maxSockets: 1        function error  response  body      ;      this.agent is still being set to this.httpModule.globalAgent  and then the global maxSockets is being overwritten with whatever is specified for the pool  which  in this case  is 1.  I m not sure if this is the best way to check for this  but this change does fix the issue while still leaving an undefined pool as using the global agent and a false agent as not using a pool.

Convenience option to return error on 4xx/5xx status codes?
body: I often want to treat a 4xx or 5xx response code from an API as an error case  so I often end up having to check that manually.  Would you be open to adding a boolean option to automatically treat 4xx/5xx responses as errors? E.g. Kenneth Reitz s requests library  for Python  has a convenience  raise_for_status  API like this  though it s a method there :  http://docs.python requests.org/en/latest/user/quickstart/ response status codes  The default would/should be to maintain the current behavior of _not_ erroring on 4xx/5xx status.  If you re open to it  the implementation is simple; the only question is what name it should have. =   Some ideas are  errorByStatus    expectSuccess    inspectStatus   but I m sure others can come up with better ideas   Thanks again for the great library. Cheers.  P.S. Usage example:      js request.get     url: url    expectSuccess: true    callback ;      And implementation snippet:      js if  opts.expectSuccess    resp.statusCode >= 400      return self.emit  error  ;
