title: Fixes around Content Type header
closed
Support for  Expect: 100 continue
body: You probably already know what this is  but if not  a client can send an  Expect: 100 continue  request header  giving the server a chance to respond either with  100 Continue  or a different  final status code  before the client sends along the request body.  http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616 sec8.html  E.g. Amazon S3 recommends using this:  http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/RESTRedirect.html  Node supports this perfectly in core    if it sees an  Expect: 100 continue  client request header  it ll send the headers right away  and emit a  continue  event if/when the server responds with  100 Continue .  http://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_event_continue  If the server responds with something else  e.g. a redirect or an error  that s a regular  response  event. And for robustness  the caller should also set a timeout to go ahead send the request body if the server doesn t respond.  > Usually  when sending  Expect: 100 continue   you should both set a timeout and listen for the  continue  event.  Conceptually  supporting this is straightforward: if the request headers include  Expect: 100 continue   don t write the request body right away  and instead set this listener and timeout.      js var written = false;  function writeBody       if  written    return;     written = true;   // write body here    req.on  continue   writeBody ; setTimeout writeBody  500 ;      But I know it might be trickier in practice with the details. =   Hope this helps either way  and thanks for the consideration

title: Wrong oauth signature when multiple same param keys exist
body: According to http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5849 section 3.4.1.3.2  when normalizing parameters to calculate base string for oauth signature  oauth client should handle multiple pareters with same key name.  For example:  quotes from RFC5849  when build base string for following request        POST /request?b5= 3D 253D a3=a c 40= a2=r 20b HTTP/1.1        Host: example.com        Content Type: application/x www form urlencoded        Authorization: OAuth realm= Example                         oauth_consumer_key= 9djdj82h48djs9d2                         oauth_token= kkk9d7dh3k39sjv7                         oauth_signature_method= HMAC SHA1                         oauth_timestamp= 137131201                         oauth_nonce= 7d8f3e4a                         oauth_signature= djosJKDKJSD8743243 2Fjdk33klY 3D          c2 a3=2 q      client should include two  a3  param keys in query string and in body  and its values.  Currently request can t do this because it builds a parameter map as object and pass it to oauth sign.  For your information  http://oauth.googlecode.com/svn/code/javascript/oauth.js builds a parameter map as array of [key  value].

title: Fixes  583  moved initialization of self.uri.pathname

title: Use www authenticate to parse www authenticate headers and generate auth...
body: I am offering a more complete implementation of RFC 2617 digest authentication  through inclusion of the www authenticate module I recently posted.  This proposed patch delegates parsing of the www authenticate header   interpretation of its challenge and generation of the authorization header to the www authenticate module.  Please note that I had to change the expected response in one of the tests in order to pass the basic and digest authentication tests.  The principal reason is that the nonce count is that  consistent with the rfc  nonce count represented as a 8  digit  hex number  00000001  rather than simply 1.  Since nc is included in the request digest calculation  its representation is significant and results in a different digest.  The order of the attributes is also slightly different and the algorithm is included.  Next step  assuming you accept this request  and essential to applying request to my application  is to generate authorization headers for any number of additional requests  much as cookies are retained and applied to a series of requests.  A single 401 can then provide the challenge for authenticating multiple successive requests.  Thanks for you work on request. Hopefully this addition will enhance its value.

Here s a test:      function send i  pool      console.time i    require  request           url:  http://localhost:3000/?delay=1000        pool: pool      function  err  res  body        console.timeEnd i          for  var pool  i = 0; i < 10; i        //pool =  maxSockets: 5    send i  pool         Due to the global pool  the requests will be chunked into two groups  of 5  the default pool size  1000ms each; as expected.      0: 1098ms 1: 1018ms 2: 1019ms 3: 1020ms 4: 1019ms 5: 2019ms 6: 2021ms 7: 2022ms 8: 2022ms 9: 2023ms      If you uncomment the line with the  maxSockets   I expect to the exactly the same behavior  but instead get:      0: 1096ms 1: 1019ms 2: 1020ms 3: 1020ms 4: 1021ms 5: 1021ms 6: 1022ms 7: 1021ms 8: 1022ms 9: 1022ms      I d submit this as a PR  undoing de8508e  but I don t understand the motivation behind that commit enough to recommend that as a solution.

title: decouple things a bit
body: I was trying to make request  [browserifyable] https://github.com/substack/node browserify   again  and I thought to myself it would be easier if I just used what I needed and took out everything else  which also probably causes problems in the  browserification . So I m going to try to make a request fork that is more minimal and extendable  just like the ecosystem of leveldb modules that go on extending levelup.  I m not going to make a pull request of this fork I m making because it breaks  request   but this is a checkpoint along that way  which I thought would be cool for request as well. It just decouples things a tiny bit  by putting components found in  index.js  in other files. It does not change the API and the tests are passing.

title: Need proxy_exclude option
body: Hello  our company network has a proxy server. We host some resources internally  which should not be accessed via the proxy server. And we need to access some resources externally via a proxy server.  In a normal UNIX like environment there is an environment variable called no_proxy that contains a comma separated list of hosts that should not need to use the proxy variables.  It seems that request does not have a no_proxy configuration option to match it s proxy configuration.  I don t know if I can provide a patch for this feature but I can write a test for it  and I can help test code if someone would help me implement this feature.

title: fix error listener leak on connection object
body: This should fix  622  When  onRequest  was called multiply times this line would be executed:      javascript if  response.connection.listeners  error  .indexOf self._parserErrorHandler  ===  1      response.connection.once  error   self._parserErrorHandler         however because the  EventEmitter.once fn   method don t add  fn  directly to the internal  ._events  object but rather a function there executes  fn  and calls  EventEmitter.removeListener   see: [node/events.js] https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/events.js L185 191   the  this._parserErrorHandler  method would never be in the  listeners  error    array.  This changes  indexOf self._parserErrorHandler  ===  1  to just  .length === 0 . Alternativ fixes are to use the  .on  method  or check the internal  .listener  property on each item in the  listeners  error    array.    I m not intiment with  request  so I couldn t figure out why  onRequest  was called multiply times  I guess it s caused by redirects  and therefore there are no added test

title: Send random cnonce for HTTP Digest requests
body: My real problem is that passport http interprets cnonce=   as an undefined cnonce.  From my understanding of cnonce  it is best to send a random cnonce with every request to make it harder to use a rainbow table based attack against the hash.  So  I offer this patch in the hopes of solving my original problem  while also making request s digest implementation more complete.  Cheers  William

title: Added license type and reference to LICENSE file to the package.json
Add ability to receive a 401 challenge once and then authorize any number of requests based upon that challenge
body: As currently implemented  every request sent by request for a resource protected by digest protected by HTTP digest authentication would require a new 401 response.  This pull request adds a digestAuth option  which works much the same way as the jar option allows maintaining cookies between requests  except that the object provided to the digestAuth option would maintain a 401 challenge from one request to the next.  The digestAuth option should reference an object that implements an interface consisting of the following two functions: 1. get_challenge response   which will be invoked whenever a 401 response is received.  It should parse the challenge posed by the WWW Authenticate header and save that challenge for later authorization requests. 2. authentication_string method path   which returns either a false value or a string to be placed in an Authorization header.  If no challenge has been received  it will return a false value.  This function may be called multiple times in order to authorize multiple requests.  A suitable digestAuth object is produced by the [www authenticate module] https://github.com/randymized/www authenticate   such as in the the following usage example:      javascript var request = require  request  ; var www_authenticate = require  www authenticate  ; var digestAuth= www_authenticate.authenticator username password ; request  method: GET  uri: /something  digestAuth:digestAuth  ; request  method: GET  uri: /something/else  digestAuth:digestAuth  ;

title: Request destroys existing socket timeout
body: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L594 L605  Request uses  req.setTimeout   which calls  socket.setTimeout   as a fail safe to abort requests. Unfortunately  this conflicts with our calling socket.setTimeout in our agentClass  ForeverAgent fork  in multiple ways. 1. New socket        When a new socket is created  req.setTimeout is called  but since it doesn t have a socket  it calls the following [code] https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/_http_outgoing.js L99 L101 :       javascript     this.once  socket   function socket          socket.setTimeout msecs ;       ;          Subsequently  timeouts set in the agentClass are overwritten:          ForeverAgent.prototype.createConnection = function       var self = this   var socket = net.createConnection.apply this  arguments     socket.on  connect   function foo        var name = socket.remoteAddress    :    socket.remotePort      socket.setTimeout self.timeouts[name]    self.timeout  function           console.log  Never called.         socket.end                 return socket;       1. Keep alive socket  reuse         Even if the new socket case were overcome  the very next request via the same logic would again call request.setTimeout  this time immediately calling socket.setTimeout and overwriting the existing socket s setTimeout.   Is the req.setTimeout necessary?   Can we avoid it when keep alives are used?   Can we check for socket._idleNext or something else to ensure the same functionality without blowing away the existing socket timeout?

title: A list in the pair value of a form should submit multiple keys with the same name
body: If I make a request like this:      javascript var r = request       url:  http://localhost:5000        form:            foo : [ bar    baz ]         ;      This gets translated on the wire into:      foo[0]=bar foo[1]=baz      This is a nonstandard way to send this data and most servers are unprepared to unpack this back into        foo : [ bar    baz ]      The usual way to do this is to send multiple keys with the same name  for example:      foo=bar foo=baz      See for example http://play.golang.org/p/8wKzOFGjMA  http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/servlet/ServletRequest.html getParameterMap    http://werkzeug.pocoo.org/docs/datastructures/ werkzeug.datastructures.MultiDict

title: Simplified Stream/Pipe Error Handling
body: Request is super simple to use  but it s not so simple to handle errors  especially when piping.  Normally error handling with pipes is very straightforward:      javascript fs.createReadStream   file1.txt    .pipe  fs.createWriteStream   file2.txt     .on   error   handleErr   // <  all read/write/stream errors can be caught here .on   close   proceed  ;      With request  that doesn t seem to be the case:      javascript request   http://google.com/doodle.png    .pipe  fs.createWriteStream  doodle.png    .on   error   handleErr   // <  many errors don t make it here .on   close   proceed  ;      Callbacks are not necessary when producing streams as it s mixing two different asynchronous conventions  though the presence of a callback could indicate which one you intend to use.  Could stream events be used when a callback is not provided  or am I crazy?

title: Work in Progress: Request re write for new streams.
body: This is nowhere near finished and most of the tests still don t pass.  This is full re write of request from the ground up. It is built on top of new style streams  streams2  and there is a concerted effort to do more of the work in dependencies.     Deprecations   piping to a destination w/ a callback parameter forces buffering.    request url  function  e  resp      .pipe fs.createWriteStream file   will now have the side effect of also buffering the entire response in to memory. Because new style streams can be piped well after nextTick   we don t have a good way to know if we should or should not buffer the response other than the callback parameter. we still will not ever buffer the response when a callback is not given.   JSON.stringify request url   probably breaks.   Deprecating the old hacky getSafe   function will dramatically improve performance and  for the most part  stringifying options with sockets attached is a bad idea.   all signing  cookies  and other non default options will require the user explicitly install their dependency.  The dep list is growing exponentially and because of the way cookies and signing work in particular it isn t possible for request to support these features without adding code to request itself. Rather than continue to let the dep list grow forever in to the future  and with the understanding that one day we may even want a feature that requires a compiled dependency  I m going to move to a model where we check for the dep when you use the feature and throw if you didn t install it.  This will not be the case for default options which will still have their deps included.     Features   NEW STYLE STREAMS    gzip support  enabled by default.  We now default to including the Accept Encoding header for gzip and transparently decompressing the stream in the underlying HTTP Duplex stream.   less memory copies when using binary response buffering.  Basically we just moved to @rvagg s  bl  module which we pipe ourself to in order to buffer the response.  bl  gives us a compatible buffer API but actually stores all the chunks in an array so we save on the big memcopy we used to do.  The code is also much cleaner  which is always the case when you re write a module that hasn t had a full re write since node.js had promises built in :

title: Unable to send binary data in forms
body: Consider this example:      js request.post       uri:  http://foo.bar       form:           sessionkey: new Buffer [0x01  0x02  0x03]           blah: 5         ;      Instead of serializing the form into  sessionkey= 01 02 03 blah=5   it sends garbage. There is no easy workaround either  since percent encoding the buffer myself causes request to further percent encode the percentage signs.

title: Request.JS not returning the same HTML as my browser
body: I am trying to scrape Vimeo and I am not getting returned any of the content related to the URL with query string. All I get is the static Vimeo HTML elements located in the page header and footer. I do not get the thumbnail video gallery grid. Here is my code:      var request = require  request      cheerio = require  cheerio      searchURL =  http://vimeo.com/search?q=angularjs ;  request searchURL  function err  resp  body     if err      throw err;     = cheerio.load body ;    // the following will properly log the element s text to console    // since it is part of the static Vimeo header nav bar   console.log     site_header .join a  .text   ;    // the following will log  Please try again  since it s dynamic content   // which is related to the search query   console.log     page_header h1  .text   ;    // the following code targets the dynamically generated gallery grid   // but it does not log anything since Vimeo won t return it       browse_content .browse_videos li a  .each function        console.log this.attr  href   ;     ;   ;        If you run that and then compare the HTML returned by Vimeo you can see it does not match what you would see if you went to  http://vimeo.com/search?q=angularjs  in your browser.   I am thinking I might have to add a user agent string to the request to let Vimeo know my scraper is a browser. If I am right about that then how do I do that? I don t see any Request.JS documentation on adding user agent strings to a request. And if I am wrong  then what is going on here and how would I fix it?

title: Socks5 support
body: This is a replacement for  648 and fixes  141.  The patch adds [mattcg/socks5 http client] https://github.com/mattcg/socks5 http client  and [mattcg/socks5 https client] https://github.com/mattcg/socks5 https client  as dependencies so that request can use the agent objects from both to support SOCKS proxying.  A test is included. To run it you should have a SOCKS5 server running on localhost:1080. Use the following command to start one if you have sshd running locally:   ssh  N  D 0.0.0.0:1080 localhost

title: Blank passwords result in different Auth headers
body: Some web services have RESTful APIs where you authenticate using your API key as your username and a blank password. I was using such a service  when I was stopped by this bug which only happens with blank passwords:      request.get url .auth  username     true ;      will send a different Authentication header than      request.get url        auth:           user:  username           pass:             sendImmediately: true         ;          Even though these two should be functionally identical.  To demonstrate this bug  I used RequestBin to log my HTTP requests  and indeed  these two different methods result in different Authentication headers being sent. Please run the following code for yourself and [see the results here] http://requestb.in/14iakdo1?inspect .      var request = require  request  ;  var requestBin =  http://requestb.in/14iakdo1 ; // Go to http://requestb.in to create a new bin var username =  username ; var password =   ;  // Authorization: Basic dXNlcm5hbWU6 request.get requestBin .auth username password true ;  // Authorization: Basic dXNlcm5hbWU6dW5kZWZpbmVk // This Auth header is WRONG. request.get requestBin        auth:           user: username          pass: password          sendImmediately: true         ;      I d just use the first method  but it means I can t have my extra options or callback.  Which is a bummer.         UPDATE:   Changing  auth.pass  to  auth.password  sends the _correct_ Auth header  somehow.      // Authorization: Basic dXNlcm5hbWU6 request.get requestBin        auth:           user: username          password: password          sendImmediately: true         ;             UPDATE 2:   This might explain why there s an extra  dW5kZWZpbmVk  in the wrong Auth header: http://www.base64decode.org/dec/dW5kZWZpbmVk/

title: Optional dependencies
body: The  request  library has a rather large dependency chain that not everybody needs. In cases with very little disk space  e.g. embedded platforms  this can be a problem. This pull request changes some of these dependencies into optional dependencies  which are still installed by default  but are skipped when installed via  npm install   no optional . The relevant unit tests are skipped in case the modules are not found on the system.

title: Sending Multi Part Request To Second Server

I have the files exposed to Node and visible using the req.files bodyParser. I am a little confused on how I would go about piping this form data to a secondary server where the file will be saved permanently  I don t need the files to persist on the Node server .  Would I need to do a fileStream or formData stream somewhere in the Node layer or truly just pipe the entire request to the second API and have the secondary server handle writing the stream to a file there?  Awesome library by the way.

title: Feature request: an extra parameter to the request callback
body: Consider a typical Express/node.js app  such as a web scraper  one that takes a user request  parses that url to make a request to the  real  website   scrapes or otherwise modifies the data  or headers  and returns it.  The handler for the user request  the express route  looks like      exports.foo = function originalRequest  originalResponse        // parse originalRequest to get a url  maybe some other options     Request.get theURL  theCallbackFunction ;        and theCallbackFunction would look something like      function theCallbackFunction error  response  body        // check for errors     var dataToReturn =   ;     // do stuff with a parser like Cheerio to collect dataToReturn     // more options   see comments below     originalResponse.send dataToReturn ;        My issue is that originalResponse is _not in scope in the callback._  Also  the callback may have additional options that should be passed down from the Express route.  For example  it might want to parse originalRequest and have an  xml  or a  json  or a  deep  or  shallow  option  etc.  There is no easy way to pas these to the callback.  One option is to next these two functions inside each other  but that forces a certain style   which I hate   plus  if theCallbackFunction makes another async call to yetAnotherCallback...  this gets really messy.  What I have been doing is declaring another variable outside the functions and putting originalResponse there  which seems to work but is also a bit clunky.  And I m not sure if that s really safe if multiple requests come in at the same time.  I m brand new to node.js  but in a  traditional  Java / threaded world that wouldn t be safe.   My  ideal  fix would be for there to be an additional parameter to the request callback  so that the express route might look something like      exports.foo = function originalRequest  originalResponse        // parse originalRequest to get a url  maybe some other options     var passMeOnDown =           originalResponse : originalResponse          specialOptionA :  xml       ;     Request.get theURL  passMeOnDown   theCallbackFunction ;        and then the signature for theCallbackFunction becomes      function error  response  body  passMeOnDown       NOTE: I m coming from Java and brand new to Javascript so maybe  with the wonders of Javascript s loosely defined parameters and variable length arg lists  this can already be done very simply.  If so a brief example code would be nice   Plus  I m sure I m not the first person to ask about this

title: Feature Request: Make req.param   a varargs function
body: Oops   never mind  I think this is an Express issue.   too many files named request.js   Sorry...  But  just in case it isn t  below is original request:  Unfortunately  you d also have to swap the order of arguments.  e.g.      req.param = function defaultValue  name1  ...       and user could call      var color = req.param  none    Color    Colour    Model.color  ;      Loop through arguments 1..N and check if present.  Alternative: keep the existing argument order  but check if name is  arrayish .  So user could call       var color = req.param [ Color    Colour    Model.color ]   none  ;      Not high priority but would be a  nice to have .  There may be other functions/methods where this makes sense...

title: Don t use charset in Content Type header with application/x www form urlencoded
body: When using request to post a form to a server that uses ISO 8859 1 I get the following response:  Unknown Content type: application/x www form urlencoded; charset=utf 8   Turns out that request sets the content type with charset header even if I explicitly set it without a charset definition.  I think this was already mentioned in pull request  609 and would be fixed via eb74903e8dc55fea96b9f908de4ec3e82de066b6 but is not included in 08793ec2f266ef88fbe6c947e6b334e04d4b9dc9  [see here] https://github.com/mikeal/request/commit/08793ec2f266ef88fbe6c947e6b334e04d4b9dc9 diff 168726dbe96b3ce427e7fedce31bb0bcL971  .  So would it be possible to get this fixed  if correct   or at least give an option to not overwrite the content type header for posts?

title: Fixing listing in callback part of docs.
getSafe   is unsafe
body: Mutating objects for cycle detection fails if for whatever reason the object being checked is immutable.  Object.defineProperty  will fail with a message along the lines of      TypeError: Cannot define property:__1b123  object is not extensible.      The safe way to do is is to do the serialization iteratively and visti recursively  and [use a stack] https://github.com/othiym23/node deeper/blob/master/deeper.js L61 L122   that example is for equality detection  but the stack based visitor pattern will work just as well for serialization .  Is there a good reason to not use  util.inspect    instead of  getSafe   ?

title: store initial request uri in request object
body: if you are doing simultaneous http requests and redirects are involved  there is no hint to the initial request uri inside the response callback function.  this commit adds the attribute initialUri to the request object. it will be set on the first call of the init   function. unlike the attribute uri  it will not be overwritten later.

title: Request.multipart no longer crashes when header  Content type  present
body: Request.multipart used to crash when options contained a header  Content type  which is not purely lowercase. That is because hasHeader is case insensitive and returns true  then the split method gets applied to undefined and crashes the application.  One could argue that headers should be spelled using only lowercase. However  mixed case headers used to work with a previous version of request  thus I suggest to incorporate this patch to ensure that legacy code does not suddenly crash after updating request.

title: Throttling Requests
body: One of the API s I use most frequently  the Shopify API . Recently put out a new [call limit] http://docs.shopify.com/api/tutorials/learning to respect the api call limit   I m seeing errors like:       Exceeded 6.0 calls per second for api client. Slow your requests or contact support for higher limits.      I ve already gotten an upgrade  but regardless of how much bandwidth I get I have to account for this. A large majority of the requests to the Shopify API are within [async.map  ] https://github.com/caolan/async  functions  which loop asynchronous requests  and gather the bodies.  I m looking for any help  perhaps a library that already exists  that would wrap around the request module and actually block  sleep  throttle  allocate  manage  the many simultaneous requests that are firing off asynchronously and limit them to say  6  requests at a time. I have no problem with working on such a project if it doesn t exist. I just don t know how to handle this kind of situation  and I m hoping for some kind of standard.

title: Parse a json response always or never

I keep forgetting this and I ve to guess  or debug  when request is going to parse my response or not. It violates the principle of least astonishment.  PLEASE  consider parsing always that the response Content Type is an  application/json  or never parse. I know is a breaking change but it will help a lot.  My vote is to parse always.

title: Add test to ensure we don t modify query string in url when no qs option is defined
body: _qs_ option is serialized using node querystring which imposes one special format to serialize arrays:     a: [1  2]    > a[0]=1 a[1]=2 .  If we don t want this format  for example if we want  a=1 a=2   the only way is to manually set the query string in the url.  We need to be sure the query string in url won t be modified.  Currently it happens if and only if _qs_ option is also defined  in which case both values are merged  with a priority on qs  which is reasonable . This behavior is useful and current not tested.  Here is a test to guarantee that:      javascript var assert = require  assert  ; var request = require  request  ; var http = require  http  ;  var s = http.createServer function req  res      res.statusCode = 200;   res.end    ;   .listen 6767  function         var requestCount = 3;   function close         requestCount  ;     if  requestCount === 0          s.close  ;              request.get  http://localhost:6767/     qs:   a: [1  2]      function  err  res        assert res.req.path ===  /?a[0]=1 a[1]=2  ;     close  ;     ;    request  http://localhost:6767/?a=1 a=2   function  err  res        assert res.req.path ===  /?a=1 a=2  ;     close  ;     ;    request.get  http://localhost:6767/?a=1 a=2     qs:   a: [1  2]      function  err  res        assert res.req.path ===  /?a[0]=1 a[1]=2  ;     close  ;     ;   ;

title: Use Cookie.parse
body: Using  new Cookie str   doesn t actually set the attributes in the cookie. This is because Cookie takes in an object and in our case we only accept a string. Using  Cookie.parse  will set the appropriate properties on the cookie.  discussed in  743

title: Redirect and pre resolution bug
body: To improve our performance  we decided not to use the dns.lookup method used by default in node.js  http library. We perform resolution with dns.resolve and then supply the result to request using the hostname option.  This works great most of the time... However  sometimes  there is a redirect to another host and in that case  the hostname may not be right anymore  yet  it looks like request keeps that :/  Is that a known bug  or am I missing something obvious?      var dns = require  dns  ; var request = require  request  ;  dns.lookup  www.clubic.com   function e  hostname       var opts =       url:  http://com.clubic.feedsportal.com/c/33464/f/581988/index.rss       hostname: hostname        // delete opts.hostname; // if commented  works as expected  if uncommented  yields 403 because we re not talking to the right server.    request.get opts  function error  response  body        console.log response ;     ;   ;

title: require aws sign2

title: multipart/related stream body upload
body: Current  multipart  option for multipart/related requests only works with buffers or string  body . When setting  body  to a stream  like a  fs.createReadStream     it silently fails and sends an empty part.  This would be a great addition to  request  to handle this.  As we don t know the stream final size this forces the use of chunk encoding  but it s not an issue for me.  In the meantime we could have a real error when the  body  type is not supported.

title: request.cookie   expects a string while tough cookie.Cookie   expects an object.
body: request.cookie    which constructs a new instance of a tough cookie  Cookie    expects a string as a parameter and throws an error if something else is passed.  However the constructor of  Cookie    expects  if anything at all  an object for configuration  see: https://github.com/goinstant/node cookie/blob/v0.9.15/lib/cookie.js L530 L537  This patch removes the parameter check inside  request.cookie    and just passes on the optional options object to the  Cookie    constructor.

title: Pass error body when json requests fail parsing

This passes back the JSON.parse error as a request failure  attatching the non json to a data attribute of the error object.  Points to consider: should it substitute its own error message with a human readable one mentioning the url  like a few of the others? Attach the url just as it now does the body? Fine as suggested?

title: Documentation adition

title: a friendly api for working with cookies
body: Please checkout https://github.com/lalitkapoor/request cookies to see the api. The code is well documented too. It builds upon the really awesome work by @stash on https://github.com/goinstant/tough cookie  The goal is to make working with cookies as easy as possible. There s been a bunch of discussion about this in  729 and briefly in some other issues as well like  743 and  767.  Basically I ve limited the API to what is necessary for this library and made some things more flexible. E.g. adding a cookie to the jar   you can now do this by passing in a cookie string  a json object or an instance of a  Cookie  object. Removing a cookie from the jar is also easy. Also added the ability to export the jar or cookie via the  toJSON  method.  /cc @stash @mikeal

title: Cookie has domain set to a public suffix  as error
body: Some websites cause a  Cookie has domain set to a public suffix  as error for me. I am not sure why this is handled as error. Should it really be handled that way?

title: Adds content length calculation when submitting forms using form data li...
body: ...brary. This is related to issue 345.  The try/catch is needed because the sync content length calculation cannot work for for streams. If used with streams  behavior is unchanged by this pull request.

title: Error: Cookie not in this host s domain.
body: Such kind of tough cookie errors should be ignored  however currently they cause errors and break normal requesting.  For example  assume  http://foo.bar.com  returns headers like  Set Cookie: NAME=value; path=/; domain=hello.bar.com . It is an invalid cookie. With the newest  request  module  this request will fail. I do not think this is a correct behaviour. These errors should be ignored.

title: Issue submitting multiple form values
body: Maybe there s a workaround  but I have an issue submitting multiple values for the same key in a form for a POST.  Say  in an HTML form  the user can select multiple states or provinces via checkboxes.  The website expect to receive something like    state=CA state=WI .  If  using Request  I go    form[ state ] = [ CA   WI ]   it will eventually get to qs   index.js   where  stringifyArray     line 297 in my version  adds an extraneous  for me  [n]  e.g.  it generates output     state[0]=CA state[1]=WI   My temp fix was to edit line 297 of index.js to be  ret.push stringify arr[i]  prefix  ;   and everything is happy  but seems like this should have come up before and there is a better way???

title: Add support for promises over callbacks
body: Now that [ES6 Promises] http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/es6/promises/ toc api  are getting more stable  I would expect a lovely library like this eventually would support promises over callbacks.  I don t know how the roadmap is looking  but I d love promises to my requests :

title: request.get does not explicitly set method to GET
body: If I were to do something like this:      var options =   url:  http://test.com/foo   ; request.put options  function error  response  body        request.get options  function error  response  body            // handle error or success...       ;   ;      The second will be a PUT as well  not a GET  because  options.method  is set to   put   by  request.put  but is not set by  request.get .  I don t know if reusing options objects like this is not intended behavior  but it still seems like a bug to me.

title: Unhandled stream error in pipe.  Error: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND
body: Hi   I am using mikeal/request in order to proxy API requests. It works fine like 99  of the time  but every once in a while it throws a getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND error. Usually these errors are caught and printed to the console  but just now the error went unhandled and took down the server. The error looked like this:  stream.js:94       throw er; // Unhandled stream error in pipe.             ^ Error: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND     at errnoException  dns.js:37:11      at Object.onanswer [as oncomplete] dns.js:124:16   npm ERR  manageapp@0.3.2 start:  node server.js  npm ERR  Exit status 8 npm ERR   npm ERR  Failed at the manageapp@0.3.2 start script. npm ERR  This is most likely a problem with the manageapp package  npm ERR  not with npm itself. npm ERR  Tell the author that this fails on your system: npm ERR      node server.js  The only call to request   that I make in the entire app is below:          if  access_allowed === true           // proxy the request       var api_endpoint =  http://    API_HOSTNAME   req.url;        req.on   error   function err               console.log   Error on request object:    err  ;                            .pipe  request  api_endpoint                .on   error   function err               console.log   Error piping request object to mikeal/request  :    err  ;                            .pipe  res             .on   error   function err               console.log   Error piping response from mikeal/request   to response object :    err  ;               ;                else         res.writeHead 403   Request method     req.method     and path     req.url     not found in permissions for user role     role  ;       res.end  ;                Two points of interest: 1  The api_endpoint variable is always constant as it s taken from a static config file  so it s weird that DNS should have an error in resolving the address after many requests went through to the same exact destination just a moment before the error hit. 2  I ve watched this error get caught hundreds of times over the past couple of days  but this time it went unhandled. Did I miss a spot when I added the  error  event handlers?  Any suggestions? Also thanks for request  it s hugely helpful.

title: Upcase Authorization header to fix HTTP Basic Auth
body: Some web servers are particularly sensitive to proper casing with the HTTP Authorization header. This PR fixes that problem by changing the header from  authorization  to  Authorization . All tests were passing without modification.

title: 404 while actually being a redirect
body: If I perform a request to the following URL  for instance  I always get a 404 as the res.statusCode. I guess this is the same issue as  658   var options =     uri:  http://t.co/D4X2FbInA1      followRedirect: true    timeout: 15000    headers:        Connection :  Close       ; request options  .... ;  res.request.redirects.length returns the right thing  res.request.redirects.pop  .redirectUri returns the right thing  res.request.redirects.pop  .statusCode returns the right thing. However: res.statusCode remains 404. Any idea why?

title: Add a changelog
body: This is based on successfully merged pull requests into the master branch.  Addresses  771.

title: Hawk responses are not checked for authorization
body: Unless I missed it in the source  request s Hawk support sends a valid request header but it does not verify the incoming response. This should at least be documented since developers will be creating a security hole in their client code.  This is how responses are verified with Hawk:    https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk response payload validation    client.authenticate    from https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk usage example

title: NTLM Support
body: Is there any way to support NTLM auth with request?  I have seen this issue  https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/593  but it didn t work for me either.

title: upgrade tunnel proxy to 0.4.0
body: Please upgrade tunnel proxy to 0.4.0 so that we can avoid the issue reported by  779

title: add some exposition to mpu example in README.md

body: I thought by not providing an  encoding   value in the request options  it would be treated  like   null  and the body would be in binary  as https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/57 described. title: SSL type auto detection
body: When requesting an SSL enabled URL  if the site s SSL runs on TLS  I must disable  secureProtocol:  SSLv3_method  .  If it runs on SSLv3  I must enable  secureProtocol:  SSLv3_method   so that no errors happen.  Is there a way to force  node request  to auto detect/handle this?  Or  if I m sending requests to a bulk of HTTPs sites  how can I send the right request to the right site without knowing which SSL type they are using?  Thanks.

title: Outputs headers in Pascal Case.
body: I understand that according to the RFC headers aren t case sensitive. But I ran into a server where they were  phantomjs ghostdriver  version: 1.9.7 . And because this library is used in @webdriverjs. Well you see the problem. The issue is fixed in the phantomjs webserver  but apparently still not shipped :shipit: or it s due to me running on windows  https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/issues/11487 . Since it doesn t really matter and most clients do output the headers in Pascal Case. I thought it might be a good idea to address it here.  @camme I ran into the  cannot get a session token  issue. When connection directly to phantomjs from webdriverjs. With this  fix  it works.

title: It assume that response always in utf8
body: Even if site return data with content type: text/html; charset=windows 1251. It return string encoded in utf8.  On [L956] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L956       if  self.encoding === null                response.body = body             else               response.body = body.toString self.encoding                   self.encoding by default is undefined and it convert buffer to string  which assume undefined as utf8. But i am expecting to get buffer.

title: Proxying POST Requests
body: I m trying to setup a fairly simple proxy to proxy requests to an external website through my internal corporate proxy via my local machine.      javascript var http = require  http       request = require  request       r = request.defaults  proxy:   http://my proxy.com:8080     http.createServer function req  res        req.url =  http://www.foo.com       r req .pipe res    .listen 8888       The proxying works really well however for POST requests it appears the data isn t piped through. Is this something that would be expected to work out of the box? Or do I need to listen for the data event  capture the body and then forward the request on?  Any help appreciated...

title: GET is randomly slower/faster for the same size files
body: Not sure if this is a request module issue  or a Heroku issue  or what. Basically I have a site that streams Twitter posts and occasionally requests user avatars then uploads them to a rackspace CDN. Sometimes these requests are quick and other times they take a lot longer. I ve attached a screenshot of Nodetime where you can see one request completing at 90 milliseconds and the next request completing at 554 milliseconds  even though both requests are for a 73x73 image.  It is causing my Node app memory usage to spike unpredictably  most of the time I m running between 400 and 600 MB  but occasionally I almost reach my Heroku limit of 1GB which messes things up. Is there some setting I need to change  maybe timeout or poll/maxSockets?  I ll also supply the code block I m using.  When I comment it out  I run perfectly steady around 300 MB for days at a time  so the issue w/ my memory spikes definitely seems to be with request or maybe pkgcloud.       javascript request idocs[ikey].tweet.user.profile_image_url.replace  _normal.    _bigger.   .on  response   function response        avatars.push path.basename path.dirname response.request.path      /    path.basename response.request.path  ;     var headers =   ;     if  response.headers    response.headers[ content type ]            headers[ content type ] = response.headers[ content type ];           if  response.headers    response.headers[ content length ]            headers[ content length ] = response.headers[ content length ];           response.headers = headers;   .pipe client.upload       container: process.env.RACKSPACE_CONTAINER      remote: path.basename path.dirname idocs[ikey].tweet.user.profile_image_url      /            path.basename idocs[ikey].tweet.user.profile_image_url.replace  _normal.    _bigger.       function err  result        if  err            console.log err ;          ;       [nodetime_http] https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/46009/2338744/0334c652 a4ad 11e3 8745 b2a456ea5065.png

title: Recursive call?
body: From the examples I could not determine if there was a way to make a recursive call? The need comes out of a REST OData call where odata.nextLink property on the JSON coming back may be set indicating that there is more data available so the natural thing to do would be to change the URL in the options an reissue the request. But specifying the callback becomes problematic 1  Because I am not sure how to indicate to request that any given request is the  final  one. 2  It seems to necessitate building a global variable that would contain the accumulation of the  n  REST calls. Ideas?

title: OAuth POST using application/x www form urlencoded
body: Hey   I Use request to do API calls on the Aweber s API  https://labs.aweber.com/   but I had some problems with the base signature  when I pass the parameters using form :       javascript options :        url:  https://api.aweber.com/foo/bar       form:   name:  Alex         oauth:            consumer_key:  AzAzAz           consumer_secret:  ZaZaZa              Aweber doesn t expect these parameters to be encoded in the base signature  but Request does encoded it  I read the standard and It seems request has the correct implementation can you confirm?  Aweber s response :       javascript    message :  Invalid signature. Expected signature base string: POST https 3A 2F 2Fapi.aweber.com 2F1.0 2Faccounts 2F4691231553 2Flists 2F14323123218880 2Fsubscribers oauth_consumer_key 3DAkNJrSSzDs023zmY 26oauth_nonce 3D88d44e13204442cfa2288a80fc8 26oauth_signature_method 3DHMAC SHA1 26oauth_timestamp 3D1314231583 26oauth_token 3DAgDNvdvsfDHaRbF23s0nnlVw 26oauth_version 3D1.0 https://labs.aweber.com/docs/troubleshooting unauthorized         To make the code above work with Aweber I ve to add the form s parameters inside the url :       javascript options :        url:  https://api.aweber.com/foo/bar?name=Alex  // This will generate the signature expected by Aweber      form:   name:  Alex    // But this is still needed       oauth:            consumer_key:  AzAzAz           consumer_secret:  ZaZaZa              What s disrupting me  is when I create the requests using POSTMAN  chrome extension   I don t have this problem of incorrect signature :/ So I don t know who s doing things wrong.  Me ? Aweber? Request?   Alex

title: Add a separate connectTimeout option
body: Let clients limit the time spent waiting for a connection to be established separately from the timeout for the entire request. This is important to avoid waiting overly long when using load balancers like LVS which might in some situations send traffic to a black hole.

title: Location  header is automatically assumed to be a 302 Found
body: It seems that if the server responds with a  HTTP/1.1 202 Accepted   and probably also the  201 Created  header  in conjunction with a Location header    which points to the newly created resource    the  response.statusCode  in request somehow magically becomes a  302  no matter what.  Easy test:  Make a PHP script with something like the following:      php <?php header  HTTP/1.1 202 Accepted  ; header  Location: http://www.newlycreatedresource.com  ;      Request that script via  request  and check the  response.statusCode :      js var require  request    someFormData =   name:  name     options =   url:  http://www.thephpscript.com   form: someFormData  ;  request.post options  function error  response  body        console.log response.statusCode    ;

title: Pool  agent  maxSockets   documentation
body: There is little to none documentation on  pool    agent     maxSockets .  See  588  which points to  428  which is not great.  Indeed  the solution to set  pool.maxSockets  will bypass the use of  globalPool : https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/bfea018c3eaf83b18d49001797096f990b59b446/request.js L111      javascript if   self.pool    self.pool  == false  self.pool = globalPool      This is probably a bug: we do want to be able to use the  globalPool  _and_ still set some agent options like  maxSockets . See  617.  The code seems to read  maxSockets  in addition to  pool.maxSockets   and this would bypass the bug  but this option is not documented.  Also  if we want to pass other options to the agents  we cannot use  pool.    In fact we can pass other options to the agents with  agentOptions   which is not documented either.  Finally  there is no documentation to describe the  pool  object like expected and constructed in getAgent    see  588   and it seems it s only usable with a pool constructed by Request itself  accessible only via the response of a request : we probably can t expect users to construct the pool key used in getAgent  .  So I propose this: 1/ Deprecate the use of  pool.maxSockets  because it collides with the pool object agent caching  and breaks globalPool usage  maybe add an explicit option to tell  use the Request global pool too?  2/ Also deprecated  maxSockets   document  agentOptions  instead which seems to be well suited for this. 3/ Either deprecate  pool  altogether  or document the key format for  pool   or add a function to request to construct it  so that users don t have to know the internal format  that could change . Even better: add a function to directly construct a  pool   and  pool  would be an opaque object to forward to request    this would be similar to getAgent  just isolated .  Finally  some questsions:  1/ Why do we even have a pool of agents like that? Could we have some use case examples where it is useful?  and put them in the README.md?   See  476: they seem to try to have different  maxSockets  per domain  but it s not working since the code that adds the host   port to the key is only for node <= 0.4. I suppose it s because since node 0.6 the  http.Agent  can work with multiple domains  so that part was removed from the key  but the  http.Agent   maxSockets  is global to the agent  not per domain  so this useful feature is lost. https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/bfea018c3eaf83b18d49001797096f990b59b446/request.js L598 L604  2/ How do I force the usage of an externally built agent  like it s done with  http.Request ? See  565. I can t find a way to pass the agent via  pool  since I must know the key  and the key is not the same depending on the requests  at the very least it is  http  or  https  . Maybe add the same api as http.request: just accept an  agent  option?   And I ve only gone through the first page of issues https://github.com/mikeal/request/search?q=agent pool type=Issues

title: Feature Request: Support the  no_proxy  environment variable
body: Currently  to bypass HTTP_PROXY for local destinations  e.g. localhost  requires specific passing special options to a request made to local.  While env.HTTP_PROXY can be used set a proxy globally or per app  it seems not possible to define an exclusion list in the same way  unless I am mistaken .  This is problematic in cases like using bower programmatically with a local registry. While you could delete process.env.HTTP_PROXY to gain access to the proxy  it would would break connectivity to the outside world at the same time.   TL;DR: It d be great if exclusions to env.HTTP_PROXY could be declared via the env.no_proxy environment variable.  http://www.w3.org/Daemon/User/Proxies/ProxyClients.htm  curl   noproxu

title: Performance degrades when using request to make http calls to EC2 instance
body: I originally asked this question  nodejitsu/node http proxy 614  due to some issues I was having with [nodejitsu/node http proxy] https://github.com/nodejitsu/node http proxy   however  during my testing  I discovered that it was affecting the request module as well  so I figured it might be worth posting my findings here as well to see if anyone might have encountered anything like this before.  Basically  I was trying to create a simple http proxy for an EC2 instance; however  I realized that anything I put through http proxy was being delayed considerably. I wanted to make sure it wasn t a node thing so I tried the same requests with http.get  and everything was fine. I then wanted to isolate http proxy and to my surprise  when I made the get call with request  it also had considerably performance degradation.   So here is where I m at after messing with this over the weekend; I ve placed the following server code up onto a public EC2 instance so you can test it yourself  to rule out the possibility of my internet being the problem :      javascript var http = require  http  ;  var server = http.createServer function  req  res        res.end  Hello World  ;   .listen 3000 ;  // This was added to test what others have reported as fixing the issue server.on  connection   function  socket         use strict ;     console.log  server.on.connection   setNoDelay  ;     socket.setNoDelay true ;   ;      The public ip address of the server is 54.209.167.233  When I request http://54.209.167.233:3000/ in my browser  I m using the [Advanced REST Client] https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/advanced rest client/hgmloofddffdnphfgcellkdfbfbjeloo?hl=en US  for chrome   I consistently get a response between 60 120ms.   If I run the following code  both cases respond for me in roughly the same amount of time  about 100ms each :      javascript var http = require  http  ;  // Stream request console.time  stream  ; http.get  http://54.209.167.233:3000/   function res        var data =   ;     res.on  data   function  chunk            data  = chunk;       ;     res.on  end   function  chunk            console.log data.toString   ;         console.timeEnd  stream  ;       ;   ;  // Pipe request console.time  pipe  ; http.get  http://54.209.167.233:3000/   function  res        res.pipe process.stdout ;     res.on  end   function  chunk            console.log  ;         console.timeEnd  pipe  ;       ;   ;      However  if I run the following example  I get times in the 800 2000ms range:      javascript var request = require  request  ;  // Get using request module console.time  request  ; request.get       url:  http://54.209.167.233:3000/     function  err  res  body        console.log body ;     console.timeEnd  request  ;   ;      My original tests involved using [nodejitsu/node http proxy] https://github.com/nodejitsu/node http proxy   and if you are curious to see the same result there  you can run the following example  and then request the response from localhost  I also get times in the 800 2000ms range :      javascript var http = require  http  ; var httpProxy = require  http proxy  ;  var proxy = httpProxy.createProxyServer  ; proxy.on  proxyRes   function  res        res.pipe process.stdout ;     res.on  end   function  chunk            console.log  ;         console.timeEnd  proxy  ;       ;   ;  // Proxy requests http.createServer function  req  res        console.time  proxy  ;     proxy.web req  res    target:  http://54.209.167.233:3000/    ;   .listen 3000 ;      This is as simple as I can make the cases and still illustrate the problem. Clearly it has something to do with EC2  but the fact that the http requests come back in a reasonable amount of time makes me think that it also has something to do with the way request  and [nodejitsu/node http proxy] https://github.com/nodejitsu/node http proxy  for that matter  are handling requests at the node level.

title: Options object is mutated by calling request
body: I m trying to run following piece of code:      function testUrl options  callback      request.head options  function  err  res        if  err    res.statusCode === 405    res.statusCode === 501          request.get options  callback ;       else         callback err  res ;           ;        Unfortunately this makes the HEAD request two times. After the call to  request.head  it seems the options object now has a  method:  HEAD   which isn t overriden by the call to  request.get . I can make it work by not reusing  options  but it seems to me that something like this should work.

title: setTimeout should be called on the  socket  event
body: Refering to this location   https://github.com/request/request/blob/f1bb537ee2440bd664ea8c445ac3a2c6e31e9932/request.js L676  The setTimeout starts the timer immediately. However  there are two issues    1. The http request doesn t even get to the global Agent s queue until request.end   is called. 2. Under high load the request might actually be queued behind several requests.  Under normal circumstances  that s fine. However  under high load when the node server is handling a lot of traffic  we don t want the time out timer to start until the request actually gets a socket. We want to measure the timeout from the point the request was actually made from the host until it came back. I will be happy to submit a patch for this.

title: prevent hanging when piping empty streams to request
body: This not really a bug  since this is supposed to be addressed by https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/4969  However  when using one line proxying in a connect/express application  some previous middleware may have consumed or switched the request object to old streaming mode. This causes pipes coming to request   to wait for an  end  event which is not gonna happend again.  As a robustness concern  it would be cool if request checked if it is being piped ended readable streams and not wait for an  end  event to happen but still used headers from that stream if it is an Http.IncomingMessage object.

title: Disabling features based on the status of optionalDependencies causes confusion
body: I just spent a few hours trying to figure out why I couldn t get cookie jars working with request  and it turned out that the  tough cookie  dependency was missing. I m not sure if npm failed to install it or what  but since it s part of  optionalDependencies   I never noticed. Finally  by digging into the source for request  I realized that it was marked as optional  and I manually installed it with npm.  I think it s okay to disable functionality based on missing libraries  but the absolute last thing the library should do is provide  stub  functionality that pretends that everything is okay  but in reality is doing nothing. This is _incredibly_ confusing.  Would it be possible to make it throw an error if you try to use cookies without  tough cookie  installed  or is it better to make the dependency mandatory instead?  I m happy to send pull requests for either option

title: Error: You cannot pipe after data has been emitted from the response.
body: I am encountering an issue where I will get the  You cannot pipe after data has been emitted from the response.  error when trying to pipe to a WriteStream. This only occurs when there has been a delay between when the  request    call was made  and when the  readStream.pipe writeStream   call is made.  Node version: v0.10.24 Request version: 2.34.0  I created a github repo with the source that reproduces the problem: https://github.com/joe spanning/request error  Code is also below for convenience:      javascript var fs = require  fs      request = require  request  ;  var readStream = request     url:  https://gist.githubusercontent.com/joe spanning/6902070/raw/8967b351aec744a2bb51c16cb847c44636cf53d9/pipepromise.js    ;  // wait for 5 seconds  then pipe setTimeout function        var writeStream = readStream.pipe fs.createWriteStream  test.js   ;    writeStream.on  finish   function         console.log  all done   ;     ;    writeStream.on  error   function err        console.error err ;     ;     5000 ;      You might need to play with the timeout value to reproduce the error. Longer timeouts increase the probability that the error will occur.      /request error/node_modules/request/request.js:1299       throw new Error  You cannot pipe after data has been emitted from the re             ^ Error: You cannot pipe after data has been emitted from the response.     at Request.pipe  /request error/node_modules/request/request.js:1299:13      at null._onTimeout  /request error/pipe error.js:16:32      at Timer.listOnTimeout [as ontimeout]  timers.js:110:15

title: Allow recursive request.defaults
body: This change allows you to call  request.defaults  on the function that is returned from a call to  request.defaults   The idea is to be able to recursively call  .defaults  to override or add new configs to the previous defaults.  For example      var proxiedRequest = request.defaults  proxy:  http://proxy1.com   ; var nonRedirectedProxyRequest = proxiedRequest.defaults  followRedirect: false  ;      In this example  proxiedRequest  would just have the  proxy  as the default and  nonRedirectedProxyRequest  would have both the  proxy  and  followRedirects  as defaults.  You can also do something like      var r1 = request.defaults     timeout: 1000    followRedirect: false   ; var r2 = r1.defaults  timeout: 3000  ;      in which case  r1  would not follow redirects and have a timeout of 1000ms and  r2  would also not follow redirects but would have a timeout of 3000ms

title: Request fails on an IPv6 network
body: As originally described [here] https://github.com/popcorn official/popcorn app/issues/504   Request fails to connect over an IPv6 network  even in the presence of NAT64.  I m belive  but I m not not sure  one of these scenarios is true  I m not familiar enough with node to properly debug this  sorry :   Request is assuming there s native IPv4 connectivity  a bug .   Request is not using the system resolver  not strictly a bug  but this would break NAT64  as well as scenarios with split horizon DNS  and there s no reason _not_ use it .        cat test.js  var request = require  request   request  http://github.com   function  error  response  body      if   error    response.statusCode == 200        console.log body  // Print the google web page.       else       console.log error           node test.js   [Error: connect ENETUNREACH] code:  ENETUNREACH   errno:  ENETUNREACH   syscall:  connect         For the record  NAT64 solves this just fine:        dig  short github.com 192.30.252.128   ping6 64:ff9b::192.30.252.128 64 bytes from 64:ff9b::c01e:fc80: icmp_seq=1 ttl=50 time=169 ms 64 bytes from 64:ff9b::c01e:fc80: icmp_seq=2 ttl=50 time=167 ms ^C      Or simply:        ping6 github.com PING github.com 64:ff9b::c01e:fc83  56 data bytes 64 bytes from 64:ff9b::c01e:fc83: icmp_seq=1 ttl=50 time=188 ms 64 bytes from 64:ff9b::c01e:fc83: icmp_seq=2 ttl=50 time=174 ms ^            curl  I github.com HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently Content length: 0 Location: https://github.com/ Connection: close

The error is:  The error is:      sh Running  compress:main   compress  task >> Error: Filename  node_modules/frisby/node_modules/request/node_modules/lodash.merge/node_modules/lodash._basecreatecallback/node_modules/lodash.bind/node_modules/lodash._createwrapper/node_modules/lodash._basebind/node_modules/lodash._basecreate/node_modules/lodash._isnative/LICENSE.txt  is too long even with prefix support [270/255] Warning: Archiving failed. title: Request should accept  also  array of headers
body: It s possible to have several headers with the same name and different value.   [specs extract] http://stackoverflow.com/a/3097052/325365 :      > Multiple message header fields with the same field name MAY be present in a message if and only if the entire field value for that header field is defined as a comma separated list [i.e.    values ]. It MUST be possible to combine the multiple header fields into one  field name: field value  pair  without changing the semantics of the message  by appending each subsequent field value to the first  each separated by a comma. The order in which header fields with the same field name are received is therefore significant to the interpretation of the combined field value  and thus a proxy MUST NOT change the order of these field values when a message is forwarded.   known headers which support multiple occurance according to [specs] http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616 sec14.html  and reality:     Cookie  prohibited    Set Cookie: http://stackoverflow.com/q/16305814/325365  [interesting stuff also here] https://code.google.com/p/browsersec/wiki/Part2 Same origin_policy_for_cookies      WWW Authenticate     Warning     possibly comma separated values of headers  such as If None Match  If Match  Content Language  Content Encoding  Cache Control  ...?

title: Invalid protocol error is emitted before the handlers can subscribe to it.
body: Invalid protocol error is raised in a function called by the Request object constructor  before any I/O operation. So  the event is emitted in the same event loop round when the listeners were not added yet  and the error is lost.  For example:  var myDomain = require  domain  .create  ; myDomain.on  error   function  err         console.log  Shouldn t be here   ;   ;  domain.run function          req = request  url: url_with_no_protocol   ;      req.on  error   function err            console.log  Should be here  but not  ;        ;   ;  The problem is request.js: if   self.httpModule  return this.emit  error   new Error  Invalid protocol:     protocol    It can be solve adding a nextTick call  so the emit call will run in the next event loop round  after the handlers are set.   I ve already fix it  so if you don t mind I will file a PR.

title: Move emit of invalid protocol to nextTick because the handlers are not i...
body: Fixes  917

title: Response stream emits readable event but is null
body: Is Request supposed to support the new streams API?      var request = require  request  ;  request  http://oliverjash.me/  .on  response   function  response        console.log 1 ;     // Works     // response.on  data   function  data        //     console.log 2  data ;     //   ;     // Doesn t work:     response.on  readable   function              console.log 3  response.read   ;         // => null  2 times        ;   ;

title: Sending requests with content length equal to zero raises an error
body: In the request.js file there is a check: if  length        if   self.hasHeader  content length    self.setHeader  content length   length    else       throw new Error  Argument error  options.body.     which prevents sending files with zero length. I understand this not very important issue  but still. Specification says  Any Content Length greater than or equal to zero is a valid value.   http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616 sec14.html   I faced with this restriction when using cradle which we use to save user files to CouchDB and some of files have zero length  CouchDB also accepts empty files   so the problem is caused only by the request module.

title: Get cookies
body: I added support for the tough cookie CookieJar getCookies to the RequestJar and added documentation to the README on how to use it and what to expect.

title: Get cookies
body: added support for the tough cookie CookieJar getCookies to RequestJar an...d updated the readme

title: Authorization: Bearer header with auth shouldn t require user   password
body: javascript request     url:  https://example.com     auth:       bearer:  my token         function     /  ...  /   ;      fails because  Error: auth   received invalid user or password . If I have a token I want to specify instead of user and password  why do I also need to provide a user / password?  I realize I can just set an  Authorization  header but thought this was weird. Any thoughts?

title: Proposal: Multi part Form Data as a request option
body: Background  Multipart Form Uploads  MPUs  currently take advantage of the  form data  module. This handles uploads for us  but the interface is [confusing to many users] https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/345  and seems to clash with the normal  request options   interface.        javascript // From README Forms var r = request.post  http://service.com/upload   someOptionalCallback ; var form = r.form   form.append  my_field    my_value   form.append  my_buffer   new Buffer [1  2  3]   // ...      I have a callback chain that modifies an  options  object before calling  request options  . Supporting MPU data means passing a second object of form data to append later  or attaching the form data to this options object and then removing it later. It would be much easier   intuitive if request could handle Multipart form data via the normal options object  just as it does for all other parameters.       Proposal  I d like to propose handling the simple multi part form case via the options passed to request. The interface would look like this:      javascript var options =       url:  http://service.com/upload       mpu:           my_filed:  my_value           my_buffer: new Buffer [1 2 3]         ; request options  someOptionalCallback ;       request  would check for  mpu  in the options object. If found  it would get a new FormData object from  self.form    and call  form.append  on all mpu properties. This would handle most MPU use cases  like the README example above   and we would keep the current  form    method for developers who need to handle some advanced case.   Open questions: 1. What should the option be called? I d like to use  form   but it s already taken. formMPU? formUpload?     I m happy to tackle this in a PR  but I wanted to get some feedback from @mikeal et. all and a confirmation that this was desired before I did.

title: Add support for multipart form data via the request options
body: See original proposal here  924       Summary  Instead of creating your own form for multipart uploads and having to append data separately  pass the data you d like to attach via the request options argument. For more advanced cases where the third append argument is required  the current solution can still be used.      Before      javascript // From README Forms var options =   /  ...  /  ; var r = request.post options  someOptionalCallback ; var form = r.form   form.append  my_field    my_value   form.append  my_buffer   new Buffer [1  2  3]   // ...          After      javascript var options =       url:  http://service.com/upload       formMPU:           my_filed:  my_value           my_buffer: new Buffer [1 2 3]         ; request options  someOptionalCallback ;

title: Encode url during redirects
body: Redirects is failing if the URL to be redirected to contains chars that needs encoding.  eg.  http://example.com/landing page  redirects to  http://example.com/error     which should have been encoded to  http://example.com/error  C3 B8 .  How about specifying that request should handle url encoding?

title: Bump version of hawk dep.
body: Hawk used to be locked to node 8 and below. This was fixed in the 1.1.1 release: https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/commit/a523a412afbda2eca1fb1d253b8e3511fdbd371d  I did test this with the 2.x release of hawk and everything worked but I figured bumping by a major version could have some bad side effects.

body: javascript request.post  https://googleapiexample.com             form:                 access_token:  xxxxx                   function  error  response  body            console.log error ;         console.log body ;         if error               throw error;          else if response.statusCode == 200               try                   body = JSON.parse body ;               catch  e                   throw new Error  Can  t parse JSON  ;                           if body.error                   throw new Error body.error ;              else                  console.log body ;                               ;      Returns:        [Error: Parse Error] bytesParsed: 11587  code:  HPE_INVALID_CONSTANT

title: Post form converts numerical data to string
body: I am sending a post request similar to the following      query=  selection :  id :100  name : username   other : 123    request.post  http://host.com   form: query        on the server  if  I do      console.log clientRequest.body  I get:    selection:   id:  100   name:  username   other:  123           As you ll notice in the body of the request  the value of field  id  has been turned into a string. Is this intended/standard behavior or rather a bug?

title: How to get  readable  stream in callback
body: I need to get a  readable  stream in order to pipe it further. But passing  body  in callback means that  res  stream became exhausted and contains no data in it to read. So are there any ways to get  readable   res  stream and undefined body in callback      coffeescript request.get  http://some.domain.com     e  res  body    >   res.pipe  other  .pipe  another

title: Return Buffer if encoding is undefined
body: I just ran into issue  823 today as well. It seems like it makes the most sense to have not providing an  encoding  value  i.e.  encoding  is  undefined   do the same thing as setting  encoding  to  null . This can be easily done by changing [one character] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L967    ===  to  ==  .

title: Request performance
body: Hi   I m developing a crawling system with  1000 victim domains  3M requests/h and both use 2 node module support download a url: Request and Fetch  https://github.com/andris9/fetch .  Request is better in most properties excepts Performance. When I crawling 1 domain using Request my server  8Cores  32G Ram  100SSD  always using 100 CPU  >100 Ram while I run 999 domain with Fetch it work well  <40 CPU  <60  RAM   Could you help me ?

If I log the option object passed to request just before the request is made the uri contains the special character but it s as if the special character is ignored behinds the scene.  eg.  uri: http://backurl/resources/profilresponsabiliterole?page=1 start=0 limite=10 filtre=[roleCode roleDescription dateDebut dateFin actif]:like:unit   Returns me an empty object but if I receive this  without the     uri: http://backurl/resources/profilresponsabiliterole?page=1 start=0 limite=10 filtre=[roleCode roleDescription dateDebut dateFin actif]:like:unite    It works ok.  I m using utf 8 encoding.  Any ideas ?  Thank you

title: [fix] Support httpOver  outbound proxying.
body: Thanks to @jcrugzz for finding this  but it appears that outbound proxy tunneling was only setup for  httpsOver   and not for  httpOver  . Assuming there wasn t a reason for that  this adds that functionality.

title: Preserve a context
body: Hi  Is there a way to save a context object so it can be used in the call back function? Thanks in advance Shay

title: Support externally created tough cookie jars
body: In one of my projects  I create multiple tough cookie jars in a phase  where request isn t required. When I pass these jars to a request object  things fail. This is due to request requires calls to  getCookieString  and  setCookie  to be made synchronously. When using request.jar   to create a tough cookie jar  these two methods are overwritten and actually call  getCookieStringSync  and  setCookieSync  respectively. When using an externally created tough cookie jar  this overwrite does not happen. For fixing this  I applied slight changes to request.js  where the actual cookie reading / cookie writing happens.

title: Fixing  939
body: applied conditional calls to getCookieStringSync as well as  setCookieSync in request.js  where the actual cookie reading / cookie writing happens.

title: Progress: Make _bytesDispatched an official attribute?  broken in node webkit
body: For posting files with multipart post whilst measuring the   I did something like this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12098713/upload progress request  except the attribute was  r.req.connection.socket._bytesDispatched   This works fine with node  but not node webkit. No idea why yet. Perhaps it should be an official API feature rather than an internal based hack.  The attribut is simply not defined in node webkit using the same version of request. Would the internal node version be the culprit?

title: [fix] Support httpOver  outbound proxying and make tunnel explicit
body: Based on discussion in  937

body: Hello  and thanks for a great project I have used many many times.  Was trying to get a project where I have been using request with node working in the browser with browserify  and ran into issue  455  Just swapped out the mime library  as suggested in the issue  and request now works in the browser.  Have a great day

title: defaults: merge headers
body: As requested  https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/257  headers are merged into default headers. In the example below  the user agent isn t lost.       javascript var req = request.defaults     headers:        user agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_3           req url    headers:   accept:  application/json       callback

title: Incorrect cookie date handling with CookieJar  mangled expires dates
body: Consider the following code:      javascript var request = require  request  ;  var cookieJar = request.jar  ; var loginUrl =  https://www.boots.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/LogonForm?storeId=10052 langId= 1 catalogId=11051 URL=http 3A 2F 2Fwww.boots.com 2F ;  request.get   url: loginUrl  jar: cookieJar    function err  res  body        console.log res.headers ;     console.log cookieJar ;   ;      This code makes an HTTP GET request to the boots.com login page  and then spits out the response headers and the contents of the cookie jar.  If I examine the res headers  they look something like:            server:  IBM_HTTP_Server       pragma:  No cache       ....more headers  snip ...       set cookie :      [          WCDC_CURRID=ABC123; Expires=Thu  26 Jun 14 18:59:58 GMT; Path=/           ....more cookies  snip ....     ]        Notice the expires date of the cookie  Thu  26 Jun 14 18:59:58 GMT . Now examine the contents of the cookie jar:        _jar:       store:          idx:    www.boots.com :              / :                               WCDC_CURRID: Cookie= WCDC_CURRID=ABC123; Expires=Mon  26 Jun 142000 18:59:58 GMT; Path=/; hostOnly=true; aAge=416ms; cAge=416ms                 ... more cookies  snip ....      Notice that the cookie expires date is  Mon  26 Jun 142000 18:59:58 GMT   the year 142000? WTF ?  It s not just this one cookie either  all of them seem to have mangled dates. Some of them even look like this:      BP: Cookie= BP=; Expires=undefined  0NaN undefined NaN 0NaN:0NaN:0NaN GMT; Domain=boots.com; Path=/; hostOnly=false; aAge=415ms; cAge=415ms       Anything obvious I m missing that s causing this? A bug with tough cookie perhaps. I tried the Boots login page in Chrome browser and all the cookie expires dates seem to be interpreted correctly.
