Probably stuck in a redirect loop http://a.triggit.com/pxfbcm?s=miss     at Request.onResponse  /home/myproject/node_modules/request/request.js:864:26      at ClientRequest.g  events.js:180:16      at ClientRequest.EventEmitter.emit  events.js:95:17      at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient [as onIncoming]  http.js:1688:21      at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete [as onHeadersComplete]  http.js:121:23      at Socket.socketOnData [as ondata]  http.js:1583:20      at TCP.onread  net.js:527:27       I have a try/catch block around my call to request   but it doesn t catch the error.

title: Add support for gzip content decoding
body: My apologies in advance for adding yet another gzip implementation for you to consider  but it appears that work on the alternative solutions   303   458   464   660  has stalled while interest in a solution is still high   539   725   747  and requires non trivial effort to implement outside of the library  although it s certainly not horrible .  Unlike the previous solutions  this pull request supports stream based usage and does not introduce any backwards incompatible behavior.  It is intended to serve as a bridge for the 2.x series until 3.0 is ready for release  at which points its existing gzip implementation can supersede this one.  This commit introduces the  decodeContent  boolean option to allow users to explicitly request decoding of supported response content and inclusion of the appropriate content negotiation header   Accept Encoding    if unspecified.  Although  deflate  support is also common on servers  this commit does not add  deflate  support due to compatibility issues with non conformant  raw  deflate encodings and the lack of a compelling reason to support it given  gzip  s wide availability.  Thanks for considering  Kevin

title: Adding support to client certificate with proxy use case
Add async Content Length computation when using form data
body: Related to  345  396  522

title: HPE_INVALID_CONTENT_LENGTH on HEAD request   core Node.js http module handles it fine
body: HEAD requests with the  request  module on some shortened  301 redirecting URLs return the following error:        [Error: Parse Error] bytesParsed: 123  code:  HPE_INVALID_CONTENT_LENGTH         For example  I get this on http://cnb.cx/1vtyQyv. Very easy to reproduce  node v0.10.29  request v2.36.0 :      var request = require  request  ;  request   url: http://cnb.cx/1vtyQyv   method:  HEAD     function err  res        console.log err  res ;   ;      The error is thrown from within [Node.js s core http parser] https://github.com/mattn/http server/blob/master/http_parser.c . Doing a GET request with  request  works fine  however   it follows the 301 and returns the contents of the specified page. Also  as pointed out in an answer to my [Stack Overflow question] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24538520/node js head request returns hpe invalid content length error   the core Node.js  http.request  function has no problem with it  which is what leads me to think this is a bug in  request .      var http = require  http  ;  http.request     host:  cnb.cx     path:  /1vtyQyv     method:  HEAD     function res      console.dir res ;   res.resume  ;   .end  ;      For your benefit  here is the result of  curl  HEAD request on this URL:        curl  I http://cnb.cx/1vtyQyv HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently Server: nginx Date: Wed  02 Jul 2014 18:16:05 GMT Content Type: text/html; charset=utf 8 Connection: keep alive Cache Control: private; max age=90 Content Length: 124 Location: http://www.cnbc.com/id/101793181 Mime Version: 1.0 Set Cookie: _bit=53b44c65 00194 0369a 281cf10a;domain=.cnb.cx;expires=Mon Dec 29 18:16:05 2014;path=/; HttpOnly      Content Length looks fine  and the body length is in fact 124  as can be verified with  curl http://cnb.cx/1vtyQyv   wc  c   so I don t know why the error is happening in the first place.  This is an issue  by the way  because I m using [node unshortener] https://github.com/Swizec/node unshortener  which makes repeated HEAD requests until it finds the full URL.

title: check for content length header before setting it in nextTick
body: extending https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/793 so it does not override a custom content length header.  Especially relevant when passing in a stream since  _form.getLengthSync  [doesn t calculate] https://github.com/felixge/node form data/blob/fdc52f3fa32198da44644bb158e6f5764feb3767/test/integration/test errors.js L61 L62  the length of the stream in form data  making this statement: https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/345 issuecomment 13818530 not technically correct.

title: How select the submit button with a form with 2 submit?
body: Hi all    I m currently writing some API tests for my work. The basics of _Request_ are really easy. I was able to write my first test with _Mocha_ really fast. I use waterfall  function from [async] https://github.com/caolan/async  librairy to chain the requests.  But now I m blocked. I have to submit a form where there is two buttons to submit it: _Save_ and _Delete_.      HTML <dd id= save element > <input type= submit  name= save  id= save  value= Save  class= ui button ui widget ui state default ui corner all ui state hover  role= button  aria disabled= false ></dd> <dd> <input type= submit  name= delete  id= delete  value= Delete  class= ui button ui widget ui state default ui corner all  role= button  aria disabled= false ></dd>      Here what I did.      JavaScript global.request = request.defaults  json: true  jar: true            Javascript async.waterfall [   function cb        var params;     params =         url:  http://baseURL/login         form:  username:  myuser   password:  mypwd        ;     request.post params  function err  response  body          cb err  body ;       ;         function body  cb        request.post  http://baseURL/FormPage    form:   delete:  Delete    ;     ] ;      I m well log in  but my second request seems not to be taken into account.   Can you show me how request a page and directly submit a form  all the field are already filled.  throught the _Delete_ button?  I guess I did something wrong.

title: Silence EventEmitter memory leak warning  311
body: When performing a lot of concurrent requests on a keep alive connection  a lot of error handlers can be added  which in turn will result in the following warning:  possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 listeners added . This isn t really a memory leak and should just be silenced.

title: Fixing  Content Length  bug
body: Adding Content Length header when using form options.  There is a problem with the header when using      javascript var r = request  http://example.com/upload   fn ; r.form   form: data   ;      This does not create a Content Length header  even though the code would say it does.

title: Support gzip with encoding on node pre v0.9.4
body: This pull request addresses an oversight from  951 that before 0.9.4  zlib  streams did not support the  setEncoding  method.  This means that on these versions of node  using the  encoding  and  gzip  options together would cause an error and result in test failures on these versions.  This pull request addresses the issue by chaining the zlib stream with a [stringstream] https://www.npmjs.org/package/stringstream  when both the  encoding  and  gzip  options are specified and  setEncoding  is not available on the zlib stream.

title: [feature request] http pipeline support
body: http pipeline is send many request at once  compared with raw keep alive  it don t wait server response then send another  and improved performance.  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_pipelining  http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616.html section 8.1.2.2 and more  just send requests without waiting and first in first out response.  seems node.js http module is also not support that

title: Contributor Call Next Week
body: First of all  I d like to thank every contributor to  request . This project isn t maintainable by a single person and I ve relied on you all a lot for help.  Similarly  I think that the work of  leading  the project  and the 3.0 effort  is also now more than I can handle on my own. It s about time to formalize some of the project management and spread out more of the responsibility and visibility of  request .  I d like to have a call next week on Tuesday to discuss how to move forward. I ll invite all of the existing collaborators  if you aren t interested cause you haven t been involved in a while feel free to ignore this. If you are interested in participating please give me your preferred email  for Google Hangouts  and the timezone you re in so I can try to find a good time.  Benjamin Atkin @benatkin  Isaac Z. Schlueter @isaacs  Jason Smith @jhs  Brian White @mscdex  Eran Hammer @hueniverse  Marco Rogers @polotek  James Nylen @nylen  Andreas Lind @papandreou  Maciej Ma ecki @mmalecki  Jeremy Stashewsky @stash  Lalit Kapoor @lalitkapoor  Kevin Locke @kevinoid  Lo c Mahieu @LoicMahieu

title: Using request for Instagram Oauth
body: Hello this is not really an issue as I am sure your system works but more a call for help if that is ok with you. Please try not to mind my ignorance on the subject if you can.  Basically I am trying to use your middleware to Authenticate with Instagram using express.  I have been trying to follow Instagram Server side  Explicit  flow  which is a 2 step operation:   request an access code   request an access token  Right now my server is set up using:      express         = require  express    app             = express  ;      and to initiate the first step I am using:      app.get  /   function req  res     var url =  https://api.instagram.com/oauth/authorize/?client_id=  CLIENT ID   redirect_uri=  YOUR REDIRECT URI   response_type=code    res.redirect url ;   ;      And then I use this to handle Instagram s callback:      app.get  /auth/instagram/callback   function req  res      console.log  Instagram code:    req.query.code ;    var data =       url : url     client_id  :  CLIENT ID       client_secret  :  CLIENT SECRET       grant_type  :  authorization_code       redirect_uri  :  YOUR REDIRECT URI       code  : req.query.code    ;    var url =  https://api.instagram.com/oauth/access_token ;    request.post     method:  POST     url: url    body: JSON.stringify data          function  e  r  body       console.log  The body:    body ;      ;    ;      unfortunately despite receiving a valid access code from Instagram from the first step  I do get the following response. I also tried hardcoding an actual client ID  client secret and even code in the data field but keep on getting the following response.      The body:    code: 400    error_type:  OAuthException     error_message:  You must provide a client_id         Any light on this would be most appreciated.  Thank you and I hope this does not take too much from your time.  Respectfully   Jules

title: Cleanup response.body buffer creation to use Buffer.concat
body: I just noticed that there was an unnecessary loop over the array of response body buffers  where  Buffer.concat    would work just as well and take care of the complexity for you. Docs: http://nodejs.org/api/buffer.html buffer_class_method_buffer_concat_list_totallength  I also took the chance to clean up some confusing/vague variables:    buffer  was actually an array of Buffers  each one being a chunk of the final response body buffer     now  bodyDataChunks     bodyLen  could have meant length of the array     now  bodyTotalSize     body  could still be modified before becoming the final  response.body      now  bodyData   All tests are passing  and the update was working fine when I tested it inside my own application.     Note: Buffer.concat   was introduced and has [remained unchanged since v0.8.0] http://nodejs.org/docs/v0.8.0/api/buffer.html buffer_class_method_buffer_concat_list_totallength   so request s version compatibility will remain unchanged.

title: Post amble CRLF for .NET Web API Request
body: I have had to monkey patch Request to work with Web API  [Microsoft ASP.NET Web API 4.0.30506] https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi/4.0.30506   because the .NET Web API requires CRLF after the boundary as well or get a 500 error.      js // https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L1189 Request.prototype.multipart = function  multipart      var self = this   self.body = []    if   self.hasHeader  content type          self.setHeader  content type    multipart/related; boundary=    self.boundary      else       var headerName = self.hasHeader  content type  ;     self.setHeader headerName  self.headers[headerName].split  ;  [0]    ; boundary=    self.boundary         if   multipart.forEach  throw new Error  Argument error  options.multipart.      if  self.preambleCRLF        self.body.push new Buffer   r n           multipart.forEach function  part        var body = part.body     if body == null  throw Error  Body attribute missing in multipart.       delete part.body     var preamble =        self.boundary     r n      Object.keys part .forEach function  key          preamble  = key    :     part[key]     r n             preamble  =   r n      self.body.push new Buffer preamble       self.body.push new Buffer body       self.body.push new Buffer   r n           self.body.push new Buffer        self.boundary             // .NET Web API requires CRLF after the boundary as well or 500 error   self.body.push new Buffer   r n       return self        The error I get looks like this:      Response Body:   Message : An error has occurred.   ExceptionMessage : Unexpected end of MIME multipart stream. MIME multipart message is not complete.   ExceptionType : System.IO.IOException   StackTrace :    at System.Net.Http.Formatting.Parsers.MimeMultipartBodyPartParser.<ParseBuffer>d__0.MoveNext   r n   at System.Net.Http.HttpContentMultipartExtensions.MoveNextPart MultipartAsyncContext context         Related to the preamble issue in https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/272  I am not sure how you might want to handle this though because it looks like you are making the preambles optional  however  I didn t see any documentation about the options .

title: feature request: Add start and end events for monitoring
body: We use Request to wrap all of our calls to 3rd party websites as a practice.  We have a new requirement that we need to measure and report on all of these calls as well.  Easiest way would be if there was a start and end event that we could subscript to within the main Request object instance  request .  I ve basically monkey patched this in to some extent  but this doesn t cover everything.      var Request = require  request  ; var util = require  util  ; var events = require  events  ; var emitter = new events.EventEmitter  ; var wrapMethods = [ post    put    patch    head    del    get ];  var counter =  function      var getNanoSeconds = function getNanoSeconds          hr = process.hrtime  ;       return hr[0]   1e9   hr[1];      ;   var loadTime = getNanoSeconds  ;   return function from       var v =  getNanoSeconds   loadTime  / 1e6;     return from?v from:v;    ;     ;  var RequestTimed = function      var args = Array.prototype.slice.call arguments ;   var cb = args[args.length 1];   var start = counter  ;   var uri = args.uri  args.url   args[0]?args[0].uri  args[0].url  args[0]:args ;   var method =  args.method   args[0]?args[0].method   GET : GET   .toUpperCase  ;   var done = function error  response  body       var end = counter start ;     emitter.emit  request::end           method: method        uri: uri        args: args        start: start        end: end        duration: end start        error: error        response: response        body: body       ;     cb.apply this  arguments ;    ;   if typeof cb  ===  function        args[args.length] = done;    else      cb = noop;     args.push done ;       emitter.emit  request::start         method:  Request       uri: uri      args: args      start: start     ;   return Request.apply this  args ;  ;  util.inherits RequestTimed  Request ;  var wrapCall = function key  method  source     return function        var args = Array.prototype.slice.call arguments ;     var cb = args[args.length 1];     var start = counter  ;     var uri = args.uri  args.url   args[0]?args[0].uri  args[0].url  args[0]:args ;     var done = function error  response  body         var end = counter  ;       emitter.emit  request::end             method: method          uri: uri          args: args          start: start          end: end          duration: end start          error: error          response: response          body: body         ;       cb.apply this  arguments ;      ;     if typeof uri  == string          uri=  ;           if typeof cb  ===  function          args[args.length] = done;      else        cb = noop;       args.push done ;           emitter.emit  request::start           method: method        uri: uri        args: args        start: start       ;     return source[key].apply source  args ;    ;  ;  var noop = new Function  ; var start = counter  ; var keys = Object.keys Request ;  keys.forEach function key     if wrapMethods.indexOf key.toLowerCase   === 1       RequestTimed[key] = function          return Request[key].apply Request  arguments ;      ;     return;       var method = key.toUpperCase  ;   RequestTimed[key] = wrapCall key  method  Request ;   ;  RequestTimed.on = RequestTimed.addListener = function event  listener     emitter.on event  listener ;  ;  RequestTimed.once = function event  listener     emitter.once event  listener ;  ;  RequestTimed.off = RequestTimed.removeListener = function event  listener     emitter.off event  listener ;  ;  RequestTimed.removeAllListeners = function event     emitter.removeAllListeners event ;  ;  RequestTimed.setMaxListeners = function n     emitter.setMaxListeners n ;  ;  module.exports = RequestTimed;      Any chance something like this could be incorporated directly into request?

title: 3.0    Cut optional dependencies
body: Optional dependencies have been tricky and painful since we moved to them.  I don t like the idea of having to throw at runtime because you didn t install something. That doesn t mean I think that we should just take all those deps back as regular dependencies.  The deps I think should just return to being regular dependencies are:  form data  and  tunnel agent . In 3.0 I think we should make a breaking change to authentication and signing. Basically  we should define an object that can be passed in to  auth  which can handle all the authentication and signing use cases. Then signing libraries can produce those objects and we can just accept them  removing the need for optionalDeps. Example:      javascript var o = require  oauth sign    consumer_key:key  access_token:token       request = require  request     ; request  https://site/needsauth    auth:o  json:true   function  e  resp  body   console.log body          We can handle cookies essentially the same way  and that interface has already been pretty standardized by @lalitkapoor so it should be even easier.

title: toJSON no longer results in an infinite loop  returns simple objects
body: This commit is an attempt to solve issue  1011 where instead of succeeding or throwing   JSON.stringify request   and  JSON.stringify resp   can cause infinite loops. This solution involves returning much smaller objects without any circular references so that serialization is possible.  The purpose of this PR is to look for feedback   keep the conversation going on whether this is a direction we want to go.       Context / Thinking  taken from  1011 :  > ... when the unknowing user serializes the object  intentionally and unintentionally  would they rather the default behavior be to throw an error  or successfully serialize only the basic properties? >  > I definitely see the value in throwing and letting the user handle it every time  but this also means that every user will need to go into the object and find out what fields they need themselves. I imagine it s much more likely for the general user not to care  and maybe even prefer to have it extract only the basic  most valuable info. Also  if an expert user didn t like our simple serializer  they could just remove it  either through an option we provide or manually via  delete r.toJSON  .       Open Questions 1. Are there any other crucial properties? I just chose the few that seemed important 2. Do we want to keep  json stringify safe  for serializing a json body object? I m not sure if we d actually want to allow complex objects / objects with circular dependencies to be submitted via request  since they aren t really valid JSON. It might be helpful for users to remove this dependency/functionality for 3.0 3. Is this considered a breaking change? In some cases it didn t infinite loop  so for those cases it definitely is one.     /cc @mikeal @netpoetica

title: User Agent HTTP header not being set on CONNECT requests
body: The User Agent HTTP header is not being set on HTTP CONNECT requests specifically.  This is needed in scenarios where connections are passing through a proxy server  and there is a need to white list traffic via the User Agent header.  These findings originate from an NPM issue  which NPM contributors have attributed to a difference in behavior within the request module.  See NPM issue:  https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/6007  Thanks

title: Memory allocation abort on pipe  2.40.0
body: I could not find this in the issues so I am reporting this   request@.2.40.0   currently the latest available in  npm   reproducible test case:      var fs = require  fs  ; var request = require  request  ; var opts =  url:  http://localhost:5984/mock 2Fdatabase/mock 2Fdocument/mock.avi  ; var conn = request opts  function err  res  doc     ; conn.pipe fs.createWriteStream  ./target/mock.avi   ;      Results in:      FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_0 Allocation failed   process out of memory      I tracked this down a little to the Buffer allocation here:  https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/v2.40.0/request.js L1018  This can be bypassed by adding      self.dests.length  to the conditional on:  https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/v2.40.0/request.js L1016  However  this then results in:      FATAL ERROR: JS Allocation failed   process out of memory      The  mock.avi  file has a byte length of  367333376 .  At this point I stopped debugging as I have verified that using the node  http  module does not result in these errors  this is definitely a  request  issue.  I have not tested against more recent versions of  request  in git.  Using node  v0.10.29  on:      Darwin pearl.local 10.8.0 Darwin Kernel Version 10.8.0: Tue Jun  7 16:32:41 PDT 2011; root:xnu 1504.15.3 1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64      The only workaround I am aware of is to use the  http  module directly when downloading large files that you wish to pipe to a file.

title: Race condition with gzip encoding and large responses
body: We have run into an issue where the maximum call stack size gets exceeded when we are using gzip encoding and there is a large response such that the Gunzip data stream will buffer. The cause is that this line https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L955 is being called before the gunzip has completed and therefore this line  https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L1002  has not been executed yet  since  dataStream  is now the Gunzip . This causes a recursive call to  response.emit  end    and back to  response.on  close   .  To fix this  it seems like  self._ended = true  should be set when the response has closed and not when the gunzip stream has completed. I m not sure of the internals of how  self._ended  is used though.

Example is in coffeescript.      coffeescript options =       url: https://api.sample.com    /users/me?password=    userpassword       method:  DELETE        auth:         bearer: accessToken       headers:          Accept :  application/json   request options   error  response  body   >   console.log response.statusCode      Results in:      bash Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected end of input at Object.parse  native      at Request._callback  /Users/daniel/Projects/test/coffee/src/tasks.coffee:21:19      at Request.self.callback  /Users/daniel/Projects/test/node_modules/request/request.js:123:22      at Request.emit  events.js:98:17      at Request.<anonymous>  /Users/daniel/Projects/test/node_modules/request/request.js:1047:14      at Request.emit  events.js:117:20      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  /Users/daniel/Projects/test/node_modules/request/request.js:998:12      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:117:20      at _stream_readable.js:943:16     at process._tickCallback  node.js:419:13       The part that really has me confused  if I add  console.log arguments  in the  request  function  I can see the request and response data before the syntax error.  The server is responding with a 204 as I am expecting.  Request just hits this syntax error and everything falls apart.   If I simply change the method to  GET  I get an expected 405 without issue.      coffeescript options =       url: https://api.sample.com    /users/me?password=    userpassword       method:  GET        auth:         bearer: accessToken       headers:          Accept :  application/json   request options   error  response  body   >   console.log response.statusCode      Results in:      bash 405

title: Explicitly use sync versions of cookie functions
body: Currently  the request module does not support asynchronous cookie stores and is restricted to use only the  sync   cookie functions.  The  request.jar    returns a modified  tough cookie  jar where the async functions have been reassigned as their synchronous counterparts.  Passing on regular  tough cookie  objects fails as request attempts to use the async functions as if they were synchronous.  In this pull request I have switched all calls to the cookie jar to reference the sync versions directly  allowing plain  tough cookie  objects to be passed into the request object.

title: How to request HTTPS with self signed keys
body: I am currently building a node module with a secure REST API and I am using Request.  I use HTTPS with a self signed key  on the server  to secure the connection  but since they are self signed  I must set strictSSL to false. The documentation for Request mentions  however   to use your own certificate authority  you need to specify an agent that was created with that CA as an option .  How would I go about making sure that the request client would only connect to the server if it has the correct self signed key? It s fine if I need to keep some keys on the client servers.  PS. I m aware that there s a reason for official CAs  but I am determined to not use them. Most developers will only be using my module between servers and have no need to pay a CA for an officially signed key. All I need is protect from potential MITM attacks.  Thanks

title: Common API documentation format for all Node packages
body: I m the developer behind [Dash] http://kapeli.com/dash   an API documentation browser.  The current state of node packages is that each package has its own custom format for providing documentation  most in a README . This makes things extremely hard if you want to collect all these docs under one app and also an inconvenience for users  as they have to learn how to reference and navigate each doc format of each package they use.  I ve asked the NPM team to promote a doc format that node packages should use in hope that the community would embrace it and they ve asked me to contact the maintainers of the most popular packages and get them to agree on a format  and if it gets popular with the community it will get supported by NPM as well. The NPM issue is tracked here: https://github.com/npm/newww/issues/100.  Some questions: 1. Have you considered using an API documentation generator for your node package? I ve heard of JSDoc over and over  but I ve never seen a node package use it for their docs 2. Do you think it would be better if the APIs of node packages would be documented inside the code  where a doc generator would turn them into actual docs   and the READMEs be used just as a guide? 3. Any thoughts about this issue?

title: How to  end  Request after first buffer?
body: I have code to detect fileType of remote file like this      js var request     = require  request  ; var fileType   = require  file type  ;  request.get url .once  data   function  chunk        console.log fileType chunk  ;     this.end  ;   ;      This code successfull output file type from remote url  but request wont stop  its still downloading .. compare to this basic http code  this is success to stop request after first buffer      js var http = require  http  ; var fileType = require  file type  ; var url =  http://162.220.9.250/HowToTrainYourDragon2.rar ;  http.get url  function  res        res.once  data   function  chunk            res.destroy  ;         console.log fileType chunk  ;       ;   ;      Any solution how to make first code that using  request  to work?  thanks

title: Rewrite Tests
body: Okay so I would like to rewrite the tests to use a testing framework. Something like Mocha js or whatever the majority concludes. I just want us to agree that it would be nicer to have some extra structure around these tests.  Any thoughts? @mikeal @FredKSchott

title: Make Request an organization
body: Hey I had the thought that maybe it would be cool if request was an organization on github. Any thoughts? I am not to sure of the benefits  but I d figured I would ask the question.

title: Patch 1
body: Added a stripped down version of test gzip that sends uncompressed data with a gzip header and checks for the zlib error on the client.  I m assuming the error code is  Z_DATA_ERROR  on every platform.

title: Missing a way to pass a ssl method when connecting via proxy
body: If an SSL call via a proxy requires a specific SSL method  e.g.   SSL V3    there is no way to pass the parameter.  For now  to get my app working  hacked the code to add the following to the tunnelOptions passed to the tunnelFn:  secureProtocol : https.globalAgent.options.secureProtocol   Would appreciate a proper way to pass it as an option to the request call   so we can have this without this hack.

title: Aws is now possible over a proxy
body: The path of a Request will contain the fully qualified domain name when using a proxy.  So it is not usable to calculate the amazon authorization header of. Previously this broke aws signature calculation when combined with  a proxy.

title: strictSSL=false prevents request from using the globalAgent
body: Setting  strictSSL  to false sets rejectUnauthorized to false as well:      // https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L148 if  self.strictSSL === false      self.rejectUnauthorized = false        Which causes  getAgent    to set  options.rejectUnauthorized  on [Line  620] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L620   which ends up failing the check to get the globalAgent:      // https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L676 //  options  has property  rejectUnauthorized   so  Object.keys options .length == 1  if  this.pool === globalPool     poolKey    Object.keys options .length === 0    this.httpModule.globalAgent         Just leaving  strictSSL  out of the request options fixes this  but since we have a true/false value to define  strictSSL  it s a lot easier to just do that.   I don t see it documented anywhere  but what is the difference between  strictSSL: false  and  strictSSL:undefined ? Is this behavior intentional?  /cc @mikeal

title: Pass whitelisted headers to tunneling proxy.  Organize all tunneling logic.
body: Fix  1019 Incorporates  1028

title: Exception when proxy auth  but no uri auth in 2.41.1
body: The exception:      Cannot call method  split  of null TypeError: Cannot call method  split  of null     at Request.self._buildRequest  /build dir/project/node_modules/request/request.js:414:40      ...      Affected line: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L414      if  self.proxy     self.tunnel      if  self.proxy.auth     self.proxyAuthorization        var authPieces = self.uri.auth.split  :  .map function item   return querystring.unescape item         var authHeader =  Basic     toBase64 authPieces[0]  authPieces.slice 1 .join  :        self.proxyAuthorization = authHeader       if  self.proxyAuthorization      self.setHeader  proxy authorization   self.proxyAuthorization         You ll notice that this snippet tries to use  and split   self.uri.auth  to construct the proxy authroization string   it should probably be splitting on  self.proxy.auth .  Likely introduced here: https://github.com/mikeal/request/commit/9a222ff2f2a3639712cb96065e9523f6b43525eb diff ccc0734f65dd7a299409ff07d35be095R404

title: Fixes  1051
body: See  1051

title: Fix  1051 Parse auth properly when using non tunneling proxy
Failing https redirect since version 2.41.1
body: Upgraded from 2.40.1 to 2.41.1 and have a lot of failing http => https redirects.  This code   url replicates the problem      js var r = require  request        u = require  url  ;  r.get  uri: u.parse  http://realfuturecrm.com     console.log ;

title: Broken link markdown in README
body: If you search the README for:  > See  the wikipedia page on HTTP Tunneling [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_tunnel] for more information.  you ll see the    and [] are inverted  causing the link/title to be displayed as inline text.

title: Fix redirects when passing url.parse x  as URL to convenience method
body: This fixes  1054.  This is a strange interaction between the following:   Convenience method like  request.get    called   The result of  url.parse x   passed as the  uri  option   The request results in a cross protocol redirect.

title: Defaults should not overwrite defined options
body: In a recent commit  the applying of defaults changed from a  forEach  loop that only applied a default if the option is  undefined   to using node s  util._extend   which simply copies from one object to another. This change introduced a regression where defaults overwrite defined options.

title: Fixed redirect with authorization issue   450   860
body: Don t know if this was suggested also by someone else  but this commit simply removes the  authorization  header when the request needs to be redirected.  Also added  .idea  files to  .gitignore .

title: json in defaults not merging correctly.
body: This seems to have appeared at some point between 2.39.0 and 2.42.0   i ve not had a chance to dig any deeper yet.  To reproduce  use the following JS      js // index.js var request = require  request  ;  var client = request.defaults  json: true  ;  client       url:  http://httpbin.org/post       method:  POST       json:  a: 1     function err  res  body        console.log err  body ;   ;      And then run it in debug mode      bash NODE_DEBUG=request node index.js      The  json  property remains  true   which leads to an empty body being submitted.  In previous versions this would post the specified json body as expected.

title: Request mutates passed in headers option
body: It seems that since 2.41.0  inclusive  if a headers object is passed into request then it is mutated  e.g. content length is added   which did not occur in previous versions. This is causing couchapp 0.11.0 push to fail  on the second PUT   as it uses the same default header object each time  and the second request length is usually different to the first  couchdb reports an 400 invalid_json error because assuming that the second put is larger   explicit length truncates the request body .

title: Support for getHeaders removed
body: Broken by the fix for  1001

title: Original headers object is modified
body: Hello there   I was just debugging something for a while  because request is modifying the headers object  which was a problem because I had my own reference to that obect.  Here is an example. Let s say you have a variable called headers with some standard headers  empty in this case .      js var headers =    request  url:  http://example.com   headers: headers  json:  a: 1   method:  POST         After doing this request the value of the variable headers is:      js   accept:  application/json      content type :  application/json      content length : 7        This did cause a problem in my case  because my next request was not working  when using the  headers  variable again  because it now contained wrong information from the first request.  I think that behavior is not intuitive  so I think it should be changes. I guess the solution would be cloning the headers object. That would add cost  however since the headers object is not nested  it s actually okay.  Best  Finn

title: copy the input headers object  1060
body: Use a copy of the input headers  closes  1060

title: Fixing HTTP redirects  not carrying pre defined host header value when the Location header is not a URL .
body: Fixing HTTP redirects  not carrying pre defined host header value when the Location header is not a URL .

title: Sending requests to IP with  host  header for performance  a  possible  bug and fix
body: @mikeal We are making a very high number of requests using node request.  In order to increase the performance and not make DNS resolving each time  we  plan to send the requests as: http://74.125.232.67 with  host :  google.com  in the header rather than using http://google.com as the URI.  This works great except one thing  for redirecting URLs  HTTP 301 302   the  host  header is not carried to the redirecting URL with the host  74.125.232.67 in this case .   So  the redirecting request goes to http://74.125.232.67 with Location header  /?search  rather than the google.com/?search.  I propose a fix for that  https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/1064 .  It only deletes the  host  header if the Location header is a URL in case it is a redirection to another domain. Otherwise  the  host  header is carried between redirects.  It seems to work fine on my case but are there any issues it can create that I can t foresee?

title: Timeout ignored when using Nock
body: Hi    Not sure this is a Nock or a Request issue. Timeout property of is ignored when using Nock:      js  var options =           method:  POST           url: http://www.google.com          timeout: 100          ...   ;  ...  httpRequest options  function  error  sipsResponse  body           //throw 599 if  ETIMEDOUT    ;      Content of my test:      js nock  http://www.google.com       .post config.sips.orderInitializeUrl      .delay 2000       .reply 504   Timeout in the chain              Content Type :  plain/text         ;      request server.app .post  /myapi       .set  Accept    application/json       .send            test :  test             .expect  Content Type    plain/text       .expect 599   Timeout while calling google   done ;      But when running this  the 504 error is thrown after 2000ms. The expected behavior is that the 599 error  ETIMEOUT  should be thrown by Request.  Any idea why this is happening ?

title: Alterations to support HTTPS requests in a browser environment when the library is loaded via browserify.
body: The changes are minor and they are related to the fact that browserify does not resolve dynamic paths when building client side browser javascript. So  when modules are loaded using the optional   module  they are loaded dynamically  their names are passed in  so browserify can not resolve the dependencies   since the resolution happens before runtime.   This minor fix uses the process package to determine if the environment running the module is in fact the browser  and if it is  we explicitly import modules rather than using the optional flag.  e.g.  https = optional  https    became:  https = process.browser ? require  https   : optional  https

title: add optional postamble required by .NET multipart requests
body: Provide an option to append a postamble CRLF before the end of a multipart request. Ensures compatibility with C .NET web services.

title: refactor the constructObject helper to use the module soc
body: I took the constructObject pattern and made a module out of it. It is maintained in Livescript  not sure how people feel about having dependencies written in AltJs ;  but I figured I d be upfront about it. Let me know what you guys think.

title: Allow specific headers to be sent exclusively to proxy
body: Sometimes proxy requires specific headers that shouldn t be sent to destination site so it can t detect that it s accessed through proxy. Currently request supports only the opposite behavior  all headers are sent to destination site except as for  Proxy Authorization  header  and only whitelisted are sent to proxy . Would be nice to add this ability  too.

title: refactor the request.js file
body: Here s some initial work on refactoring the request.js file. I added some helper functions  and organized other helper functions. Also cleaned up Request constructor a bit.  Work in progress  feedback would be awesome :

title: 2.42.0 breaks couchapp
body: I haven t fully debugged why this happens  but it is a regression since 2.34.  I haven t bisected yet.  Couchapp does a GET  then a PUT  and then immediately does a GET afterwards to the same url.  For some reason  this is hanging at the second GET.  I see from the  NODE_DEBUG=request  output that it s getting to  self.httpModule.request ..   call in  start     and then the http module is debug outputting  outgoing message end   but then it just sits there doing nothing.  If anyone has any ideas or whats to dig in further  be my guest.  If not  I ll probably get to it eventually.

title: Cannot set timeout.
body: I have been using this code to make a post request and if the response takes more than 2 minutes then I get an error    [Error: socket hang up] code:  ECONNRESET    . But if the timeout is set to less than 2 minutes then the timeout occurs.      var options =       url: https://127.0.0.1:3001       headers: accept:          timeout:900000  ; var r = request.post options function err response body       if err          console.log err ;   ; var form = r.form  ; form.append  xyz   abc  ;      I would like to keep the connection open for more than 2 minutes. Am I doing anything wrong?

title: use Request.abort   to abort the request when the request has timed out
body: This change will affect the behavior of request that has timed out. Now when a user is listening for the error event on a request and that request times out  The error handler will only be called once. The error given to the callback will be the timeout error.  Fixes:  304

   node.exe   c:  Programme  node  node_mo dules  npm  bin  npm cli.js   install   imagemin gifsicle  npm ERR  cwd c: xampp htdocs my tg tooltip npm ERR  node  v v0.10.26 npm ERR  npm  v 1.4.3 npm ERR  code ELIFECYCLE npm ERR  npm ERR  Additional logging details can be found in: npm ERR      c: xampp htdocs my tg tooltip npm debug.log npm ERR  not ok code 0      So I checked my proxy configuration and it looks fine:        npm config get proxy http://iproxy http:8080/      Could it be that the substring  http  in the proxy URL causes a problem in the postinstall script? According to a reply to this ticket  https://github.com/imagemin/imagemin gifsicle/issues/2 issuecomment 55736890  I was told that I should open a ticket here. How can this be fixed?

title: The json option does not work anymore.
body: According to the documentation:  >  json   sets body but to JSON representation of value and adds Content type: application/json header. Additionally  parses the response body as JSON.  This property does not seem to work anymore.  Here is what I experienced:  1  I had an older project where my mikael/request dependency version was just specified as       in package.json 2  Recently I deleted the node_modules folder  did an  npm install  to reinstall all the dependencies  and it pulled in the latest version of request  2.42.0   over the older version that it had before. 3  After the NPM install I noticed that my project was no longer sending JSON bodies with its POST requests as it did before. Instead on the other end of the line the POST requests were coming through with empty bodies. Naturally this broke a lot of things. 4  I was able to get my code working again by changing from using the  json  property to the  body  property.  Example of what I had before which used to work in the older version of request  and which should still work according to the docs:      js     request                  url:  REDACTED           method:  POST           json:             foo:  bar                           function  err  response  body          ;      The above example no longer worked  however changing it to this did work:      js    request                  url:  REDACTED           method:  POST           body:             foo:  bar                           function  err  response  body          ;      In summary it appears that the  json  options longer functions  or has been deprecated.  If this is the case then it should be removed from the documentation in the README since it no longer works. However  if it is intended to work then this would be a bug.

title: Request not working  but http.request does?
body: I m facing an issue with request library. I m trying to send a POST request to a restful server like so: javascript router.post /add function req res var session = req.session; request.post http://localhost:8181/Test/users json: action: add function error response body console.log body ; ; ; And it s not working at all. I m getting in the body a http message saying: > Internal server Error > The server encountered an unexpected condition which prevented it from fulfil > ling the request > You can get technical details here But whenever I try it with http.request it works properly and I get a response which is printed in the console. Why is it? Am I doing something wrong? javascript router.post /add function req res var session = req.session; // We need this to build our post string var querystring = require querystring ; var http = require http ; var fs = require fs ; // Build the post string from an object var post_data = querystring.stringify action : add ; // An object of options to indicate where to post to var post_options = host: localhost port: 8181 path: /Test/users method: POST headers: Content Type : application/x www form urlencoded Content Length : post_data.length ; // Set up the request var post_req = http.request post_options function res res.setEncoding utf8 ; res.on data function chunk console.log Response: chunk ; ; ; // post the data post_req.write post_data ; post_req.end ; ;

title: Specifying form :  ...  as option sends Content Length  but calling .form ...  doesn t
body:
In v2.44.0 it looks like there is a difference between specifying form : ... in options and calling .form : js var request = require request ; require request debug request ; console.log // BEGIN FIRST REQUEST ; request.post http://nylen.tv/test.php form : action : add function err res body console.log // END FIRST REQUEST: err res res.statusCode body n ; console.log // BEGIN SECOND REQUEST ; request.post http://nylen.tv/test.php function err res body console.log // END SECOND REQUEST: err res res.statusCode body ; .form action : add ; ; Output: js // BEGIN FIRST REQUEST request: uri: http://nylen.tv/test.php method: POST headers: host: nylen.tv content type : application/x www form urlencoded; charset=utf 8 content length : 10 body: action=add response: headers: date: Tue 23 Sep 2014 12:31:16 GMT server: Apache/2.4.6 Debian x powered by : PHP/5.5.6 1 content length : 18 keep alive : timeout=5 max=100 connection: Keep Alive content type : text/html statusCode: 200 body:

It works

// END FIRST REQUEST: null 200

It works

// BEGIN SECOND REQUEST request: uri: http://nylen.tv/test.php method: POST headers: host: nylen.tv content type : application/x www form urlencoded; charset=utf 8 body: action=add response: headers: date: Tue 23 Sep 2014 12:31:16 GMT server: Apache/2.4.6 Debian x powered by : PHP/5.5.6 1 content length : 18 keep alive : timeout=5 max=100 connection: Keep Alive content type : text/html statusCode: 200 body:

It works

// END SECOND REQUEST: null 200

It works

Note the missing content type header in the second request.

title: Weird issue with POST transactions using 2.44.0
body: I was slamming my head against the wall for 2 days trying to figure out a very weird issue that started occurring ever since I upgraded to 2.44.0: 1. GET client calls through request to my API work fine 2. Initial POST client calls through request to my API work fine 3. Then after one or two more POST calls using request  the API errors out because the POST payload either doesn t get there at all or only partially gets there and the API has a JSON parse error for the partial JSON message.  I honestly have no idea what is the root cause  but I tried switching back and forth between 2.44.0 and 2.43.0 several times and the issue consistently happens when I am using 2.44.0. Sorry I don t have more info than that  but I can provide any additional information you think would help to debug this.

title: Post encoded form data
body: I d like to perform an HTTP form request where the form body is encoded with ISO 8859 1. However the default encoding is UTF 8.  Is there a way to override the content type header? I am trying to do:  iconv.extendNodeEncodings  ; var buf = new Buffer  n r      paa    binary  ; var options =       url : url      method:  POST       headers :            Content Type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=ISO 8859 1             form :            melding : iconv.encode buf   ISO 8859 10          ;  However  after verifying the package in Wireshark  I see that the post request is still sent with charset= utf 8 .

title: Fix to allow setting a  requester  on recursive calls to  request.defaults
body: Right now in  request.defaults  in checks if the  method === request  to know if it should use the passed in  requester   The issue is that on recursive calls to  request.defaults  the  method  will not  ===  to  request   it will be the function returned from  request.defaults .  This PR changes the check to use  method === self  instead so that you can set a  requester  on recursive calls to request.defaults

title: Support/refactor request constructor
body: This came out of the request refactoring  1071 In this PR I refactored the Request constructor  mostly by extracting logic into separate functions. I also took some initiative to move general helper functions in to the helper file.  Review please: @mikeal @FredKSchott @nylen

title: Resolved issue with argument name in code example
Use strict mode in request
body: Catch a few hidden bugs caused by accidental global variables  and enable strict mode so that bugs like this aren t ever introduced again.  Related:  1103

title: It s time to start linting
body: This project is too big and too important to not have at least basic linting. Adding this will help enforce standards and keep the codebase cleaner  making it easier for people to pull requests and even catch hidden harmful bugs.   I d like to propose the following: 1. [x] People s  run linters themselves to catch some of the more egregious errors/bugs. Create PRs to fix these. 2. [x] Add a linter to the project s devDependencies. Allow anyone to easily run the linter via npm scripts  npm run lint   3. [x] Create a list of linting rules that A  everyone agrees on   B  pass on our codebase     1.  trivial amount of fixup work allowed to get them to pass. If non trivial amount of work is needed  make the rule more lienient and create an issue to address non trivial work in the future  4. [x] Add linting to npm test. Tests won t pass unless the linter passes 5. [x] Start linting the testing directory  non trivial . Once the directory is in a clean state  add auto linting.  For the project linter  I d like to suggest [eslint] http://eslint.org/ . It s actively developed  and the pluggable rules are perfect for an incremental approach to clean up our  currently  messy code base. I ve used it on a few projects now and have only had good experiences with it.  full disclosure: I know   work with it s the creator   Thoughts? /cc @mikeal   literally everyone

title: linting fix: remove unused variables
body: copy  No longer used within index.js  tls  No longer used within index.js  error_connecting  was never used  and seems to have been added by accident here: 54e6dfb77d57757d4006982f813ebaab9e005cd5

title: Impossible if statement?
body: See here: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L278      if   self.uri.host     self.protocol== unix:            self.protocol  will always be a boolean  so   self.protocol== unix:   will always return false  which means this statement has never been entered.  Does anyone have any context here? Happy to fix/remove it otherwise.  Introduced: 54e6dfb77d57757d4006982f813ebaab9e005cd5

title: linting fix: remove function call from if else conditional statement
body: response.resume   was getting called as a part of the conditional check  which was really doing nothing  actually  there s a small chance that  self.response = response  was getting sucked up as the line to be executed only if that else check passed  instead of all the time as intended.

title: linting fix: replace lazy  ==  with more strict  ===
body: Most of these were string comparisons  so the change shouldn t be risky.   The only one I d really liked looked at is https://github.com/FredKSchott/request/compare/mikeal:master...FredKSchott:linting fix eqeqeq?expand=1 diff ccc0734f65dd7a299409ff07d35be095R1267 where we were checking for  null   but it sounds like we really meant to be checking for  undefined . Both passed with the lazy comparison  but now we only check for undefined. If we d like to check for both  lets replace this line with  if   body   instead.

title: add basic linting to request library

You can run this manually via    npm run lint   List of custom rules taken from  1106  based on proposal and comments.  Changes and bikeshedding still allowed and even encouraged  Check http://eslint.org/docs/rules/ for any rules you d like to see added as well that aren t enabled by default   /cc @mikeal @nylen   everyone else

title: Let s spend this money :

It s probably best to hand this over to all the contributors since I m a giant bottleneck on this.

title: Integrate node request retry?
body: I ve been looking for a way to retry failed requests without needing to manually do it for every request  and I came across [node request retry] https://github.com/FGRibreau/node request retry   which seems to do exactly that. The problem is that using it means I m limited to whatever version of request is shipped with the library  which isn t great. It s MIT licensed  so can consideration be given to integrating this functionality into request  maybe contacting the author first ? It d be a useful feature and the code s already written.

title: Lint: catch spaces in function declarations and calls
body: We have inconsistent spacing for defining functions:      js var x = function      ...  ; // 1st style // or var x = function     ...  ; // 2nd style          js function x      ...   // 1st style // or function x     ...   // 2nd style      @seanstrom and I agree that the second style is preferable.  There s an eslint rule [ no spaced func ] http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no spaced func.html  that handles spaces in function calls  but not declarations.  Also see eslint/eslint 1340.  Also see previous discussion towards the end of the thread at  1103.

title: added tests around using objects as values in a query string
body: I was curious how request encoded:      javascript       request.get           url:  http://    host    :    port    /user           json: true          qs:            where:   foo:  bar                       function  err  resp  body            return done  ;         ;      And:      javascript       request.get           url:  http://    host    :    port    /user           json: true          qs:            order: [ foo    bar ]                    function  err  resp  body            return done  ;         ;      So I put some tests around it.

body: @coolaj86 does this help?  re:  1084

title: Correct infinite loop with the same location
body: The issue is apparent when loading from Google Drive  e.g.  https://dd7777360edd06ed6fa7cbc0725dbd736cbda015.googledrive.com/host/0B9Vee7pZ81xmUzBqUmluT3FWVkU/my.js  . The root cause is that the  304 Not Modified  responds with a location header  which results in an infinite loop to the same url. This patch only does a redirect now if the url has changed.

title: Multipart deletes part.body
body: AFAICT there isn t a reason to delete the part s  body  during multipart processing  an unfortunate side effect.  https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/7d30d64deb45083288c0cc411e2c1a0cc216d8ea/request.js L1241

title: Fix multiple redirects and  self.followRedirect
body: Currently when a redirect occurs  the  self.init  function is being run. However  since it s already been run on the initial execution  the original value for  self.followRedirect  has been lost. This means the custom function for  self.allowRedirect  will only ever work on the first redirect and not subsequent redirects.

title: Add ability to specifiy querystring lib in options.
body: Add the ability to specify whether qs or querystring should be used for parsing and stringifying by passing a useQuerystring boolean option. Fixes  644.  Has been addressed earlier in https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/847 and will now merge cleanly.

title: allow hostname and port in place of host on uri
body: This is an issue I noticed in 2.45.0 that was not present in 2.44.0. I passed in a URL of this format:          hostname:  whatever.com     port: 8080    path:  /something    protocol:  http:         It fails [here] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L246   in this block:        if   self.uri.host    self.uri.protocol  ==  unix:         // Invalid URI: it may generate lot of bad errors  like  TypeError: Cannot call method  indexOf  of undefined  in CookieJar     // Detect and reject it as soon as possible     var faultyUri = url.format self.uri      var message =  Invalid URI      faultyUri           if  Object.keys options .length === 0          // No option ? This can be the sign of a redirect       // As this is a case where the user cannot do anything  they didn t call request directly with this URL        // they should be warned that it can be caused by a redirection  can save some hair        message  =  . This can be caused by a crappy redirection.            // This error was fatal     return self.emit  error   new Error message            But based on [node s URL format] http://nodejs.org/api/url.html url_url_format_urlobj   using  hostname  and  port  should be an acceptable alternative to using  host .  This is easy enough to work around by formatting the url before passing it in  but this pull request resolves the issue and passes unit tests. Happy to rework it if there are any issues.

title: Question about Error: reqgetaddrinfo ENOTFOUND on request.post
body: I m encountering intermittent errors using request.post to an api endpoint  not google.com  running on Linux.       js    var request = require  request  ;    var postBody = someJson;    var myServer =  http:/someURL/api/test ;    request.post       uri: myServer      body: postBody      function error  response  body          if  response    response.statusCode === 201             successCallback  do something  ;               if  error            logger.log  error    Unsuccessful Post:    error ;         ;      Occasionally I m seeing an error  Unsuccessful Post: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND   In a stack overflow post http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17690803/node js getaddrinfo enotfound with a similar error yuxhuang mentions this documentation for Node http://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_http_request_options_callback   If no  response  handler is added  then the response will be entirely discarded. However  if you add a  response  event handler  then you must consume the data from the response object  either by calling response.read   whenever there is a  readable  event  or by adding a  data  handler  or by calling the .resume   method. Until the data is consumed  the  end  event will not fire. Also  until the data is read it will consume memory that can eventually lead to a  process out of memory  error.    It doesn t seem like I need to do anything with body for a post if all I care about is the response.statusCode is 200 or not.  I was wondering how the request package handles the response  if I should be handling this differently or if this is just an intermittent issue with bad connections.  Any help on this would be very appreciated  its not a frequent error  but this post is a critical part of the code I m working on.  Otherwise  this package is working great.  Thanks   Laura

title: Rewrite all tests to use tape
body: As discussed at  1003  migrate tests to use @substack s [ tape ] https://github.com/substack/tape  testing framework which outputs [ tap ] http://testanything.org/ .  This is a massive PR  but I hope it can be reviewed and merged quickly because:   We badly need to move away from the ad hoc testing structure we have now.  In the process of rewriting the tests I found a lot of instances where tests were not being called or were not working as expected.   This will go stale pretty quickly if it s not merged.   It was a lot of work on my end.  For pretty reporting  I m using [ taper ] https://github.com/nylen/taper   a project I found  forked  and fixed up.  It s not perfect  but I couldn t find an existing tap reporter that met my wishlist:   Clean  concise  preferably colored output  with clear indications of where errors occur   Test file timeout support   this is crucial for tape because it s easy to forget to end a test properly  and when this happens they just hang.  You can see what the output looks like:   [when all tests pass] https://travis ci.org/nylen/request/jobs/37699501    [when some of them fail] https://travis ci.org/nylen/request/jobs/37697054 .  This should also help with the intermittent build failures we ve been seeing on Travis.  For example  [this job output] https://travis ci.org/nylen/request/jobs/37698924  gives more clues as to the problem with  test timeout.js .  I also cleaned up any code style issues that stood out to me  so we should be well positioned to start linting the test directory as a next step.  I ll be around to help address any follow up issues.

title: Request.init    Refactor Proposal
body: I was about to post this in  1094  but decided not to pollute the overall restructuring conversation going on there.   Another thing at the top of my Refactoring Christmas list is to move the user provided request options off of the Request instance itself. Right now everything is thrown onto the request instance  and then some are set with defaults while others are not. This  processing the options  logic is then mixed with the  setting up the request based on options  logic in the  init    method. This makes it hard when reading the code  especially when tracing different request properties through the life of the request.  Here s what I m imagining:      javascript Request = function  options      // set defaults and otherwise process user given options into an expected object format   options = processOptions options ;    // initialize with expected options object   this.init options ;   // set options onto instance for later methods / the public to access   self.options = options;    Request.prototype.init = function  options      // Use the options object itself for everything   if  options.proxy        self.setupTunnel         // etc...        This would reduce the size of the large  init    method  currently at  500 lines  by removing everything not related to the actual request initialization.   Thoughts? @mikeal @seanstrom @nylen   anyone else

title: jQuery.ajax   from jsdom using accept encoding: gzip deflate?
body: I am currently using jsdom xmlhttprequest but am limited in what I can do with accept encoding. I am hoping to receive gzip d response bodies from within jsdom in a jQuery.ajax   call. I am sharing code across browser and server so the advantages of having a pluggable xhr object are huge for me. But it seems as though neither jsdom nor xmlhttprequest are picking up the duties of inflating deflated content. I noticed that with the native zlib node module and request.pipe   it s possible but it looks to me like I would have to modify my code to use straight  .ajax   in the browser but on the server use request.pipe  ? Has anyone else come across and solved this problem?

title: Remove UNIX Socket URL Validation
body: In  516   UNIX Socket URL Support  added support for the  unix://  protocol  which allowed developers to make requests locally  like so:  request.get  unix://tmp/unix.socket/httppath     This feature is neat  but it comes at a cost: asynchronous initialization. since that PR  request objects are be created but not fully initialized until nextTick  for the unix case  sometimes even a full second later . This is because request was validating the full unix URI before continuing with initialization. Because it wasn t sure where the path started and the socket began  it would attempt to connect to each different combination until one succeeded.  This is completely unnecessary  bordering on ridiculous. Instead of validating the route  why not just add an option to do:           unix:        path:  /foo/bar        socket:  /absolute/path/to/socket             Regressions:   No longer automatically parse a  unix://  URI  Improvements:   Reduce  init   / request  by 100  lines   Make  init    synchronous again  and removing the half initialized state on construction   Improve performance on  unix://  URIs   Bring  _buildRequest    back into  init     having both is confusing   The best part is  automatic parsing can still be done in a separate module outside of request  so nothing is really lost.  Thoughts?   /cc @mikeal @seanstrom @nylen @emkay

:wave: I don t have a unit test for this one but here is how I system tested it js request.post https://api.mailgun.net/v2/[your domain].mailgun.org/messages auth: user: api pass: apikey headers: content type : multipart/form data formData: from: request@mailinator.com to: request@mailinator.com subject: Multiple Attachments html:

Awesome

text: True idd attachment:[fs.createReadStream cat.png fs.createReadStream coffee.png ] function err res body ; The result is an email with two attachments to it [Mailgun Sending] http://documentation.mailgun.com/api sending.html sending > attachment File attachment. You can post multiple attachment values. Important: You must use multipart/form data encoding when sending attachments. Same thing with Sendgrid [Sendgrid Sending] https://sendgrid.com/docs/API_Reference/Web_API/mail.html > files Files to be attached. The file contents must be part of the multipart HTTP POST. Ex: files[file1.jpg]=file1.jpg [file2.pdf]=file2.pdf Now when I think about it why is the headers: content type : multipart/form data not set by default when the formData key is present?

title: Stream multipart/related bodies
body: :wave:   Related to this one https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/1181  My test case      js request.post  https://www.googleapis.com/upload/drive/v2/files       qs:      access_token: ...       uploadType: multipart         multipart: [              Content Type : application/json         body: JSON.stringify           title: cat.png                               Content Type : image/png         body: fs.createReadStream  cat.png           ]    function  err  res  body     ;      Basically I m using the same module that _form data_ uses internally   https://github.com/felixge/node combined stream  Google [implements] https://github.com/google/google api nodejs client/blob/master/lib/apirequest.js L142 L181  their  multipart/related  support in much the same way  using [multipart stream] https://github.com/hendrikcech/multipart stream  which in turn uses [sandwich stream] https://github.com/connrs/node sandwich stream

title: Support Smarter Unix URL Scheme
body: A part of  1146  Request.init    Refactor Fixes  1166    No longer validate UNIX URLs by attempting to connect to every possible combination of hosts and paths   Now possible to bring  _buildRequest    logic back into the  init    method  So I went the  smarter URL scheme  route  and more or less copied the work done in ngx_http_proxy_module. We now use the URL scheme   http://unix:SOCKET:PATH  . No new option required  and the change is much less severe. It also makes more sense  since these requests were already using the http protocol behind the scenes.      OLD: request.get  unix://absolute/path/to/unix.socket/request/path   NEW: request.get  http://unix:/absolute/path/to/unix.socket:/request/path        An error is thrown if you use the old format.  /cc @mikeal   everyone from  1166

title: Tweaks to no_proxy support
body: I was really hoping this PR would make it so that  npm  would honor  no_proxy : https://github.com/mikeal/request/pull/1096  Unfortunately it doesn t yet  even though  npm@2.1.5  includes  request@2.45.0   which has the PR. It appears a few things need to happen for full  no_proxy  support in npm: 1.  npm  needs to no longer set a proxy setting on request objects. See issue  https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/6524 2.  npm request client  should bump to  request@2.45.0 . See issue https://github.com/npm/npm registry client/issues/75 3.  request  needs to be tweaked to support  self.proxy === undefined . See below.  The problem is that none of the no_proxy logic in  request  will be executed if the  self.proxy  property exists  even if the value is  undefined . Here s the current code:      if  self.hasOwnProperty  proxy           This means any consuming packages have to actually delete the proxy property instead of just setting it to  undefined  or  null . You can see this code here: https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L357  Is there a reason to not use  if   self.proxy    ? I d be happy to submit a pull request  but wasn t sure if there was some other reason for using  hasOwnProperty .  I m suggesting this because when the default proxy settings in  npm  are removed   1 above   request objects appear to be created with  proxy=undefined . This causes the no_proxy logic to be skipped.

title: Use no_proxy when self.proxy is falsey
body: When  self.proxy === undefined  or  self.proxy === null   the no_proxy logic is not executed. Change test to look for falsey value of  self.proxy  instead of existence of property.  See https://github.com/mikeal/request/issues/1194 for more details.

title: Moving to the request org
body: This has come up a few times but I m ready to pull the trigger if none of the contributors disagree.  There s already a bunch of request dependencies that lack the contributors we have here. I d like to move in a direction where _more_ of request is broken in to modules we depend on which will only exacerbate this problem.  I ve gone ahead and moved all the current deps I own there and added all the contributors from this repo. I can move this repo tomorrow if nobody thinks this idea is terrible :

If I set timeout at a low value  for instance 1  and I request to a slow server  my node app colapses.      javascript stream.js:94       throw er; // Unhandled stream error in pipe.             ^ Error: ETIMEDOUT     at null._onTimeout  /home/user/NetBeansProjects/myApp/node_modules/request/request.js:713:15      at Timer.listOnTimeout [as ontimeout]  timers.js:112:15       Is it me not handling the error correctly?  This is my code:      javascript app.all  /passthrough/   function  req  res    var options =       url: req.query.q      headers:            User Agent :  my app header               timeout: 1   ;  var request = require  request  ;  var x = request options ;  req.pipe x ;  x.pipe res ;      ;

title: Changelog requires manual work :
body: Looks like there used to be a [CHANGELOG] https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md  that is no longer maintained. To save ourselves from this immense shame  we should probably do one of the following: 1. Remove it 2. Add a  Deprecated: see commitlog for list of changes  message to the top 3. Auto generate it as a part of the release script  something [like this] http://shelljs recipes.tumblr.com/post/95110327624/generating a changelog   4. Manually update it as a responsibility of the releaser 5. After release  create an issue ticket to manually update changelog 6. Some combination of the above  3   4 together   auto generate and then manually clean  up/prune   could be powerful   Thoughts? /cc @mikeal @nylen @seanstrom @simov

title: 2.46.0 Host header causes crash
body: I often make requests to servers that expect uppercase host header. I don t control these servers so I work around the issue by setting a capitalized Host header in request. This used to work but started failing in version 2.46.0:      js var request = require  request  ;  request     uri:  https://www.github.com/     headers:   Host:  www.github.com       function  err  res      if  err  return console.log err.stack ;   console.log res.statusCode ;   ;      This crashes with:      /var/www/node_modules/request/request.js:1195         if  self.uri.hostname  == self.originalHost.split  :  [0]                                                        ^ TypeError: Cannot call method  split  of undefined     at Request.onRequestResponse  /var/www/node_modules/request/request.js:1195:53      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:95:17      at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient [as onIncoming]  http.js:1692:21      at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete [as onHeadersComplete]  http.js:121:23      at Socket.socketOnData [as ondata]  http.js:1587:20      at TCP.onread  net.js:527:27       Actually I d prefer to be able to just  define  the Host header with uppercase and it being filled by request. That would work better with the way options flow through my program structure. Would that be a possible feature you d consider?      js request     uri:  https://www.github.com/     headers:   Host:         function  err  res      // ...   ;

title: Allow  Host  header instead of  host  and remember case across redirects
body: As of v2.46.0  because of  1184  we get a crash when the user specifies    headers : Host    and a redirect occurs.  This fixes  1210  see that issue for details.  We should also preserve the case of the header name if the user specifies  Host   because lots of  broken  servers expect the header name to be  Host  and not  host   and this has been an issue for a lot of people:   346   406   411   426   430   990   1210.  Needs review @mikeal @FredKSchott @seanstrom @tbuchok and anyone else.  The test especially is a little hairy  so I m definitely open to better ways of doing it.

title: Remove cruft left over from optional dependencies
body: Now that tough cookie is always installed we can remove a few things.

title: Add proxyHeaderExclusiveList option for proxy only headers.
body: Fixes  1070 by adding  proxyHeaderExclusiveList  for list of headers that should be sent exclusively to proxy in tunnel mode.  This also simplifies handling of  Proxy Authorization  by avoiding old flow where: 1  header was firstly removed in any case and temporarily stored to inner property; 2  when in tunnel mode  it was added back to  proxyHeaders  hash; 3  when not in tunnel mode  it was added back to regular  headers  where it was firstly removed from.  Now any header from  proxyHeaderExclusiveList   incl.  Proxy Authorization   goes through simpler flow: 1  if in tunnel mode  move it from regular  headers  to  proxyHeaders ; 2  that s it :P  So it covers the same flow that  Proxy Authorization  had  and at the same time gives ability to extend list with custom proxy only headers.  Incorporates  1028 and  1050.

title: Made json and multipart options coexist
body: Simply made the behavior of combining the options more consistent. For example I can have  json  option and  formData  option coexist  in other words getting the JSON parsed body in the callback and stuff like that.  Currently that s not possible for the  multipart  option  and if the only reason for this if/else https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L577 L582 was to make the header check inside the multipart method works https://github.com/mikeal/request/blob/master/request.js L1420 L1425 I m fixing that

title: Added check for originalHost before splitting
body: I encountered an issue when following all redirects on a request:  ../node_modules/request/request.js:1195         if  self.uri.hostname  == self.originalHost.split  :  [0]                                                        ^ TypeError: Cannot call method  split  of undefined     at Request.onRequestResponse  ../node_modules/request/request.js:1195:53      at ClientRequest.EventEmitter.emit  events.js:95:17      at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient [as onIncoming] http.js:1688:21      at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete [as onHeadersComplete] http.js:121:23      at Socket.socketOnData [as ondata] http.js:1583:20      at TCP.onread  net.js:527:27   Upon further debugging  it appeared that self.originalHost was undefined at one point in the series of redirects  a simple check for self.originalHost seems to have resolved this issue.

body: forever  isn t mentioned anywhere it the readme  but it looks like a  forever    method and a  forever  option both exist.  1. Does the  forever  options still work properly? Is it deprecated? It looks like we re using  Connection: keep alive  by default  but the ForeverAgent seems to add some extra  free sockets  logic on top. But I ve tried performance testing with forever on and off  and I don t see a difference in performance between the two. 2. Is the  forever    method doing anything other than calling  request.defaults    with forever: true? There s no real reason to have this one option get a special method  we should deprecate it with a message to use  request.defaults    instead.  @ everyone  any ideas?
