title: Support for oauth with RSA SHA1 signing
body: This is  1042   tests and docs  and also a change to use the  private_key  OAuth parameter for RSA SHA1 signing instead of the  consumer_secret  parameter which is used for HMAC SHA1 signing.  Per [the RFC] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5849 section 3.4.2  this is correct.  @FredKSchott @mikeal or anyone else: review please?  Also  here are a couple of test scripts against http://oauthbin.com/ that give me confidence that this works correctly:  https://gist.github.com/nylen/639ef899d9964cb2957c

title: Cover in README how to allow  ca s for self signed certificates
body: The README currently covers how to make a request where the local part is required to have a certificate.  It does not cover how to allow requests to domains using certificates signed by a certain certificate authority that is not generally recognized.  This is a fairly common use case  as applications can come pre packaged with CAs to accept  hence not needing to look up CAs online.  I wrote this answer to a questiong regarding the same thing: http://stackoverflow.com/a/26629402/1080564

title: Feature request:  body  event
body: I like the structure of making requests like this:      js request.get  http://localhost/  .on  error   function  error      // process error   .on  response   function  response      // process response    response.on  data   /  data listener  / .on  end   /  end listener  / ;   ;      While I have to write multiple requests in a single file  for some testing purposes  I don t really like to listen to  data  /  end  events of the response  I would like to add to the request s chain a listener for the  body  event which would serve the full body of the response. So essentially I want this to be implemented:      js request.get  http://localhost/  .on  body   function  body      // process body   ;      If it looks ok from the point of view of the module s owner I could contribute with a PR.

title: Request with interval   eventually produces ESOCKETTIMEDOUT and ECONNRESET
body: I have a persistent process that goes off and crawls urls every X minutes.       node v0.10.33 request 2.44.0 ubuntu 14.04 on EC2 uname  a Linux ip myip 3.13.0 37 generic  64 Ubuntu SMP Mon Sep 22 21:28:38 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux      I get into this state periodically where all my requests get ESOCKETTIMEDOUT and ECONNRESET errors. Also when it gets into this state  my tcp connections for node process is stuck at only 13 established  these are my mongodb connections :      lsof  p 9514   grep TCP   wc  l 13      If I restart node things go back to normal  for a while .  The lsof command goes up and down as expected  until issue is hit again.  This is the block of code that is called via  interval         var separateReqPool =  maxSockets: 100         reqObj =               pool: separateReqPool              uri: feed.feedUrl              headers:   User Agent  :  Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8  AppleWebKit/537.13   KHTML  like Gecko  Version/5.1.7 Safari/534.57.2                timeout: 5000              jar: false              maxRedirects: 5              strictSSL: false        ;      request reqObj  function error           if error               cfg.logger.error  ERR: bad request:   error  error ;                          .on  response   function response               ...                    .on  error   function error               cfg.logger.error  ERR:   error  error ;                    .on  end   function                cfg.logger.info  feed pull complete     feed.feedUrl ;                       ;      Any ideas? thanks in advance.

title: Weird issue with setting and not setting headers option
body: Hi Guys   I m new to nodejs and I have encountered a weird issue that doesn t make sense to me. This is in relation to the character encoding I m receiving which affects some special characters. Specifically the  content type  in response.headers. Basically if I specify the headers option I will get UTF8 result if not I will get ISO 8859 1. Though the only option I have set in headers is user agent and I haven t specify encoding. See code below:      var headers =        user agent  :  Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8  AppleWebKit/537.13   KHTML  like Gecko  Version/5.1.7 Safari/534.57.2      var siteURL =  http://www.google.com.ph   // This one returns result charset as ISO 8859 1 var requestOptions1 =   encoding: null  uri: siteURL   request requestOptions1  function  error  response  body        console.log  Header not set:    response.headers ;   ;  // This one returns result charset as UTF8 var requestOptions2 =   encoding: null  uri: siteURL  headers: headers   request requestOptions2  function  error  response  body        console.log  Header is set:    response.headers ;   ;      The issue here is that the two code renders different results with characters displayed in browser as ?. I have tried with and without iconv lite and it seems correct characters will be shown without iconv lite by just specifying headers in request option  even though setting the headers option not related to encoding fixes the issue. Can someone explain what s happening here?  Thanks guys

title: Using a default cookie jar is broken.
body: Seems ilke cookies don t work if only set via  defaults .      var request = require  request  ; var tough = require  tough cookie  ;  var jar = request.jar  ; request.defaults   jar: jar   ;  console.log jar ; // Check contents of jar. Empty.  // Visit page that should create some cookie. request.get  url: http://www.google.com        function error  httpResponse  body            if error                console.error error ;           else               console.log httpResponse.headers ; // Notice  set cookie  header.             console.log jar ; // Check contents of jar. Still empty.                  ;      However  if you change this line:  request.get  url: http://www.google.com     to this instead:  request.get  url: http://www.google.com   jar:jar    then cookies are properly set in  jar .

title: Require npm version which supports  ^  specifier
body: The only problem in [this error] https://travis ci.org/request/request/builds/38507557  is that npm v1.2 doesn t support  ^  version specifier. It s not the problem of Node v0.8 itself. So I added  before_install  command to install the latest version of npm before installing the dependencies of request.   This change requires the users of this module to use npm >= 1.4.3. So I updated [ engines ] https://www.npmjs.org/doc/files/package.json.html engines  in package.json and added [ engineStrict ] https://www.npmjs.org/doc/files/package.json.html enginestrict  field.  After merging this PR  we can also merge  1189 without dropping Node v0.8 support.

title: Tunnel mode host header inconsistent
body: If I use tunnel mode  and want to connect to host https://xyz:8443  then the http CONNECT header contains:  CONNECT xyz:8443 HTTP/1.1 host: xyz:443 Connection: close  The authority in the request line  xyz:8443  and the host header  xyz:443  should match. Code is not taking custom port into account setting host line.

title: Tunnel mode proxyHeaderWhiteList and proxyHeaderExclusiveList must be lowercase
body: When using proxyHeaderWhiteList and proxyHeaderExclusiveList members of the list must be in lowercase or they are not honoured. This should either be documented or fixed to not require specific case.

My expertise is limited  I hope this makes sense.  Thanks

title: maxSockets does not limit the number of socket connections
body: Hi folks   I am trying to use  pool  maxSockets: 100    to increase the default  maxSockets  number. I find that once I set  pool  in the option  no matter what value you give to  maxSocket   it seems always enable maxSockets to be  Infinity .  My local test:      coffee    index.coffee restify = require  restify  client  = require  ./client   server = restify.createServer    server.get  /test   client.send  server.listen 8080      > console.log  server started            coffee    client.coffee  request = require  request   exports.send =  req  res  next   >   options =     url:  https://google.com.au      strictSSL: true     secureProtocol: true     pool:        maxSockets: 5    request options   err  response  body   >     res.send 200  body      so if you  npm start  and go to  localhost:8080/test   you would send a get request to  https://google.com.au   Now I use the performance tool  wrk  to run this test:  wrk  t12  c3000  d30s http://127.0.0.1:8080/test   which initiates 12 threads to create 3000 connections and last 30 seconds.  Next get the  ip  of google.com.au by  host google.com.au  and I get:      google.com.au has address 74.125.237.111 google.com.au has address 74.125.237.127 google.com.au has address 74.125.237.120 google.com.au has address 74.125.237.119      Then in the console I do   watch  netstat  an   grep 74.125   wc  l   From the output I can see there are always hundreds of socket connections opening  no matter what value I give  maxSockets . But If I don t set  pool :   maxSockets: xxx   in the  options   I will only see around 10 opening sockets from console.  Is my way of using  maxSockets  correct? Do I miss something here?  Thanks

title: Add multipart chunked flag
body: Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1243  That s just to show up the idea from my last comment. Basically I m bringing back the code from v2.46 and I m introducing a flag so that both implementations can exist together.  I m proposing this syntax for non chunked/streamed multipart/related bodies      js multipart:     data: []   // in place of the default one multipart: []      Obviously that s ugly  but I can t think of anything more reasonable at this point. Once we agree on the syntax I ll add tests for it.

title: Easy header overrides for simple passthru
body: Currently the request.get url .pipe response  style of passing data is easy to use  but if any headers from the initial URL need to be accessed or modified  the ease of use breaks down.  There is a whitelist for proxy headers  but it seems there could be one for normal requests as well.

title: Get status code without using Node response stream
body: I want to get the status code of the response  given this code:      js /  jshint esnext: true  / var r = request  http://csswizardy.net/     gzip: true        .on  error   reject      .on  readable      =>           // How to get status code now?         var responseBody = r.read  .toString  ;       ;      AFAIU  it s only possible to get the response status code by reading the response stream in the  response  event. However  I want to read the response using the initial request stream as above  because this supports decompression of gzip.  IRC  content is not decompressed on the gzip stream because it is just a copy of Node s internal response stream.

title: Combination of using .form with a string will result in a missing content length header
body: request  api   callback .form  foo=bar        Will result in a missing content length in the request headers and thus in a chunked request. This is not expected behaviour because adding a body at another time will add in the content length.

title: Can t handle InvalidUri when on streaming mode
body: When I do a request on streaming mode. That is  i don t pass a callback to the request function  it doesn t seem possible to handle InvalidURI errors.  By code inspection  of the Request.init method  you can see:      javascript   if   self.uri.host    self.uri.protocol  ==  unix:         // Invalid URI: it may generate lot of bad errors  like  TypeError: Cannot call method  indexOf  of undefined  in CookieJar     // Detect and reject it as soon as possible     var faultyUri = url.format self.uri      var message =  Invalid URI      faultyUri           if  Object.keys options .length === 0          // No option ? This can be the sign of a redirect       // As this is a case where the user cannot do anything  they didn t call request directly with this URL        // they should be warned that it can be caused by a redirection  can save some hair        message  =  . This can be caused by a crappy redirection.            // This error was fatal     return self.emit  error   new Error message            The code detects the error and does an emit   of it. But  since this is part of the initialization process  we haven t yet had the possibility to register an on  error   handler. Something like this:      javascript request  a bad uri  .on  error   errorHandler       Our errorHandler won t be registered since the error emision happens before the .on   call. So  the default error handler takes control and it crashes.  The only error handler present at that moment  is the one is set within the Request.init method for the callback sent on the request   call. So this  works ok:      javascript request  a bad uri   callback       The problem is  that if i do this  the response body will be buffered  and that s not desirable in my case.  My diagnosis  might be incorrect  and I might be missing something here  sorry about that. But if I m correct  this problem is also true for every detected error within the  init    method  before the process.nextTick at the end.  A Probable fix would be to delay all error emision to the process.nextTick at the end of init  . I can do that and send the pull request  but i m not sure if it would break something else. Let me know

title: Stream multipart/related is broken: missing chunked encoding for default  GET  method.
body: Issue  1185 implemented  multipart/related  stream support even for streams of unknown length. This means using HTTP  Transfer Encoding: chunked  because the other transfer encoding  the default one  requires setting the  Content Length  header beforehand.  HTTP chunked encoding is _not_ implemented in current  request  master: Using wireshark I see that currently neither the  content length  nor the  transfer encoding: chunked  is set. The combined stream is part of the solution  but it needs to be piped to a chunk encoder before sending it to the socket. I don t know what can be done by node.js itself  with its http module .  This means that current multipart/related requests are broken HTTP requests since  request  2.47.0.  Tested with node v0.10.18   v0.10.33 on 2.48.0   current master   I don t understand how and why for some people it did send chunked encoded requests  it seems to be the case here:  1243 .

title: Enable non object JSON bodies
body: Updated JSON requests so they can contain bodies that are not objects

title: Multipart Improvements
body: After I changed the behavior of the multipart API in https://github.com/request/request/pull/1185 a few issues popped out because of it: https://github.com/request/request/issues/1243 fixed here https://github.com/request/request/pull/1253  then https://github.com/request/request/issues/1271 fixed here https://github.com/request/request/pull/1276 so I thought we could handle that in a better way.    Detect body streams  This one overrides the rest of the options. In case the user set a stream as the body value  then chunked encoding will be used and all of the data will be piped with combined stream.  The detection for a stream is here https://github.com/simov/request/blob/e74000d7ed82e293e46e7a8bce167eae144873ca/request.js L1442 L1444   no idea if that s a reliable solution   or not  .  Essentially this case will allow existing clients to continue to work without any changes  in other words this fixes the introduced breaking change for CouchDB users and possibly others as well.    Always chunked  By setting the  transfer encoding: chunked   header explicitly you get the expected behavior from it   request will be chunked and body parts will be piped   always  .    Using multipart object options  Having the object option here is good in case we want to add more features to it  or extract this API into a separate module. The  chunked  option here overrides the  transfer encoding: chunked   header  if set   also the detection of body streams is still viable here.

title: v2.46.0 can t open as many parallel requests
body: After upgrading to v2.46.0  I noticed that the request library can t open as many requests in parallel as before. The issue appears to stem from the change in  1168 to change the  process.nextTick  call into a  setImmediate  call. This change seems like it will generally make the request library less aggressive in hogging the event loop  which is probably a good thing  but if you re actually trying to achieve high levels of request concurrency  it seems to prevent that. Now  despite the lower concurrency  there isn t a huge performance difference between the approaches  although it does seem like the library is marginally slower when using  setImmediate  with a bunch of parallel requests.  My use case might not be very common  but why I care about the request concurrency is that I m using the request library inside an integration test that performs parallel requests against a server. The test is trying to check rate limits and concurrency limits on the HTTP server  so this is why I noticed the reduced concurrency  since the tests are no longer able to achieve the levels of concurrency we re trying to test .  I m not sure what the best solution is here  but would there be any interest in a pull request to make this configurable  so you could pick whether you wanted to use  setImmediate  or  process.nextTick  for the  defer  behavior ? Because it seems like  setImmediate  might be the right call in most cases  but if you re actually trying to achieve higher levels of concurrency  then it seems like you have to use  process.nextTick . Or is there maybe some other way I m missing to achieve high concurrency levels with  setImmediate ?  I ve put together a little example of a server and client to demonstrate the changes in behavior caused by this between v2.45.0 and v2.46.0:    server.js        js var http = require  http  ; var server = http.createServer function req  res      res.writeHead 200     Content Type :  text/plain    ;   res.end  Hello World n  ;   ; server.listen 8099   127.0.0.1  ;  var openConnections = 0; var maxOpenConnections = 0; server.on  connection   function socket      openConnections  ;   if openConnections > maxOpenConnections        maxOpenConnections = openConnections;        socket.on  close   function         openConnections  ;     ;   ;  setInterval function       console.info  maxOpenConnections:     maxOpenConnections ;    1000 ;        client.js        js var async = require  async        request = require  request  ;  var options =     pool:       maxSockets: 500        ;  var start = Date.now   async.times 250  function index  callback      request.get  http://127.0.0.1:8099/   options  function error  response        callback error ;     ;    function       console.info  Finished. Took:      Date.now     start     ms  ;   ;      Steps to reproduce:   Run the server.js file. This server just keeps track of the maximum number of concurrent open connections and prints it out every second.   While the server is running as a separate process  run the client.js. This attempts to open 250 parallel requests to the server and prints how long it took to execute all of them.  Prior to  1168:   The server reports  maxOpenConnections: 250  meaning that all 250 of the parallel requests were at least connected to the server at one time.   On 3 test runs  the client reports execution times of 210ms  214ms  and 212ms  After  1168:   The server reports  maxOpenConnections: 17  meaning at no point were more than 17 concurrent connections actually established to the server.   On 3 test runs  the client reports execution times of 232ms  233ms  and 236ms

title: Update README.md to explain custom file use case
body: Add documentation to indicate a use case for custom file values and options in multipart form data requests.   The added sentence may have saved my team a few hours.  Our specific use case:   We wanted to receive uploaded files and send them directly to an external service without allowing the files to be written to disk.   Because we were uploading a file from a stream  we needed to add custom file related information in our request to the external service.

title: client side certificate doc mistake
body: There is a mistake in the documentation on how to use client side certificate. The cert  key and passphrase should be given to the  options  object and not to the agentOptions.  I also created a pull request for this: https://github.com/request/request/pull/1289  I didn t touch the SSLV3 paramters inside the agentOptions  so please also verify if this is the correct place for it.  I hope this helps.

title: Disable HTTP tunneling for all protocols
body: From the docs:     tunnel     If  true   then   always   use a tunneling proxy. If  false   default   then tunneling will only be used if the   destination is https  or if a previous request in the redirect chain used a tunneling proxy.  What if I need to use a proxy that doesn t support tunneling to make a   https   request?  Shouldn t this module have an option to completely disable tunneling for all protocols?

title: getProxyFromURI might return false positive on detecting no proxy element
body: request.js:201 204      noProxyItem = noProxyItem.replace /^ . /   .   if  hostname.indexOf noProxyItem  === hostname.length   noProxyItem.length               return null                 when  hostname.length   noProxyItem.length  equals  1  this code actually do the opposite of what is wanted.

title: fix proxy : no proxy false positive
body: If one of the no proxy item is exactly one character longer than the request URL  it was considered as a valid match for no proxy case detection.  This patch handle the special   1  value to close issue  1294.

title: Post file in Body has issue: Fixed
body: Hi Team   I found an issue when you posting file into Body json  its converting Buffer data into String  so I have fixed that issue  Below is the code:      Request.prototype.json = function  val      var self = this   if   self.hasHeader  accept          self.setHeader  accept    application/json          self._json = true   if  typeof val ===  boolean         if  typeof self.body ===  object           self.body = safeStringify self.body        if   self.hasHeader  content type              self.setHeader  content type    application/json                     else       //Neelesh Fix     if Buffer.isBuffer val         self.body = val;     else       self.body = safeStringify val ;     if   self.hasHeader  content type            self.setHeader  content type    application/json                return self

title: Cast timeout to a number.
body: This creates consistency in the timeout feature.  The  setTimeout  implementation in node will correctly cast any strings passed in to a number using   = 1   This means that       js request     uri:  /foo     timeout:  5000     cb ;      will work as expected.    HOWEVER   the  req.setTimeout  method does not cast strings to number. It instead defaults to no timeout when passed a string.   To guard against this bug in node core we manually cast the string to a number in  request/request  itself so that it is consistent.

title: Error handler should pass the requested uri in the error message when request fails completely
body: For those times when fe. there are connection issues on either end and request fails completely then all you get is this...        [Error: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND] code:  ENOTFOUND   errno:  ENOTFOUND   syscall:  getaddrinfo         ...and stack like this  which at least could be fixed with firing custom error when request gives out error ...      Error: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND     at errnoException  dns.js:37:11      at Object.onanswer [as oncomplete]  dns.js:124:16       ...which  when you look at the server error logs  gives you no idea which request and where was the culprit. Would be nice if the requested uri would be added into the error object so that the debugging would get bit easier.

title: Add optional support for jsonReviver
body: Allows the use of a reviver function when parsing the response body as JSON

title: Retry on ECONNRESET
body: I m working on a [PR] https://github.com/pouchdb/pouchdb/pull/3015  for PouchDB to enable PouchDB in node.js to make replication GET requests in parallel. But in testing this code under duress with a pool of 15 connections I inevitably run into a situation where one of the connections fails with a ECONNRESET. This then causes request.js to throw a failure and ends up causing all of PouchDB to quit.  At first I thought this was because I wasn t using the forever agent  whose existence I knew nothing of and learned about by accident . Eventually I passed in  forever : true  and confirmed that the forever agent is being used. But that didn t fix things. I was still failing occasionally on ECONNRESET.  I did find [the code] https://github.com/request/request/blob/ce705147036b57e5b4c91d2f0ff7b48c7512b561/request.js L960  that handles this error but it depends on _reusedSocket which is always undefined in my tests and so the test always fails.  Question 1   should the _reusedSocket test be removed?  Question 2   Even if the answer to question 1 is  yes  it seems like the retry logic is more than a little fragile in these cases  there would be exactly one retry and no way to configure more . Is the intent that one is required to use something like [node request retry] https://github.com/FGRibreau/node request retry ?  Question 3   Why does node request retry need to exist? Isn t this the sort of functionality that should be in request? Or is there some line in the sand that says these are separate issues? Sorry if this is a silly question but I m new to all of this.  Thanks

title: Upgrade form data  add back browserify compability. Fixes  455.
body: The form data module now has moved to a  browserifiable  mime module  so request can again be built with browserify if we upgrade to the latest version of form data.  This PR fixes that.  Just wondering. If I make a PR where I add a test suite for making sure request can be used with browserify  will that be considered being added into request?

title: Add browser test to keep track of browserify compability.
body: As discussed  or more like suggested  over at issue  1307: A browser test to make sure request can be built with browserify.  Last time it broke it was because one of the dependencies had a dependency which in turn used  fs.readFile   which obviously does not work well in browsers. But those things are hard to spot unless it is automated.  So to sum it up. This is not for testing that all features actually work in the browser. Just to make sure it will bundle nicely.  One negative thing about this is the added dependencies and the added test build time. In addition to having more tests to  support  of course. For me the positive effects outshines this  but I can understand if someone might make that argument.  Anyway  this is the first take. Open for discussion  of course.  Oh  and thanks once more for making and maintaining this fantastic library. Have a nice day

title: Weird POST behaviour after upgrading to 2.50.0  from 2.49.0
body: Hi   I ve upgraded  request  to  2.50.0  and I ve noticed a very weird behaviour when doing a  request.post   application/x www urlencoded .      js // client  var request = require  request  ;  request.post  http://localhost:3000/login       form:   username:  test   password:  test       json: true    function err  res  body      console.log res.body ;   ;          js // server  var express = require  express  ; var router = express.Router  ;  // ...  router.post  /login   function req  res      console.log req.body ;   res.json   status:  ok    ;   ;      With request  2.49.0   the  req.body  on   server   is the expected:      js   username:  test   password:  test         With request  2.50.0   the  req.body  on   server   is the following:      js     username :  test   password:  test     // ???      I m using [body parser] https://github.com/expressjs/body parser  on Express apps and [koa body] https://github.com/dlau/koa body  on Koa apps.   obviously  this behaviuor broke all my tests and I have to switch back to  2.49.0

See below    From the docs  > form   when passed an object or a querystring  this sets body to a querystring representation of value  and adds Content type: application/x www form urlencoded header. However  request  2.49  seems unaffected.

title: improve documentation re timeout
body: >  timeout    Integer containing the number of milliseconds to wait for a request to respond before aborting the request  Could you please clarify here that this  timeout  does not affect OS wide setting of effective maximum value for connect timeout. So  beyond this point  higher  timeout  values will have no effect in case when TCP connection cannot be established.  See also:   [Similar question on stackoverflow.com] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3586760/how do i set a timeout for client http connections in node js    [Details regarding socket connect timeout in Linux] http://www.sekuda.com/overriding_the_default_linux_kernel_20_second_tcp_socket_connect_timeout

title: How to properly configurate pool
body: simply I tried with a snippet below in a ubuntu 14.04 box      js setInterval function        request           url:  http://www.google.com           method:  GET               function err  resp body           if err                        console.log err ;          else                       console.log  sent  ;                    1000 ;      I observed that as time going   TIME_WAIT  connections are growing until it ate up all socket resources.  I know that this is because of  http Agent  create sockets with keep alive  enabled. WIth  require  pool:false     which effectively set  agent = false  for underlying  http.request  can eliminate this problem.  But I want to take the benefit of connection pool while keep the amount of them under control.   I tried with 3rd party agents  e.g.  agentkeepalive  and  keep alive agent  with  request  agent: 3rd_party_agent    which work with raw  http.request   but no luck with  request . I saw the amount of  TIME_WAIT  connection growing with such combination.  My question is that  how can I properly apply pool  agent  implementations to  Request  so that I can both limit my connections in a reasonable amount and enjoy the advantages of pools?

I tried making the linter ignore the file but it seems we re using an older version of the linter which may not support ignoring paths.  I may be wrong but this was an alternative solution  safely delete the file before running the linter.

title: Fixed an issue which created broken base64 encoded strings.
body: Fixed an issue which created broken base64 encoded strings.  This lead to authentication issues while using basic authentication.

title: Wrong encoding for basic authentication
body: The _request_ module provides an option to authenticate requests via basic authentication. The method wich is applied to encode the user credentials is described in RFC2617 https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2617.txt   It states:      To receive authorization  the client sends the userid and password     separated by a single colon   :   character  within a base64 [7]    encoded string in the credentials.        basic credentials = base64 user pass       base64 user pass  = <base64 [4] encoding of user pass       But the RFC doesn t state the encoding which has to be applied before the strings get converted to base64. The _request_ module in it s current implementation uses _ASCII_ encoding  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/helpers.js L77 . This leads to wrong base64 encodings when it s getting towards string which are only defined in ISO 8859 1 or even UTF 8  The problem is discussed over here in detail  with the result that ISO 8859 1 instead of ASCII or UTF 8 should be used for the encoding http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7242316/what encoding should i use for http basic authentication

title: Restructure documentation
body: Our README has gotten really long and I think it s time to split it into separate files  see discussion at  1331 .  Here are the sections in it now:      sh   grep  ^     README.md    Super simple to use    Streaming    Proxies    UNIX Socket    Forms    HTTP Authentication    OAuth Signing    Custom HTTP Headers    TLS/SSL Protocol    request options  callback     Convenience methods    Examples:    Debugging      Here s how I would reorder and modify these sections:      sh    Super simple to use add link to full list of options    Streaming short explanation with link to  doc/streaming.md     Forms short to medium explanation with link to  doc/forms.md     HTTP Authentication short explanation with link to  doc/auth.md     Custom HTTP Headers this one is fine    OAuth Signing short explanation with link to  doc/oauth.md     Proxies short explanation with link to  doc/proxies.md     UNIX Socket change name to  Unix Domain Sockets     TLS/SSL Protocol short explanation with link to  doc/ssl.md     request options  callback  change name to  All Available Options  or similar we could also move the full API to its own file  and give each option its own section?  this would allow linking directly to individual options    Convenience methods this should go wherever the full API docs go    Examples: move these to the  examples/  dir and have a readme describing the examples  with each one in its own .js file    Debugging this one is fine      These are just some first thoughts  so feedback welcome.  @rockbot I think this helps address your concern by making it easier/quicker to find the full options we support  but I want to keep the narrative of  here s what this library can do... OK finally here s how you do all these things and more.

title: Emit FormData error events as Request error events
body: As per  1336 created a clean request which passes tests.  Below is a stack trace  from 1st October 2014 sorry it s old   caused by uploading an image to the Facebook API using request. The trace is caught by a node domain otherwise it d be ignored.      Error: write ECONNRESET Error: write ECONNRESET at errnoException  net.js:904:11  at afterWrite  net.js:720:19                                                 at Readable.on  _stream_readable.js:707:33  at pipe  tls.js:1455:10  at exports.connect  tls.js:1352:19  at Agent.createConnection  https.js:79:14  at Agent.createSocket  http.js:1293:16  at Agent.addRequest  http.js:1269:23  at new ClientRequest  http.js:1416:16  at exports.request  https.js:123:10                                                 at Stream.pipe  stream.js:57:10  at CombinedStream.pipe  /node_modules/request/node_modules/form data/node_modules/combined stream/lib/combined_stream.js:63:25  at end  /node_modules/request/request.js:415:22  at /node_modules/request/request.js:444:11 at /node_modules/request/node_modules/form data/lib/form_data.js:273:5 at /node_modules/request/node_modules/form data/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:254:17 at done  /node_modules/request/node_modules/form data/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:135:19  at /node_modules/request/node_modules/form data/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:32:16      As you can see there is an ECONNRESET in combined_stream which is passed up to the form data module  however this error is not then passed up to request  unless domains are in place it is just lost.  This change will pass the error up to request so users can act on the  error  event  in my case I d retry the request. The only impact this should have on existing applications is they emit error events more often if the application uses form data instead of ignoring it.   The alternative option would be to in the application would be to listen to the  error  event on the form object created from request.form   which I m happy to do but I thought since it s used by request it d be good if it could be sent to the callback.  I would write a test case for it but I ve no idea how to trigger an ECONNRESET in combine_stream intentionally  if anyone knows how I ll gladly write a test case

In this PR:   Removed HTTPS requiring usage of HTTP tunnelling   Added test via @nylen    Updated documentation

title: getProxyFromURI Extraction Refactor

title: process.env.no_proxy is ignored / not working correctly
body: I m unfortunate enough to have to work behind a corporate proxy. Mostly it works but I have issues when working on  localhost  or  127.0.0.1  or basically anything where I need to ignore the proxy for development purposes   otherwise proxy will map my http requests to corporate urls.  I set as required all the following env variables:   HTTPS_PROXY    HTTP_PROXY    NO_PROXY    https_proxy    http_proxy  and  no_proxy .  However  when making calls using the  request  library it doesn t work.  We instantiate the request library using our own wrapper library that does the following:      var defaultOptions = _getDefaultOptions  ; this.request = request.defaults defaultOptions ;      Where  _getDefaultOptions    is as follows:      function _getDefaultOptions         var options =   ;      _checkProxies options ;     _checkCertificates          [ /etc/pki/certificate.pem ]          options      ;      if   options.cert            var defaultClientCertificatePair =               certLocation:  /etc/pki/tls/certs/client.crt               keyLocation:  /etc/pki/tls/private/client.key           ;         _checkCertificateKeyPair [defaultClientCertificatePair]  options ;            options.rejectUnauthorized = false;      return options;        Further debugging revealed that the issue is because the method  getProxyFromUri  is never entered  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L170   This is because the block  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L427        if  self.hasOwnProperty  proxy         self.proxy = getProxyFromURI self.uri         To invoke the above method is never entered is set. I m just wondering why self.hasOwnProperty  proxy   needs to be false for it to  getProxyFromURI . Are we instantiating the client incorrectly or is there a bug here?

title: Custom FormData instance
body: How can I feed my own FormData instance?  If it s not yet possible  I think that  formData : new FormData    should work  it doesn t for now . Passing the FormData instance as parameter of the  .form [form]   api call send it urlencoded.

title: Make sure we return on errored browser requests.
body: Turns out that if browser requests are erroring out on an early stage  this could be error on DNS  cross domain security cancellation or user has no internet connection   request will fail when trying the method  caseless.has   because this will invoke Object.keys on undefined. So just wrapping the check here in a check for headers fixes the issue.  I also added a browesr test for this. The test proves the problem: it will fail if request.js is not updated  for example with this code .  I realize I could have also sent a PR to caseless to avoid calling Object keys on an undefined object  but seems to me that we should not even invoke caseless when we have no headers to work with.   Please let me know if you feel this should be solved in another way  Have a great week

title: WIP request oauth as a separate module
body: Not an actual PR    I got inspired lately from some other refactoring PRs  so I just moved the  oauth  method into a separate _module_. The  oauth  method in request now looks like this:      js Request.prototype.oauth = function  _oauth      var self = this    var result = roauth.oauth       uri: self.uri      method: self.method      headers: self.headers      body: self.body      qsLib: self.qsLib      oauth: _oauth         if  result.transport ===  header         self.setHeader  Authorization   result.data        else if  result.transport ===  query         self.path  = result.data       else if  result.transport ===  body         self.body = result.data        return self        My idea is for a separate module in the request org called  request oauth  currently this is a [single file] https://github.com/simov/request/blob/1bd0ca14b538e0afa3a8066f5f6f5049655461fe/request oauth.js  with only minor changes in it.  So if @mikeal @nylen @tbuchok @seanstrom and everyone else give it a green light  I would do the following: 1. Create documentation 2. Write unit tests 3. Make some minor changes to the code  right now it s really just copy/pasted

title: Error: DelayedStream maxDataSize of 2097152 bytes exceeded.
body: When downloading a large file that does not have a defined  Content Length   i.e. it s using  Transfer Encoding: chunked    I m encountering this error:      Error: DelayedStream maxDataSize of 2097152 bytes exceeded.     at FormData.CombinedStream._checkDataSize  /opt/apps/1421199886807/0 Worker/package/node_modules/form data/node_modules/combined stream/lib/combined_stream.js:165:19      at Request.emit  events.js:117:20      at Request.source.emit  /opt/apps/1421199886807/0 Worker/package/node_modules/form data/node_modules/combined stream/node_modules/delayed stream/lib/delayed_stream.js:30:21      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  /opt/apps/1421199886807/0 Worker/package/node_modules/request/request.js:1263:12      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:95:17      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  _stream_readable.js:765:14      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:92:17      at emitReadable_  _stream_readable.js:427:10      at emitReadable  _stream_readable.js:423:5      at readableAddChunk  _stream_readable.js:166:9        maxDataSize  can be overridden according to the  delayed stream  package [documentation] https://github.com/felixge/node delayed stream buffer limits   but this does not seem configurable from  request .  Here is an example use that will fail  but it s admittedly not particularly insightful:      js request.get     url: getUrl    headers:       Authorization: oauth1Header        timeout: 18000    function err  httpResponse  body        console.log  download done  ;   ;

title: Promises
body: Why does this package does not use the Promise API?

title: Refactor basic  bearer  digest auth logic into separate class
body: WIP    I moved the  auth  method logic into separate file. The  auth  method is split into two methods  basic  and  bearer . Also I moved  _digest  and the part of the code in  onRequestResponse  related to these 3 methods.  The reasons to move exactly these functions is as follows: all private flags  _hasAuth    _sentAuth  and private variables  _bearer   _user    _pass  are local for the  Auth  class. That way  request  now knows only about only 3 distinct methods  _auth.basic    _auth.bearer  and  _auth.response  versus 6 variables  _hasAuth    _sentAuth    _bearer    _user    _pass  and  _digest   The  Auth  class keeps a pointer to the  request  instance  but only use it to modify the headers  as well as reading some values  as I said private variables related to the  Auth  class are not set in  request    Other than that the code is mostly copy/pasted without changes  it certainly can be improved but I wanted to make this PR as short as possible. Also the  debug  call is currently commented out.  Ping @nylen @seanstrom @FredKSchott

title: Refactor OAuth into separate module
body: This is a follow up to my previous PR https://github.com/request/request/pull/1350 Also it might be related to this one https://github.com/request/request/pull/1360  The  getParams  function is about the generation of OAuth parameters. I think it s pretty straightforward to understand which parameters have defaults  which are excluded  and what parameters are required for the OAuth signature.  The  concatParams  function is the old  buildSortedParams  but I though it deserves it s own function  I mean the  oa  parameter was used from the outer scope  so it was not exactly a function in that sense.  One change in  concatParams  is that the signature is no longer appended to the end of the string  but that can be changed if it not confront to the spec in some way.  The  oauth  function is pretty much what s left from the original one  but I think now it s more compact and easy to follow  it even fits on my screen. The  getParams  and  concatParams  are called from there  there is only one level of indirection so again it s very easy to follow.  All of the available input  args  parameters are listed on top of the  oauth  function. Also right now in Request this module is called like  var result = oauth.oauth  which is a bit silly  but I couldn t come up with something more reasonable.  At first I thought that returning of a map is not a good idea for the  oauth  method  but then I liked how it feels  I mean  result.transport  and  result.oauth  sounds good to me.  That s all I could think of at the moment.

This fixes [Issue 1259] https://github.com/request/request/issues/1259  where the user is prompted for the private key password when performing mutual authentication using a tunnel proxy with a password protected private key.

title: Rewrite tunnel test to be pure Node.js
body: The new test is doing much more than the old one was  and as far as I can tell  no one was ever running it since it required  squid .  This will be nice to have when making further changes/fixes related to tunneling and proxies  such as  1344 and  1368.

title: Allow explicitly disabling tunneling for proxied https destinations
body: Before  tunneling would default to false for http destinations and be forced to true for https destinations.  Now  allow specifying  tunnel : false  to perform a regular GET request to HTTPS destinations.  This is insecure  so make a note accordingly.  Supersedes  1344 and fixes  1293.  Also add some more tests for proxy environment variables   it hasn t been easy to test proxying HTTPS URLs without tunneling until this change.

title: Use karma browserify for tests. Add browser test coverage reporter.
body: Hey.  So I started writing some more browser tests. But before I did that  I wanted to make the test runner to compile browserify by itself  and also add some coverage checking  to make it easier to write tests .  This PR does the following:   Modifies the scripts in package.json to not compile with browserify directly.   Modifies the clean script to delete the coverage folder  not sure if this is preferred over adding it to . ignore    Add some new dependencies.   Make sure karma does both coverage and browserify.   Also added stderr from the child process that runs karma.  I have some follow up questions about how we should structure the actual test suite  but let s do that in another issue.

title: Proxy settings with     not supported on Mac OSX
body: I have worked with npm on Windows at my office and there was never any issues with setting my corporate proxy. This proxy has a domain  which must be resolved like this:  http://domain password:username@proxy.address.com:9999   In Windows  the proxy works when I escape the     as   5C  like so:  http://domain 5Cpassword:username@proxy.address.com:9999   but on OSX  that will not resolve the proxy properly. When I try to npm install  I get the following error:  npm ERR  network getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND proxy.address.com   I have tried various ways of encoding the     on OSX  but none of them work  and Googling this problem leads me to a bunch of dead ends  and all the normal encoding methods are not working.  The NPM team recommended I open a ticket here  as  request  is used to make this connection. You can see the NPM ticket here: [Proxy Settings with     not supported on Mac OSX   Issue 7150] https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/7150 .  If this is NTLM login  is that functionality planning on being added in  request   or is this a bug in the current implementation?

title: Add missing HTTPS options that were not being passed to tunnel  @brichard19
body: This is a re roll of  1380 with lint issues fixed and a few other cleanups.  It passes more special HTTPS options to the tunnel  but there is more work needed after this:  we still have to do some [special] https://github.com/nylen/request/blob/0f6d1b1bfde40e8baf463d6ff8227b43876af6d7/tests/test tunnel.js L32 L36  [stuff] https://github.com/nylen/request/blob/0f6d1b1bfde40e8baf463d6ff8227b43876af6d7/tests/test tunnel.js L114 L124  to get HTTPS tunnels and destinations to use a custom certificate authority.  We will probably need to modify [ tunnel agent ] https://github.com/mikeal/tunnel agent  in the future to fix this.  I d like to release a new version after this change gets through  it has been a while and we have a couple of fixes that people have requested.

title: Make more browser tests
body: Hey.  As mentioned in  1376 I started seeing if I could write a more extensive browser test suite. So first things first  we now have coverage info  via that issue .  So next thing I started doing was just copying some tests from the  server side test suite   and noticed a couple of things. I am going to use test toJSON as an example  since it is fairly small and easy.      Tests are starting servers  This is an obvious one. And why shouldn t tests start servers  right? The thing is that I can make all assertions in test toJSON pass  if I only execute the parts that does not open or close the server.  So my question is: Wouldn t the ideal thing here be to share the test cases? Not sure what the ideal model would be  but for example this would work:      js  use strict   var request = require  ../index       http = require  http       tape = require  tape    var s = http.createServer function  req  resp      resp.statusCode = 200   resp.end  asdf       tape  setup   function t      s.listen 6767  function         t.end            require  ./common/test toJSON   tape  request ;  tape  cleanup   function t      s.close function         t.end                ...or something like that.  The other alternative is to duplicate the tests that are actually relevant for the browser. Which of course is not every test anyway.      Starting servers for the browser.  My next question is. Some of the tests will not work via CORS. For example are you not allowed to read all the same headers when the request is cross domain. Luckily karma has a built in proxy  so you can actually get /basic to go to a server with basic auth  for example . What is our best course of action here? Should we try to reuse the servers in the tests also? Should we add some routing to the one server  and make it serve what we need for the tests we need?  ...or should we just be pragmatic and toss in whatever we can make pass into the tests/browser directory?   And final question: one PR per test suite? A PR now and then with a couple of tests suites?  Thoughts?

title: EventEmitter memory leak on redirect
body: I was debugging https://github.com/blakeembrey/popsicle/issues/10 and found out that there s actually an event listening bug that occurs on every redirect. It keeps attaching the same  pipe  and  end  event listeners every redirect.  I ll try to get a PR with tests ASAP  but didn t want this to get lost.  The referenced issue is somewhat related to https://github.com/request/request/pull/1132 since it hits an infinite redirect on  302  which made this fun to debug. FWIW   curl  did not get stuck in an infinite redirect  maybe another PR  and correctly closed.       > GET / HTTP/1.1 > User Agent: curl/7.37.1 > Host: example.com > Accept:  /  >  < HTTP/1.1 302 Found < Date: Fri  30 Jan 2015 15:12:52 GMT   Server Apache/2.2.15  Red Hat  is not blacklisted < Server: Apache/2.2.15  Red Hat  < Expires: Thu  19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT < Cache Control: no store  no cache  must revalidate  post check=0  pre check=0 < Pragma: no cache < Location: http://example.com < Content Length: 107 < Connection: close < Content Type: text/html; charset=utf 8 <    Closing connection 0 <html><head><meta http equiv= refresh  content= 0;url=http://example.com /></head></html>

title: supplying both a URI object and QS object can cause unexpected behaviour
body: This might be more of a thing to document than a bug but anyway.  I  hand built  an object like the one produced by  url.parse  and supplied that as the  uri     url  argument along with an object for  qs  to the  request    function and watched most of the objects settings get nulled out...      js var myHandBuiltUriObject =      protocol:  http:     slashes: null    auth: null    hash: null    search: null    query: null    pathname:  /timers/test zz     path:  /timers/test zz     href:  /timers/test zz     hostname:  ::ffff:127.0.0.1     port: 8899    var requestOpts =     uri: myHandBuiltUriObject    qs:  page:10     method:  GET     request requestOpts ;  // Error: Invalid protocol: null //    at Request.init  /Users/sandfox/code/tmp/node_modules/biws/node_modules/request/request.js:594:31  //    at new Request  /Users/sandfox/code/tmp/node_modules/biws/node_modules/request/request.js:264:8  //    at request  /Users/sandfox/code/tmp/node_modules/biws/node_modules/request/index.js:50:10   var myUriObjectAfterBeingMangledByRequestInternally =      protocol: null    slashes: null    auth: null    host: null    port: null    hostname: null    hash: null    search:  ?state=on     query:  state=on     pathname:  /timers/test zz     path:  /timers/test zz?state=on     href:  /timers/test zz?state=on          After some digging around inside request it appears that if you supply both the URI object and the QS object  request will use just the  uri.href  key and ignore all the  host    port    protocol  etc when bodging on the querystring and making a new uri.       self.uri = url.parse self.uri.href.split  ?  [0]    ?    rfc3986 qs    self.url = self.uri  self.path = self.uri.path      https://github.com/request/request/blob/f0acc0b3e0bbc8a57d3418ab93eadbf162089514/request.js L1328  I m not really sure quite what the solution to this or what I really expect to happen but at the least I suppose that document how  request  uses the  uri  object might be useful?  If anyone is wondering why I have a hand constructed uri object  it s because I have one library that wraps request and does a form of load balancing by supplying the port/hostname/protocol for each http request made.

title: Refactor multipart/related logic into separate module
body: I just refactored the behavior I proposed here https://github.com/request/request/pull/1283   The  isChunked    setHeaders  and the  build  methods can be used outside of this class. The  related  method just wraps them up  but that logic can be put somewhere else.  The reason why I pass the  request  instance to each method individually is because I don t think it belongs to that class as a property. I even allow the  setHeaders  method to modify the instance  so I contradict myself here  I know  but it seemed more logical in this case.  Other than that I really want to see a few more modules out of request before I can decide on the best approach about the instance.  I moved the  boundary  field into the  multipart  instance  no idea what was the reason to have it attached on the  request  instance  since it wasn t used anywhere else.  The  related  method sets up the  self._multipart.chunked  and the  self._multipart.body  properties  and then use them to pipe with request if needed  not the most elegant code  but that will change I guess       js if  self._multipart    self._multipart.chunked      self._multipart.body.pipe self

title: new streams support  please
body: There s plenty of issues with streams since node 0.10   This code will fail  but only under load. If the response is a file  it will be missing a few bytes from the beginning.      javascript var requestObject = request ...  // need to pause here requestObject.pause   requestObject.on  response   function  resp      if resp.statusCode===200       requestObject.pipe somewhere     else      //retry...       ;      pausing  requestObject  saves the day  but it doesn t get resumed when you call  requestObject.pipe  and has to be resumed manually.  Now the other way:  if I pass an option:      javascript formData:    file: stream        All s well  request is sent  but no content type and filename set. So I go on and do:      javascript formData:    file:       value:stream      options:        filename:  whatever   //silently required  see https://github.com/felixge/node form data/issues/74       contentType:  text/xml                   If  stream  is a plain string  all works well. If  stream  is a new node 0.10 stream  it hangs forever.  Seems serious to me.  This bug could be split in two if the first case can be fixed without intervention in  form data . In that case  let me know how I could help and where to start looking if I want to make a PR.  PS. I wrote the code in github textbox and tried to make indents with tab and space so it got submitted too early.

title: Upper Buffer Limit
body: Is it possible to create a maximum Buffer size  so it must be consumed before continuing to fill the rest of the buffer? Is it also possible to be able to pause a data receive?  It s not documented and I would like to avoid >1gb files using memory  or needlessly writing to disk.

title: Abstract proxy implementation
body: Wouldn t it be good to abstract your proxy implementation into a separate module that people can make use of? Currently proxies is kind of a no man s land but with this module it just seems to work.  Sure  one could use request for everything but this module is pretty big and includes a lot of features which in many cases aren t needed.

title: Cookies from domain aren t being sent to subdomain
body: I wrote a piece of code that uses cookies and multiple requests for authentication purposes  the requests span over two domains  example.com and subdomain.example.com.  I noticed that cookies from example.com aren t available on subdomain.example.com.  That behavior is  if I read it correctly  against HTTP specs which specifies that if no domain was set  the cookie should be available to this domain and every subdomain under it.

title: Refactor redirect logic into separate module
body: In the last few days I have the idea that the request plugins should introduce  onRequest  and  onResponse  hooks at minimum. Also all of them should be classes that caches the  request  instance internally.  Then in  base  we should have defaults like:      js function Auth         Auth.prototype.onRequest = function  options      // just nothing  or throw some error accordingly   Auth.prototype.onResponse = function  response      // just nothing  or throw some error accordingly    function Redirect         Redirect.prototype.onRequest = function  options      // just nothing  or throw some error accordingly   Redirect.prototype.onResponse = function  response      // just nothing  or throw some error accordingly        and so on  The idea is that request  base  should work without having certain plugins included. Essentially all plugins should modify the request instance on their own.  Then we can configure the plugins like this:      js var request = require  request    // just like the defaults method var custom = request.config [ auth    redirect    streams ]       Obviously with this approach we should have the hooks defined internally  in other words this does not allow for user made plugins. The reason why is that certain plugin hooks should be called in specific parts of the code  like for example the  auth  response hook called inside the  redirect  plugin  but that may change   My initial idea was to just loop through all plugins required by the config method  inside the  init  and  onRequestResponse  methods  so we can think about these plugins as middlewares that are used or not. I guess that would be possible at some point  and this will allow just about any custom made plugin/middleware to be called for each request/response pair  and modify the state accordingly.  Let me know what do you think :

title: Redirect is loosing Authorization
body: After a page redirect  authorization data is lost.  This is because we have an unconditional  new Auth  in init   at this line: https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L498  The following hack works for  Basic   but we probably need something more elaborate for the other authorization schemes.      diff     request.js.orig 2015 02 05 14:58:12.401690494  0100     request.js  2015 02 05 14:57:24.809909090  0100 @@  495 6  495 7 @@          // Auth must happen last in case signing is dependent on other headers  if  self._auth        self._auth = new Auth       if  options.oauth    @@  528 7  529 7 @@        options.auth.bearer                     if  self.gzip     self.hasHeader  accept encoding           self.setHeader  accept encoding    gzip              This feature is needed for single sign on  when authorization is done by a third party through redirects

Content Type header incomplete for  multipart/related  requests
body: From RFC:      3.1.  The Type Parameter     The type parameter must be specified and its value is the MIME media    type of the  root  body part.  It permits a MIME user agent to    determine the content type without reference to the enclosed body    part.  If the value of the type parameter and the root body part s    content type differ then the User Agent s behavior is undefined.  3.2.  The Start Parameter     The start parameter  if given  is the content ID of the compound    object s  root .  If not present the  root  is the first body part in    the Multipart/Related entity.  The  root  is the element the    applications processes first.

title: Request truncates large response body
body: We re using the latest version of the request lib and are experiencing an issue that when the response body hits a certain size it is truncated.  Because of this it often results in malformed JSON as the object is cut off mid string.   Have tried explicitly concatenating the chunks using .on  data   however it still stops at a certain size    <700000 bytes . The expected response size is itself around 700000 bytes.  I don t believe this is an issue with the endpoint itself as we have fixed it by using Node s lower level http.request:              var responseBody =   ;         var statusCode;         var options =               host: services.django.endpoint.replace  https://                    path:  /api/buildings/               headers:                    Authorization : services.django.token                        ;         http.request options  function response                response.on  data   function chunk                    responseBody  = chunk;               ;             response.on  end   function                     res.status response.statusCode .json JSON.parse responseBody  ;               ;           .end  ;

title: Allow fully qualified multipart content type header
body: Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1416  The problem here was with poorly written logic about the boundary field in multipart/related content type header. Now we allow fully qualified multipart headers  including ones containing their own boundary  in that case the boundary property is set from the content header for that instance  see test multipart.js   I ve done some major refactoring on the chunked detection tests and moved them to test multipart chunked.js I also fixed the logic where the transfer encoding header overrides the value set through the chunked key  because the header wasn t removed anyway  and I don t think that should be the case either. Probably the previous tests were not catching this edge case.

title: Some multipart requests are invalid
body: When attempting to run the following code  I get a 400 Bad Request error back from the Google API.      javascript request.post        uri :  https://www.googleapis.com/batch        auth :            bearer :  Bearer ...auth code...              headers :            Content Type :  multipart/mixed;             multipart: [                        content type :  application/json               body:  GET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/activities/user                                    content type :  application/json               body:  GET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/circles                ]   ;      I ve been able to successfully run the same request by manually setting the boundary and then manually writing each part of the request:       javascript request.post       ...      headers :            Content Type :  multipart/mixed; boundary=    boundary            ...   .write   r n      boundary     r nContent Type: application/http r n r nGET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/activities/user r n r n r n      boundary     r nContent Type: application/http r n r nGET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/circles r n r n      boundary         ;      When using the  multipart  option the request fails. I ve looked into this and can see that the request is in fact invalid:      javascript headers:        content type :  multipart/mixed; boundary=af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c        host:  www.googleapis.com        authorization:  Bearer ...auth code...         content length : 274      body:    af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c r ncontent type: application/http r n r n GET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/activities/user  r n   af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c r ncontent type: application/http r n r n GET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/circles  r n   af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c           It seems to me that the body of the request is invalid as commas are added:      raw   af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c content type: application/http   GET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/activities/user     af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c content type: application/http   GET /plusDomains/v1/people/me/circles     af62abce cef0 4805 9d24 c44ae1dd663c        Is this a bug? Or am I missing something?

title: Fix recursive requester
body: Right now if you set a  requester  function in  request.defaults  it will override all further defined  requester  functions when using  request.METHOD  to make a request. For example      javascript var request1 = request.defaults     function uri  options  callback       console.log  I AM THE FIRST REQUESTER FUNCTION  ;     request uri  options  callback ;     var request2 = request1.defaults     function uri  options  callback       console.log  I AM THE SECOND REQUESTER FUNCTION  ;     console.log  I WILL NEVER GET CALLED BY request2.METHOD  ;     request1 uri  options  callback ;     // currently using request.METHOD will only hit the first requester request2.get url  // I AM THE FIRST REQUESTER FUNCTION  // using request directly will hit the both requesters request     uri: url    method:  GET     // I AM THE SECOND REQUESTER FUNCTION // I WILL NEVER GET CALLED BY request2.METHOD // I AM THE FIRST REQUESTER FUNCTION      This PR fixes  request.defaults  so that recursive  requester  functions will get called by both  request    and  request.METHOD

title: Lingering requests after a ETIMEDOUT
body: I have a periodic loop that checks a DB every second for unsent documents to send to a receiving API built with Node   Express running on Windows Server 2008. The device sending the data is an Ubuntu 14.04 laptop running Node   Request 2.53.0 which roams about moving in and out of a WiFi connection.   Today the loop tried to send the same document 183 times and each time the loopback passed an error:   [Error: ETIMEDOUT] code:  ETIMEDOUT    but the receiving API still received the request 183 times. Its like the request IS timing out after 10000ms but ISN T and are getting sent anyway. Even Linux TCP should timeout after 20 seconds. Do I need to manually abort the request or what s happening here?  The sending request looks like...       js var request = require  request  ; var url = require  url  ; var submit_url =  http://    argv.server    /apiv1/submit_move ;  // Begin periodic loop // when an unsent doc is found mark the doc as  sending  so its not re sent setDocStatus.sending doc   request       uri: submit_url      method:  POST       timeout: 10000      form:           original_id: doc.id          moveCode: doc.moveCode          opID: doc.opID           function error  response  body       if   error   // handle response  mark doc as sent if appropriate            else  // mark the doc as unsent

title: Is it possible to proxy a request with multipart/formdata and add Digest auth?
body: I d like to add authentication to a proxied multipart/formdata request. The following one line proxy code works for Basic authentication but not for Digest  I m guessing because Digest requires an additional request :      js function submit req  res  next       var submissionUrl =  https://some.thirdparty.com/submission ;     var submissionRequest = request  submissionUrl  .auth  username    password   false ;      req.pipe  submissionRequest  .pipe  res  ;        Is there a way to pipe the request and add Digest authentication? My main goal is to avoid a solution that requires parsing the request body and re adding the form data to a new request.

Right now if you want to use defaults to just pass in a custom  requester  function you need to pass in an empty options object  like this...    request.defaults     function uri  options  callback       This PR adds the ability to do...        request.defaults function uri  options  callback     // note we left out the first param of

title: Should have possibility to set global defaults
body: Fe. having to be able to force timout globally  ie. anyone who just requires request will get it with that default setting  would be greatly appreciated. Just had an issue where requests didn t have timeouts and they started piling up on the internal API load balancer  which then caused other issues.  In order to have correct settings set  having to call defaults with correct optiosn every time you use request is a bit on the dangerous side  especially on diverse teams.  On app.js  just being able to call something like...      js require  request  .globalDefaults     timeout: 10 1000   ;      ...could be hugely beneficial. Or even setting custom headers etc.  In this case  I ended up fixing the issue by duckpunching  .get    .post  etc. shorthand methods with logic that adds timeout to the requests. Not a pretty solution but works for now.

With node 0.12/ io.js there s now an error thrown by  socket setTimeout  when it s passed a negative number. https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/timers.js L160  I ve tried to catch this error when  req setTimeout  is called here https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L907 using a try catch  but it only seems to get caught in  process.on  uncaughtException   . Any ideas how to handle this better; do we still need this test?

title: Prevent crash with authorization and followRedirects of false
body: Currently turning followRedirects to false while passing in authorization information causes a crash.  self.redirects is only set if followRedirects or followAllRedirects is set: https://github.com/request/request/blob/2f5f5e1913cad4b83fc379b1f96ac0f2f0fe1c7b/lib/redirect.js L34  redirectTo is set to a value here if you are using authorization: https://github.com/request/request/blob/2f5f5e1913cad4b83fc379b1f96ac0f2f0fe1c7b/lib/redirect.js L66  I found this working with 2.27.0  but it seems to have been transferred to the latest code.

title: Access original URL ?
body: In a case where a request is redirected  how can I access the originally requested URL ? e.g:      js var request = require  request  ;  var url =  http://httpbin.org/redirect to?url=http://httpbin.org/status/200 ;  request       url: url    function  e  res        if  e            throw e;            console.log  > Requested URL=   url ;     console.log  > Last URL=   res.request.uri.href ;     console.log  > Redirects=   res.request.redirects ;   ;      This sample code will print:      > Requested URL= http://httpbin.org/redirect to?url=http://httpbin.org/status/200 > Last URL= http://httpbin.org/status/200 > Redirects= [   statusCode: 302      redirectUri:  http://httpbin.org/status/200    ]      Of course in this case  the  url  variable is in scope  but in a case where the stream interface of a request is used  you don t have that luxury.  Is there any way to access the value of  url  inside de  response  object ?

title: Request URI Too Long
body:
When trying to download google documents the following is returned html < DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC //IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN > 414 Request URI Too Long

Request URI Too Long

The requested URL s length exceeds the capacity limit for this server.

How can this be avoided without reconfiguring Apache?

title: Clarify documentation on strictSSL
body: The README says   strictSSL    If true  requires SSL certificates be valid. .  This gives the impression that it s false by default and request has a bad security practice that has to be overridden explicitly every time you use it.  However looking at [the actual code] https://github.com/request/request/blob/a60482bf06b7e16d3cdbabcdee7f0b62d93117c2/request.js L388 L390  strictSSL is compared  === false  so its default is to verify certificates.

title: Implement progress events
body: It would be nice to have  optional  progress events that would fire for progress  against content length if available  on the raw entity body.  There are 2 libraries that do progress events for request  [request progress] https://www.npmjs.com/package/request progress  and [progress stream] https://www.npmjs.com/package/progress stream .  However both of them fail when you use  gzip: true .  Content Length  describes the length of the entity body  compressed  but both of these libraries only have access to the inflated  uncompressed  stream request gives out.  It doesn t seem possible for these libraries to dig themselves into request s internals to access the raw stream and watch the data that streams through it. So support for progress events looks like something that can only be implemented correctly from within request.

title: Reuse agentClass on redirect
body: Fixes  1304  As no options are passed to  init    on redirect  Request fell back to the default agent. This fixes changes the behaviour so that the default is not used if  self.agentClass  is already specified.  Includes a test case.
