title: Test on Node.js 0.12 and io.js with allowed failures
body: This is based on  1415 by @demohi  except I configured Travis to allow failures on Node 0.12 and io.js. This way  contributors can work on bug fixes and see the test results in CI without breaking the build for Node 0.10.

title: timeout error throw more than once
body: when set the timeout parameter and the timeout happen like this:      js var req = request.get  http://website.com/   timeout:10000  ; req.on  response  function res         do something   ; req.on  error  function e       console.error e ;   ;      the error callback function will called more than once

title: response body serialization
body: Hi   My point is maybe stupid but I would like to avoid doing this in all my request responses:      js     request url  function  error  response  body            var result = JSON.parse body ;       ;      Questions:   Is that possible to automatically serialize response?    If so  is there an option that I can set once  to actually do that?

title: set options.agentOptions properly when use .forever
Abort request client side
body: I d like to abort a request before it resolves. There s a built in method for this in the node core: http://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_request_abort  The above method triggers an error event on the request which I don t like. If an error event can be avoided I d prefer it.  I haven t been able to find a similar abort method in request. Is this something that already exists or would you be interested in implementing something like this?  My use case for this is to abort a request to a long poll endpoint  add more data to the request  and then establish a long poll again.

title: Add cloneJar method
body: Some complex libraries that depend on  request  require the ability to clone the cookie jar  because of the way the jar is implemented cloning a  tough cookie  cookie jar will not work therefore the object must be re built by setting each cookie individually.  I wanted to add some basic tests  though the code is tested in my end  but the way you guys are doing your tests is overcomplicated  maybe consider using mocha or another test runner. Also you can mock the  http  package with  nock . But well thats a different topic

title: Add option to time request/response cycle  including rollup of redirects
body: Sure  it d be fairly trivial to grab timestamps before initiating the request  and in the response callback  and compare them; on the other hand  I ll eventually have a _lot_ of tests where I want to use the functionality  and writing a wrapper around the request library doesn t appeal to me.

title: localAddress or proxy config is lost when redirecting
body: See https://github.com/request/request/pull/1437 Will merge it very shortly

title: Fix readme for failing test on node 12 and io.js
body: Added link to the failing build https://travis ci.org/request/request/builds/53174289  Also see https://github.com/request/request/issues/1421  Feel free to suggest a better wording

title: See RAW request.
body: I need to see which one is the RAW headers to be able to analyze why my command is failing.  Right now with normal JS I can do this request:      GET /XXXXXX/directory Host: domain.net User Agent: Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:38.0  Gecko/20100101 Firefox/38.0 Accept: text/html application/xhtml xml application/xml;q=0.9  / ;q=0.8 Accept Language: en US en;q=0.5 Accept Encoding: gzip  deflate X Akamai ACS Action: version=1 action=dir format=xml X Akamai ACS Auth Data: 5  0.0.0.0  0.0.0.0  1425588090  868320501  keyname X Akamai ACS Auth Sign: jCCZZ1tdrpU8zKwK6ZOZwLYZsuQpI KKIINBbnVqZsI= Referer: https://referer.org/ Origin: https://referer.org Connection: keep alive      And it will work ok. However  if I try this using this module:      var _request =  require  request    _options  function err  res  body      console.log  Requests header   _request.headers ;   ;      It shows:        Host:  domain.net      X Akamai ACS Action :  version=1 action=dir format=xml      X Akamai ACS Auth Data :  5  0.0.0.0  0.0.0.0  1425589348  536128204  keyname      X Akamai ACS Auth Sign :  FqAiGTbF3KeqxNYEBS1h4g4jGByO0D44JjessjnTQTA=      User Agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:38.0  Gecko/20100101 Firefox/38.0     Accept:  text/html application/xhtml xml application/xml;q=0.9  / ;q=0.8      Accept Language :  en US en;q=0.5      Accept Encoding :  gzip  deflate      content length : 0        But the response from the first request  the one with js  is 200  while the one with node is 403  which means the request is malformed... but since I m not able to see the full request  raw request  I cannot know what is wrong.  Thanks in advance.

title: Uncaught TypeError when passing a JSON body alongside with non json content type header.
body: javascript var request = require  request  ;  request     uri:  http://google.com     json: true    headers:        content type :  application/x www form urlencoded         body:       blah:  this is json body. it should be string. But I don  t thing request   should have uncaught TypeErrors         method:  POST     function error  response  body      console.log error  response  body ;   ;      This throws      /Users/lxe/devel/request test/node_modules/request/request.js:237   return str.replace /[     ]/g  function c                 ^ TypeError: Object  has no method  replace      at rfc3986  /Users/lxe/devel/request test/node_modules/request/request.js:237:14      at Request.json  /Users/lxe/devel/request test/node_modules/request/request.js:1432:21      at Request.init  /Users/lxe/devel/request test/node_modules/request/request.js:554:10      at new Request  /Users/lxe/devel/request test/node_modules/request/request.js:264:8      at request  /Users/lxe/devel/request test/node_modules/request/index.js:50:10      at Object.<anonymous>  /Users/lxe/devel/request test/test.js:3:1      at Module._compile  module.js:456:26      at Object.Module._extensions..js  module.js:474:10      at Module.load  module.js:356:32      at Function.Module._load  module.js:312:12       Instead it should just throw the usual  Error: Argument error  options.body. . Or serialize the body.

title: Allow configuring a default base url
body: It will be useful for REST clients to be able to do something like this:      js var request = require  request  .defaults       baseUrl:  http://api.domain.com:9999/api/v1    ; request  /objects  ; // GET http://api.domain.com:9999/v1/objects

title: Binding on IPV6
body: Hi there :  any leads on binding to ipv6? i think it s a dns issue when i am trying to resolve the host. For example if the host example.com has ipv4 and ipv6 resolvers request will connect to the ipv4 address which will not work.

title: how to modify config that get from url  and post it back to url
body: I can get config through request.get  the  body is the config file I need to modify the the config file and post it back to url  How can I achieve it?      js function get_config    var option=   url: http://XXXXXXXX   headers:   Content Type : application/xml    Accept : application/xml      ; request.get  option  function error  response  body   if response.statusCode ==200   console.log body ;                   request.post   option  function error  response  body           else  console.log response.statusCode ;

title: Re enable io.js/node 0.12 build
body: Fixed the negative msecs error and re enabled io.js and node 0.12 in the build.  Closes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1421 Closes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1414

title: Feature/base url
body: Closes  1464 Closes  1476   Some remaining questions:   What to do when baseUrl has a path component  like http://example.com/base/path?  Append path or ignore?   What to do when baseUrl has query parameters?  Ignore or append/replace?   More tests needed?

title: Cache for GET requests?
body: What about cache for  GET  requests? Request is an HTTP Client  but for now  as I understand  it doesn t cache any  GET  requests  even if the appropriate headers are set. Should we add cache logic to the  request  module? May be  it would be better to create other module for that?

title: I get xml from server  then transform it to json by xmlreader  how can I modify the json.
body: I get xml from server  then transform it to json by xmlreader  how can I modify the json  and save it as xml.

title: forever agent does not work with Node 0.12
body: Moving https://github.com/request/request/issues/1421 issuecomment 74371413 since this technically doesn t block request from working unless the forever option is enabled  I m using the forever option with request. Starting 0.12 this option leads to ENOTSOCK and ECONNRESET errors. This never works presumably because the HTTP Agent API changed quite a bit with node 0.12. eg:      js var request = require  ./index  .forever  maxSockets: 1  ; request  http://www.yahoo.com   function  error  response  body        if  error            console.log error ;       else           console.log response.statusCode ;         ;       leads to        [Error: connect ENOTSOCK] code:  ENOTSOCK   errno:  ENOTSOCK   syscall:  connect         vs on node 0.10 it logs      200

title: Array parameters in the query string produce numeric indexes
body: js request  uri:  http://foo.com   qs:  filter: [ a    b ]   ;      Will make a request to http://foo.com?filter[0]=a filter[1]=b. It should be making a request to http://foo.com?filter[]=a filter[]=b.

title: Require Colon in Basic Auth
body: Going by RFC 2617  it seems that a colon is required in the base64 encoded user pass.         To receive authorization  the client sends the userid and password     separated by a single colon   :   character  within a base64 [7]    encoded string in the credentials.        basic credentials = base64 user pass       base64 user pass  = <base64 [4] encoding of user pass  except not limited to 76 char/line>       user pass   = userid  :  password       userid      =  <TEXT excluding  : >       password    =  TEXT      https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2617.txt  Some servers handle the case of a missing colon  but others do not. For instance  the standard method in Golang for parsing basic auth requires a colon. http://golang.org/src/net/http/request.go?s=16575:16641 L518  Rather than force users to specify an empty string  it would be preferable to treat an undefined password as an empty string.

title: Possible npm release missing for v2.53.1
body: I was poking around the repository s tags and its npm page to see what the latest release is  and I noticed that there is a tag for v2.53.1  while 2.53.0 is the latest release on npm. Is this intentional  or did someone forget to  npm publish ?

title: relative URLs with the request library
body: please see this SO question:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29026346/relative uri for node js request library  is it possible to use relative URLs with the request library?

title: Add support for qs options via qsOptions key
body: Closes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1473  The  qsOptions  key can be used to pass options to both the  parse  and the  stringify  methods of the  qs  and  querystring  modules.  The  arrayFormat  options was missing from the  qs  readme https://github.com/hapijs/qs/pull/72

title: Add a note to the readme about the current stable release not having Node 0.12/io.js support
body: The master branch has recently been fixed on Node 0.12 and io.js  and the tests run on those versions along with 0.10   though it may not be obvious to some users that the current stable version does not support this yet.

title: encoding: null is a hard to find trick when response body is not utf 8
body: Hi  i am requesting some xml file encoded in iso 8859 1 and have to go through this      var icon = require  iconv lite  ; request  url: myurl  encoding: null   function err  res  body      var str = iconv.decode body.toString  binary     Latin1  ;   // do stuff with utf 8 string   ;      to convert it to utf 8. The  encoding: null  thing is particularly tricky   Don t you think request API should be more explicit ?

title: Weird JSON.parse   issue on Node v0.12.0
body: The JSON you receive on a GET call from https://api.github.com/repositories is a perfectly valid one. But JSON.parse   on the body gives a  SyntaxError: Unexpected token u  error. The body variable has string type. eval   fixes it but eval   is evil. Performing .toString   on body and then  JSON.parse body   works fine.

title: Fix baseUrl and redirections.
body: I found a bug in new  baseUrl  feature  when used in combination with redirection.  This script produce absurdly error  [Error: options.uri must be a string when using options.baseUrl] :      javascript var request = require  ./node_modules/request  ; var http = require  http  ;  var s = http.createServer function req  res      if req.url ===  /redirect/         res.writeHead 302          location :  /             else        res.statusCode = 200       res.end     .listen 6767 ;  request     url:  /     baseUrl:  http://localhost:6767/redirect      function  err  resp  body      console.log err ;   s.close  ;   ;      This is due to the fact that first call changes URI to an object  and therefore in the second iteration  to redirected page  can be seen as a string. The solution is delete  baseUrl  immediately after use  because certainly no longer needed.  This pull request fixes this bug. Test included.

title: facebook login problem
body: Hi.  I have an issue about facebook login. When I try to login facebook send me this error:       error :  message : Missing client_id parameter.   type : OAuthException   code :101   :        I double check my code. There is not error I think. Here is my code. Maybe request has got a bug or something else. Am I missing something?      js var request = require  request        qs = require  querystring        createSendToken = require  ./jwt.js        config = require  ./config.js        User = require  ../models/User.js  ;   module.exports = function req  res        var accessTokenUrl =  https://graph.facebook.com/oauth/access_token ;     var graphApiUrl =   https://graph.facebook.com/me ;      var params =           client_id: req.body.cliendId          redirect_uri: req.body.redirectUri          client_secret: config.FACEBOOK_SECRET          code: req.body.code      ; /  I check the req.body. title: Not obeying customAgent CA

I ve tried passing it in the globalAgent object as well as to the pool...  My environment is an AWS private subnet with a Squid caching proxy performing transparent SSL Bumps.  I have generated a self signed CA which is working perfectly with modules that use node s core https library  such as aws sdk .  When I run: If I run  openssl s_client  showcerts  connect www.googleapis.com:443  I get the error I expect:  Verify return code: 19  self signed certificate in certificate chain    However  as long as I specify my CA    openssl s_client  showcerts  CAfile /etc/ssl/certs/myCA.pem  connect www.googleapis.com:443  Open SSL shows  Verify return code: 0  ok    I m passing this customAgent on to request:      js     var customAgent = new https.Agent           ca : require  fs  .readFileSync process.env.SSL_CA_CERT         ;      and still get the self signed cert error.  NODE_DEBUG=request  seems to show the ca buffer as the request is made  but I still get the cert error...  Thanks

title: https proxy fails with ECONNRESET  and  unknown header
body: Hi   I ve been trying to install tnode sass on my machine and I keep hitting problems with my proxy server. I ve raised the issue sass/node sass 768  and it appears that this may be an issue with request  or a misuse of request.  Anyway  here is the case:   I ve got a proxy  cntlm  that can be accessed through both HTTP and HTTPS. When I specify the proxy url using  http:  things work as expected. When I specify the proxy url using  https:  nothing works at all.  Basically  whenever I use  https  as proxy url I get the same root cause for the error: The script returns an  ECONNRESET  error  with no more information about what was wrong   and the proxy debug logs show the following:              Round 1 C: 21         Reading headers  21 ... HEAD:  headers_recv: Unknown header    . headers_recv: fd 21 error  4 Joining thread 140418809730816; rc: 0      This error message seems to indicate that the headers part of the request contains a     character that the proxy does not understand. It also seems that this     character is not followed by a line break.  The same thing happens whether I set  tunnel  to  true  or  false .  The  options  object passed to request is the following:      javascript      rejectUnauthorized: false    proxy:  https://127.0.0.1:3129     tunnel: true    ca: null    strictSSL: false         Note that in my situation  I don t have many possible workarounds  such as setting the proxy URL to http  because the script must run without extra configuration on all the computers of my organization  which has a very heterogenous setup.

title: Empty response detected as Connection refused
body: Chrome gives me ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE for Web1 and ERR_CONNECTION_RESET for Web2. Request gives me ECONNRESET for both of them.

title: Support/refactor init method
body: Hello everybody   it s been a while since I ve submitted a refactoring PR  and this time I decided to try to break up and clean the logic that s happening in the Request.prototype.init function. At the moment I ve refactored a bunch of code into some well meaning functions. I also leveraged the  constructObject  function heavily  I do notice that s not necessary in every place I use it  but the I do feel that it s useful in most of the areas.  The biggest difference is that the init logic has been moved to another module. This is more of a temporary refactor  there was just to much logic polluting the request.js file. Another big difference is the way I m doing some error handling  you ll see what I mean  but just know I m not completely set on that implementation.  Overall this is still a work in progress  but I would like to hear some feedback.  Summoning: @simov @nylen @FredKSchott @mikeal

title: Update eslint
body: @simov I saw you mention updating eslint and decided to have a go at it.  In general I tried to avoid rocking the boat.  There are some new options which raise some issues since the code style was not consistent.  I just disabled these options in .eslintrc for now.  [no shadow] http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no shadow.html  Sounds like a good idea to me.  There are 21 no shadow issues in the code right now.  [key spacing] http://eslint.org/docs/rules/key spacing.html  At the moment the codebase uses a mixes of the two styles  which means eslint can t help us.  [no multi spaces] http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no multi spaces.html  There are a lot of inconsistencies in the code with this one:      // test baseUrl.js var http = require  http       request = require  ../index       tape = require  tape       url = require  url        vs      // test agentOptions.js var request = require  ../index       http    = require  http       server  = require  ./server       tape    = require  tape        as well as:      // lib/getProxyFromURI.js:67     return process.env.HTTPS_PROXY               process.env.https_proxy               process.env.HTTP_PROXY                process.env.http_proxy     null

title: Add table of contents in readme
body: Add table of contents in readme   Add back to top links at the end of each section   Add horizontal line divider after each section   Add visual cues in options list  Closes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1340 Also related to https://github.com/request/request/pull/1331  Basically I refactored the readme according to what @nylen outlined in https://github.com/request/request/issues/1340 issuecomment 69367275 as collaborative effort to improve the readme.  Easier to review the this PR would be to just check out the rendered markdown file https://github.com/simov/request/tree/refactor readme  Table of contents and back to top links at the end of each section are pretty self explanatory. The horizontal line divider between the sections is mostly for easier maintenance of the file  if you have good markdown syntax highlighting you ll now what I mean  Also I m putting 2 blank lines before and after each horizontal rule  and two blank lines before each header  not an actual rule  just fyi   The last thing was to use simple horizontal lines again  this time for the list of options.  Now if you take a look at it  you ll notice that it s a bit easier to fix your sight on certain things. So the presentation remains linear  no additional headers or text  yet just enough to scan through it faster.  I also wanted to split the sections into separate files and put them under docs folder. But I couldn t figure out a good way to introduce the building process to the user while having the combined readme all the time too.  /cc @rockbot @nylen @FredKSchott and anyone else

title: Digest With Multipart Form Upload  > 401
body: This curl statement works:      curl   user username:password   digest  s  S  F  mysubmit=Install   F  archive=@file.zip   F  passwd=  http://host/path      This gives me 401 s      javascript var request = require  request  ; var fs = require  fs  ;  var formData =     archive:       value: fs.readFileSync __dirname    /file.zip        options:         filename:  file.zip         contentType:  application/zip               mysubmit:  Install     passwd:     ;  request.post     url:  http://host/path     formData: formData    auth:        user :  username        pass :  password        sendImmediately : false        callback ;      It appears that request is not honoring  sendImmediately = false    Using Wireshark to inspect what is going on  this is the initial request using curl      POST /path HTTP/1.1 User Agent: curl/7.30.0 Host: host Accept:  /  Content Length: 0      and the response      HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized Content Length: 0 WWW Authenticate: Digest qop= auth   realm= therealm   nonce= 5452323445       then curl follows up with another post request that contains the multipart form data.   request  just uploads everything  including the contents of the multipart attachments  in the initial post.      POST /path HTTP/1.1 host: host content type: multipart/form data; boundary=                          214834890626340929689820 content length: 49533 Connection: keep alive                              214834890626340929689820      Even so  the correct 401 comes back with a  nonce  and  realm   but there is no second request.  The  auth.digest  callback is getting called  verified with a  console.log  statement  and it appears it is receiving all the correct values   nonce   etc . But I am not seeing a second request that actually posts with the correct  Authorization  header.

title: options.uri is a required argument when using default uri
body: I make heavy use of the  defaults  method to to create a request object with a fixed URI and then setting the other options dynamically. As of 2.54.0  I m now getting  options.uri is a required argument  when trying to make a request on that object  where I ve already set the uri . Downgrading to 2.53.0 clears it up. I didn t see anything in the changelog that would indicate that this would break.

title: forever not playing nicely with pool in node 0.12
body: It seems like the  forever  option isn t documented  anymore?  so I m not sure how intended this behavior is  or if it s the result of using a deprecated feature.  We ve used the  forever: true  alongside  pool:  maxSockets: 1024   in the past. This has worked well  but recently we ve found that it throws an error in node 0.12.  Here s a failing test I wrote for that: https://github.com/faradayio/request/commit/abe8b55  It s possible that since both  pool  and  forever  affect the agent  they were never intended to be compatible with each other  maybe. We ll be moving to  request.forever  maxSockets: 1024   .  Should request throw a warning if the user tries to combine these options? Are they supposed to work together?  Here s the error that occurs when I try to combine them in 0.12:      TypeError: Cannot read property  length  of undefined     at ForeverAgent.<anonymous>  /redacted/request/node_modules/forever agent/index.js:22:34      at ForeverAgent.emit  events.js:110:17      at Socket.onFree  _http_agent.js:202:10      at Socket.emit  events.js:104:17      at _http_client.js:453:14     at process._tickCallback  node.js:355:11

title: Question: returning the underlying native request?
body: Hi folks   I maintain [a module] https://github.com/thingdom/node neo4j  that builds on Request. To date  the module has entirely abstracted Request away; it takes care of making all requests and parsing all responses.  I d like to add an API that lets callers stream request   response data directly  but it d be nice to still maintain that abstraction/encapsulation of which lib I m using internally.  To that end  I thought maybe this new API could return the underlying native [ http.ClientRequest ] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_class_http_clientrequest   so after some investigation  I gave it a stab with Request [like so] https://github.com/thingdom/node neo4j/blob/4866366e8bc3da211e3ec72a02e5de3c559d083b/lib new/GraphDatabase.coffee L67 L72 :      js var req = Request  / ... /  ;  // Instead of leaking our  third party  Request instance  make sure to // explicitly return only its internal native ClientRequest instance. // https://github.com/request/request/blob/v2.53.1/request.js L904 // This is only populated when the request is  start ed  so  start  it  req.start  ; return req.req;         This  works ... but not really.  E.g. there s a race condition if you  pipe  anything to the native request: the Request wrapper no longer [ knows  about the pipe] https://github.com/request/request/blob/v2.53.1/request.js L618   so it may [ end  the request early] https://github.com/request/request/blob/v2.53.1/request.js L676   leading to a  write after end  error .   FWIW  this same race condition exists with Request proper  if you stream request data yourself manually via async  write  calls  rather than  pipe . But I m sure that s an uncommon use case.   In general  I also worry about other bugs: Request is expecting to manage the request and response  and it no longer will.  I could simply create the native request directly  via [ http.request ] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_http_request_options_callback   but it s nice to have the extra features that Request provides  e.g. proxy support.  So perhaps the answer is to simply return the full Request instance directly. But then the caller has to look at another API  and also depend on the particular version that my module is using  etc.     All of this is to say: is there any recommended/supported way of working with the underlying native request directly? Or is that explicitly discouraged? Any other suggestions?  Thanks

title: Node 0.12 keep alive?
body: Hey folks   Node 0.12  and presumably io.js  but I m less familiar there  added  keepAlive  and  keepAliveMsecs  options to the native  http.request :  https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_http_request_options_callback  Is there a way to specify or set those options with Request? If not  what s the recommendation with Node 0.12 in general?  Thanks

title: Fix defaults
body: Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1509  Introduced in https://github.com/request/request/pull/1429 https://github.com/request/request/pull/1430 follow up https://github.com/request/request/pull/1435  Related to this bug as well https://github.com/request/request/pull/1515  Calling a convenience method from default object wasn t using the defaults properties  because the method was not wrapped  and therefore the extend logic wasn t called at all.  Then I m temporarily passing a string to the wrap function so that I can make the head body check before calling the requester just to satisfy the https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/tests/test defaults.js L265 test.  I m going to improve the entire defaults related logic in index.js after this PR got merged in  because it s extremely hard to follow and obviously too error prone.

title: Refactor defaults
body: This is a follow up to https://github.com/request/request/pull/1518  Much more simplified defaults and params initialization in index.js. Basically flattened the logic  also moved the  wrap  closure outside of the  defaults  method and I left it in index.js because I think it s very closely related to the  request  method  and the convenience http verb methods. Also completely dropped all of the object extend closures  as I don t think they add any substantial value to that piece of code.  /cc @nylen @FredKSchott @mikeal

title: Add promise tests
body: A few promise tests using [bluebird] https://github.com/petkaantonov/bluebird  as it seems to be the most popular promise solution atm  plus it s used by [request promise] https://github.com/tyabonil/request promise  internally.  This is in attempt to make the promise support first class citizen in request  as it turns out that a lot of people are using promises with request. Also these tests should cover the bugs found in https://github.com/request/request/issues/1506 and https://github.com/request/request/issues/1509  @kytwb @noseglid @ericlu88 @carsy @neverfox let me know if there is anything else that can be added as test cases here.

title: Request passes along undefined headers  causing a crash
body: After update to node 0.12 and the latest request  from   2.27.0  to   2.54.0    my app started crashing with this message:      _http_outgoing.js:333     throw new Error   name  and  value  are required for setHeader  .  ;           ^ Error:  name  and  value  are required for setHeader  .     at ClientRequest.OutgoingMessage.setHeader  _http_outgoing.js:333:11      at new ClientRequest  _http_client.js:101:14      at Object.exports.request  http.js:49:10      at Request.start  /Users/ivan/dev/c code/swordfish/main/node/node_modules/request/request.js:946:30      at Request.end  /Users/ivan/dev/c code/swordfish/main/node/node_modules/request/request.js:1514:10      at end  /Users/ivan/dev/c code/swordfish/main/node/node_modules/request/request.js:717:14      at Immediate._onImmediate  /Users/ivan/dev/c code/swordfish/main/node/node_modules/request/request.js:731:7      at processImmediate [as _immediateCallback]  timers.js:358:17       It seems the problem is in  _http_client.js :      javascript if  options.headers          var keys = Object.keys options.headers ;       for  var i = 0  l = keys.length; i < l; i              var key = keys[i];         self.setHeader key  options.headers[key] ;                    One of my headers here is  undefined   they are auto generated in some code paths .  I m not sure if node.js changed or request  but either way  it might not be a bad idea to check if some of these values are  undefined  and just skip them if yes.

title: False positive on NO_PROXY parsing can lead to not able to connect
body: I ve hit this issue which is very similar  if not the same  as  1294. It happened to me on 2.54.0 and 2.48.0 but strangely  2.49.0 was a version which seems to work properly.  As mentioned in  1294 in my case the NO_PROXY contained a host which was exactly 1 character longer than my actual destination host  which should have been accessed through the PROXY . It was however tried to connect directly  which resulted to no connection.  My suspicion is that this is related to some refactoring like https://github.com/request/request/commit/b205b73960b40a1edaa24f4ccede9b676c07cbf2 change but that s only a guess.

title: Proxying requests leaks connections when client timeouts when using the default node v0.10 Agent
body: Using the default Agent for proxying requests by piping leaks connections when the clients timeout. Combined with the default outgoing connection pool size of 5 this causes pool exhaustion quickly.  Reproduce with https://github.com/hvrauhal/requestjs proxy leaks agents.

title: More eslint
body: I updated eslint to 0.18.0 and added a couple rules for style consistency.          // Use if            //       ^ space      space after keywords : [2   always ]       There were only a few instances of  if    and  else   in the code  so this was clear.          // Use if            //          ^ space      space before blocks : [2   always ]       There were only a few instances of  if      in the code  so this was also clear.          // Use function test           //                 ^^ no space      space before function paren : [2   never ]      This one was harder.  There were tons of  function    s and  function name    s in the code  including  function Request    .  But there were way more  function   s and  function name   s.  Introducing with   always   created 739 errors  vs   never   creating 245.  One additional change  1ffc50d53511eb1b81d64da816adad3aa687e6b0 : eslint complained about an empty block statement  so I added the comment  // empty  to explicitly mark it as empty.

title: regression with  request.defaults      since version 2.54.0
body: I just upgraded from  2.53.0  to  2.55.0  and noticed some parts of my codebase have stopped working. I ve looked at the Change Log and see that  2.55.0  specifically mentions fixes here    but unfortunately I m seeing issues regardless.  In particular   json: true  is not being propagated and I end up with a string rather than an object in the  body  [probably nothing is  but that s the one that stands out]. Here is an example of how my code is laid out:      js var Request = require  request  .defaults      gzip :       true     json :       true   ;          js function _request method  extraOpts      var request = Request.defaults       foo:  bar      ;    return Promise.promisify request[method]   https://foo.bar   extraOpts ;        As is  this fails to include the defaults specified above:      js _request  get  ;      But if I explicitly specify it again things come back all JSONy:      js _request  get    json: true  ;      Request v0.53.0 works :v:

title: Fix coveralls
body: Added 3 test fixes that was causing the coveralls build to fail  check out the comments .  Coveralls is now using the GitHub s status API to report the coverage status  instead of using comments  So this will make the merge status bar color change based on the coverage results  just like any other build error do. Decrease in coverage will be considered a warning. Click on the _Show all checks_ button below.

title: clarify confusing timeout note
body: In the README  the documentation for  timeout  states:  > _timeout_   Integer containing the number of milliseconds to wait for a request to respond before aborting the request. Note that if the underlying TCP connection cannot be established  the OS wide TCP connection timeout will overrule the timeout option  the default in Linux is around 20 seconds .  I am confused by this. I assume that this note is supposed to refer to the  socket.connect    call timing out. http://linux.die.net/man/2/connect  However  in my testing it appears that  request  sets the timeout on the socket before the  connect    call  so it times out via the integer setting.      javascript var request;  request = require  request  ;  request.get     uri:  http://10.0.0.7     timeout: 3000    function err  res      console.log err ;   console.log res ;   ;      I also tried with  google.com:81 . Both timed out after 3 seconds  which is definitely not the system timeout  nothing in my  /etc/resolv.conf    and removing the timeout parameter means the queries hang for much longer.

title: Array is sent as object?
body: Not entirely sure that this is the fault of the request module  but it has been suggested that request is passing an array  [ some_state ]   as an object parameter s value  to an object itself     0  :  some_state    .  Relevant discussion: https://github.com/wit ai/node wit/issues/7 Relevant code:      js // Params     var options =           context:               state: [ some_state ]                      var query_params = _.extend   q : text   options ;  // Request options     var request_options =           url:  https://api.wit.ai/message           qs: query_params          json: true          headers: getHeaders access_token       ;  // Make the request     request request_options  function  error  response  body            if  response    response.statusCode  = 200                error =  Invalid response received from server:     response.statusCode                   callback error  body ;       ;

title: Doesn t try next IP after ECONNREFUSED?
body: I ve been doing some testing of various HTTP clients to see which ones will  after an ECONNREFUSED  try the next ipv4 address returned.  e.g. if we want to do an HTTP request of mail.google.com:  The DNS lookup yields these DNS records  in random order :      googlemail.l.google.com. 216    IN  A   74.125.237.213 googlemail.l.google.com. 216    IN  A   74.125.237.214      The HTTP client first tries 74.125.237.213  and if it fails to connect  it then tries 74.125.237.214.  Most clients  browsers  cURL  PHP  RubyGem::RestClient  all web browsers  do this. Some actually initiate a connection to   all   IPs and continue the request with whichever connected fastest.  _Request_  and indeed Node native http client  do not appear to do this; they just give up after the first failure.  Not sure what your position is on implementing this   just thought I d put it out there. Also tangentially related is the idea of  [happy eyeballs] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Eyeballs

title: Emit error instead of throw
body: Related to this https://github.com/request/request/issues/1318 issuecomment 97374120 onward      Breaking change  Any code that previously relied on catching the errors in the  catch  block will now receive them in the  callback  as errors if a  callback  is specified      js request  uri: ...    function  err  res  body      if  err        // all errors are received here       .on  error   function  err      // that s being called before being registered            No callback during initialization  This repository still have two error cases that throws in index.js But if the callback is missing  any error will be thrown anyway      js try     request  uri: ...   .on  error   function  err        // that s being called before being registered        catch  err      // EventEmitter throws the error if the event is unhandled           After successful initialization      js request  uri: ...    function  err  res  body      if  err        // all errors are received here       .on  error   function  err      // after successful initialization this is being registered              One possible way to receive the errors during initialization in the  on  error    event handler  is to use this hack      js setTimeout self.emit.bind self   error   new Error  ...     0  // instead of self.emit  error   new Error  ...         But it s unreliable and I m not going to use it.  // cc @mikeal @nylen @FredKSchott @saper

title: How do I set a socket timeout without setting a request lifetime timeout?
body: When I set the timeout option  I notice that the timeout can trigger before the the socket is opened. Looking at the code  it looks like a  setTimeout  is used before the request is opened. This is a problem for a project of mine since I want to launch concurrent requests but only apply a timeout to the opened socket and not to the entire lifetime of the request  e.g.  I don t want to time out waiting for a connection in the connection pool to become available . How can I set a timeout on the socket without enforcing a timeout on the entire request lifetime?

title: Update combined stream
body: This updated combined stream now uses an updated delayed stream which no longer uses the non standard  __defineGetter__  syntax. By removing this  request can now be loaded in IE10   which doesn t support  __defineGetter__  .

title: formData: Maximum call stack size exceeded
body: Hey guys   We are using your library in a project which sends a multipart body with an array of recipients. If the number of recipients is higher than 500 aprox  an exception is thrown. Check it out:      js var request = require  request  ;  var array = []; for  var i = 0; i < 500; i          array.push  data     i ;    var data =        array  : array  ;  request.post     url:  http://localhost:3000/example     formData: data    function  err  response  body        if  err  console.error err ;     console.log  All done.  ;   ;      This returns the following error:  RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded   We have been debugging the code and we think that the problem comes from   request.js  lin.  509 :      js    var appendFormValue = function  key  value          if  value.hasOwnProperty  value      value.hasOwnProperty  options              requestForm.append key  value.value  value.options          else           requestForm.append key  value                    for  var formKey in formData          if  formData.hasOwnProperty formKey             var formValue = formData[formKey]         if  formValue instanceof Array              for  var j = 0; j < formValue.length; j                  appendFormValue formKey  formValue[j]                        else             appendFormValue formKey  formValue                               If you have any doubt  do not hesitate to let us know. Thanks in advance :

title: Cannot issue HEAD request with a body
body: request prevents sending a HEAD request with a body. I think this is too strict.   It is only the _response_ to a HEAD request that must not include a body. The HEAD request itself may include a body  cf. [RFC 7231 section 4.3.2] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231 section 4.3.2  :  >  A payload within a HEAD request message has no defined semantics; >    sending a payload body on a HEAD request might cause some existing >    implementations to reject the request.  In other words  you can send HEAD with a body  but you might run into trouble.  The same is true for [GET] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231 section 4.3.1  and [DELETE] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231 section 4.3.5 :  > A payload within a GET request message has no defined semantics; >    sending a payload body on a GET request might cause some existing >    implementations to reject the request. >  >  A payload within a DELETE request message has no defined semantics; >    sending a payload body on a DELETE request might cause some existing >    implementations to reject the request.  Since request allows GET and DELETE with a body  I think it should allow HEAD with a body as well.

title: In case of errors  can the user expect res to be defined?
body: I was experiencing an issue where I was requesting a document from a server with a faulty HTTPS configuration  resulting in UNABLE_TO_VERIFY_LEAF_SIGNATURE.  In that case  the software I was using was still relying on  res  to be defined. Is that a valid assumption  meaning it s an issue with request  or isn t it  meaning it s an issue with the software I was using .  Original issue: https://github.com/Strider CD/strider/issues/767

title: Request that redirects leaves handles open
body: This code:      javascript var request = require  request  ;  request  http://google.com   function  error  response  body      console.log  Request done  ;   ;      hangs at the end  after quickly printing the  Request done  message.  It seems to be related to the redirect that happens in the problem code  from google.com to www.google.com .  The same code but with  http://www.google.com  exits immediately after printing the message.  Printing process._getActiveHandles   in the handler shows that there are two requests still active.  I ll take a stab at finding the cause  but any pointers from experienced contributors will be welcome.

title: Does request uses keep alive by default?
body: I can t find this anywhere.

title: Response stream closing doesn t stop the request  input  stream.
body: Reproduction: https://github.com/tmeasday/npm request hang  instructions contained.  Tested on 0.10.x  a few recent versions  and 0.12.2 w/ request 2.47.0 and 2.55.0.  We are streaming a request to a http server response almost verbatim like the proxy documented here: https://github.com/request/request streaming  On AWS Ubuntu machines  if a client drops the request before it s finished  the input stream   request.get   never closes  eventually filling up the socket pool  with default settings on 0.12.x it never runs out but it s a leak .

title: Weird issue when piping a chunked data from HTTP to a file in OS X
body: From [http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30085943/nodejs unexpected behaviour when piping chunked http data to a file in os x?noredirect=1 comment48289848_30085943] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30085943/nodejs unexpected behaviour when piping chunked http data to a file in os x?noredirect=1 comment48289848_30085943 .  I m getting a weird issue when piping a chunked data from HTTP to a file in OS X.  When triggering the GET HTTP request that initiates the download  my server responds with the following headers:      < content disposition: attachment; filename= resin Rpi2 0.1.0 0.0.12.img  < content encoding: gzip < content type: application/octet stream < date: Wed  06 May 2015 19:03:33 GMT < X Frame Options: DENY < x powered by: Express < transfer encoding: chunked < Connection: keep alive      My code goes like this:      fs = require  fs   request = require  request      If you want to try it by yourself  register to https://dashboard.resin.io   create a Raspberry Pi application  note the id on the url    and get the token from the preferences page. APPID =  ...  TOKEN =  ...  DEST =  imagetest.img   request   url:  https://dashboard.resin.io/download?network=ethernet wifiSsid= wifiKey= appId=  APPID     method:  GET    gzip: true   headers:       Authorization:  Bearer   TOKEN    .on  data    data   >   console.log data   .pipe fs.createWriteStream DEST        If I run that script  I correctly get the initial chunks  corresponding to about 10MB of data  but the connection then suddenly ends  and no other event  close  end  etc  is triggered from any of the streams.  What s even more weird is that commenting out  gzip: true  leads to the desired behaviour  I of course get a  .img.gz file in that case   and it also works as expected if keeping the  gzip: true  and piping to  process.stdout  instead of to a file.  Also notice the issue is not reproducible on Ubuntu. It only seems to happen in OS X and Windows.   cURL  also works as expected:        curl  H  Authorization: Bearer [token]   https://dashboard.resin.io/download?network=ethernet wifiSsid= wifiKey= appId=[appid]   o image.img      I ve proceeded to analyse the packet communication  [you can get the pcap here] http://filebin.net/5h4k576f6t/ResinImageDownloadIssue.pcap  :  I can see my IP is suddenly sending a ACK/FIN while the server is still sending me chunks:      Id = 2984 Source = 192.168.0.16 Destination = 52.4.102.97 Captured Length = 66 Packet Length = 66 Protocol = TCP Date Received = 2015 05 06 18:11:36  0000 Time Delta = 10.27246999740601 Information = 52264  > 443  [ACK  FIN]  Seq=2137874087  Ack=3255859962  Win=10407       Followed by a long loop of RST and ACK:      ... 192.168.0.16  > 52.4.102.97  52264  > 443 RST 52.4.102.97  > 192.168.0.16  443  > 52264 ACK ...      And finally an agreed ACK  FIN from both sides.  After a lot of experimentation  the issue is gone if I write the chunks to the destination stream manually instead of piping:      destination = fs.createWriteStream DEST   request   url:  https://dashboard.resin.io/download?network=ethernet wifiSsid= wifiKey= appId=  APPID     method:  GET    gzip: true   headers:       Authorization:  Bearer   TOKEN    .on  data    data   >   destination.write data

title: Fix stall when piping gzipped response
body: When the response content is piped through additional streams for decoding  e.g. for gzip decompression   pause and resume calls should be propagated to the last stream in the pipeline so that back pressure propagates correctly.  This avoids an issue where simultaneous back pressure from the content decoding stream and from a stream to which Request is piped could cause the response stream to get stuck waiting for a drain event on the content decoding stream which never occurs.  See  1567 for an example.  This commit also renames  dataStream  to  responseContent  to remedy my previous poor choice of name  since the name will be exposed on the Request instance it should be clearer and closer to the name used to refer to this data in the relevant RFCs.  Fixes  1567

title: Fix pause before response arrives
body: This PR fixes a bit of fallout due to overlooking the pause behavior before the response arrives in  1568 last night.  I added some additional tests which should help catch similar issues in the future.    If anyone has ideas for how to avoid the arbitrary  setTimeout s when testing  pause / resume   that would be great  currently it waits a bit between sending chunks to allow pausing and waits a bit more after calling  pause  to confirm no more data arrives .  Also  if there is a better location for the tests  I m open to moving them around too.  Due to  1568  we now propagate pause and resume to the response content stream  rather than the response stream.  However  when pause is called before the response arrives  the pause is still being applied to the response object directly.  Fix this by applying it to the response content stream in both cases.  This avoids the issue that if pause is called on a gzip request before the response arrives  it pauses the response then resumes the response content  meaning the response can not be resumed.  Also add tests of the pause/resume behavior for both the gzip and non gzip case both before and after the response has arrived.  This commit also makes the ancillary change that resume is now called unconditionally  when defined  in  Redirect   since we always want to dump the response data  and it was previously called unconditionally in  onRequestResponse  .

title: Discovered tests that weren t properly running
body: I came across some tests in the test body.js that didn t seem to be actually asserting anything. It seems that assertions are only being done if there is an expectBody property and if the value of the expectBody property is a Buffer  otherwise it won t run an assertion and just pass. To make matters even more complicated some of the tests don t give an expectBody property  so I m not completely sure how to fix those tests. Just wanted to bring this to our attention.

title: Refresh the oauth_nonce on redirect   1573
body: Cache the initial oauth options passed to request in _oauth.params   On subsequent calls to init   use the cached _oauth.params   to invoke the oauth params generation logic again  Fixes  1573

title: request.defaults   doesn t always preserve headers and cookie jar
body: javascript var baseRequest = request.defaults     headers:  x token:  my token       var specialRequest = baseRequest.defaults     headers:  special:  special value           According to the documentation   specialRequest  should send both the  x token  and  special  headers. However  this isn t always the case; sometimes  it only sends the  special  header. Similarly  the cookie jar  if one is being used  gets unassigned.  I can provide a more concrete example if required.

title: Making several request.forever calls
body: I want to know if this is intended functionality and if so why.      javascript r = request.forever  maxSockets: 1    uri:  http://google.com    function err  res  body      r2 = request.forever  maxSockets: 3    uri:  http://google.com    function err  res  body      console.log r.agent.maxSockets  // 1 console.log r2.agent.maxSockets  // 1 console.log r.agent === r2.agent  // true       Essentially we re reusing the same Agent object for both requests and not updating to  maxSockets: 3  for the second request. Is this intended? @simov @nylen @mikeal

title: Error: custom CA behind corporate proxy
body: Hello all and congratulations for this awesome library .  I ve been experiencing some issues passing custom CA certificates to request. I followed the documentation  setting  agentOptions.ca  successfully in an non proxy environment  but then I moved the code to a proxied one  proxy configured via   http_proxy    and found that it didn t work any more. Te error that returned the previously working code was that it couldn t verify the CA. After some debugging and code inspection I ve summed up the following:  1. using  options.agentOptions.ca   which is the way stated in the documentation  will work in a non proxied env  but not in a proxied one. 2. using  https.globalAgent.options.ca   which is not documented  but is stated in many places  stackoverflow  forums...  as a feasible way of setting it  will work on non proxied but won t in proxied again. 3. using  options.ca   which is not documented  I had to find it inspecting code and later in some issue comments in github  WORKS IN BOTH  non proxied and proxied environments.  The problem lies in this piece of code  or so I think       javascript function constructTunnelOptions request      var proxy = request.proxy    var tunnelOptions =       proxy :         host      : proxy.hostname        port      :  proxy.port        proxyAuth : proxy.auth        headers   : request.proxyHeaders            headers            : request.headers      ca                 : request.ca      cert               : request.cert      key                : request.key      passphrase         : request.passphrase      pfx                : request.pfx      ciphers            : request.ciphers      rejectUnauthorized : request.rejectUnauthorized      secureOptions      : request.secureOptions      secureProtocol     : request.secureProtocol        return tunnelOptions        In order to account for other possibles sources of CA information  this code should become something like:      javascript var tunnelOptions =   //...     ca                 : request.ca     agentOptions.ca    https.globalAgent.options.ca //...        This should take the right order of priority for CAs  request > agentOptions > globalAgent . There s a problem  though:  agentOptions  is not accessible from  constructTunnelOptions . Other alternative could be to use  request.agent    agentOptions  are used to construct that  .agent   but then again   request.agent  is constructed way after  constructTunnelOptions  is called  thus no luck there neither.  One point worth to be discussed  then  is if it s  sane  or semantically correct to set the CA in  agentOptions while in a proxied environment  as there s going to be no agent involved in the communication  it instead uses a tunneled TLS connection   and that s tat. But I also find that  as request tries  and   THANK YOU FOR THAT    to hide the proxy configuration from the developer  it should maintain coherence in the settings among proxied and non proxied environments.    CONCLUSION:   I think the best way to solve this issue is also the simplest: document  options.ca  as the right way of setting the CAs for request  as  agentOptions.ca  would leave uncovered proxied environments  as it has to be  . Then  if something breaks  try to fix it. But PLEASE document  options.ca  now  as not doing so _is a defect in itself_.  I ve found that this lack of documentation is related to a number of other issues   1490   1290   1229   1236  and even pull request that didn t make it to master   1289  but fixed this issue.

title: Refactor test default tests  according to comments in  1430
body: Hopefully this will make the maintenance of these tests a bit easier  because even with all functions folded is hard to constantly jump back and forth just to follow a single test. Also the tests are actually using tape now instead of assert and some dummy assertion in the request s callback.  Comments here  1430 and in subsequent PRs as well.

title: Fixing documentation regarding TLS options   1583
body: Fixing the documentation to recommend using  options.ca    options.cer    options.key  and  options.passphrase  instead of  options.agentOptions.  homologues  to avoid trouble in proxied environments  as commented in  1583

title: Question: can loop the request?
Form Data and Basic Auth => request timeout

The request takes for ever and then eventually times out.....              var formData =                   my_field:  my_value           ;         var options =                   url:  http://posttestserver.com/post.php?dir=example                   method:  POST                    auth :                            user :  username                            pass :  password                            sendImmediately : false                                    formData : formData          ;         request options  function optionalCallback err  httpResponse  body                            if  err                                    return console.error  upload failed:   err ;                                                   console.log  Upload successful   Server responded with:   body ;                 res.send body ;                 res.end  ;           ;       If you comment out the formData  it works. Or If you instead comment out the auth info=> works.

title: No abort   method on invalid protocol
body: If you are redirected to a site with an invalid protocol  request will handle this fine and emits an  error  event with the message:      [Error: Invalid protocol: mailto:]      Now if you want to handle that error and abort the request like this:      js var request = require  request  ;  var requestStream = request  http://httpbin.org/redirect to?url=mailto:test@example.com  ;  requestStream     .on  error   function              console.log  [error]   arguments ;         requestStream.abort  ;       ;      you will get the following exception:      /node_modules/request/request.js:1264     self.response.abort                     ^ TypeError: Object  <IncomingMessage> has no method  abort      at Request.abort  /node_modules/request/request.js:1264:19      at Request.<anonymous>  /protocol issue.js:12:17      at Request.emit  events.js:95:17      at Request.init  /node_modules/request/request.js:591:17      at Request.onRequestResponse  /node_modules/request/request.js:1127:10      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:95:17      at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient [as onIncoming]  http.js:1688:21      at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete [as onHeadersComplete]  http.js:121:23      at Socket.socketOnData [as ondata]  http.js:1583:20      at TCP.onread  net.js:527:27       due to the  IncomingMessage  object not having a  abort    method.  I m calling the  abort    method here just to make sure that everything is cleaned up after the request errored out  no memory leaks .

title: Webworker support
body: I m not sure if this was even considered  however here is a simple example of what I am talking about. https://gist.github.com/formula1/888cbc3b332aa7451374.  This is important in situations where the developer expects large sets of data and would prefer not to have them iterated over them within the browser.

title: Global handlers

I m using .defaults to set a number of global defaults and would like to let request handle connection errors so my code can focus on other types of errors but I m having a hard time figuring out how to do this. Particularly because I really would like to extend request after applying some defaults to it.  Can anyone point me to where I may be able to read more about this? Perhaps an example or the section of the code I need to understand to figure this out? I ve tried to go through the source but still can t figure it out.  Is it even appropriate to use  util.inherit MyClass  request   or  util.inherit MyClass  request.defaults ...   ? So I can later do  myClassInstance.get  ....   Thank you

title: A few minor fixes:
body:
Moved removeRefererHeader to the appropriate section of the options docs Pass options to the redirect s module onRequest method as it makes it more obvious from where these options are coming from the extending of the request object in the ctor is a bit unexpected to say the least Attached the debug function to the request s prototype to make it accessible to the modules through the request instance
This also fixes the request.debug call in the har module which obviously is not covered by the tests atm or rather it should be obvious if coveralls was actually working ..

title: Invalid URI throws exception when NO_PROXY is set in environment
body: > request.post  uri:  invalid    function err  res      /.../node_modules/request/lib/getProxyFromURI.js:5   return hostname.replace /^ . /   .  .toLowerCase                    ^ TypeError: Cannot read property  replace  of null   at formatHostname  /.../node_modules/request/lib/getProxyFromURI.js:5:18    at uriInNoProxy  /.../node_modules/request/lib/getProxyFromURI.js:21:18    at getProxyFromURI  /.../node_modules/request/lib/getProxyFromURI.js:55:25    at Request.init  /.../node_modules/request/request.js:447:18       The URI validation happens on [line 457 of request.js] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L457   but when  NO_PROXY  is set in the environment  the hostname is parsed out of the URI before the validation happens. If an invalid URI has no hostname  then the above null error is thrown  which is no good for asynchronous code.  It looks like it d be possible to move the URI validation above the proxy and tunnel bits  so that the error can be emitted normally.

title: Extract the querystring logic into separate module:
body: Update  qs  to version 3.0.0 with support for rfc3986 encoding   Use request s rfc3986 only when using the  querystring  module   Add test branch for rfc3986 encoding tests using  querystring    Support for  eq    sep  and  options  arguments for  querystring     parse  and  stringify  methods via option keys  I was waiting for this PR https://github.com/hapijs/qs/pull/76 to get in to refactor the  rfc3986  logic in request. Then this bug report https://github.com/request/request/issues/1593 came out  so this PR is fixing both issues.  At first I tried using  querystring.escape  for rfc3986 encoding in  querystring.stringify       js this.lib.escape = function  str   return this.rfc3986 str  .bind this       But that would affect the global namespace so I opted out for standard wrapping.  Next I had to export the  querystring.unescape  out of the Querystring module      js Querystring.prototype.unescape = querystring.unescape      because it s used in two places in request.js Quick check on the node s code revealed this:      js QueryString.unescape = function s  decodeSpaces      try       return decodeURIComponent s ;     catch  e        return QueryString.unescapeBuffer s  decodeSpaces .toString  ;      ;      So probably we can use directly  decodeURIComponent  in our context  but then again I chose the safer option.  @limbo lab now you can pass the  sep    eq  and  options  arguments to the  querystring  module like this:      js qsStringifyOptions: sep: ;   eq: :   options: ...        Let me know what do you think  as there no tests for this behavior yet  and it s not documented in the readme.  Fixes  1593

title: Is ignoring res.resume a problem in the browser when doing streaming?
body: I have seen that in [redirect.js] https://github.com/request/request/blob/3249d71d36ded7e84d271e688316469ed8ac092a/lib/redirect.js L86 L91  there is a workaround for Browserify  which is related to [this issue] https://github.com/substack/http browserify/issues/81  :      js     // ignore any potential response body.  it cannot possibly be useful     // to us at this point.     // response.resume should be defined  but check anyway before calling. Workaround for browserify.     if  response.resume          response.resume              Now I wonder whether this may cause any undesired behavior in the browser when using streaming. Does anybody have some experience on this?

title: Move tunnel logic into separate module
body: Following the current convention for the rest of the internal modules in request I moved out the tunnel logic. The first two commits are strictly non breaking changes. In the third one I removed 3 properties out of the request instance.  I m overriding the  proxyHeaderWhiteList  and  proxyHeaderExclusiveList  via the  options  argument in  setup . In future I would like to not rely on extending the instance in the request ctor  so this approach will help me on the next step of the refactoring. In future I would like to have a strict mechanism with corresponding tests to explicitly define all of the expected public properties for the request instance. This will give us the flexibility to make internal changes more easily  as right now it s not clear if a property is set on the request instance with the intention to be public  or just to carry state through out the instance. And of course someone down the line might actually rely on it.  Also what I noticed is that  options.proxyHeaderExclusiveList  extends  defaultProxyHeaderExclusiveList   but  options.proxyHeaderWhiteList  overrides  defaultProxyHeaderWhiteList . Changing  options.proxyHeaderWhiteList  to extend  defaultProxyHeaderWhiteList  doesn t break anything  therefore we don t have tests for that behavior  so I left it as it is.  //cc @mikeal @nylen

title: Fix OAuth query transport_method

Additionally now  request.uri  is constructed properly when using OAuth  transport_method:query   so when using  request debug  the correct  uri  is dumped containing all of the query parameters.  Lastly I greatly improved the OAuth transport_method related tests  because they were a bit loose and the cause of this bug in the first place.

title: Version 2.50 introduced odd JSON behavior
body: We are having a problem interacting with a server written in GO when we update request from 2.49.0 to 2.50.0.  This issue still exists in the latest 2.x release   The issue is that the JSON being sent when  json: true  is set in the options is wrapped as a string.  Here is a request body from v2.49.0:      POST / HTTP/1.1 host: 192.168.1.8:8755 accept: application/json content length: 102 Connection: keep alive    directory :    filename : 6 8 2015.DAT   body : 6 8 2015 t8/6/2015 7:00:00 PM t8/6/2015 7:21:00 PM        Here is the same exact request body from v2.50.0      POST / HTTP/1.1 host: 192.168.1.8:8755 accept: application/json content type: application/json content length: 118 Connection: keep alive      directory  :       filename  :  6 8 2015.DAT     body  :  6 8 2015  t8/6/2015 7:00:00 PM  t8/6/2015 7:21:00 PM          The latter causes the Go  json.Unmarshal  method to choke with:   json: cannot unmarshal string into Go value of type main.ServerMessage   Looking through the changelog.md file the only change that seems to be relevant was the addition of an optional  reviver     however undoing that change doesn t seem to solve this problem.

title: forever: true  causes memory to leak like the deepwater horizon
body: javascript var request = require  request  ;  var concurrency = 128; var inProgress = 0; var startedCount = 0; var finishedCount = 0;  function fillQueue       while  inProgress < concurrency        makeRequest  ;        function makeRequest       inProgress  ;   startedCount  ;    request.post       uri:  http://localhost/       forever: true      function        inProgress  ;     finishedCount  ;     fillQueue  ;     ;    fillQueue  ;  setInterval function      console.log inProgress   requests in progress    startedCount   started    finishedCount   finished  ;    1000 ;      When executed  this script will leak memory until you run out of it. This effect has been observed on ubuntu 14.04 using node 0.11.16 and 0.12.4.   There is no memory leak in 0.10.25  .  Don t run this script if you have a server running locally on port 80  this might DOS it.  Commenting out  forever: true  will cause this script to run as normal  but without the memory leak  and presumably without keepalive support.

title: request readable stream does not implement read method
body: From what I can tell the docs suggest that  request  returns a readable stream.  However the  read    method is not implemented [per the stream docs] https://nodejs.org/api/stream.html stream_readable_read_size .  This prevents interoperability with other libraries that rely on this method being implemented.  Here is an example: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30902851/stream response from nodejs request to s3  There are libs like [s3 upload stream] https://github.com/nathanpeck/s3 upload stream  but seems like this should be un necessary.  I m using request 2.57.0 and node 0.10.33

title: Update README.md
body: The documentation for the  encoding : null  argument does not emphasize that this is necessary for binary response data  something that is not obvious   see http://stackoverflow.com/a/14855016/368896. I ve added a parenthetical comment to emphasize this in the documentation. This would have saved me  and hopefully will save others .

title: docs appear to be incorrect for a simple request
body: The docs say request should be called like:       js var request = require  request  ; request  http://www.google.com   function  error  response  body      if   error    response.statusCode == 200        console.log body  // Show the HTML for the Google homepage.             When I use  request  like:       js //  this is just some prototype code         for  i = 0  len = urls.length; i < len; i              url = urls[i];         result = [];         logger = this.logger;          request url  function error  resp  body    // url is a string  not an object or array           console.log  status:    resp.statusCode ;      It s getting routed to:    function request  uri  options  callback      line 44  and my callback is being passed in the options position  causing my callback to not be called. No errors are thrown though.   It looks like the docs may be incorrect.

I get the exact file uploaded. I have turned off the CRLF tokens yet this thing is done. Can somebody help here?

title: Fix form method
body: Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1630  It turned out that when the body is set via the  .form    method the  content length  is not being set  and therefore the request is sent as  transfer encoding: chunked   which may cause problems with some servers.  So I refactored out the logic responsible for setting up the  content length :      js function setContentLength        if   Buffer.isBuffer self.body      Array.isArray self.body         self.body = new Buffer self.body        if   self.hasHeader  content length          var length =  Array.isArray self.body         ? self.body.reduce function  a  b   return a   b.length   0        : self.body.length     if  length          self.setHeader  content length   length        else         self.emit  error   new Error  Argument error  options.body.                     Much sexier than it was before  plus that conditional structure allows it to be called again inside the  defer  method. Now for the function name and declaration position it s just there for now  I couldn t figure out a better place to put it  but then again it s visible inside the  defer  function.  Lastly the  test form urlencoded  tests now checks if the  content length  header is present as well.

title: accepting url objects in request constructor

title: pipe/proxy but also attach a key / write after end error
body: I m trying to setup a webservice that could call other webservices if something is on a remote machine.  To make this semi secure there s a hashed auth key that gets sent with the request  the master server should attach this prior to calling the remote .  However it seems if I try to add the auth key I get write after end error. I ve tried in several ways...      js var proxyReq = req.pipe request       url: server.url   req.url      body:  auth: auth       json: true    ; console.log  forwarding     req.url ; auth server.auth    config.auth  req.url  function err  auth       if err  return res.error err ;     //TODO can you forward form data  etc?     req.on  error   function err           console.log  ERROR: master s request had error:  ;         console.log err ; //write after end error occurs       ;     res.on  error   function err           console.log  ERROR: master s response had error:  ;         console.log err ;       ;     req.on  end   function            console.log  ENDED: master s request ended  ;       ;     res.on  end   function            console.log  ENDED: master s response ended  ;       ;      proxyReq.pipe res ;     // req.pipe request       //  url: server.url   req.url      //  body:  auth: auth       //  json: true     //   .pipe res  ;      // request[req.method.toLowerCase  ]       //  url: server.url   req.url      //  body:  auth: auth       //  json: true     //   .pipe res ;   ;      I don t want to look or have to deal with any of the data from the request if it s going to be proxy ed  method  form data  queries  json  steams  etc ... Is this possible with this module...?

title: Ability to distinguish connect timeouts and read timeouts
body: This request times out because the  connect  socket call fails:      javascript var request = require  request  ; request.get  http://google.com:81    timeout: 3000   function err  response  body        console.log err.code ===  ETIMEDOUT  ;     process.exit 0 ;   ;      This request times out because the  read  socket call doesn t see any response in 3 seconds:      javascript var request = require  request  ; request.get  http://localhost:5501    timeout: 3000   function err  response  body        console.log err.code ===  ETIMEDOUT  ;     process.exit 1 ;          I m using [hamms] https://github.com/kevinburke/hamms  in the second test   It would be nice to be able to distinguish these. Particularly  requests to a third party provider are failing and it would be good to distinguish whether the request actually made it to their server  their problem  or not  our problem .  It would also be neat because you could figure out whether or not the request made it to the server   a connection timeout is always retry able  a read timeout on a POST is not.

body: I cannot figure out why  but running a simple one liner application as the following      js var request = require  request  ;      using [ babel node ] https://babeljs.io/docs/usage/cli/ babel node  throws a rather strange error:      /usr/share/javascript/node uuid/uuid.js:225   if  _global.define    define.amd                 ^ TypeError: Cannot read property  define  of undefined      Any ideas why that might be the case?

title: Providing the user defined headers to the form data set headers method
body: This change allows the user to override form data s default content type header by providing the headers object to the getHeaders function.

title: Breaking change: 2.50.0
body: Hi there    I m really struggling to update a private module of mine past v2.49.0 because 2.50.0 seems to have a breaking change in my code.  Through request debug each version shows near identical data. Logging the request objects that are sent shows identical data  yet the response from the site who s API I am using fails.  Does anyone have any knowledge of what changed in 2.50.0 to create this I am having?       js var opts =           method: type          url: settings.gatewayUrl   loc          headers:               Accept:  application/json  text/javascript   / ; q=0.01               Cookie: this.cookies               Content Type :  application/json                     callbacks:              success: successCallback              failure: failureCallback            ; if  data            opts.data = JSON.stringify data ;         Opts is passed as obj to the send function       js Gateway.prototype.send = function  obj        var req =           method: obj.method          url: obj.url          headers: obj.headers          json: true      ;     if  typeof obj.data  ==  undefined            req.body = obj.data;           request req  function  err  res  body            if  err                if  typeof obj.callbacks.failure ===  function                     obj.callbacks.failure err ;                                 if  typeof obj.callbacks.success ===  function                 obj.callbacks.success body ;             console.log req ;             console.log body ;                   ;      Thanks in advance anyone who may have an idea as per what is causing such a difference between the two minor versions of request. All requests go through the send function  GET s work fine  POST s seem to be the ones to break. It is not a cookie issue  as the GET s correctly return. POST s respond with a server code of  requestError   even though I know that doesn t really mean much...

title: Can t pipe from request that has a POST body
body: I m trying to create a new request object by piping from an Express request. This works fine for GET requests  but for POST requests that have a body  the body does not seem to be copied into the new request. I tried copying over the body manually like so:   let pipedReq = req.pipe request   url:  http://www.example.com   form: req.body    ;   This copies over the body but then I get a  write after end  error when  pipedReq  is cleaned up. Might be related to  1659.  It s easy to reproduce the problem with the following simple Express app:      js  use strict ;  let express = require  express  ; let request = require  request  ;  let app = express  ;  app.use  /    req  res  =>     req.pipe request.post   url:  http://www.example.com   form:   foo:  bar      ;   ;  app.listen process.env.PORT    3000 ;      Backtrace:      Error: write after end     at ClientRequest.OutgoingMessage.write  _http_outgoing.js:413:15      at Request.write  /.../node_modules/request/request.js:1354:25      at end  /.../node_modules/request/request.js:548:16      at Immediate._onImmediate  /.../node_modules/request/request.js:576:7      at processImmediate [as _immediateCallback]  timers.js:358:17
