title: Request POST body does not get forwarded to the redirected URI if request instance is a target of a ReadableStream.
body: Let s say I have the following scenario:         BROWSER             PROXY SERVER                       THIRD PARTY SERVER                                                                              POST /        >                         forward request to /                         to third party                  >                                                             / Redirect 307                                                  <         Location: /redirect target                             follow redirect with POST body                        to /redirect target             >   /redirect target                                                                 process request body                                                                 send response                                                                     <                              send response back to browser              <                 Response  Received       If I pipe a  readableStream  to an instance of  request  that has  followAllRedirects  set to  true   the final third party request handler   /redirect target   sees a 0 length request body  and a content length header erroneously set to 0.   However  If I assign a    body:  something     to the request options  the third party request handler does see the proper body length and content.  The request body is being set to zero here:  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L572  Here s a test snippet demonstrating it:      javascript var app = require  express    ; var bl = require  bl  ; var request = require  request  ; var ReadableStream = require  stream  .Readable;  app.post  /route should redirect   function  incomingRequest  outgoingResponse      outgoingResponse.redirect 307   /redirect target  ;   outgoingResponse.end  incorrect response  ;     app.post  /redirect target   function  incomingRequest  outgoingResponse      incomingRequest.pipe bl function  err  requestData        if  err  throw err;     console.log  should see  correct request :   requestData.toString   ;     outgoingResponse.end  correct response  ;      ;   ;  var server = app.listen 3000 ;  var processResponse = bl function  err  responseData      console.log  should see  correct response :   responseData.toString   ;   server.close  ;   ;  function works       var outgoingRequest = request       method:  post       url:  http://localhost:3000/route should redirect       followAllRedirects: true       // Pre defined body     body:  correct request      ;    outgoingRequest.pipe processResponse ;    function doesNotWork       var outgoingRequest = request       method:  post       url:  http://localhost:3000/route should redirect       followAllRedirects: true     ;    outgoingRequest.pipe processResponse ;    // Body as a readableStream source that we pipe to the request instance:   var source = new ReadableStream  ;   source._read = function noop     ;   source.pipe outgoingRequest ;   source.push  correct request  ;   source.push null ;        I might be missing something obvious  but I ll continue to investigate.

title: Request stream   manipulating cookie before response piping
body: I have a Express proxy that uses request to make CRUD calls to a remote server. On the response  I do cookie manipulation to change the path. This is the code here.          request           method: req.method          url: proxyUrl          jar: jar          headers: headers          json: jsonBody         function error  response  body             if  error    response.statusCode  == 201    response.statusCode  == 200                logger.info  proxying failed   reason:     error ;             return res.status response.statusCode .send body ;          ;         var cookies = jar.getCookies proxyUrl ;         for  var i = 0; i < cookies.length; i                  var cookie = cookies[i];             if  cookie.path  ==  /                     cookie.path =  / ; //change path from /api to /                 cookie.secure =  os.hostname  .indexOf  local   >  1 ? false : true ;                           res.cookie cookie ;          ;         res.headers = response.headers;         return res.status response.statusCode .send body ;       ;      This works fine. But now  NodeJs comes with streams. So  I write this piece of code to achieve the same with nodejs streams.          req.pipe          request               method:req.method              url: proxyUrl              jar: jar              json:req.body             .on  response   function response            var cookies = jar.getCookies proxyUrl ;         console.log cookies ;         if  response.statusCode === 201    response.statusCode === 200    response.statusCode === 202                logger.info  successfully proxied  ;              for  var i = 0; i < cookies.length; i                      var cookie = cookies[i];                 if  cookie.path  ==  /                         cookie.path =  / ; //change path from /api to /                     cookie.secure =  os.hostname  .indexOf  local   >  1 ? false : true ;                                   jar.setCookie cookie  proxyUrl ;                         else               logger.info  proxying failed   reason:     error     refer body  ;                 .pipe res

title: through2 compatibility
body: Hi guys  congrats for this awesome lib.  I need to transform the request body before it has been proxied.  This is my code      javascript  function write chunk  encoding  next     var transformed_body = new BodyHelper JSON.parse chunk   this.body_transformation .apply     this.push JSON.stringify transformed_body     next  ;    var transform = through.obj write ; transform.body_transformation = // custom rule req.pipe transform .pipe request.post settings  .pipe res       the output of the transformation is correct but your module don t send the body  why?  Thanks

title: Error: socket hang up in Node 4.2.1  but not 0.12
body: Hello   I m trying to debug this issue: https://github.com/blakmatrix/node zendesk/issues/110  Having looked into it a bit  it looks like it is a bug in  request  the only alternative could be that the API I m making requests to is rejecting the useragent with  node/4.2.1  in and not the one with  node/0.12  in.   request  is being passed the same data in both versions of Node  and is being called multiple times. It never fails on the first time it is called  it usually fails between the third and sixth times it s being passed only slightly different data  page numbers   but sporadically fails.  This is some sample data that sometimes succeeds and sometimes fails:        stores:      defaults:       Literal           type:  literal           store: [Object]          mtimes:             readOnly: true          loadFrom: null          logicalSeparator:  :         sources: []    headers:       Content Type :  application/json        Accept:  application/json         User Agent :  node zendesk/1.1.5  node/4.2.1         Authorization:  Basic [redacted]       uri:  https://[redacted].zendesk.com/api/v2/search.json?page=3 query=checkout failure     method:  GET         And request is being given the following defaults:        jar: RequestJar   _jar: CookieJar   store:   idx:             encoding: null    timeout: 240000    proxy: null    secureOptions: 134217728        The following error is  eventually  thrown:      Error: socket hang up     at createHangUpError  _http_client.js:203:15      at TLSSocket.socketOnEnd  _http_client.js:288:23      at emitNone  events.js:72:20      at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:166:7      at endReadableNT  _stream_readable.js:903:12      at doNTCallback2  node.js:439:9      at process._tickCallback  node.js:353:17       What could be causing this? Is this a bug in request  or is there something wrong with how we re calling it?  I m too far deep into a library I am unfamiliar with to make a stripped down test case. If necessary  I can make one wanted to check it wasn t something obvious before investing the time  first  though.  Here is where request is initiated: https://github.com/blakmatrix/node zendesk/blob/master/lib/client/client.js L35 L41   Here is where it is called: https://github.com/blakmatrix/node zendesk/blob/master/lib/client/client.js L100 L102  Help would be much appreciated  thanks

title: Cannot set localAddress to IPv6
body: Hi  I m getting a  bind EINVAL  error but only when attempting to connect to https. Do you have any insight as to why this might be happening?  Here s my error:     [Error: bind EINVAL 2604:a880:1:20::27:a000]   code:  EINVAL     errno:  EINVAL     syscall:  bind     address:  2604:a880:1:20::27:a000      It only has this issue when using IPv6 and https at the same time. Here s my proof of concept code:      var request = require  request  ; var opt =   url: http://icanhazip.com   // doesn t work: url: https://www.google.ca/search?q=what is my ip address   timeout:5000  headers:      // User Agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64  AppleWebKit/537.36  KHTML  like Gecko  Chrome/48.0.2564.10 Safari/537.36     ; opt.family = 6; // Works fine if the following line is removed: opt.localAddress =  2604:a880:1:20::27:a000 ; request opt function error  response  data        if   error    response    response.statusCode == 200             console.log data ;       else           if   response   console.log response.statusCode ;         console.log error ;         ;        Something really interesting is that if I comment out the  opt.localAddress  line and just let it use  opt.family = 6  then it will work  and with the same exact interface that I m trying to set  localAddress  to. But if I attempt to set  localAddress   Only while using HTTPS  then it will come up with the  bind EINVAL  error.    I highly suspect that it s not a  bind EINVAL  error because I can connect to it using standard  http  library and from command line and PHP using this interface. I really would like to use this library more than others. Please help me  : 1:

title: ECONNRESET emitted twice
body: I have a request like this:      javascript progress request options       .on  progress   function state          ...            .on  error   function err          ...            .on  data   function data          hasher.update data ;            .on  abort   function           ...            .pipe unzipper      .on  error   function err          ...            .pipe writeStream      .on  error   function err          ...            .on  finish   function           ...       ;     ;      and if I stop the server while downloading a file from a HTTPS URL an  ECONNRESET  error is emitted twice. Here is a stack trace for both      Error: read ECONNRESET Trace     at Request.<anonymous>     .js:81:15      at emitOne  events.js:82:20      at Request.emit  events.js:169:7      at Request.onRequestError  ... node_modules request request.js:820:8      at emitOne  events.js:77:13      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:169:7      at TLSSocket.socketErrorListener  _http_client.js:259:9      at emitOne  events.js:82:20      at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:169:7      at emitErrorNT  net.js:1253:8  Error: read ECONNRESET Trace     at Request.<anonymous>     .js:81:15      at emitOne  events.js:82:20      at Request.emit  events.js:169:7      at Request.onRequestError  ... node_modules request request.js:820:8      at emitOne  events.js:77:13      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:169:7      at TLSSocket.connectionErrorHandler  ... node_modules request request.js:81:25      at TLSSocket.g  events.js:260:16      at emitOne  events.js:82:20      at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:169:7       Is this intended behavior?    And why does the pipe not end on error? Altough calling  this.end    explicitly in the first error listener does not lead to the  finish  event.    Not a streaming expert  Edit: I learned that the stream unpipes on error so that the end   does not propagate.

title: Some errors thrown by Node s  lib/net  during socket setup are impossible to handle
body: For example  the port range exception:  https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/6fff47ffacfe663efeb0d31ebd700a65bf5521ba/lib/net.js L924  I m able to catch it fine when I use  http  directly:      node try    http.get  http://localhost:999999999999/     catch err      console.log  Gotcha    err.message   ; // Gotcha  port should be >= 0 and < 65536: 999999999999      but when I use  request  I can t catch it either through a  try/catch  or by doing  .on  error   handler  . I always get a stack trace:      node try    request.get  http://localhost:999999999999/   function         console.log  BAR   ;     .on  error   function         console.log  FOO   ;        catch err     console.log  Gotcha    err.message    > RangeError: port should be >= 0 and < 65536: 999999999999     at lookupAndConnect  net.js:927:13      at Socket.connect  net.js:904:5      at Agent.exports.connect.exports.createConnection  net.js:63:35      at Agent.createSocket  _http_agent.js:174:16      at Agent.addRequest  _http_agent.js:143:23      at new ClientRequest  _http_client.js:133:16      at Object.exports.request  http.js:31:10      at Request.start  ..../node_modules/request/request.js:746:30      at Request.end  ..../node_modules/request/request.js:1357:10      at end  ..../node_modules/request/request.js:574:14       Not sure what s the right thing to do here. Catch the errors in  end    and stuff them into the error callback if we have one  re raising if we don t?

title: Middle of response timeouts
body: One thing I have been having a problem with is that some of the requests I make never finish    they just hang midway. I would like request to be able to time out a request if no new data is sent within x time.  Reproduction:      javascript  use strict  let request = require  request   let http = require  http    console.log  creating server    let srv = new http.Server   srv.on  request   function request  response     response.setTimeout 1  function        // do nothing  so the response doesn t time out        response.write  this is a      // response.write  complete request     // response.end      srv.listen 24888   console.time  request   console.log  creating request   request  http://localhost:24888   function err  response  body     console.timeEnd  request     console.log  got response     console.log err    console.log body      process.on  SIGINT   function      console.log  stopping request     console.timeEnd  request     process.exit           When I run the code for a few minutes:      creating server creating request ^Cstopping request request: 307429.949ms

title: Updating request defaults in place
body: I m trying to figure out how to I could fit in this pattern using the request library.  Currently I have a  request.js wrapper module that is imported by all my other modules that need to make http calls.  request.js       js var options =     baseUrl: window.location.protocol   baseUrl    json: true    simple: false    resolveWithFullResponse: true  ;  module.exports = require  request promise  .defaults options ;      While the user is using the app  they can also  log in   and at that point I d like for all their requests to be authorized with a new header.  I want to do something like this:      js var request = require  ./lib/request  ; //... onLoginCompleted: function user  rememberme         this.user = Immutable.Map user ;       request.defaults   Authorization :  Bearer   this.user.get  token    ;       this.trigger this.user  this.active ;             At which point  I d like for   require  ./lib/request  ;  to have new defaults  so that all other modules importing my request wrapper not make authorized calls. Is this possible?

title: helpers.isReadStream identifies only fs created streams
body: https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/helpers.js L41   .isReadStream  checks to see if the provided object has three truthy properties:  .readable    .path   and  .mode . While these three properties all exist on streams created by [ fs.createReadStream ] https://nodejs.org/api/fs.html fs_fs_createreadstream_path_options   this is not true for all readable streams that may contain file data.  In particular  I am working on a project using  sails@0.11.3  and  skipper@0.5.8 . The  upstream  paradigm that  skipper  uses creates a transform stream containing file data. This allows  sails  users to write file management middleware that sends file data to any desired storage location without first writing any data to disk. Because the file data is coming directly from the request and into the transform stream  no file system read is happening  and therefore no  .path  and  .mode  properties exist for these streams which contain file data.  I m opening this issue to ask whether there is a more flexible way for  request  to identify readable streams. Node exposes four different stream classes that implement the readable interface   Readable    Duplex    Transform   and  PassThrough . All of these stream types appear to share two properties:      javascript [ Readable    Transform    Duplex    PassThrough ].forEach function type      var stream = new require  stream  [type]  ;   console.log type    stream._readableState    stream.readable ;   ;  /  Output Readable true true Transform true true Duplex true true PassThrough true true  /      One possible refactor that appears to allow  request  to accept non fs file streams while avoiding a regression is:      javascript function isReadStream  rs      return rs.readable      rs.path    rs.mode     rs._readableState ;        Are there any foreseeable downsides to opening  request  up to accepting any readable stream  as opposed to only those created by  fs ? Is there a catastrophic failure point somewhere where  request  is assuming the stream to be an  fs  stream?

title: Safari: Empty Bearer Authorization header causes error in Safari  Desktop/iOS
body: Currently  I have a default request object setup with the following options:      js var options =     baseUrl: window.location.protocol   baseUrl    json: true    simple: false    resolveWithFullResponse: true    auth:       bearer: function           if  AdminStore == null            AdminStore = require  stores/admin  ;               return AdminStore.getToken  ;            ;      When the user is not logged in   getToken    will return  null . When this happens request auth code [will opt to send an empty Bearer token] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/auth.js L45 .   auth.js       js if  sendImmediately    typeof sendImmediately ===  undefined         if  typeof bearer ===  function           bearer = bearer             var authHeader =  Bearer      bearer           self.sentAuth = true    return authHeader         This results in the Authorization header being set to  Authorization: Bearer . For some reason Desktop Safari 9.0.1 and iOS Safari 9.1 don t like this  and when you try to set the header you get  DOM Exception 12: An invalid or illegal string was specified.  If I return a garbage string in  Bearer   such as  abc   the error does not occur.  Possibly related: https://forum.ionicframework.com/t/solved ios9 fails with setrequestheader native with custom headers in http service/32399/8   In any case  it seems to me the best option would be not set the header at all if the  bearer  function returns null.

title: Check if the functions exist before executing
body: Sometimes you get the error self.req.abort/response.resume is not a function. To prevent the error first check if the function exists.

title: Check form data content length value before setting up the header
body: When creating a POST request with form data where the contents of the form data comes from http.IncomingMessage stream from another HTTP response  sometimes the length of the request cannot be calculated.  One case is when the IncomingMessage is a chunked response.  Then the form data module cannot calculate the length until the stream is fully read  and it returns NaN in getLength   callback.  The header Content Length should not be set in such situation  otherwise the remote server returns with 400.  Ran into this problem a lot while processing the responses from google drive servers as they tend to send chunked response.

title: Event  complete  triggered twice of a request.
body: javascript request url  options              .on  error    function  error                    ......               .on  response    function options  response                        ......                     this.readResponseBody response ;                     this.on  complete   function  response  body                            ......                       ;              ;      In this code  the  complete  callback function wil be invoked twice.

title: Use isstream for more robust stream.Readable detection
body: See https://github.com/request/request/issues/1949 for the original issue description.  In short   helpers.isReadStream  is overly restrictive in what it deems to be a readable stream. Specifically  only streams created via  fs  that stream file data from disk pass the test of this function. However  it is entirely valid to have a non  fs  stream that contains valid file data  e.g. streams generated from file data contained in  multipart/form data  requests.  This pull request updates  helpers.isReadStream  to use the  .Readable  method contained within the existing dependency  isstream . However   isstream.isReadable  on its own is not restrictive enough to detect the kinds of readable streams that  request  needs to detect  as the  http.IncomingMessage  and its sub classes are also readable streams  yet they need to be rejected by our test.  So  the combination of  isstream.isReadable  and  instanceof http.IncomingMessage  should be sufficient to successfully detect non http readable streams that may contain file data.

title: Best Practices   Pitfalls
body: This library has been around for a while  so I figure some people have come up with interesting design patterns. Does anyone have any they would like to share?  For instance  I like to imagine the  callback  as more of a  Handler  class that works a lot the way  Express  does for  http.Server .

title: How to force HTTP 1.1?
body: More and more websites started to use HTTP 2.0 and sending HTTP requests with Nodejs to such websites return no responses  no statusCode or body or headers .  These websites usually have HTTP 1.1 fallback  yet  HTTP requests with Nodejs somehow doesn t trigger this fallback.  Is there a workaround for this?  As an example  we shall normally get HTTP 200 from teh request below but it returns no response:      javascript var request = require  request  ;  request  https://www.tunetheweb.com       headers:        User Agent :  request         function  error  response  body      if  error        console.error error ;     else         console.log response.statusCode ;

title: [Error: socket hang up] code:  ECONNRESET  when  knownLength  is set for multipart request
body: Hi   I run a simple PUT request to upload something like the following      js var util = require  util  ; var fs = require  fs  ; var http = require  http  ; var request = require  request  ; request.debug = true;  var r = request.put  http://www.xxx.de/index.html     function optionalCallback err  httpResponse  body        console.log util.inspect err  ;   ; var form = r.form  ; form.append  index.html   fs.createReadStream  ./index.html          filename:  index.html       contentType:  text/html       knownLength: 1   ;      I always get    [Error: socket hang up] code:  ECONNRESET    . This error is too much difficult to debug. What happens there? If I remove  knownLength  or set it as 0  it works.  If I use file path instead of stream in form data   knownLength  is smaller than 30  the same error occurs. If the value of  knownLength  is biggeer than 30  it works again.  I really can not understand this ridiculous problem. Who knows what s the  knownLength  used for except for  Content Length  header. Is it used for an option of  fs.createReadStream  as well? I guess the file stream is close before request stream starts to pipe.  Best regards  Kevin

title: Redirect URL coming in the body of a text/x json response
body: I have been struggling with a server that does not redirect using a HTTP 3xx response code. Rather  the server responds with HTTP 200 OK  sets Content Type to  text/x json  and sends me a body containing the following data:   status:  true   redirect:  /index.html   .  Firefox handles this kind of redirection fine  so I presume other servers out there may be sending redirects the same way.  Do you have any plans to support this redirection mode in your code base? Thanks

title: Move timeout code to after a socket is assigned
body: In the old code the timeout was started when the request was queued  not when the request was send to the server. If maxSocket option is set on an Agent  the actual request might be send later. This is not what is suggested in the documentation. Code to reproduce the problem can be found in this gist: https://gist.github.com/evanderkoogh/e7e94f036c7a7a6b8f29  I have moved all of the code related to setting up timeouts to self.req.on  socket  . This event is called when the request has been assigned a socket. After changing my local copy the code above runs perfectly now.

title: followAllRedirects  option may cause odd behavior
body: Under some highly specific circumstances involving redirects  the  request  may call it s callback argument with an error  yet successfully complete the operation.  The situation is:   1.   The client sends a PUT request with a large enough amount of data.   2.   The server responds with a redirect after it has received the request headers  and hasn t yet received the whole data body .   3.   The server drops the connection unexpectedly.  The library handles this sitation in a bad way. It simultaneously:   continues following the redirect  and potentially successfully completes the operation .    calls the callback with an error.  I ve assembled a fully working example that illustrates the problem: https://github.com/tempname11/request redirect bug  Actual output:      Server 1: starting... Server 2: starting... Client: starting... Server 1: have request for / Server 1: Sent 307. Server 1: dropping connection. Client: error ECONNRESET Server 2: have request for / Server 2: Received 33554432 bytes. Server 2: sent 200. Server 2: closing connection.      Expected output   A        Server 1: starting... Server 2: starting... Client: starting... Server 1: have request for / Server 1: Sent 307. Server 1: dropping connection. Server 2: have request for / Server 2: Received 33554432 bytes. Server 2: sent 200. Server 2: closing connection. Client: have response.      Or  alternatively  expected output   B        Server 1: starting... Server 2: starting... Client: starting... Server 1: have request for / Server 1: Sent 307. Server 1: dropping connection. Client: error ECONNRESET      My point being that either behavior   A   or   B   should happen  that is:   This specific error should be ignored and further redirected exchanges should happen as normal.   the callback should receive an error  and no further redirected exchanges should be made.  I ve made a quick fix that results in behavior   A  . It s at https://github.com/tempname11/request/commit/096042de28938c3496c9f1426d6c9badd0b59cd0

title: Pretty Website
body: I think we need a fancy website :   I ran a poll today to see which http clients people use and people sent me a _ton_ of clients I didn t know about  all of them promise based. I think a website that showed people docs for  request promise  as well as request would be great  and also something that showed people the defaults API first  that saves so much time and almost nobody knows about it.  @request/promises

title: Improve proxy support
body: Currently there s no option to pass NO_PROXY setting with the request options. The NO_PROXY setting is read from the env variables ONLY if no proxy is set in options.   This pull request adds the options  httpProxy    httpsProxy    noProxy  while keeping the existing  proxy  for backward compatibility.  This way it is possible to do:      var r = request.defaults   httpProxy : http://localproxy.com    noProxy :  artifactory         Modules like bower art resolver are unable to be properly implemented because of this limitation: https://github.com/JFrogDev/bower art resolver/issues/9

title: HTTPS_PROXY is not working
body: I am trying to send requests using my company proxy to outside world and it does not work for HTTPS_PROXY. Works fine for HTTP_PROXY only HTTPS_PROXY is failing. Here is how my request looks like process.env.HTTPS_PROXY =  https://httpproxyurl:80 ;     console.log process.env.HTTPS_PROXY ;     options =           url: https://externalurl.com          method:  POST           headers:  Content Type :  application/xml             body:  body           timeout: 1200      ;     request options  function error  response  body           if   error  response.statusCode == 200                console.log  call succeded:  body ;               else   console.log  call failed  error ;              ;      error I am getting: tunneling socket could not be established  cause=139939808655168:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s23_clnt.c:782: =Error: tunneling socket could not be established  cause=139939808655168:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s23_clnt.c:782: at ClientRequest.onError

title: ETIMEDOUT before entire request is sent
body: It appears that the  timeout  timer starts when it starts to send the request. So when uploading a sufficiently large file the  ETIMEDOUT  error occurs before the request has been sent  while the upload is in progress . Is it possible to start the timer after the request has been sent? Any suggestions?

title: Use the  extend  module instead of util._extend
body: Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1997  See also https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/11104

title: Maximum call stack size exceeded in redirects
body: Hi   I m randomly getting the error below  but unfortunately I have not been able to come up with a reproducible case.  Looking at the code  there appears to be a problem with redirect handling.  Request s code below      response.on  close   function        if   self._ended        self.response.emit  end            and Node s http code seem to be stuck in a loop.  Probably to prevent this issue  I think you might want to remove the request event handler before emitting an event on the response.  Note I m using request version 2.63.0.      RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded     at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:117:44      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  /home/ec2 user/DoculusServer/node_modules/request/request.js:951:23      at emitNone  events.js:72:20      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:166:7      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  _http_client.js:234:11      at emitNone  events.js:67:13      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:166:7      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  /home/ec2 user/DoculusServer/node_modules/request/request.js:951:23      at emitNone  events.js:72:20      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:166:7      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  _http_client.js:234:11      at emitNone  events.js:67:13      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:166:7      at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  /home/ec2 user/DoculusServer/node_modules/request/request.js:951:23      at emitNone  events.js:72:20      at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:166:7

title: Support JSON stringify replacer argument.
body: Adds support for the replacer argument of JSON.stringify  in the same way that request already supports the revivier argument for JSON.parse.

title: Content Type header missing when passing BASIC Authentication
body: I am using request to interact with TestRail API. Since it uses basic authentication I am setting the headers as follows:      var mainHeaders =          Authorization : Basic     new Buffer config.userName    :    config.APIKEY .toString  base64           Content type :  application/json     ;      but the TestRail API rejects saying Content Type header is missing. Checking the response from the server I can see the client request header was:           Authorization :  Basic <my authentication data>      accept :  application/json      referer :  http://xxxxx.testrail.net/index.php?/api/v2/get_cases/1 suite_id=1         So I am assuming the Content Type header is being   removed   somehow.   Is there any reason the Content Type header could be removed from the request header object? The header above is all I set.  It might not be request problem  but I am current lost. Any help is appreciated?  Thanks  Paulo

title: Question: fire and forget
body: Is it possible to use request to run a  POST   but not want to worry about the response?  In particular  I have a CLI that s posting a beacon/analytics to a server  so it s important the request has been sent  but waiting for the response is not required   and currently waiting is adding a minor latency to the CLI s exit time  which I m looking to reduce .  Is this possible with request?

title: Callback of request full of data?
body: Hey there   is it for sure that the callback of the request x callback  has the whole content within the body? Or is ist possible that the callback comes several times and respresents partial parts of the whole page? Who can i than detect the end of the page? Or is it save request with whole content all the way?   thanks a lot

title: Fix remote memory disclosure with multipart attachments
body: If the node process makes a request with a multipart attachment  and the type of the  body  option is a  Number   then that many bytes of uninitialized memory will be sent in the body of the request. Here s an example:      js request     method:  POST     uri:  http://localhost:8000     multipart: [  body: 1000  ]        And here s a more complete reproducible example:      js var http = require  http   var request = require  request    http.createServer function  req  res      var data =      req.setEncoding  utf8     req.on  data   function  chunk        console.log  data       data  = chunk        req.on  end   function          // this will print uninitialized memory from the client     console.log  Client sent: n   data         res.end     .listen 8000   request     method:  POST     uri:  http://localhost:8000     multipart: [  body: 1000  ]    function  err  res  body      if  err  return console.error  upload failed:   err    console.log  sent           This PR fixes the issue by coercing the type of the  body  option to a string.  An alternate solution would be to throw an exception in this case.   Further reading:   https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/4660   https://github.com/nodejs/node eps/pull/4

title: converting this cURL call with request

I try to translate this curl command:      curl   digest   user dba:dba   url  http://192.168.99.100:32772/sparql graph crud auth?graph uri=http://graph.org   X POST  T file.txt      This will stream a file into a server via a POST request using a digest authentification. Any ideas ?  Thanks a lot.

title: Fix event listener leak
body: When request handles a redirect  extra event listeners for the  pipe  and  end  events are erroneously attached to the request object.  This causes a few problems:   When the request finally completes and  end  is fired  the [cleanup function] https://github.com/request/request/blob/v2.67.0/request.js L796 L800  ends up running multiple times  1   number of redirects .  This doesn t actually hurt anything  but it is wasteful.   If someone were to pipe to the request after a redirect had occurred  which is an error   the [ pipe  event handler] https://github.com/request/request/blob/v2.67.0/request.js L506 L534  will run multiple times  thus emitting the  error  event multiple times.   If there are 7 or more redirects  node will print leak warnings to stderr:       node  warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 pipe listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners   to increase limit. Trace     at Request.addListener  events.js:239:17      at Request.init  ./node_modules/request.js:507:8      at Redirect.onResponse  ./node_modules/lib/redirect.js:148:11      at Request.onRequestResponse  ./node_modules/request.js:898:22      at emitOne  events.js:77:13      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:169:7      at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient [as onIncoming]  _http_client.js:415:21      at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete  _http_common.js:88:23      at Socket.socketOnData  _http_client.js:305:20      at emitOne  events.js:77:13   node  warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 end listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners   to increase limit. Trace     at Request.addListener  events.js:239:17      at Request.start  ./node_modules/request.js:797:8      at Request.end  ./node_modules/request.js:1358:10      at end  ./node_modules/request.js:575:14      at Immediate._onImmediate  ./node_modules/request.js:589:7      at processImmediate [as _immediateCallback]  timers.js:383:17       These warnings have been reported many  many times   107   281   311   585   622   673   708    842   870   1497   1809  but the underlying issue has never actually been properly resolved.  This fixes the leak for good by not attaching additional handlers if they re already there.  The diff makes it look like there are more changes than there actually are due to changes in indentation.  The only actual change is to wrap the event listeners:      diff    if  EventEmitter.listenerCount self   ...   === 0         ...           The small client   server I used to demonstrate this issue can be found [here] https://gist.github.com/daguej/13a712bdf2db1a23862f .

title: HTTP/2 support
body: Hello Request maintainers and community. I am creating this issue to discuss whether there s interest in implementing HTTP/2 support in Request.  I have a working fork of Request with hacked in HTTP/2 support  but it only does what I need for my use case  the use case is load testing   I only ever connect to and send requests to one host  and I m not concerned with potentially maintaining multiple connections to different hosts .  Some considerations:   Should  http2  be an explicit option? Do we want to upgrade to HTTP/2 automatically if the server supports it?   HTTP/2 has  push  events   these may need to be exposed to the user.   With HTTP/2 there s a persistent connection to the server which probably can t be  unref   d safely as is the case with HTTP. The user will need to be able to close the connection manually.   Should HTTP/2 without TLS be allowed?  TLS is not mandatory  but strongly encouraged    Should this be done in Request Next?  https://github.com/request/request/issues/1982   I d be happy to take ownership of this and write and submit a proper PR based on the discussion here.  Thanks

title: Error: Parse Error after multiple requests.
body: Request version: 2.67.0 Node version: 5.5.0 or 4.2.2  I have an array of urls to ebay items. If I call all of them in parallel I almost instantly get following error:      Error: Parse Error     at Error  native      at Socket.socketOnData  _http_client.js:315:20      at emitOne  events.js:90:13      at Socket.emit  events.js:182:7      at readableAddChunk  _stream_readable.js:147:16      at Socket.Readable.push  _stream_readable.js:111:10      at TCP.onread  net.js:523:20       If I call those urls in chain with a decent timeout  100ms   requests run through without a problem. I am guessing that ebay has some sort of IP rate limiter in place to protect themselves. I understand that  but I think requestjs should not crash  but rather throw in error.

title: Breaking Change in v2.68.0 w/ Browserify
body: Looks like v2.68.0 introduced a breaking change by requiring a separate  aws4  dependency.  Apparently with browserify  that dependency isn t optional  causing build failures.

title: restore aws4 as regular dependency
body: It was moved in  2036 as a devDependency  but is still used in request.js  This should fix  2040.

title: declare the character set used in the body for x www form urlencoded post
body: Declare the character set used in the body for x www form urlencoded post  basic form request  . It could help the server side    especially for which default charset is not utf8   decoding the request body.  Otherwise the server will use it s default charset decode our utf8 encoded body.

title: Unhandled HPE_INVALID_CONSTANT error on 304 responses
body: Consistently I m getting an error when the server responds with a 304.  I was able to mitigate it by using native HTTP module  however it s defeats the purpose of the request module that I have to do that.  With the code below  I was able to handle the error by attaching an error event listener and there abort the call again.  Is there a way to achieve this i request ?      js var http = require  http  ;  var options =       method:  GET       uri: [URL]      json: true      headers:     ;  var callInterval = 1000;  var requestFn = function           var query =           host: [HOST]          path: [PATH]          headers: options.headers      ;      try            var req = http.request query  function  response                 options.headers[ If None Match ] = response.headers.etag;             options.headers[ If Modified Since ] = response.headers.date;              if  response.statusCode == 304                    req.abort  ;                 return;                            var str =   ;              //another chunk of data has been recieved  so append it to  str              response.on  data   function  chunk                    str  = chunk;               ;              //the whole response has been recieved  so we just print it out here             response.on  end   function                      console.log str ;                  setTimeout requestFn  callInterval ;               ;           ;          req.on  error   function err                console.log err ;             req.abort  ;             setTimeout requestFn  callInterval ;           ;          req.end  ;            catch  err            setTimeout requestFn  callInterval ;        ;  setTimeout requestFn  callInterval ;

title: SUPPORT: CHANGELOG.md  package.json  npmjs.com and tags appear out of sync with semver
body: This is a little confusing when we do dependency updates as of late and I ve just noticed this...   [ c54be10 /package.json L10] https://github.com/request/request/blob/c54be10eb11f4514ec29f97f83206520401ec5c1/package.json L10  states version 2.68.1   [npmjs.com] https://www.npmjs.com/package/request  states version 2.69.0 _    npm   depth 0 outdated  as well _   [ c54be10 /CHANGELOG.md] https://github.com/request/request/blob/c54be10eb11f4514ec29f97f83206520401ec5c1/CHANGELOG.md  states version 2.68.0   [GH Releases tag] https://github.com/request/request/releases  currently states [version 2.69.1] https://github.com/request/request/releases/tag/v2.69.1   What changed in 2.69.0 on npmjs.com and why are all of these completely out of sync across the board?  I do read the CHANGELOG.md to better understand this project and its changes.  I don t [see a branch with 2.69.0] https://github.com/request/request/branches/all  either.   Did I miss something with my deer in the headlights look with this? Is there a stable versus unstable release structure here? Apologies if it is obvious to others but I am definitely confused here.  TIA  Cc: @mikeal

title: Update contributing guidelines
body: @request/contributors I m going to introduce two handy labels:    Help  please use Stackoverflow      Not enough info  see CONTRIBUTING.md    So that it will be easier to filter out the noise   closing issues without further notice  the first case .

title: Karma fixes for latest versions
body: So  here is some fixes that closes  2035 and  2044 and  2056  First off  one of the issues were that we are testing across 3 versions of npm. They have different behaviours when encountering peerDependencies. So ideally I would almost say we should upgrade npm to at least npm@2 for node 0.10. But open to opinions there. This was the least disruptive change  in my opinion.  Second  one of the issues were pointing out that the response object changed for one of the tests. So I ran the same test code with node  where the result was illuminating the fact that the browser test was testing for something only happening in the browser. So I changed that test  so it can check for a result that also is the same result when running on node.  Fixes  2035 Fixes  2044 Closes  2056

title: Redirects not redirecting
body: One simple POST request gets back a 302 redirection. I don t know if I should do something additional to get my script to follow that but... what I just get is that a 302 and end of the script. The documentation is not very extensive and the examples are even more scarce. So I ve been trying with no success adding followRedirect: true followAllRedirects: true etc. When I use that last one param the script can t even successfully log in to the site with that POST . The code goes something like this: request method: POST followRedirect: true uri : Spider.globals.postURL jar : Spider.globals.jar body : Spider.globals.postMessage function error response body console.log Response status: response.statusCode > response.statusMessage ; console.log body ; ; And the response: Trying to log in... success. Response status: 302 > Found You are being redirected. End of script.

How can I bypass this?                      console.log  Response status:     response.statusCode ;                                                           ^ TypeError: Cannot read property  statusCode  of undefined     at Request._callback  /xxx:88:59      at self.callback  /xxx:199:22      at Request.emit  events.js:107:17      at Request.onRequestError  /xxx:821:8      at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:107:17      at TLSSocket.socketErrorListener  _http_client.js:271:9      at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:107:17      at TLSSocket.<anonymous>  _tls_wrap.js:942:18      at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:104:17      at TLSSocket._finishInit  _tls_wrap.js:460:8  Error: Error: self signed certificate in certificate chain

title: It s possible to abort a non started request
body: I am getting an exception like this:      TypeError: Cannot call method  end  of undefined at Request.end  node_modules/request/request.js:1372:12  at Request.destroy  node_modules/request/request.js:1393:10  at IncomingMessage.onclose  stream.js:87:50  at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:117:20  at abortIncoming  http.js:1917:11  at CleartextStream.serverSocketCloseListener  http.js:1928:5  at CleartextStream.emit  events.js:117:20  at tls.js:694:10 at process._tickDomainCallback  node.js:486:13       So  by reading the code here:      javascript Request.prototype.end = function  chunk      ...   if   self._started        self.start         self.req.end    // here        and here:      javascript Request.prototype.start = function        ...   if  self._aborted        return           end  will guard itself from not being started by using the  _started  flag. however  start  won t do anything if  _aborted  is true. and  abort  doesn t use  _started   we end up with: 1. aborted a non started request 2. destroy is called 3. end is called 4. end will call start 5. start won t do anything because it was aborted 6. end will crash because it wasn t started.  I will workaround this on my code by only calling  abort    if  _started  is  true  unless you have a better idea.

title: Update vulnerabilities in deps badge
body: The badge that was being used was _incorrectly_ showing that request held vulns in it s  production  dependencies  but this is wrong.   Request uses hawk  which _had_ a vuln  but has been patched and released in 3.1.3  and is [vuln free] https://snyk.io/test/npm/hawk/3  in the 3.x branch   and the semver range for hawk in the  package.json  is   3.1.0    so 3.1.3 is going to be installed.  Disclosure: I ve been working on snyk since mid last year  but I ve been relying on request for even longer and I didn t want it be wrongly represented as vulnerable

title: toString failed   buffer size issue for big files  maxBufferSize
body: I m requesting a big file with 150K records but it throws  toString failed  error. https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/3175 says it s because of maxBufferSize. Request works well for 200 records but its an external api and the requirement is to get all records at once.[no pagination there :  ] Is there any way to set buffersize for this request?  EDIT:      request  http://www.site containing big data/api           function  error  response  body                console.log  got something to show  ;             if  error    response.statusCode == 200                    resolve body ;              else if error                   reject error ;                         ;      but nothing shows in console other than  toString failed  message

title: Connections not closing  keepAlive?
body: It seems that my requests are holding open connections even after the callback fires. I ve done some research on the Node  http  module  and it seems  by default  the setting is to  keepAlive   > http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6658761/how to destroy a node js http request connection nicely. How would I achieve      var request = http.get options           function res                console.log res.statusCode ;              ; request.shouldKeepAlive = false      ^ what one would do with this using node s native  http  module w/  request . Also  if you have any other tips here  as per why the connection doesn t seem to close  that d be great  as it s been a tough one to debug.  PS: I ve also tried passing in  headers:   connection:  close     as opts to _request post_.

title: Accept streams as body
body: If I want to send the request body e.g. gzipped  I currently need the return value and pipe the gzipstream there. However I only have access to the return value when using callback API but we are normally using promise API where the return value  slot  is taken by the promise and we cannot interact with the stream.  I propose extending the  body  option to accept stream which would do this for me so that I don t need to waste the return value  slot . Any errors should be redirected to the callback error argument.

title: Filename is automatically turn into basename for formData POST request
body: I am trying to use request to upload a file a server. It works very well for simple upload but I would like to choose a specific filename in the http request. And  request  seems to cut the complete filename and send only the basename in the http request.      javascript var formData =           custom_file :               value: fs.createReadStream  data.txt                 options:  filename: /../../titi.txt   contentType: text/txt                  ;     var r = request.post  url:hostname  :  port  /upload   formData: formData   function err  httpResponse  body           if err               console.log  erreur   err ;             return;           else if httpResponse.statusCode  = 200               console.log  http response   httpResponse.statusCode ;             return;                   fs.readFile pathname  function err  buf2               if err                   console.log err ;               else if md5 buf   = md5 buf2                    console.log  bug during upload  ;               else                   console.log  file uploaded  ;                 fs.unlinkSync pathname ;                         ;       ;      And in wireshark :  form data;name= custom_file ;filename= titi.txt  .   Is it feature or is it a bug ?

title: Event equivalent of callback
body: Given this code:      js request  http://google.com   function  err  res      if  err      return console.error err ;    console.log res ;   ;      What is the equivalent events  to get the same result? Say I wanted to pipe a file:      js var r = request  http://google.com     .on  error   console.error    .on  response   console.log ;  fs.createReadStream  some file  .pipe r ;      It doesn t seem like  response  is actually the same in the last example  and from the documentation I wouldn t guess either.

title: Redirect LOOP with specific URLs
body: This is simple  I m creating a crawler using the request module and for some urls that have strange characters like this one  I get a redirect loop  Here it is the example:  http://www.casasbahia.com.br/Moveis/EscritorioHomeOffice/EstacoesdeTrabalho/Mesa para Computador 2ultivisao   Branco 25231.html  If you open in your browser you get a 200 response after a single 301 redirect but if you try to get using the request module I get a infinite 301  This is not a cookie problem  this is a character encoding issue.  It looks like that the url to be redirected is not being decoded or encoded properly

title: Replace lib/getProxyFromURI.js with proxy from env
body: I was looking for a package that implements support for the  de facto  standard proxy environment variables  but didn t find any except for getProxyFromURI.js in this library. My two main issues with the implementation is that it uses suffix matching  e.g.  NO_PROXY=example.com  also matches  notexample.com   and that it uses  HTTP_PROXY  even for https URLs . The latter is problematic if I want to proxy all HTTP requests  but not HTTPS requests  because there is no way to get  NO_PROXY  to stop matching https requests. I ve fixed all of the above issues and published the result as https://www.npmjs.com/package/proxy from env  and decided to submit a PR here so that eventually all Node.js applications/libraries that want to support setting the proxy via the environment variables do so in a consistent and standard way.  Compared to the existing implementation in request  there are two backwards incompatible changes  see the commit message for other differences and more details :    HTTP_PROXY  is no longer used for https requests  use  HTTPS_PROXY    or  ALL_PROXY  .   The items in  NO_PROXY  are no longer used in suffix matching  but used as an exact match  unless the item starts with a dot or asterisk  then suffix matching will be used .  The proxy from env library [has an extensive set of tests] https://github.com/Rob  W/proxy from env/blob/master/test.js . With a small modification  the tests can also be used to check the existing implementation:      sh git clone https://github.com/Rob  W/proxy from env.git cd proxy from env    Get current implementation from request wget https://github.com/request/request/blob/c2dab797d362ad158e0399140aa59829fa50d9b3/lib/getProxyFromURI.js?raw=true  Oindex.js    Change module signature to match the library. echo  module.exports= getProxyForUrl: function s    return getProxyFromURI require  url  .parse s        ;   ;  >> index.js    Install dependencies and run tests npm install npm test      Here is the test output: http://pastebin.com/raw/Dk9f79Vq  anything without a checkmark is a test failure .

title: Proposal to allow setting of timeout with env var
body: When I start work with an unfamiliar open source project I try to make sure the tests pass. Some of these projects use request. Sometimes  the connection or requests their tests make timeout. It would be nice if I could get the tests to pass without modifying any of the code of a build that passes in other contexts. Being able to set a different timeout across all the calls made with request is one way that I can work around exceptional latency  without changing the requirements of the open source project under test.  I am curious as to your own approach for debugging this. Sometimes unfamiliar open source projects layer abstractions on top of request. It can be difficult to find where to provide an alternate timeout value.

title: Make some of the dependencies optional
body: Could we make a change to the dependencies  any component that s not always used make it an optional dependency  like the oauth1 dependency or Hawk  etc. These are all dependencies that I would think would only be needed if reaching the appropriate IDs  making them optional would allow consuming components to not include them  making applications smaller  as well as avoid the need for them  which would increase the ability to use Request inside organizations that are restricting certain npm components.

title: Calls to request options  callback  shall never throw an error and call the callback instead
body: As discussed briefly in  1429  calls to  request options  callback   shall never throw an error as this is not a recommended error handling pattern. If a function return an error asynchronously  then all the errors including those can be identified right away  shall be returned asynchronously.      js var options =     url: url    method:  HEAD     body:  Some data    request options  function  err  response  body      // never called    // throws an error instead      For a more detailed discussion on the matter  please refer to [Error Handling in Node.js] https://www.joyent.com/developers/node/design/errors   section  Throw  Callback  or EventEmitter? .  Please consider updating the error handling to always call the provided callback instead of throwing errors.

title: Extra optional parameter
body: Allows the user to define using the options an extra option which he can use inside the callback functions.  This is important when you use request inside any loop  as it is not recommended to define callback functions inside a loop but rather use a pre defined method.

But if we receive urls from an external source   they may or may not be encoded. Is there some kind of built in mechanism to deal with this?  Other than doing  encodeURI decodeURI url

title: Don t set content length if transfer encoding is already set to chunked.
body: Hi there   This patch solves a bug I experienced with requests having the following form:      js    request          url:  http://localhost:8000         method:  post         headers:   Transfer Encoding :  chunked          formData:            file:               value: fs.createReadStream   somefile.txt                options:                  filename: encodeURIComponent   somefile.txt                                         ;      A request sent like this will set content length even though transfer encoding is set to chunked.  This will provoke an ECONNRESET on an express application listening to this request  which  to make things worse  will fail silently.  This request is malformed and goes against the standard  so I propose this patch to solve it.  Please feel free to modify the code style and even the functions invoked. My sole purpose is to make request avoid setting content length when transfer encoding=chunked is present.  Thank you very much

title: Reduce npm payload size by updating .npmignore
body: Thanks for creating a module I used every day  I m trying to give back in whatever little way I can.  The npm payload delivered from  npm install request  contains a few files which are not needed for the module to actually work  so I added these things to the  .npmignore  file. Here is the data for your package before and after this change:       Including deps   Excluding deps     : :   : :   : :     Current   5 136 KB   276 KB     Updated   5 120 KB   260 KB       Savings       0.31        5.80       _I got these numbers using  du  shk <directory> _  The difference between the  Including / Excluding deps  columns is whether or not the  node_modules/  directory containing  request  s dependencies is included.  [According to  request  s npmjs.com page] https://www.npmjs.com/package/request    request  has been downloaded 588 799 times in the last day. At 276 KB per download  ignoring  request  s dependencies   that is 162.5 GB per day for this module alone  With this change  that number drops by 5.80  to 153.1 GB.  In case you want to double check the resulting package  you can do so locally:        Create a tarball of the resulting package   npm pack    See the file list of that tarball   tar  tf request <version>.tgz package/package.json package/README.md package/LICENSE package/index.js package/request.js package/CHANGELOG.md package/lib/auth.js package/lib/cookies.js package/lib/getProxyFromURI.js package/lib/har.js package/lib/helpers.js package/lib/multipart.js package/lib/oauth.js package/lib/querystring.js package/lib/redirect.js package/lib/tunnel.js    Install the tarball as a local node module   npm install request <version>.tgz

title: Query strings auto encoding and OData APIs
body: Let s say I have an OData API that responds to the following query:      https://app.io/Products? filter=Name ne  Milk       I compose the request like this:      js const request = require  request  ;  request     method:  GET     url:  https://app.io/Products     qs:        filter:  Name ne   Milk           function error  response      if  error        throw error;       ;       request  will send a GET request to  https://app.io/Products? 24filter=Name 20ne 20 27Milk 27   you can check  response.request.uri.path  .  Notice the dollar sign from   filter  is escaped to   24   causing my request to not match the intended route and fail.  This behaviour comes from  querystring :      sh   node > var querystring = require  querystring  ; > querystring.stringify    filter:  Name ne   Milk      ;   24filter=Name 20ne 20  Milk         I understand this the default behaviour from a NodeJS built in library  but it causes a lot of pain when using OData query strings.   Have you encountered such behaviour before? Is there a way to disable the automatic encoding from query strings?  What I m currently doing is passing the query string manually to  url  instead of using the handy  qs  object  although its far from ideal  and I have to scan the current url for existing query strings to append correctly.

title: Re evaluate dependency usage
body: Yesterday a developer unpublished the left pad module and broke a lot of builds. The lesson for me at least was to be a lot more careful about which dependencies we take. Especially in cases where the code is trivially inline able  it may make sense to bring the code into the project  rather than rely on a dependency  and have all of  request  s users rely on that dependency .  Here are some that could be inlined:    is typed array : https://github.com/hughsk/is typedarray/blob/master/index.js    caseless : https://github.com/request/caseless/blob/master/index.js    isstream : https://github.com/rvagg/isstream/blob/master/isstream.js    json stringify safe : https://github.com/isaacs/json stringify safe/blob/master/stringify.js    stringstream   especially if you ignore the AlignedStringDecoder code  https://github.com/mhart/StringStream/blob/master/stringstream.js  Furthermore  readable stream   buried under  bl   takes dependencies on  isarray  and  util deprecate   which seem pretty trivial to copy inline.

title: Honour RFC 1945   RFC 2048
body: RFC 1945   RFC 2048 state that upon a 301 or 302 redirect  user agents should not automatically change the request method to GET:  > Note: When automatically redirecting a POST request after >        receiving a 301 status code  some existing user agents will >        erroneously change it into a GET request.   There is a relevant note for the 302 redirection as well  https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1945 section 9.3  This relates to  2060

title: Request pipe keeps a wrong header
body: Hi   I ve built a small app which downloads from a url and upload to another. Here is my code:      var downloadRequest =       url: downloadUrl      method:  GET       headers:  Authorization:  Bearer bearertoken     var uploadRequest =       url: uploadUrl      method:  PUT       headers:      request downloadRequest .pipe request uploadRequest  ;       So it is very simple but my first request needs authorization so it contains an Authorization header  Bearer  and the second one does not. However  this header Authorization line is still present during the pipe and blocks the upload request  Authorization header is not allowed .  I ve tried the following code which does not work:      request downloadRequest                .on  response   function resp                    delete resp.headers[ Authorization ];                       Node version: 4.2.1 Request version: 2.69.0  Do you deal with this issue too?

title: Security issue with hawk
body: Please see https://nodesecurity.io/advisories/77  Your  master  already has  hawk:  3.1.3  since https://github.com/request/request/commit/ebb2c3b63113d9e7225aacf6a636242c44eae385  I suggest locking version to  >=3.1.3 < 4.0.0    >=4.1.1  and publishing new patch version on npm

title: request video url to client with buffer question
body: I try to use request to provide video stream to client. here is the simple code:      js var stream = require  stream      request = require  request      express = require  express  ; var app = express  ;  app.get  /   function  req  res      var url = req.query.url;   request url .pipe res ;   ;  var server = app.listen 8100  function        var host = server.address  .address;   var port = server.address  .port;   console.log  Running on  s: s   host  port ;   ;  server.listen 8100 ;      when i provide a video url  users now can watch the video  but the problem is that they can t skip  when they pause the video  then start again  the video doesn t work anymore. So I think maybe I should use buffer before pipe to client   can you help me how to solve the problem

title: defaults not working with json or jar options
body: It seems setting json or jar through defaults doesn t work  again . I ve looked through the issues and this seems to be a recurring one. Perhaps something can be done to prevent this in the future?  Setting json through defaults:      javascript request.defaults       json: true   ;      > Error: Argument error  options.body.  Setting jar through defaults  json being set with the request :      javascript request.defaults       jar: true   ;      >   ForbiddenError: invalid csrf token...  Setting json and jar in the regular request options works without a problem  but it would be nice if we could just set them once.

title: ability to side step helper.safeStringify   for form data
body: In every case I have tried  I cannot seem to bypass the encoding of the body of a PUT. Even with the content type header set as www url encoded  AFAIK there isn t a requirement that the body be encoded in any way unless it exceeds certain size limits  nor that services have to decode the body of a PUT. It can just be raw. Something akin to   cUrl https://rawdataservice.biz  d @./filename  X PUT   It looks to me like all forms are run thru safeStringify in the helper and I can t find a way to just send raw form data.

Please close this issue if there is already this functionality  Sorry I couldn t find it in the documentation

title: Added checks to prevent undefined formdata values
Can t catch error using callback and on error handler
body: Hello  I can t handle error in the following code:      javascript         this.request.get               url: url              headers: this.headers             err  res  body  =>               if  err  return callback err ;              callback err  res  body ;           .on  error   err =>               console.log err.stack ;             callback err ;           ;      I got error output:      Error: read ECONNRESET     at exports._errnoException  util.js:856:11      at TCP.onread  net.js:550:26       After this my process terminates.

title: Adding a transform stream to request proxying
body: Hi there  I ve used request for many different projects  and I admire your work    thank you   This line from the documentation  the one line proxying  works perfectly for me:      javascript req.pipe request  http://mysite.com/doodle.png   .pipe resp       If I access this node script from my browser  my browser renders the correct response.   This is desirable     I tried adding a transform stream  which I intended to accomplish nothing other than make sure it works with a transform stream :      javascript var transform = new require  stream  .Transform  ; transform._transform = function chunk  encoding  done      this.push chunk ;   done  ;  ; req.pipe request  http://mysite.com/doodle.png   .pipe transform .pipe resp ;      If I access this node script from my browser  my browser prompts me to download the file  rather than rendering it directly in the browser.   This is undesirable.    My understanding is that adding the transform stream in between the request stream and response stream broke something. Given that I m not very familiar with node streams  let alone request streams   can you shed some insight on why this is happening?  I m certain this is not a bug  just myself being a noob. However  any insights you can share on how request relates to this is very appreciated  :

title: response.pipe doesn t work as expected
body: I wanted to do some conditional piping depending on the response from the first request.  Starting from this example in the docs:      javascript req.pipe request  http://mysite.com/doodle.png   .pipe resp       I wanted to do something like this instead:      javascript // req and resp come from http.createServer or express.js  var r = request url  function error  response      r.pipe resp ;   ;  req.pipe r ;      My desired result is for the end user to not see the difference between both implementations. However  in the second implementation  the server just hangs. I added  r.emit  end    and  r.emit  close    after piping to  resp   but the server doesn t return anything there.  How can I troubleshoot the second implementation so that I can both 1  have the same user experience as the first implementation and also 2  be able to add extra logic based on the  response  variable before committing to piping to  resp ?

title: Catch errors from the underlying http module
body: Fixes  2120

title: Check for self.req existence inside the write method
body: Fixes  2120  Also see https://github.com/request/request/issues/2120 issuecomment 208954497 and https://github.com/request/request/issues/2164

title: Add  delete  alias for the  del  API method
body: Only Using  del  seems to be a little bit opinionated if there is no  delete  method provided together; and  del  also introduced redundant ternary assignment. Thanks   Fixes  1917

title: Fix TravisCI badge reference master branch
body: I also noticed there re two badges for Coverage  one pointing to Codecov and the other one to Coveralls. Is this intended or one should not be used?

title: Explicitly destroy request buffer
body: This fixes the issue mentioned in  1723. The lifetime of the buffer variable defined in  readResponseBody  is linked to the Request object. This can lead to leaky behavior if references to the request persist in memory.  Fixes  1723

title: Add callback option
body: Just another useful way to pass the request s callback.

title: Send OPTIONS request?
body: I have to mimic an Ajax call which sends an OPTIONS request before it does a GET request.  Is there anyway to force  request    do to this? When I tried making two requests manually it doesn t work as expect    I m assuming because its taking too long  but not sure.  I was hoping for some flag like  do_options_request: true  I can set when I do a GET request.

title: Request does not support  deflate  encoding.
body: This request results in the raw response being dumped to the console:      javascript var req = require  request  ;  req       url:  http://httpbin.org/deflate       method:  GET       headers:         followAllRedirects: false      followRedirect: true      jar: true      timeout: 15000      gzip: true      rejectUnauthorized: false      strictSSL: true    function  err  res  body        if  err            console.error err.stack    err ;           console.log body ;   ;      The expected behavior is that  body  contains the decoded response.

title: Add support for deflate content encoding
body: Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/2171

title: Support for aws service name
body: There is a problem when using sigv4 to sign requests for URL endpoints that are not the traditional Amazon endpoint. The  aws4  library that works in conjunction with this module  will introspect the host url to determine the  service  and the  region . Unfortunately  if you use DNS entries to provide your user with a more traditional API endpoint  the service name  and the region  are no longer deterministic.  Consider the same endpoint in two different formats 1. https://ye4r9923df.execute api.us west 2.amazonaws.com/test 2. https://myapi.example.org  The second host name has been configured via Cloudfront to direct to the API Gateway endpoint shown in the first example. However  a request signed and executed against URL 1 will succeed  while a request against URL 2 will fail with this exception.      Error: Credential should be scoped to correct service:  execute api .       If the aws property on the request is modified to accept a  service  property  and this property is passed through to  aws4   the request will succeed. It may even be useful to allow a region to be specified in the same way.   It is unfortunate that AWS is forcing clients to know something as extraneous as a service name in order to invoke a general API endpoint.

body: request       method:  GET       uri:  https://api.nytimes.com/svc/movies/v2/reviews/search.json       qs:   query :titleEncode  api key :api_key       headers:  encoding:  utf8    Content type :  application/JSON      function response  body  error   ...   I need to check the full url that is created by this code because there is a bug in how this is being established.  I can hardcode the query value and get a result from an api I am hitting up but when I move to this type of structured request using the  qs  key I get nothing back.  Is there a way to console log the url after it is made?  I am not sure what the url looks like when making a request like this.  Thanks.

title: Is there a way to re issue same request again
body: I am using Express to proxy requests to a separate API server which is protected by OAuth 2 access tokens. When a token expires  the server will return a 401 which I am now handling in my router middleware to then go and refresh the access token associated with the clients session  I am using  express session  .  Here is my code:    router.js     app.use  /api   require  ./routes.js   ;     routes.js        javascript     var express = require  express          router = express.Router          routesController = require  ./routes.controller.js  ;      router.route  /          .get routesController.fetch ;        routes.controller.js        javascript module.exports.fetch = function req  res  next          var options = helpers.buildAPIRequestOptions req ;       request options  function err  response  body           if response.statusCode === 401              authController.refreshToken req  res  next ;           else             res.status response.statusCode .send body ;                   ;      ;         authController        javascript module.exports.refreshToken = function req  res  next          var formData =             grant_type:  refresh_token             refresh_token: req.session.refreshToken            scope:  PRODUCTION                     headers =              Authorization  :  Basic     consts.CLIENT_KEY_SECRET_BASE64_DEV          ;       request.post  url:consts.ACCESS_TOKEN_REQUEST_URL_DEV  form:formData  headers: headers  rejectUnauthorized: false   function err  response  body           var responseBody = JSON.parse body ;         if  response.statusCode === 200               req.session.accessToken = responseBody.access_token;           req.session.refreshToken = responseBody.refresh_token;           next  ;           //How to recall the same request issued from fetch controller function after this point?           else             console.log  SOMETHING ELSE HAPPENED   ;                   ;      ;      After updating the token  I would like to re issue the original API request that I am triggering using the  request  module in my fetch controller.  I m a bit stumped how I actually go about doing this  is there an elegant way to achieve this?

title: 404 error does not cause callback to fail
body: Not sure how the error handling works for the callback function  but when I get a 404 returned from a request  the first parameter  which is  error  in the documentation  is  null   which then makes the request look successful. Example code:      javascript request           url:  https://example.com/           method:  POST           json : true          body :   content  : 1           headers:               Authorization  :  token          function error  response           if error                // Return error message           else               // Success                 ;      Result:      javascript error == null response ==   statusCode :404   body  :  Not found        Thoughts?

title: incorrect header check when deal with deflate content encoding
body: js var rq = require  request  ; rq.get  https://web.wechat.com    gzip: true  ;  Error: incorrect header check     at Zlib._handle.onerror  zlib.js:370:17       While the response from https://web.wechat.com is in deflate format  it show this error. According to PR  2172  request library support deflate content encoding.  After I change  responseContent = zlib.createInflate    to  responseContent = zlib.createInflateRaw    in [request.js] https://github.com/request/request/blob/750fe8513926769c2e7e7476469b6510d234fd6e/request.js L932   it work fine.

title: Document the properties added to the http.IncomingMessage
body: Hi  I am currently helping to maintain the [Typings] https://github.com/typings/typings  definitions for the  request  package.  I noticed that  request  adds the following properties to the response object:  request    toJSON    caseless    body    read  so the result object is no longer a  pure   http.IncomingMessage .    Why are these properties not documented ?    Are they deprecated ? Is it just something forgotten in the doc ?  but I checked your tests and I did not found anything about these properties . Basically  are these properties reliable or should we keep them hidden ?

title: test
Fix link to http.IncomingMessage documentation
Merging form and body options.
body: These options can be confusing. You have to know about the existence of the other one before you can use either. If  for instance  one puts an object in  body  it ll fail because it s not the right type with a very obtuse exception. This is even more confusing if you re using  request promise . Ideally  the api shouldn t do this. It should have the body/form merged into the single storage container body  and a new option   encodeRequestAs  form/json.  This would also work well with a  decodeResponseAs  which could provide JSON or custom decoding modules  YAML  etc. .
