title: EventEmitter memory leak when header option for User Agent is included
body: This _could_ be a server side issue but it s rather strange because it only happens when sending a custom user agent string using the request module.      var request = require  request  ; var url =  http://www.bigassfans.com/case studies/delphine restaurant/ ;  request       url : url      followRedirect : false      headers:            User Agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_11_4  AppleWebKit/537.36  KHTML  like Gecko  Chrome/50.0.2661.94 Safari/537.36           function error  response  html           console.log response.statusCode ;         console.log response.headers ;   ;       When you run this  notice the response statusCode is 302  which is weird because the Location header in the response is the requested page itself.  If you run this without the User Agent header  it works as expected and you get a 200 OK response.  If you send the User Agent but comment out the  followRedirect : false  option  you get this error  > Warning: Possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 pipe listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners   to increase limit

title: Response stays in memory?
Avoid leaking callback functions when Agent pools with keepAlive=true
body: While analyzing some heapdumps I noticed that some callback functions  and all of their closure data  were being kept in memory longer than I expected.  It turns out that if request uses an Agent pool  and the pool keeps sockets around for keepAlive  then the memory is held until the initial connection is closed.    The most obvious leak is the  callback  and  _callback  references.  The agent pool holds onto references to the connection options  and if the callback is in the options it will stay in memory until the socket is removed from the pool.  The other options I removed hold less direct references back to the callbacks.  I ve put a testcase up here: https://gist.github.com/mdlavin/97b4e6755c18cdb8305681fbb6433ac0.  Without the fix below  the output looks like this:      leak changes [   what:  LeakingClass       size_bytes: 240      size:  240 bytes          : 10         : 0   ] leak changes []      Showing that the LeakingClass gets created and never removed from memory.  With the fix  the testcase outputs:      leak changes [   what:  LeakingClass       size_bytes: 240      size:  240 bytes          : 10         : 0   ] leak changes [   what:  LeakingClass       size_bytes:  240      size:   240 bytes          : 0         : 10   ]      Showing that the LeakingClass is created and then released from memory.

title: gzip: true  not setting  Accept Encoding  header automatically may be more flexible.
body: On our app  we would like to support gzip only for websites that force it whether you send an  Accept Encoding  header or not. So  our plan was to have a non gzipped communication for sites who support it and gzipped communication with sites who force it  ir order not to get hit by the CPU load gzipping all communication may create.. if it does .  Yet  making  gzip: true  currently adds  Accept Encoding: gzip  header automatically. So  it is an all or none option.  It would have been great if  gzip: true  hadn t added  Accept Encoding: gzip  header automatically but only uncompressed any gzipped responses.  And  if we still need the current behavior  gzipped communication for all requests   adding  Accept Encoding: gzip  manually will do the job.  Just an idea : .

title: GET request with Query set by function losing protocol and host
body:
see [my example of this issue] https://github.com/jesjobom/request qs bug example When trying to access an URL using GET method and adding a Query by _qs_ function AND using a Proxy configured with _http_proxy_ the request will be configured without protocol or host. Given the NodeJS app as published running http_proxy=http://localhost:3128 node index.js will give me the content of [error.page.html] https://github.com/jesjobom/request qs bug example/blob/master/error.page.html : >
>

The following error was encountered while trying to retrieve the URL: /?format=json

>
>

Invalid URL

>
>
Notice that I am using Squid as a local proxy runing at _localhost:3128_. Running http_proxy= node index.js will work: json ip : 172.0.0.1 fake ip =P I was able to correct this behavior by modifying the request.js from Request Module. diff diff git a/original/node_modules/request/request.js b/modified/node_modules/request/request.js index 124157e..e7eef40 100644 a/original/node_modules/request/request.js b/modified/node_modules/request/request.js @@ 1142 7 1142 7 @@ Request.prototype.qs = function q clobber self.uri = url.parse self.uri.href.split ? [0] ? qs self.url = self.uri self.path = self.uri.path self.path = self.uri.href if self.uri.host === unix self.enableUnixSocket request debug http_proxy=http://localhost:3128 node index debug.js request: debugId: 1 uri: http://api.ipify.org/?format=json method: GET headers: host: api.ipify.org response: debugId: 1 headers: server: squid/3.3.8 mime version : 1.0 date: Wed 25 May 2016 17:06:02 GMT content type : text/html content length : 3177 x squid error : ERR_INVALID_URL 0 vary: Accept Language content language : en x cache : MISS from jesjobom note x cache lookup : NONE from jesjobom note:3128 via: 1.1 jesjobom note squid/3.3.8 connection: close statusCode: 400 body: < DOCTYPE html PUBLIC //W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd > n n nERROR: The requested URL could not be retrieved n n n
n

ERROR

n

The requested URL could not be retrieved

n
n
n n
n

The following error was encountered while trying to retrieve the URL: /?format=json

n n
n

n
n n

title: Application crashes a few kb before finishing a large download

This problem also occured in NW 0.12.   32 bit with an older request version. This issue seems to occur in Windows XP 32 bit 100  of the time and I ve managed to get the same result in Windows 7 randomly.  I ve created a reproduction environement: _URL removed_  I highly suggest downloading the video manually from _URL removed_ and changing the download URL in index.html to your localhost  eg. http://localhost/large file.mp4  since this greatly speeds up the process of downloading the file and thus  testing.

title: Remove connectionErrorHandler to fix  1903
body: The  socket._httpMessage.emit  error   error   line currently throws when the keep alive period expires and the socket resets  after a redirect to a different host. This is because the listener on the socket is never cleaned up  and the socket no longer has _httpMessage  the ClientRequest is long gone . This is bug  1903  which is also responsible for npm/npm 9984.  It looks to me like node core correctly re emits socket error events on _httpMessage now  so we shouldn t have to. Looking at core I also cannot even find a  res  property on socket   if there s a reason to leave this  please speak up.  Closes https://github.com/request/request/issues/1903

title: Piping proxied response through intermediate stream
request options  jar  clarification
body: From README.md  on request options  callback :  > jar   If true  remember cookies for future use  or define your custom cookie jar; see examples section   var j = request.jar   is also used to create a custom jar. and we can set cookies in the jar by using j.setCookie cookie  url .  I d just like to ask for clarification. Is the jar used for sending cookies to a server  storing cookies obtained from the server or both?  As far as the README.md explains  it s only for storing cookies obtained from the server.

title: [Error: Parse Error] bytesParsed: 215  code:  HPE_INVALID_CONSTANT
body: It occure when I use request to get data from depositphotos API: getMedia to purchase a image      var params =              dp_command :  getMedia              dp_apikey :  http://api.depositphotos.com              dp_session_id : sessionId             dp_media_id : mediaId             dp_media_option : mediaOption             dp_media_license :  standard              dp_purchase_currency :  credits   ;  request.get     url: Stocksow.thirdParty[ depositphoto ][ url ]    qs: params    function err  res  body     if err       console.log err ;     callback err ;     else       console.log body ;     callback null  body ;       ;      And I ll receive an error with    [Error: Parse Error] bytesParsed: 215  code:  HPE_INVALID_CONSTANT      If I use PAW to make the same request  the raw data of response is below:      HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx Date: Thu  16 Jun 2016 09:46:18 GMT Content Type: application/json Content Length: 215 Connection: close Content Language: en Set Cookie: dEEn2wbX=jjliv080gqpb73l14kdaenuff7; expires=Thu  23 Jun 2016 09:46:18 GMT; Max Age=604800; path=/; domain=.depositphotos.com Expires: Thu  16 Jun 2016 09:46:18 GMT Cache Control: public  max age=0 Last Modified: Thu  28 Apr 2016 12:18:24 GMT    timestamp : 2016 06 16 05:46:17   version : 1.3   type : success   downloadLink : http: / /depositphotos.com /download_prepaid_file.php?id=xxxxxxxx   licenseId :12345678  method : credits        Can anyone give me a tip how to fix it?

title: Post request Issue from Node Js to another application
body: Hi   I am using http post to send data from Node to another application . Sometime the data which I am trying to POST is getting bigger than 3 MB. I am sending the data on request body. For requests where data is more that 3 MB the whole data is not getting received on the other application side. Is there a limitation of how much data we can POST and if the limitation is there   then how can we modify it ?

title: Add Force ipv6 option similar to curl
body: The request module seems to be only making requests using ipv4. In curl I can add a  6 flag to use ipv6.

title: Timeout when uploading
body: It seems that if one uses timeout options  for example 30 seconds  and I use request to upload with POST a large body which takes longer than 30 seconds to upload  a timeout error is thrown  despite uploading being happening and intervals between chunks of upload body being smaller than 30 seconds. It seems timeout code assumes that sending a request will always happen before the timeout  which works for small requests but not large.  It would be great if timeout would simply work in both directions the same. So timeout should happen only if there was no sending or receiving of a chunk for 30 seconds.

title: request             2  3
request is super slow to require
body: Description   const request = require  request     takes 100 to 150ms to execute  on Linux . Whereas [needle] https://www.npmjs.com/package/needle   a similar library  only takes 20 to 25ms. I haven t tested needle s require time on Windows  but request s require time clocked in at around 800ms on Windows 7  which is pretty ridiculous. The time to require a module may not be an issue for a lot of applications  but it _is_ a concern for [electron] http://electron.atom.io/docs/  apps. For example  if I were to build an electron app that called some api  my app s startup time would take an automatic hit of around 100ms just to require in request  and even longer on Windows . Any delay [longer than 100ms] https://www.nngroup.com/articles/response times 3 important limits/  is felt by a user  so right of the bat  my application loses any chance at being perceived as fast.  I ve been working around this by using node s archaic http module  but I m at a point where its increasingly hard for me to escape request. It is so damn popular. Basically any npm module that talks to a server uses request under the hood and consequently inherits request s slow require time.     Steps to Reproduce      js console.time  time to require   const request = require  request   console.timeEnd  time to require           Going Forward  Can we bring down request s require time  at least to needle s levels ?

title: How do I call this Request module from AWS Lambda function?
body: Sorry   am a REAL noob here   but trying to deploy a Lambda function for an Alexa skill    but cannot get  request module figured out....   I do a  require  like I do for HTTPS  like this:  var request = require  request  ;   and get an error when I actually call the Request library:  errorMessage :  Cannot find module  request     How do I include Request into my AWS Lambda function?

title: Inspect request defaults
body: Is it possible to inspect the defaults set through request.defaults   after setting them and  if so  can someone share how? I haven t been able to figure it out.  Thank you

title: Basic Auth if Username is Empty
body: The API I am working with uses ONLY a password field  NOT a username field. How can I craft a Request object that has null for username?  I end up getting   Error: auth   received invalid user or password  if I try to pass in null or an empty string for user. If I ignore the username field entirely  I get:  Error: no auth mechanism defined

title: Unable to find  elapsedTime  attribute
body: I need to be able to use the response times of my http requests so I made this test function to reproduce my issue      js TestFunction function err  res  body     ;  function TestFunction  callback        var options =            url  :  https://google.com            time  : true       ;     request options  function  error  response  body            console.log response.elapsedTime ;         return callback error  response  body ;       ;        It s telling me that the elapsedTime attribute is undefined.  I can t seem to find it when I sifted through the response itself either.  Anybody have an idea of how I can access it? It s said to be available in the docs

title: Considering  servername  to get new agent
body: Problem  : I m trying to use   SNI   on  request  passing the  servername  to agentOptions. After a ssl connection is established  the  request  does not create a new connection when different  servername  is passed to the same IP.   Solution  : Use  servername  as key to get new agent in pool.

title: ETIMEDOUT after a lot requests
body: my app is doing a lot http requests. After a while  > 2000 requests  I get ETIMEDOUT on each request. Restarting node fixes this. My target system is windows  node 4.3.1.

title: Enable TCP no delay setting
body: Hey   I didn t find way to pass a TCP no delay parameter with the library   Any idea how to enable TCP no delay with this library?    Thanks    Eitan

title: All events?
body: Any chance to get a list of all events?  How to read data from  response ? You do not explain it. Suddenly in your docs  on  data   appears and without any explanation as well. I suppose there are gazillion events you just do not cover in docs. How may we know them?

title: Removal of Authorization header is surprising
body: I had requests getting 401 d because of the following:  https://github.com/request/request/blob/290111d4e94ac9f6c8d3abecbc8920c96d1b32be/lib/redirect.js L137  I suggest adding an option  e.g.  keepAuthorization: bool    or some way of keeping all headers across redirects.

title: ssl3_check_cert_and_algorithm:dh key too small
body: When I try a basic authentication  I get the below error. Any advise?   request.get  https://host/api  .auth  admin    password   false ;    Error: write EPROTO 101057795:error:14082174:SSL routines:ssl3_check_cert_and_algorithm:dh key too small:openssl ssl s3_clnt.c:3617

title: Realm is unnecessarily encoded with rfc3986
body: The realm parameter should be excluded when encoding parameters in lib/oauth.js  concatParams  function with  oauth.rfc3986 . Servers taking the realm value into consideration will reject the authorization because of the escaping.  Providing a test case for the failure is a bit difficult because it partially depends on the server implementation.  From oauth spec :  > The OPTIONAL realm parameter is added and interpreted per [RFC2617]  section 1.2.   From RFC2617  > The authentication parameter realm is defined for all authentication >   schemes: >  > realm       =  realm   =  realm value > realm value = quoted string

title: Module does not resume/recover from network loss mid get request
body: We are using the request@2.52.0 module to download files from a node server. This has also been tested on request@2.73.0  We are using file streaming from the node server and we are also streaming the response to a file  If we loose connection mid download the module gets stuck and never finishes. We are running a synchronous application and there for it stops working when the request module gets stuck.  I wrote a test code which you should be able to use to test this.      //for server install restify and throttle npm i restify npm i throttle //for client install request npm i request      server code      js     var restify = require  restify  ;     var throttle = require  throttle  ;     var fs = require  fs  ;     var server = restify.createServer  ;      server.use restify.bodyParser   ;     server.use restify.queryParser   ;      server.get  /server   function req res         res.send 200   This is the correct server  ;             server.get  /download   function req res         var trott = new throttle 512 ;       fs.createReadStream  fileUpload/file.dat  .pipe trott .pipe res ;       ;      server.listen 3000  function           console.log  Download Server listening  ;       ;      client code      js     var request = require  request  ;     var fs = require  fs  ;    // require  request debug   request ;     var reqObj =         url:  http:// url :3000/download         headers:         ;      request.get reqObj .on  response   function response         if response.statusCode === 200           console.log  got file  ;         var output = fs.createWriteStream  fileDownload/file.dat  ;         response.pipe output ;         output.on  finish   function                        console.log  finished writing file  ;           ;          output.on  error   function error             console.log  write error:    error.message ;           ;                  .on  error   function error         console.log  request error:    error.message ;       ;      Request Debug output      js   request:       debugId: 1       uri:  http:// host :3000/download        method:  GET        headers:   host:   host :3000          response:       debugId: 1       headers:          date:  Fri  15 Jul 2016 14:24:36 GMT           connection:  close            transfer encoding :  chunked          statusCode: 200          How to recreate  Deploy the server code to a remote server and create a file of size x      dd if=/dev/zero of=file.dat bs=1M count=250 //250M size      Run the client code on your desktop and turn off your internet adapted for more than 10 minutes.  I used a ubuntu virtual machine and turned off the  Enable Networking   When internet connection is resumed the module gets stuck and never finished the pipe and therefor the code in the output.on  finish   function is never run.  There the callback is called in our application   If the internet connection is dropped for less that 10 minutes the output finish function is called but does not finish download the file. This scenario is okay for me because this will initiate a redownload.  The deadlock we have when the output finish function is never called is a big problem for us.

title: Make  arrayFormat:  brackets   a default stringify option
body: [Over on  qs   repo] https://github.com/ljharb/qs/issues/107   I and some others have identified an ambiguity in query string parsing that may be particularly problematic with [ request  and  express ] https://github.com/ljharb/qs/issues/107 issuecomment 233094445 . This ambiguity may be resolved on the  express  side by parsing all problematic querystrings [as objects] https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/3039   but to preserve the developer s intent to serializing an _array_  the  arrayFormat  needs to here be made something that can be parsed unambiguously: either   brackets   or   repeat  .   qs   maintainer has signaled his [preference for   brackets  ] https://github.com/ljharb/qs/issues/107 issuecomment 233110210  and that this may be made the default in the next version of  qs . As a stopgap  would you consider making this a default [here] https://github.com/request/request/blob/473cae3c89683885de2c6b73c2a7c3b4c43ce56a/lib/querystring.js L22 ?  It would probably need to be a breaking change  but I suspect it would inconvenience few developers since the current version of  qs   as used by  express   will parse   brackets   format as arrays no problem; and [  .param ] http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.param/  also serializes arrays using   brackets   format  so other web frameworks are probably used to handling that format.

title: IPv6 address misinterpreted
body: there are already a couple of IPv6 related issues filed   1705  1944 but all are different with this new one:  my server is binding on IPv6 address  [::]   means same as IPv4 s  0.0.0.0 ; in dual stack OSes  like Linux   this resulted being able to handle both IPv4 and IPv6 clients  but this request package is handling IPv6 address wrong  see this example:  I use nc to simulate an http server listening on IPv6 any address [::] port 3000; this listening address and port can be confirmed with  lsof       console   nc  l6  p 3000 ...    lsof  nPp 26678          from another shell  find out the pid of nc is 26678 ... nc      26678  user    3u  IPv6 391972      0t0     TCP  :3000  LISTEN       then make a curl call of this server  with IPv6 address  like  curl  v [::1]:3000/any url  the nc side can echo what is actually sent in the request:      console   nc  l6  p 3000 GET /any url HTTP/1.1 Host: [::1]:3000 User Agent: curl/7.47.0 Accept:  /        The  Host: [::1]:3000  is sent by curl as a http client  which is correct;  however  with the request as the http client  this is actually sent on wire:      console POST /any url HTTP/1.1 host: ::1:3000 accept: application/json content type: application/json content length: 307 Connection: close       by request call code is      javascript request.post        url:  http://[::1]:3000/any url         json:   a: 2  ...           err  resp  body  => console.log err  resp  body  ;      the  host: ::1:3000  part is wrong  IPv6 address should be enclosed in bracket.  BTW: I tested other nodejs http client as well  like this one http://restify.com/ jsonclient      console   node > var restify = require  restify  ; undefined > var client = restify.createJsonClient   url:  http://[::1]:3000/tasks    ; undefined > client.post  /abc    a: 2    err  req  res  obj  => console.log err  req  res  obj  ;       then the nc server side got correct result:      console POST /abc HTTP/1.1 accept: application/json content type: application/json user agent: restify/4.1.1  x64 linux; v8/5.0.71.52; OpenSSL/1.0.2h  node/6.2.2 date: Wed  20 Jul 2016 22:27:07 GMT content length: 7 content md5: qrRX4OwkT0d 4MCXuUonKA== Host: [::1]:3000 Connection: keep alive    a :2

title: Making an HTTP request to a named pipe on Windows
body: Node.js provides opening a listening socket on a named pipe  both on Windows and on Linux. See:   https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_server_listen_path_callback   https://nodejs.org/api/net.html net_server_listen_path_backlog_callback  For this  I use the express module to open a listening socket like so:      JavaScript var express = require  express  ; var path = require  path  ; var app = express  ; app.get  /:id   function req  res      console.log req.params.id ;   ; var pipe = path.join      ?  pipe   process.cwd     myctl  ; app.listen pipe  function       console.log  Listening...  ;   ;      This seems to work as sysinternal s processexplorer tells that the Node process is indeed opening handles to that named pipe.  However  it does not seem like the request module supports making HTTP requests to a named pipe:      JavaScript var pipe = path.join      ?  pipe   process.cwd     myctl  ; var request = require  request  ; request.get pipe ;       gives  Invalid URI  error .  whereas using net.socket the following works  results in the /:id route being taken on the server :      JavaScript var pipe = path.join      ?  pipe   process.cwd     myctl  ; var sock = require  net  .Socket  ; sock.connect  path: pipe   function       sock.write  GET /1 r n r n  ;   sock.end  ;   ;      Another question I have is: Is it possible to provide an already configured net.socket to the request module  or does request always try to open its own socket?

title: Document request.pause   and request.resume
body: In my search to find an efficient way to use  request  to only pipe status 200 responses to files  the only decent solution I found involved using  request.pause    and  request.resume   . SO describes this solution here: http://stackoverflow.com/a/26163128/650894. I also plan to use this solution to block against initiating downloads of files exceeding a certain length.  Because  .pause    and  .resume    are not documented in the readme  I worry that you devs may not feel bound to continue supporting them or to maintain backward compatibility. It would be nice to see these documented  both to help others who find themselves with similar problems and to give us a warm and fuzzy about dev commitment to these methods. Thanks

title: Could we start breaking features out as other modules?
body: I just noticed how much is being installed when I use request. Most of my projects I use it with  I don t use OAuth or Aws  so really  have these included are a waste of space. I m pretty sure there are other packages included in this fashion. I love using request  just would love to see it lighter.

title: Can not set custom headers when post with form data
body: I found that when using:      request                       url:  xxxx                        method:  POST                        formData: xxxx                       headers:    Content Type :  application/json              function error  response  body                       // handle response here          ; The content type is still  multipart/form data   can not be set.

title: Error in Request callback
Timeout for request through https proxy
body: I m trying make request through proxy. It s my code.      var proxyList = [     http://username:pass@hostname:65233       https://username:pass@hostname:65233  ];  var ADDRESS =  https://google.com ; var TIMEOUT = 5 1000;  var rp = require  request promise  ; var url = require  url  ;   function check proxyUrl      rp         method:  GET         uri: ADDRESS        proxy: proxyUrl        timeout: TIMEOUT        tunnel: true             .then function             console.log  good       proxyUrl ;                .catch function e            console.error e ;         ;    proxyList.forEach function proxyData      check proxyData    ;      http proxy works well  but on https i receive timeout curl commands works well on http and https      curl   proxy http://username:pass@hostname:65233 https://google.com curl   proxy https://username:pass@hostname:65233 https://google.com      How i can make request through https proxy?

title: request always throwing 200 over https
body: javascript var request = require  request  ; request  url: https://akashnimare.in/static/audio/zulip.ogg   strictSSL:false   function  error  response  body        console.log response.statusCode          even though the file does not exists. It should show 404. Where I am going wrong?

title: Support user/pass within environment
body: Current implementation seems to ignore authentication that is attached to proxy environment:      export http_proxy=http://user:pass@foo.proxy:8080 export https_proxy=https://user:pass@foo.proxy:8080

title: Request  HTTP/2  and Node.js Core
body: Hello request team   I am currently heading up an effort to explore whether and how to implement HTTP/2 support directly in Node.js core. The question of If we should do this is still open. To help answer that question  as well as determine the best course forward should we decide to move ahead  I would love to get input from each of you with regards to what would be the best approach from the Request point of view.   If this repo is not the correct place to discuss this  then please accept my apologies. I ll gladly move the conversation over to wherever you prefer it.   Refs: https://github.com/nodejs/CTC/issues/6

title: add complete proxy options to request config
body: I added proxy options to some strange cases when the complete proxy configuration is set on runtime time or simply is not configured on environment variables and the url is dynamic too.

title: Always prepending
body: I have the following code...      request.get baseUrl  things   header         .on  data   function chunk            if chunk             response  = chunk;                  .on  end   function             var objects = JSON.stringify response ;           for var i = 0; i < objects.length; i                console.log objects[i].factoryId ;                           When I put a breakpoint on chunk I see...  >  undefined[  correct JSON here... ]   This is a problem since it will not parse with JSON.parse  . Why is the undefined showing? Postman works fine and I don t see the undefined.

title: self.start invoked when request failed.
body: TypeError: self.start is not a function   at Socket.Request.write [as _write]  /node_modules/request/request.js:1380:10    at doWrite  _stream_writable.js:300:12    at clearBuffer  _stream_writable.js:407:7    at Socket.Writable.uncork  _stream_writable.js:237:7    at ClientRequest._flushOutput  _http_outgoing.js:673:10    at ClientRequest.OutgoingMessage._flush  _http_outgoing.js:647:16    at _http_client.js:156:10   at callSocketMethod  _http_client.js:531:7    at ClientRequest.onSocket  _http_client.js:536:7    at ClientRequest.g  events.js:260:16    at emitOne  events.js:82:20    at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:169:7    at tickOnSocket  _http_client.js:502:7    at onSocketNT  _http_client.js:514:5    at nextTickCallbackWith2Args  node.js:442:9    at process._tickDomainCallback  node.js:397:17

title: Not to start when object is not a Request instance
body: to fixed bug https://github.com/request/request/issues/2315

title: Using the  body  of the response outside the callback?
body: var result =    var data = request.get  https://www.googleapis.com/oauth2/v3/tokeninfo?id_token=    token   json: true  encoding: undefined    error  response  body  =>                if   error    response.statusCode == 200                    result =  body;                                 I m trying to use the request module in attempt to receive a JSON object/response from google api  and   _use the body of the response outside of the request callback._     I ve tried: 1. creating outer functions for a callback  2. pushing the body data to a variable outside the scope  3. using a concat module to collect the stream 4. returning the body 5. parsing the response  No clue what I need to do. I think it has to do with the body being a buffer and can t be save to a variable outside the scope? Can anyone help?

title: Error: Invalid URI  /
body: I find this package to be really pedantic about options.   can someone point out what might be the error in the below?         error [Error: Invalid URI  / ]    options       uri:  https://tracker.dashbot.io/track      json: true     qs:        platform:  generic         v:  0.6.0         apiKey:  xxxxx         type:  outgoing        method:  POST      href:        pathname:  /

body: On access url https://www.receita.fazenda.gov.br/Aplicacoes/SSL/ATCTA/CPF/ConsultaPublica.asp cause error below:    Error: unable to get local issuer certificate     at Error  native      at TLSSocket.<anonymous>  _tls_wrap.js:1060:38      at emitNone  events.js:86:13      at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:185:7      at TLSSocket._finishInit  _tls_wrap.js:584:8      at TLSWrap.ssl.onhandshakedone  _tls_wrap.js:416:38  code:  UNABLE_TO_GET_ISSUER_CERT_LOCALLY

title: Doc states that ESOCKETTIMEOUT should appear as ETIMEOUT but it doesn t
body: Maybe this is a documentation issue or a code issue.  The documentation [here] https://github.com/request/request timeouts  states that:  > These two situations have widely different implications for what went wrong with the request  so it s useful to be able to distinguish them.   You can detect timeout errors by checking err.code for  an  ETIMEDOUT  value.   Further  you can detect whether the timeout was a connection timeout by checking if the err.connect property is set to true.  But [code] https://github.com/request/request/blob/290111d4e94ac9f6c8d3abecbc8920c96d1b32be/request.js L776  says different  it sends  err.code  as  ESOCKETTIMEOUT

title: [Request Featured]   Websocket connection
body: I has been using your project to my application  but in my server has one request need to upgrading to websocket. I has added it into your project and tested with example server socket  but i used in my project  i can t be done   Please help me    Thanks

title: using request download file   use koa2 ctx.body = response  request s response  send file to browser   but the file is broken
body: using request download file from remote server  then use koa2 ctx.body = response  request s response  send file to browser  but the file is broken.

The method I use is :  request options function  error  status  responsebody                             if   error    status.statusCode == 200                            if responsebody                               //console.log responsebody ;                             callback responsebody ;                                                 else if error                           //console.log error ;                            callback   Ep Error :error  ;   // it throws error here .                       else if responsebody                           //console.log responsebody ;                         callback   Ep response :responsebody  ;                           else                          //console.log  An unknow error occured while sending content to ep   ;                         callback  An unknow error occured while sending content to ep   ;                                                 ;

title: form data encoding issue when posting form
body: Hi   I am having form urlencoding issue when posting data with special characters to a server. The server uses a specific charset  windows 1252  and is unable to decode those special characters when other charset is used.  is there a way in request npm package to specify a charset during request preparation to be used for encoding ?

title: Malformed host header when accessing a docker daemon
body: This may not be a bug in request  and I would be happy to report it to the docker team if that is the case. The thing is that after upgrading to the latest version of docker  1.12   when I tried to connect to the daemon using unix domain sockets  I got the error: 400 Bad Request: malformed Host header   I noticed that the host header sent by request was:  /var/run/docker.sock   On the other hand  using curl it worked well  and the request looked like this:        curl  v   unix socket /var/run/docker.sock http:/version     Trying /var/run/docker.sock...   Connected to http  /var/run/docker.sock  port 80   0  > GET /version HTTP/1.1 > Host: http > User Agent: curl/7.47.0 > Accept:  /  > < HTTP/1.1 200 OK < Content Type: application/json < Server: Docker/1.12.0  linux  < Date: Fri  12 Aug 2016 13:14:44 GMT < Content Length: 198      And by overriding the host header  I also got request working:      js request  url:  http://unix:/var/run/docker.sock:/version   headers: host:  http     function err  response  body  ...        Could it be that request is not setting the host header correctly?

title: Feature: option to enforce specific status code response
body: After many years of building and using request there s one piece of boiler that still really bugs me.      javascript request.get  /    err  resp  body  =>     if  err  throw err   if  resp.statusCode  == 200  throw new Error  Status code is not 200    resp.statusCode    // ^^ THIS LINE IS SUPER LONG AND ANNOYING ^^         It would be great if we have a feature to specify the   required    status code that would create and pass an error if it does not pass.      markdown    options.status  Specify the a required status code. If the condition is not met an error is passed  to the callback  or emitted if there is no callback .  If the option is an integer that will be the only acceptable status code. If  the option is a the status code is matched against the expression.      Thoughts?

title: how to set highWaterMark
body: Hello   I was wondering how to set highWaterMark on a stream with request? I have seen this is possible with the body option like here: https://github.com/request/request/blob/473cae3c89683885de2c6b73c2a7c3b4c43ce56a/tests/test stream.js  However this is a local stream used and I am using a remote stream. I don t know how to set a highWaterMark since I would like to reduce it in order to buffer less data than the default value reported here: https://nodejs.org/api/stream.html stream_implementing_a_readable_stream  Thanks in advance for your help.

title: content type text/html for images
body: Hi  sometimes a server mistakenly returns   text/HTML   in the header for the content type of their image URLs.  I ve noticed that when this occurs the buffer data downloaded by request appears to be invalid.  below is an endpoint that will run on nodeJS with an example URL where the content type is text/HTML instead of what it should be  an image:      app.get  /api/test   function req res          var type    =   ;     var img_buf   = Buffer    ;     var request = require  request  ;     request.get  http://images.bergdorfgoodman.com/ca/2/product_assets/Y/2/S/N/K/BGY2SNK_mu.jpg  .     on  data   function data              img_buf = Buffer.concat [img_buf data] ;        .     on  end  function w              var Canvas = require  canvas  ;       var Image  = Canvas.Image;       var img = new Image;       console.log type ;       console.log  img_buffer done downloading...  ;       img.onload = function                   console.log  i loaded  ;         res.send  done  ;        ;       img.onerror = function e                  console.log  error:  e ;               img.src = img_buf;       .     on  response   function response               type = response.headers[ content type ];       .     on  error  function error              console.log  error:   error   with:  image_urls[index] ;       ;      ;

title: TypeError: Cannot read property  secure  of undefined
body: I ve created a function that parses a JSON cookie file and generates a tough cookie CookieJar which is used with  request.defaults   jar: jar    .  When I attempt to the use the new request object I get an error:      Unhandled rejection TypeError: Cannot read property  secure  of undefined        Account.js        let Promise = require  bluebird   let fs = Promise.promisifyAll require  fs    let Cheerio = require  cheerio   let Request = require  request   let ToughCookie = require  tough cookie    module.exports =     setCookies: function cookies        let jar = new ToughCookie.CookieJar        return new Promise function resolve  reject          fs.readFileAsync cookies .then function data            JSON.parse data .forEach function cookie              let toughCookie = new ToughCookie.Cookie               key: cookie.name              value: cookie.value              expires: cookie.expirationDate              path: cookie.path              secure: cookie.secure    false              httpOnly: cookie.httpOnly    false              extensions: [                session=true                  sameSite=no_restriction              ]                         jar.setCookie toughCookie   https://facebook.com   function err  cookie                if err  reject new Error err                                    resolve Request.defaults   jar: jar             .catch function err           reject new Error err                              I use like so   index.js  :      let argv = require  yargs  .argv; let Account = require  ./src/Account.js    Account.setCookies argv.cookies .then function request      // Failing here   request  https://facebook.com   function err  resp  body        console.log body               What does this error mean? What is  undefined ?

title: Update  hawk  in order to fix  boom  unmet dependency warning

It seems that updating to  hawk  5  would fix these warnings.  Thanks

title: FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_LAST Allocation failed   process out of memory for request to registry.npmjs.org
body: Hi   We are trying to load 200mb file from registry.npmjs.org  using the request module and we have a very strange failure with process out of memory.  Here s the repro script:      JavaScript var request = require  request  ; request  http://registry.npmjs.org/ /all   function  error  response  body      console.log  before  ;   console.log response ;   console.log  after  ;   ;      If I try to use the error or body object from the callback  everything works as expected. But trying to use the response object leads to the error.  In fact this is the simplest repro case that we have. In fact issue is reproducible without console.log of the response  when there are a lot of callbacks chained  in our case we are passing the arguments from request callback to other callbacks  which call other callbacks  etc. and the process exits.  Do you have any idea what s causing this? Maybe it s related to Nodejs memory management  I m not sure what s going on here.

title: Unable to correctly retrieve headers with browserify
body: I ve traced this down from  request promise native  and it seems that the issue might be in this module. Running the following snippet in node and the browser  using browserify 13.0.1  yields different results:      var require  request  ; req  http://www.google.com   function  error  response  body    console.log response.headers ;   ;      In node:      >   date:  Tue  23 Aug 2016 17:26:51 GMT     expires:   1      cache control :  private  max age=0      content type :  text/html; charset=ISO 8859 1     p3p:  CP= This is not a P3P policy  See https://www.google.com/support/accounts/answer/151657?hl=en for more info.      server:  gws      x xss protection :  1; mode=block      x frame options :  SAMEORIGIN      set cookie : [ ... ]     accept ranges :  none     vary:  Accept Encoding     connection:  close          In browsers  browserify 13.0.1 :      Object       content type:  text/html; charset=UTF 8       cache control:  private  max age=0       expires:   1         In fact  it seems that it would only be able to retrieve these three particular headers on any requests.

title: DNS resolve
body: Hello   Please  does the  request  module deals with DNS re  resolve  automatically or through a specific parameter ? Indeed  in case of error during a POST  I need to make a re resolve  or DNS lookup .  I make some request on a domain name which IP can change randomly.  Many thanks

title: request doesn t follow 301 redirects using proxy
body: Hi  I have two urls:  http://tbphoto3.bababian.com/upload7/fuguirenshen/201606/001169212894_m.jpg  which is 301 redirected and  http://t.shuaishou.com/Get/168062675  which is 302 redirected.  But when I request to get the two with       js request.defaults     proxy:  my proxy address          only 302 redirect is returned successfully with final content.

title: Cookie not in this host s domain. Cookie:facebook.com Request:null
body: I m looping through a JSON array of cookies and adding them like so:      let cookies = []; cookies.push new ToughCookie.Cookie       key: cookie.name      domain:  .facebook.com       value: cookie.value      secure: cookie.secure    false      path: cookie.path      httpOnly: cookie.httpOnly    false      extensions: extensions    ;      I later set them like so  using request.cookieJar :      cookieJar.setCookie cookie   .facebook.com    err  cookie  =>       if err            reject new Error err  ;         return;               When making a request I am getting the following error:      Unhandled rejection Error: Error: Cookie not in this host s domain. Cookie:facebook.com Request:null      The documentation is not very good on how to set this up. I could get this to work by removing the  domain   and using  https://facebook.com  when setting the cookie. But  this is useless as this means other requests can not be made to endpoints such as  upload.facebook.com .  The cookies all contain  domain=.facebook.com .  How do I set the cookies and add them to the cookie jar properly so that they work across subdomains.

title: Progress event
body: This completes my programs requirements  but as I m not familiar with all of the ins and outs of  request   I m sure I m missing some other point where a progress event might make sense.  At the moment it:      Adds a transferred property to the  Request  object to track bytes sent.       During the  write  operation  it will emit a  progress  event that includes the standard  ProgressEvent  object as defined in the [ProgressEvent spec] https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/ interface progressevent .  Again  due to my unfamiliarity with the code base  and being the first time I ve used  tape  tests  I would say my test cases are pretty minimal and permissive  so I definitely welcome some direction from the team on that.  Closes  1450

title: Check error type instead of string
body: Upstream change broke this unit test. Fixed this in another PR and realized that it s probably better off as it s own PR.   form data  just released 1.0.0  and it changed the order of property lookup what triggers a  TypeError  when we push up a null form data property. This change just checks that it throws a  TypeError  instead of checking the string.  [Upstream code change link] https://github.com/form data/form data/compare/v1.0.0 rc4...v1.0.0 diff 121026c01234c71e2b3b316f7abc5afcR213

title: Add responseStartTime timing
body: When  time:true  is set in options  elapsedTime is added to the response object.  This PR will _also_ include  responseStartTime   the timestamp when the response begins. With this moment tagged  we can now recreate a rich network waterfall of the network activity.   For example  here s a network waterfall of some project s  npm install  with this patch and [ request capture har ] https://github.com/paulirish/node request capture har :  [image] https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/39191/18031306/9401070c 6c8f 11e6 994d 03e6b8b511e4.png

title: Pipeing and modify callback response
body: Hey guys   This is more of a question. I m pipeing one request and doing the decoding myself like this:      javascript   // decodes   .on  response   function resp       var charset = extractCharsetFromStr resp.headers[ content type ]           encoding = resp.headers[ content encoding ]          decodedRes;      // unzip     if encoding ==  gzip     encoding ==  deflate         decodedRes = resp.pipe encoding ==  gzip  ? zlib.createGunzip   : zlib.createInflate        else       decodedRes = resp      // charset     if charset  =  utf 8     iconv.encodingExists charset          return decodedRes.pipe iconv.decodeStream charset                   But this is not modifying the response body in the callback  request      err  resp  =>       my question is  if I listen to the  data  and  finish  event and buffer the body myself  will request still buffer the body on it s on if I don t pass the callback? I don t want to hold two objects like these in memory.

title: Random ETIMEDOUT
body: I am getting ETIMEDOUT in communication between servers  timeout is set to 5 seconds and request is retried 3 times. Sometimes it timeouts once  sometimes it timeouts 2 out of 3 retries and sometimes it will timeout 3 times  all 3 retries . This is not fault of the destination server because I ve tested same route from different application written in Go at the same time and i get response in 2ms  no timeouts.

title: stream pipe performace
body: I wrote this example to check the performance of just proxyn data from one source to a target  and I got very disappointed with the result. Is this degradation an expected result? is it because  request  implementation of the stream handling or is it a nodejs underlying issue?   note: I opened an issue at http proxy repo  https://github.com/nodejitsu/node http proxy/issues/1058   since it was when making performance tests when I originally found the issue       var http = require  http  ; var request = require  request  ;  http.createServer function req  res     request.get  http://127.0.0.1:3000  .pipe res ;   .listen 8080 ;  http.createServer function req  res     res.writeHead 200 ;   res.write  HELLO WORLD  ;   res.end  ;   .listen 3000 ;      And got this results  in node 4.5 :        wrk  c 64  d 15s http://localhost:3000 Running 15s test @ http://localhost:3000   2 threads and 64 connections   Thread Stats   Avg      Stdev     Max    /  Stdev     Latency     4.85ms    3.41ms 307.55ms   99.38      Req/Sec     6.73k   505.00     7.10k    93.38    202128 requests in 15.10s  24.87MB read Requests/sec:  13384.99 Transfer/sec:      1.65MB            wrk  c 64  d 15s http://localhost:8080 Running 15s test @ http://localhost:8080   2 threads and 64 connections   Thread Stats   Avg      Stdev     Max    /  Stdev     Latency    55.45ms   12.50ms 158.42ms   88.76      Req/Sec   569.33    128.19   760.00     81.94    8265 requests in 15.07s  0.98MB read Requests/sec:    548.31 Transfer/sec:     66.40KB      @indutny Any insights?

title: Adding interceptors to request
body: I m wondering if it s possible to add some sort of interception mechanism  kind of like middleware for express  to request  for things such as logging  caching  authentication  etc.  We ve been using request promise for a while now in our applications and are very pleased with it. However  in order to reuse logic for things like authentication  we ve had to wrap request promise in our own custom library  we call  endpoints   to add interception like behavior.  Ideally we d be able to add interceptors to request directly. Is there a chance this would be something that could be added? I myself would be willing to do the work to add this but would need some guidance from someone more familiar with the code base.  Ideally  the interceptor would look something like this  this is an oversimplified example  but is useful for illustrating how I think it might work :      var rp          = require  request promise  ;     interceptor = require  ./mylogginginterceptor.js  ;  rp.use interceptor   ;  rp  https://www.anendpoint.com  ;      Then the interceptor could look something like:      module.exports = function options        return function req  next  cb            // do some logging of the request         next req  function err  res                // do some logging of the response             cb err  res ;           ;      ;        Does this seem useful?

title: bug fix for formData  TypeError: The header content contains invalid characters
body: The latest version of request leaves off the function  clone  in the headers if  formData  is used:      headers:   host:  target.com        content type :  multipart/form data; boundary=                          597199664407293581467286       clone: [Function]       content length : 394  ;      As a result  the request fails with  TypeError: The header content contains invalid characters .  A proper solution would be not to store a function in the headers  but I can t be bothered so my quick fix is this  at and around line 736  in diff style :            // We have a method named auth  which is completely different from the http.request       // auth option.  If we don t remove it  we re gonna have a bad time.       var reqOptions = copy self        delete reqOptions.auth        delete reqOptions.headers.clone;        debug  make request   self.uri.href

title: stream from stdout
body: Is it possible to stream and post stdout to formData ? This code seems to be work but not      js const shell = require  shelljs   const request = require  request   const isStream = require  isstream    const file = shell.exec  cat file.jpg     silent: true  async: true     console.log isStream file.stdout   // true  const response = request   .post       url      formData:         image: file.stdout             err  httpResponse  body  =>       console.log err            PS: I just do this with:      cat image.jpg   curl  XPOST https://domain/process   form user_id=123456   form image=@       Is it possible to implement above with node ?  PS: I know there is fs.createReadStream But in real project I receive image from an external app that streams file on stdout

title: how to carry the cookies split by ; symbol?
body: here s a example: if there are at lease two keys need to be carried such as :   a : 1   b : 2   and then if I code like this:  var cookie = request.cookie  a=1;b=2  ;  We will find out that the second key might be lost at the request How to resolve it?

title: Host is set incorrectly  when url is provided as a string  due to self.uri.port being a string  not a number
body: I have a situation where request is setting the   Host  request header incorrectly by   always   appending the port.  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L294  The logic above dictates that port should only be added if its not  80  or  443   but  request  is always adding it.  The reason is that if  url  is provided as a string  request  will use  url.parse self.uri   here.  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L237 L239  When  url.parse ...   is used the  port  is returned as a   string   not a   number  .  Because of this  checking  self.uri.port === 80  or  self.uri.port === 443  will always return  false .

title: How to send two requests concurrently
body: In request module   how can we send two https requests concurrenly. Is it possible in this module or else we need to take the support of node js core things

title: Stream doesn t emit error with 500 status code
body: I m testing an API which should be returning errors and I m using a streaming  GET  call. I m then listening on the  error  event in order to do check my error handling logic. The issue I m having is that even though the response from the server has a status code of  500   the resulting stream doesn t error out and completes normally.  Is this expected behavior? The [readme] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md streaming  seems to suggest that the error event should be emitted.  Is there something else that should be done for handling errors in this situation?      javascript // on the server  res.status 500 ; res.end  Unexpected error  ;  // Sending the request var getStream = request.get url ; getStream.on  error   handleErrorLogicHere ; getStream.pipe destination ;

title: Undefined request never calls function
body: This bit me when an object property didn t exist. Per most callback patterns  I would expect the  request    function to always return either an error or a valid object. However  when the variable for the URL evaluates to  undefined   then  request    will fail silently without generating an error.

title: Digest authentication should uppercase HTTP method
body: When computing the ha2 part of the challenge  https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/auth.js L95  method is used as is  while the RFC specifies that HTTP method must be uppercase.  The problem is when you try to authenticate like this:      request      method:  get      uri:  http://test.com/asd      auth:   user:  user   pass:  pass   sendImmediately: false           While the GET is correctly performed despite the method case  the authentication will fail because the challenge is computed with the string  get  on the client size and  GET  on server side.

title: How to read same key headers from a response?
body: Hello   First of all thanks for this amazing module    Here is the issue:   After a get request I want to read two header fields called with the same key:  set cookie   I know this by inspecting the response headers in chrome s debugger.  The problem is that  when using this module  in the response headers only one appears since  I believe  it s an object already processed which doesnt allow to have same key fields.  So how do I get hold of two response headers with the same key?  Thanks    PD:  if I inspect the jar with getCookies   i get an empty array so that s not a solution. Which is also weird since before  that is  when the page I was crawling returned just one cookie for each key in the header  it worked fine and gave me an array with length > 0.

title: Wrong percent encoding for reserved URI character
body: As defined in the RFC  https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986 section 2.2  the character Apostrophe     is a reserved character and therfore should not be percent encoded when sending a http request. I went into an issue sending a request with the following path:   /api/Things  1234     because It was encoded into   /api/Things  271234 27    which cannot be handled by the backend.  As you see the paranthesis are not encoded because they are a reserved character. So encoding the Apostrophe is definetly a bug.  Btw the http.request method does not percent encode the Apostrophe.

title: req.pipe request url  .pipe res ;  can not pipe body. Can you tell me how to result it  thanks
body: when I request a response from other server via my node server  I do this: app.use function  req  res       req.pipe request url  .pipe res .    But I use request debug  find that no req.body to the other server  causing much trouble. Can you tell me how to result it. Thanks.

title: Return Request from date marked delivered
body: Return Request option should be from the date the order is marked as delivered.  Especially for custom made orders that take up to 30 days to ship out.    Would be nice to have the option to set the start date for returns from date the order was placed  shipped  or delivered.

title: How to upload file without multipart
body: Is it possible to use the request library to upload a file that doesn t use multipart  ie. you send the headers and then simply send the binary file data in the payload.  The server I am sending to is only expecting the binary data and gets confused with the multipart boundaries.

title: There is no simple way to change the port of a baseUrl
body: As [described in the README] https://github.com/request/request user content requestoptions callback   the  baseUrl  option can be used in combination with  request.defaults  to make many requests to the same domain.  This is a very useful feature when making a consumer of an API that has a lot of endpoints with the same base URL. These kind of API s are often consumed through a wrapper library for the API  and these wrapper libraries mostly have a lot of configurable options. These options typically include some kind of  port  option to specify on which port the API is running.  It s arguable that this  port  option is a bad idea  and the port should be specified in some url instead following [RFC 3986] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986 section 3.2.3   but for a lot of API wrappers that means breaking their interface.  The only way for an API to  override  the port of a  request.defaults  object s  baseUrl  is by doing string manipulation and url parsing  which is tedious  error prone and not very performant  and it s kind of stupid since both node s [http] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_http_createclient_port_host  and [https] https://nodejs.org/api/https.html https_https_request_options_callback  modules allow to easily set the port.  It would be nice to have a way to more easily overwrite the port of a  request.defaults  object for use in API wrappers.

title: Clear timeout on   abort
body: Calling   abort    does not clear timeout  process hangs until timer is triggered. There are couple of places this is done correctly    abort    happens not to be one of them. There are couple of relevant issues and PRs from   years ago  .  Sample script to reproduce:      js  use strict ; const request = require  request  ; const started = Date.now  ; const printTime = label =>    => console.log   d ms t s   Date.now     started  label ;  const req = request     uri:  http://example.com     timeout: 2500    printTime  callback   ;  setTimeout    =>     req.abort  ;   printTime  aborted    ;    10 ;  process.on  exit   printTime  exit   ;  // 27 ms    aborted // 2519 ms  callback // 2521 ms  exit      Let s close this one finally. Can any of you guys help  please? @mikeal @simov

title: Re enable timeout tests on Travis   other fixes
body: What started out as a simple re enabling of  tests/test timeout.js  on Travis has turned into more cleanup and fixes along the way.  If you want any of these commits parted out into separate PRs  let me know.  I have tested these commits on Travis many times now and each time all 4 node targets have been green  so I am fairly confident not only about  tests/test timeout.js   but also flaky tests in  tests/test pipes.js   and other random failures.  One possibly  major  change included here is the change in timeout behavior. IMHO the timeout changes  in request.js  I ve provided here more accurately reflect the intended behavior.

title: Add config option to disable body or form encoding
body: This allows for sending data exactly as it s intended  like cURL. We need this  or a comparable workaround  to POST data without it being altered by  rfc3986   . See https://github.com/splunk/splunk javascript logging/issues/9  I m happy to add some tests with a bit of guidance  I saw the following test error on Node 4  but not on 6:      /Users/me/git/request/tests/test headers.js:172     t.equal err.message   The header content contains invalid characters

title: Request does not alwasy honor SSL preApproved certs
body: Using https via a proxy will not honor https  global agent defaults.  Mostly applications pre approve self signed certs  or ca certs  by setting https  global agent s options  see [ssl root cas] https://github.com/coolaj86/node ssl root cas  which is a common module that is being used to achieve this .  It may be that on a proxy path  request will not adapt all global options for a particular protocol  but in the case of a https path the ca options should be copied over  vs. requiring every request to be annotated with a chain of pre approved certificates.

title: Handle buffers directly instead of using  bl
body: bl  does a lot  but  request  s needs are pretty simple. This PR removes  bl  in favor of operating on buffers directly. There is no change in functionality here    bl  also calls  Buffer.concat  when slicing an all buffer  BufferList .

title: Simplify  defer  helper creation
body: Removed unneeded  deferMethod  wrapper function.

title: Remove  isFunction  helper in favor of  typeof  check
body: There s already precedent for function  typeof  checks   in fact there are more of them  than  isFunction  calls.

title: Use own  isStream  helper
body: Equivalent check as  isstream   but this way related functionality is kept together for clarity  next to the preexisting  isReadStream     and you simplify the dependency graph a bit.

title: Leaking  connect  handlers with new timeout support
body: After adopting 2.76.0 I noticed that the memory on some of our servers using request started to grow when it was not growing before.  I took a heap snapshot  and it looked like there were 1000   connect  listeners on a TLS socket  holding on to other memory as a result.  It seems like the  connect  listener on a socket might not be removed if there is a timeout connecting in the new timeout implementation.  Once I reverted back to 2.75.0  the memory leak was gone.

title: Fix socket  connect  listener handling

Dose this related to  2438 ?  Thanks.

title: Node.js 0.10 is unmaintained
body:
Happy Halloween from Greenkeeper


Generated with MakeSweet




Have you heard the news?
Node.js 0.10 is no longer maintained
Up until today it used to receive critical bug and security fixes but these times are over for good.


[Node.js LTS schedule] https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/908178/19853036/0ccd8570 9f67 11e6 9bfc bbbc164c0702.png Node.js 0.10 is definitely not alive but it s also not dead yet. Its ghost is still haunting the Node.js community Many open source projects still support it and yours is among them. In order for the Node.js community to evolve we have to say goodbye to Node.js 0.10. It s time for us to finally send it to the realm of the dead. With this pull request I have removed all deprecated versions of Node.js from your project. I suggest supporting all versions of Node.js that are greater than 4 Node.js 0.12 will be unmaintained by the end of the year as well . title: Make documentation clearer on acceptable values for json property
body: The documentation is currently not clear what values can be passed to JSON  and what the values of other fields should be based on JSON s value. According to the documentation for the  body  option:    >    body    entity body for PATCH  POST and PUT requests. Must be a  Buffer    String  or  ReadStream . If  json  is  true   then  body  must be a JSON serializable object.    This implies that  json  is a boolean field; all the examples show  json  being populated with  true .   However  unit tests show that  json  can also be populated with an object.      EDIT: unit tests not found  maybe this was historical behavior that was silently deprecated?   EDIT2: code handling  json  as non boolean value [here][code example]    The documentation for  json  only says:    >    json    sets  body  to JSON representation of value and adds  Content type: application/json  header.  Additionally  parses the response body as JSON.    But doesn t say what  sets  means exactly. It would be good to clarify exactly what s acceptable for this field  and what happens in the various cases.  For example     >    json      when set to  true     sets  body  to JSON representation of value and adds  Content type: application/json  header.  Additionally  parses the response body as JSON.   When set to an object ...      It s also not clear on what happens to  form  when  json  is used  either as a boolean or object. In general  it s not clear what the behavior is when  form  and  body  are specified together.     Apologies in advance if this is already documented somewhere that I missed.     [code example]: https://github.com/request/request/blob/6739fe78759204ced0eb917f578c608f5f5f560b/request.js L1222

title: Problem with caching
body: I m currently facing with a problem between callings of my method:       function mymethod        var request = require  request  ;    var req = request.defaults  jar: true  ;    ...          I would like that every new call  a totally new request was made.    I guess there is not a manner to create a new  Request  object to avoid caching. So I m using the following technique to solve the problem  using [decache] https://github.com/dwyl/decache/  module :         function mymethod        // avoid caching of required data    decache  request  ;      var request = require  request  ;    var req = request.defaults  jar: true  ;    ...            I think using object orientation could solve that problem. Something like:           var Request = require  request  ;    var req = new Request  ;    req.post  ;    ...

title: Adds .timings array with DNC  TCP  request and response times
body: This improves upon https://github.com/request/request/pull/1459 by adding a timings breakdown for the following phases:      DNS    TCP    Request    Download    First  instead of relying on  new Date  .getTime    we can use  process.hrtime    to get a higher resolution monotonically non decreasing timestamp.  This is utilized via the [ performance now ] https://github.com/myrne/performance now  package.    The previous PR tracked  startTime   not exposed  and  elapsedTime   exposed on the request .  This PR adds a new  .timings  object that adds new timestamps and elapsed times.    Note the  timestamps  in this object are not Unix epoch based like  new Date.getTime       they are  milliseconds.microsecond  resolution relative to when the  performance now  module got loaded.    If there is a redirect when fetching the resource  the timestamps are only for the final resource fetched.    Timestamps:       start : Timestamp when  request    was initialized     socket  Timestamp when the [ http ] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_event_socket  module s  socket  event fires.  This happens when the socket is assigned to the request  after DNS has been resolved .     connect : Timestamp when the [ http ] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_event_connect  module s  connect  event fires.  This happens when the server acknowledges the TCP connection.     response : Timestamp when the [ http ] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_event_response  module s  response  event fires.  This happens when the first bytes are received from the server.     end : Timestamp when the last bytes of the response are received.    Durations:       dns : Duration of DNS lookup   timings.socket     timings.start       tcp : Duration of TCP connection   timings.connect     timings.socket       firstByte : Duration of HTTP server first byte   timings.response     timings.connect       download : Duration HTTP fetch   timings.end     timings.response       total : Duration entire HTTP round trip   timings.end     timings.start      Example:         var req = request   url:  http://foo.com   time: true    function err  response  body       console.log  elapsedTime   response.elapsedTime ;    console.log response.timings ;    ;    /   elapsedTime 271    start: 8.496343     socket: 11.571675     connect: 61.353872     response: 102.523232     end: 279.228004     dns: 3.0753320000000013     tcp: 49.782197000000004     firstByte: 41.16935999999999     download: 176.704772     total: 270.731661     /

I can submit a PR to fix this if this is in error or no longer needed.

title: Support temporary redirects with authorization
body: This PR is to remove the exclusion of 307 redirects when removing authorization headers. I m not sure why this was excluded in the first place  but it s causing issues when I try to authenticate with a server that uses 307 instead of 301/302 to redirect after successfully authenticating.     Original issue is here:  2455     Authentication spec makes no mention of special handling for 307 redirects: http://www.webdav.org/specs/rfc2617.html the.authorization.request.header

If I comment out the entire nock portion  it works as expected by getting a timeout error  since google can t respond faster than 10 ms . title: AWS support does not include the use of session tokens for temporary credentials
body: The AWS option currently only supports cases wherein a permanent access/secret key is supplied as arguments  not for temporary keys  such as those retrieved via STS . This is a common use case  wherein a user can authenticate via something other than having their own IAM user  and can then be given credentialed access to various AWS endpoints  for instance  access to an API in the API Gateway .    Fixing this is extremely simple  though there s a limitation in the aws4 library in certain cases that requires knowledge of AWS  see https://github.com/mhart/aws4/issues/30 for details   and I ll be submitting a PR for it.

title: AWS support does not include the use of session tokens for temporary credentials
body: Modified readme to indicate support of  session  as part of the AWS object.    Modified call to aws4.sign to include session token if provided.    Set x amz security token header if session was included.    Modified tests appropriately to ensure x amz security token is in place if session is provided  and is still excluded if session is not.    Fixes  2462

title: request content type is removed from request header and body is deleted when redirecting
body: The content type and body are removed from the header when redirecting. I use the content type with other header values to create authorization header. The destination server recreates the authorization using the same set of header values  Obviously the original authorization value doesn t match with the value calculated at the server side because the content type is removed when redirected. What is the reason removing the content type and body when redirecting?           if  response.statusCode  == 401    response.statusCode  == 307         // Remove parameters from the previous response  unless this is the second request      // for a server that requires digest authentication.      delete request.body      delete request._form      if  request.headers           request.removeHeader  host          request.removeHeader  content type          request.removeHeader  content length          if  request.uri.hostname  == request.originalHost.split  :  [0]             // Remove authorization if changing hostnames  but not if just          // changing ports or protocols .  This matches the behavior of curl:          // https://github.com/bagder/curl/blob/6beb0eee/lib/http.c L710          request.removeHeader  authorization

title: Multipart/related POST request breaks if passed stream throws an error
body: We noticed that it is impossible to catch an error from passed stream that is multipart chunk. It seems that if  after resuming the stream inside request  stream throws an error  it crashes the application  as the error is not caught by any event listener and cannot be handled then.    Steps to reproduce:  1. Create a stream  that will throw an error after opening  in our case: http stream returning 404   2. Pass the stream as multipart data:       const options =       method:  POST      json: true     encoding: null     uri: someURI     multipart:      [    Content ID :  <metadata>            Content Type :  application/json           body: someString             Content ID :  <content>            Content Type :  application/octet stream           body: streamHere   ]         3. Start issuing a request:     request options ;       We tried attaching multiple different event emitters to the request and to the stream directly  specifically    error  ones   but still   it seems like error thrown from the stream is unhandled and could break the app.    Just as POC   we commented out  request  part completely and tried consuming the stream in the code   it was properly handled and all the event listeners were called as expected  including  error  listener in particular .

title: Catch piped stream errors and emit them properly.
body: Added proper handler for errors caused by piped streams. Without it  streaming multipart data could  break the lib  if provided stream throws an error.

title: Memory Leak in Streaming
body: This might be a known issue.  I ve noticed a significant leak when using  request  to stream video.     The quick workaround is to undefine the callback when receiving a response.       function createStream options  callback       const requestStream = request options  error =>  error ? callback error  : undefined        .once  response    response  =>          // A bug in  request  causes a memory leak if a callback is defined        requestStream.callback = undefined;        callback undefined  response ;        ;          All memory is released once the request is aborted. That makes it more relevant when streaming for longer duration.  If anyone is interested  I also have a simple  tape  test that reproduces the issue. Running the test will cause a  300 MB leak in 10 seconds. The leak is slower when streaming live video  depending on the bit rate .

Is there anyway to limit the response body size in  request  _ i.e. return an error after a given body size is exceeded _?    Is it possible to discard the response body   pipe to /dev/null equivalent  . I.E. only care about response headers and response status code.

title: Publish and update to aws sign2 0.6.1
body: When using Rollup.js  the packing process breaks on the request dependency [aws sign2] https://github.com/request/aws sign   because of a duplicate export.         Error parsing /node_modules/aws sign2/index.js: Duplicate export  queryStringToSign   225:32  in /node_modules/aws sign2/index.js         This issue has been fixed in aws sign2  and there is an open issue on that repository to publish the new package. Right now anyone using request  or a package that uses request as a dependency  in our case Webdriver.io  node gyp and selenium standalone  cannot use Rollup  and possibly other similar products?  in their build process.    Fix should be as simple as publishing aws sign2 and updating the package in request. Thank you

title: on  error   fired twice on timeout of keep alive socket
body: When setting a timeout on a request as in this code:     js  const express = require  express  ;  const request = require  request  ;  require  request debug   request ;  require  simple errors  ;    const app = express  ;    // The code for /slow/ping just sleeps for 30s before responding.  It s just this:  // app.use  /slow/ping    req  res  => setTimeout    => res.send  delayed pong    30000  ;  app.use  /test/     req  res  next  =>      const apiRequest = request        url:  http://localhost:9000/slow/ping        timeout: 2000      ;      apiRequest.on  error    err  =>        console.log  unhandled API error:   err.code ;      if  err.code ===  ETIMEDOUT     err.code ===  ESOCKETTIMEDOUT            return next Error.http 408   API call timed out   ;             return next err ;      ;      // Defer piping the response until the response event so we can    // check the status code.    apiRequest.on  response    resp  =>        // Do not attempt to apply transforms to error responses      if  resp.statusCode >= 400           console.log  Received error   resp.statusCode  from   apiRequestOptions.url   ;        return apiRequest.pipe res ;               return apiRequest.pipe res ;      ;    ;    app.listen 12345 ;         If the timeout occurs the   ETIMEDOUT   is correctly emitted.  However  on subsequent requests to the same endpoint  it appears that the original socket is re used and then 2 errors are emitted.  Both   ETIMEDOUT    and   ESOCKETTIMEDOUT  .    This is usually on the second or third refresh.    In an expressjs application  this causes the error handler to fire twice  which breaks the application. title: Update Init to include the npm_config_strict_ssl env param
body: In larger libraries that utilize Request  setting the strict ssl  and also the tunnel  setting is difficult. I often have to edit the source implementation to allow my system to access resources from behind a corporate proxy. This update would allow users to set the npm_config_strict_ssl environment variable to better customize the proxy implementation.     I have run into this problem using Electron  node pre gyp  nightmare.js and a few other smaller npm packages.
