title: Request contains both content length and  Transfer Encoding :  chunked
body: Hi     I came across an issue using request version 2.79.0.  I want to sent a multipart request containing two elements  the first is a json object with known length  the second is a stream of unknown length.  Therefore I set  Transfer Encoding :  chunked  in the request options:         var options =        method:  PUT        uri:  http://localhost:9002/api/store/...        formData:          metadata: JSON.stringify metadata          content: part // a stream              headers:           Transfer Encoding :  chunked                  However  the server I m sending the data to raises an Error    [Error: Parse Error] bytesParsed: 1628  code:  HPE_UNEXPECTED_CONTENT_LENGTH   .   This is because request internally adds a content length header to the http request. If  Transfer Encoding :  chunked  is set in the options then request must not add a content length header.    I did some debugging and found the code that sets the header  it s in request.js line 575:  self.setHeader  content length   length    If I uncomment this line  then everything works just fine.  I guess that the code needs an additional check to anly set content length if no  Transfer Encoding :  chunked  is specified.      This is the output of request debug. There you can see that both headers  Transfer Encoding  and  content length  are set:              request:        debugId: 2       uri:  http://localhost:9002/api/store/1.1/file/environment/project1_p/zips/2a0d2a70 c210 11e6 a963 b964c3706543.zip        method:  PUT        headers:           Transfer Encoding :  chunked          authorization:  Bearer myToken           x request id :  631613F8 4BAC 4A00 B892 FDA0A2EA3A1D          host:  localhost:9002           content type :  multipart/form data; boundary=                          290886497940693959155150           content length : 499                          I m not sure if this is the only relevant line of code  as content length header is set at many different code blocks.      Bye   Daniel

title: There is bias of callback if error occured in request
body: Generally speaking  we have to keep consistence when call the callback in code which means a callback should be called always in async way. let s see the code below:       javascript  function asyncFunc options  callback        callback  ;       asyncFunc   => console.log  Second   ;  console.log  First  ;         what do we expect is:       First  Second         but we got:       Second  First         Let s make a bit changes:     javascript  function asyncFunc options  callback        if ...            http.get options callback ;       else           callback  ;              asyncFunc   => console.log  Second   ;  console.log  First  ;         What does the result look like? We don t know  But the principal of a  callback   should be called asynchronously  in this way  we keep the API consistency to developer. When it comes to the  request  module  same problem exists. Let simplify the code:       javascript  function request options  callback        self.on  error   self.callback.bind   ;      // do some merge and parsing things here...      if  typeof self.baseUrl  ==  string           // this will be executed synchronously         return self.emit  error   new Error  options.baseUrl must be a string   ;               self.req = http.request options callback ;      self.req.on  error   self.callback.bind   ; //  this will be executed asynchronously       request options   e res =>       if e            return console.log  Second  ;       else           //...           ;    console.log  First  ;         What we expect the output of above code is:       First  Second       But if there is something error with  baseUrl   we ll get  Second  immediately  that s not what we want. So I suggest that the code should be:       javascript  function request options  callback        self.on  error   self.callback.bind   ;      // do some merge and parsing things here...      if  typeof self.baseUrl  ==  string              // this will be executed synchronously           return process.nextTick function                 self.emit  error   new Error  options.baseUrl must be a string   ;            ;               self.req = http.request options callback ;      self.req.on  error   self.callback.bind   ; //  this will be executed asynchronously            What do you think of it? @simov @mscdex

title: status code 406 returns by an URL where it s possible to download with wget and curl
body: With request  the result is an empty file and the 406 status code printed in the console.       js   use strict ;    const fs      = require   fs  ;  const request = require   request  ;  require   request debug    request ;    request    .get   https://alioth.debian.org/frs/download.php/file/3979/chrpath 0.16.tar.gz      .on   response   function  res         console.log  res.statusCode ;          .pipe  fs.createWriteStream   chrpath 0.16.tar.gz   ;         output         request:        debugId: 1        uri:  https://alioth.debian.org/frs/download.php/file/3979/chrpath 0.16.tar.gz         method:  GET         headers:   host:  alioth.debian.org           response:        debugId: 1        headers:           date:  Tue  20 Dec 2016 17:57:59 GMT            server:  Apache/2.2.22  Debian              x powered by :  PHP/5.4.45 0 deb7u6             x robots tag :  noindex  nofollow            vary:  Accept Encoding             content length :  0            connection:  close             content type :  text/html; charset=UTF 8           statusCode: 406      406

title: Expose setting to utilize  dns.resolve  automatically instead of falling back to  dns.lookup
body: In a normal scenario if you do a  request.get  http://www.foo.com    Node will perform a  dns.lookup  on  www.foo.com . This is an asynchronous task in the Node event loop  but it utilizes a synchronous libuv thread. This is called out in the DNS docs  https://nodejs.org/api/dns.html dns_dns_lookup.    You can see why this matters by looking at the following Node github issue  https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/8436  and my comment on that issue at  https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/8436 issuecomment 268322327 .    Unless you utilize a custom flag  the libuv thread pool is only 4 deep. This means if you do 4 dns.lookups which are delayed for some reason  the entirety of anything governed by libuv is blocked until those returned. This means any IO is blocked until those dns requests resolve  which is really hard to debug since the Node event loop will be healthy  but IO requests will never complete.    Now  this entire operation is avoidable if  dns.resolve    is used instead of  dns.lookup   . From my tests  dns.resolve    ignores  /etc/hosts  but still utilizes  /etc/resolv.conf . So my suggestion would be expose a setting  which when passed  dnsResolve : true  then it will take the URL passed  extract the hostname  execute a dns.resolve on it  then alter the url to be by IP and pass a host header with the original value. In example  request.get  http://www.google.com/test/    would be converted under the hood to request.get  http://172.217.4.132/test/     headers :   host :  www.google.com      . All in all it s a fairly easy operation to make  and is essential for our use case. We would be willing to submit a pull request to get it into  request  if you believe it could be of value.

title: More lenient gzip decompression
body: Be explicitly lenient with gzip decompression by always requesting   zlib  to flush the input data and never explicitly ending the   zlib  input.    The behavioural difference is that on Node   6  which has a slightly  stricter gzip decoding process than previous Node versions  malformed  but otherwise acceptable server responses are still properly  decompressed  the most common example being a missing checksum  at the stream end .    This aligns behaviour with cURL  which always uses the  Z_SYNC_FLUSH   flag for decompression.    On the downside  accidental truncation of a response is no longer  detected on the compression layer.    Ref: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/8701 issuecomment 268224481

title: Fix Deprecation warning
body: Hello     I ve noticed a WARN message when installing dependencies of this module   npm WARN deprecated node uuid@1.4.7: use uuid module instead     Thanks for the great work     Michael

title: Calling GET to domain with .php in between seems to be returning 400 bad request
body: I can call directly in my browser to a url like this:    https://[username]:[password]@api.bamboohr.com/api/gateway.php/visioncritical/v1/employees/changed?since=2016 12 20T23 3A46 3A53Z    This will return some results on screen.  However  when I call it using   request.get [Same domain] ;    This is always returning status 404.  I couldn t figure out why except suspecting it has something to do with the structure of the url  e.g say having .php in between ?   Is it possible that there is a defect in request module for not supporting url in such format?

title: Add CORS support?
body: Have you thought of adding CORS support. I m using the  request  package to test a backend server and I m trying to send CORS requests and thought it would be nice if you could enable CORS functionality and I didn t have to take care of sending the  OPTIONS  request before each request I want to execute.

title: support  application/octet stream
body: support  application/octet stream

title: the length of  request body is larger then content length
body: when  i use request to transmit a post request the content length in origin header is 2007 but the body s length transformed by request module is 2410. as a result   the content of body has been cutted off.i think the content length should be reseted.     Request.prototype.form = function  form       var self = this    if  form         if   /^application /x www form urlencoded b/.test self.getHeader  content type              self.setHeader  content type    application/x www form urlencoded               self.body =  typeof form ===  string          ? self._qs.rfc3986 form.toString  utf8           : self._qs.stringify form .toString  utf8        //i think the content length should be reseted      self.headers[ content length ] = self.body.length      return self         // create form data object    self._form = new FormData      self._form.on  error   function err         err.message =  form data:     err.message      self.emit  error   err       self.abort            return self._form

title: File upload works only with standard read streams
body: I ve been trying to upload a file  using multipart POST request  that is inside TAR archive  I use  tar stream  library to get stream to a particular file inside TAR archive . But it always fails with ECONNRESET error. After a bit of experimenting it seems like it can only upload streams constructed directly with  fs.createReadStream  and fails with irrelevant error for all other streams.     Here s a minimal example to reproduce problem. If  PassThrough  stream is passed into  formData  then the following error is occurred:         ERROR   Error: socket hang up      at createHangUpError  _http_client.js:254:15       at Socket.socketOnEnd  _http_client.js:346:23       at emitNone  events.js:91:20       at Socket.emit  events.js:185:7       at endReadableNT  _stream_readable.js:974:12       at _combinedTickCallback  internal/process/next_tick.js:74:11       at process._tickCallback  internal/process/next_tick.js:98:9  code:  ECONNRESET            Server:     JavaScript  var http = require  http  ;    http.createServer function  request  response                                                                                          request.on  data   function chunk           console.log chunk.length ;        ;          request.on  end   function            response.writeHead 200   OK     Content Type :  text/html   ;        response.end  ;        ;                                                               .listen 8077 ;         Client:     JavaScript  var request = require  request  ;  var fs = require  fs  ;  var PassThrough = require  stream  .PassThrough;    var rs = fs.createReadStream  some_file.bin    pt = new PassThrough  ;   rs.pipe pt ;   request      method :  POST      url :  http://127.0.0.1:8077      formData :       uploaded_file : pt         function  err  httpResponse  body       if  err     console.log  ERROR   err ;   else    console.log    statusCode : httpResponse.statusCode   body : body   ;    ;

title: Support NO_PROXY wildcards
body: We have a full external proxy  but all internal traffic is handled separately and does not need a proxy.    The current implementation requires all subdomains to be listed in the  process.env.NO_PROXY :                    env :                     NODE_DEBUG :  request http                     HTTP_PROXY :  http://proxy.company.com:8080                     HTTPS_PROXY :  http://proxy.company.com:8080                     NO_PROXY :  subdomain 1.company.com subdomain 2.company.com ...                          Ideally it would be nice to allow wildcards in the  NO_PROXY  configuration to allow something simpler  such as:                    env :                     NODE_DEBUG :  request http                     HTTP_PROXY :  http://proxy.company.com:8080                     HTTPS_PROXY :  http://proxy.company.com:8080                     NO_PROXY :   .company.com                          I think the implementation would be relatively straight forward and would only require changes to how the [hostname is matched against the noProxyZones] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/getProxyFromURI.js L26     If people are open to this idea  I can put together a PR...

title: Error is not getting propagated to consumers of request
body: Code is here : https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L188    Because of the above referenced line of code  the actual errors in making the HTTP request are not known by the code using  request . The caller just gets an error event with no other information. Is there some reason / rationale behind this? Isn t it better to give the consumer all the available information about the cause of the error so that appropriate error handling is done?    If somebody does not want all that info  they can very easily ignore that. Am I missing something?    How this affected me :      I am using the  node gcm  package which uses  request  to make the HTTP request. The authentication key is passed to  node gcm  as an option from my code which then gets passed as an header to  request . That key had a   n  at its end and the core http implementation of nodejs does not allow that and raises an  Exception .     request  catches that here https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L745 and emits an  error  event with the actual error object  but then it gets swallowed by the code specified at the beginning of this issue.    P.S : Could not find anything like a mailing list. Hence posting this as an issue.

title: Error: connect ETIMEDOUT 202.x.x.x:80
body: hi everyone please help me understand this error and fix it    when i used  requestjs   Request to web site http:// www.example.com . i had response like this :            Error: connect ETIMEDOUT 202.x.x.x:80      at Object.exports._errnoException  util.js:1022:11       at exports._exceptionWithHostPort  util.js:1045:20       at TCPConnectWrap.afterConnect [as oncomplete]  net.js:1087:14     code:  ETIMEDOUT      errno:  ETIMEDOUT      syscall:  connect      address:  202.x.x.x      port: 80           but when i go to website in the browser it is work  but  must wait  few minutes    why and how to do that ?    thank you.

title: Saving and Using cookies in future requests
body: Cookies for not being Set  nor Added to requests for some reason.    With the code:     js  const req = request.defaults      jar: request.jar      ;  req.post          url:  http://localhost:3001/auth/login          crossOrigin: true         json: true         body:  email: email  password: password         .on  response    response  =>          console.log req.jar  .getCookies  http://localhost:3001   ;        ;         I receive in the response:         Set Cookie:session=foobar;...         Yet  req.jar  .getCookies  http://localhost:3001    returns an empty array.    I want to send a request to login  store the received session cookie and use that in all future requests.    The URL I m requesting the cookie from is not the same as the URL the client is running on  Client   API   but that shouldn t have significance in this situation. I ve checked the cookies in my browser and none have been set for  http://localhost:3001 .    Any ideas?    EDIT: I ve also noticed that although the Set Cookie header is in the response  inspected through chrome    console.log response.headers   only outputs:  Object  content type:  application/json   .     Could this be an issue with the API and the  Access Control Allow    headers?

title: A couple of  issues  on digest authentication implementation
body: Hi     more than real issues these are potential improvements to current implementation of digest authentication...    Background: we have a server that uses digest auth because  due to some contraints on the network connection between server and client  we cannot fully protect for MitM attacks  and consequently we cannot use basic auth.    As far as I understand  current implementation in request is that  when setting the immediately parameter to false  it first sends a non authenticated request and then  when the server requests digest  it sends the digest authenticated request. The problem with this implementation is that a MitM may intercept the initial request and sets authentication required to basic rather than digest  effectively  downgrading  teh authentication and intercepting the credentials.    A potential solution would be controlling through an additional field in the auth parameter object which authentication mechanisms are allowed in the second request  so basic authentication can be fully disabled.    There is also a potential improvement: currently for every request that wants to use digest auth  two http requests must be sent: one non authenticated and then the one authenticated with digest. It would be possible to keep the parameters from the previous digest authentication  including new nonce ...  and try to use them to authenticate directly for succesive requests.    I am looking at the code  and I think that both improvements are not difficult to implement. If you think they make sense  I can make a pull request once I have the changes ready    tx

title: Improvements in digest authentication support
body: As I mentioned in issue  2546  there are a couple of improvements in the implementation of digest authentication:    1.  have a mechanism to make sure that digest authentication is used:  What I did is adding a new  optional  parameter to the auth   method that can disable the use of specific authorization methods when sendImmediately is set to false. With this parameter  teh caller can disable  for example  basic and bearer authentication  thus ensuring that only digest authentication is used.     2.  optimize the use of digest authentication when consecutive requests are issued  I added a new class variable to Auth to store the information from the previous sent digest authentication. When a new request with sendImmediately=false is sent  and if there was a previous digest authentication sent  it tries to send dircetly a new digest auithentication using the parameters  qop  nonce  cnonce  seq ...  from the revious one. If the request does not work due to baud authentication  the currently implemented mechanism if resending the request with teh authentication required by the server will work.

title: PR Backlog Cleanup
body: There are a lot of open PRs for the repo with unresolved problems  broken tests  merge conflicts   last rebased 1  years ago . I d like to contribute more time to this repo  but its hard to know which of these PRs have authors that are still interested in merging/responding. Reaching out to each author and walking them through fixing up their PRs individually is time consuming and not something I could reasonably get through myself.    I d like to automate this by suggesting the following: We close all PRs opened over 3 months ago with the following comment:    > This PR has been closed as  Abandoned  as a part of an automated cleanup.  @AUTHOR  if this is a mistake and you are still interested in merging this PR  please do the following:  > 1. Rebase your changes onto the  master  branch  even if there are no merge conflicts  we want to make sure your change is under the most recent tests .  > 3. Push your updated branch to Github to update this PR.  > 4. Make sure this PR s Travis tests are still passing.  Run  npm test  locally if tests are still failing .  > 5. Comment here to let us know that you ve updated the PR and are still interested in getting it merged. Somebody from the project will respond and work with you to review.  >  > Thank you for your understanding. If you have any questions  feel free to respond here and I ll be happy to answer them.    I can commit to working with each author who responds. For anyone who doesn t respond  we can add a follow up comment in a few weeks/months asking anyone who s interested to take over with their own PR.    /cc @mikeal @simov  and anyone else who is interested in helping maintain request going forward  wdyt?

title: Removal of body and some headers on redirects
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [ ] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [ 2464] https://github.com/request/request/issues/2464   please note that an related issue has already been created  however no solution had been discussed          <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >       PR Description  As pointed out in issue [ 2464] https://github.com/request/request/issues/2464  some headers  body and _form are being remove on redirects.    Added options followOriginalBody  boolean  and followOriginalBodyForCodes  list  such that if the response status is in followOriginalBodyForCodes  [401  307] by default to maintain current behavior  or followOriginalBody is true  false by default to maintain current behavior   then host  content type and content length headers  body and _form are not removed.    Added the debug information of the headers  body and _form on redirection as the debug info in request.init options  contains the options  which are not defined in case of redirections.    Also added some tests to check that in case of redirection the above mentioned headers are being removed when the response status is not in followOriginalBodyForCodes and followOriginalBody is false  and not being removed otherwise. The removal or not of the body and _form should also be tested but couldn t find them in the request  indications on how to test them are welcome and appreciated . title: Error when consuming stream from http.IncommingMessage of on  response   response
body: Summary    When you use the http.IncommingMessage from the  on  response   response   as a stream  and combine that with timeouts or promises  you get a partially consumed stream.    It seems that someone is already consuming the stream  so if you delay yourself a bit  you get partially consumed stream. If you don t delay yourself  you are fine.        Simplest Example to Reproduce    This examples tries several scenarios y prints the first lines of each example.    The scenarios are:     Use promise AND use request response as a stream     Use promise AND use http.IncommingMessage as a stream     Use timeout AND use http.IncommingMessage as a stream     Don t delay AND use http.IncommingMessage as a stream    First   Last example work ok  the other two fail.       js  const request = require  request  ;  const   Writable   = require  stream  ;  const chalk = require  chalk  ;    class ToString extends Writable      constructor          super  ;      this.result =   ;           _write chunk  encoding  callback         this.result  = chunk.toString  ;      callback  ;            function stringifyStream stream       const sink = new ToString  ;    stream.pipe sink ;      sink.on  error    err  => console.log  something went bad with sink   err  ;    stream.on  error    err  => console.log  something went bad with stream   err  ;    return new Promise resolve =>        stream.on  end      =>          resolve sink.result ;        ;      ;         const sample =  name  inputStream  =>      return stringifyStream inputStream       .then res =>          console.log chalk.green   nBEGIN Sample:     name    ;        console.log res.split   n  .slice 0  6 .join   n   ;        ;   ;    function withPromise fn  thenFn       return  new Promise fn  .then thenFn ;       withPromise     resolve => request.get  http://nodejs.org/dist/index.json  .on  response   resolve      response => sample  request.js   WITH promise   on response   response    ;    withPromise     resolve => resolve request.get  http://nodejs.org/dist/index.json        response => sample  request.js   WITH promise   NO on response   response    ;    request.get  http://nodejs.org/dist/index.json  .on  response   response =>      setTimeout    =>        sample  request.js   WITH timeout   on response   response ;       100 ;      ;    request.get  http://nodejs.org/dist/index.json  .on  response    response  =>    sample  NO promise   on response   response  ;               Expected Behavior    All outputs should be the same        Current Behavior    The output when i delay myself is different  the stream is partially consumed  so in this example we have a few lines out of the output.        Possible Solution    Solution  I don t know. The cause I think is that the library is already attach to the original stream and it s consuming it. So if we give it enough time  it consumes everything or a part of the stream.        Context    I needed the original stream since I m using hapi and request to proxy a request. And hapi doesn t like the stream request gives back.     See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31210950/how do i stream data to browsers with hapi        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.79.0    node               6.9.1    npm                3.10.8    Operating System   OS X Sierra

title: Timings: Tracks  lookup   adds  wait  time  fixes connection re use
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.    [x] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: Addresses some feedback from https://github.com/request/request/pull/2452       PR Description  Feedback from @mcorb in https://github.com/request/request/pull/2452 found a few items with the new  .timings  object.    Changes:    1. The [ net    lookup  ] https://nodejs.org/api/net.html net_event_lookup  event is now tracked  which is the correct event to track DNS lookup time.  2. There is a new  .timingStart  property that is based on  Date.now   .  3. The  .timings.   timestamps are relative to  .timingStart   using  now    .  4. The  .timings  object now only contains  socket    lookup    connect    response  and  end   moving the durations to  .timingPhases    5.  .timings.start  is no longer needed  since it will always in effect be  0 .  6. The other durations such as  wait    dns    tcp   etc were moved to  .timingPhases .  7. A new  .timingPhases.wait  delta is added  which tracks the time from  start >socket   8. The  .timingPhases.dns  calculation is changed from  start >socket  to  socket >lookup .  9. Documentation was updated to be clearer about the handling of HTTP redirects and for all of the new properties above.  10. For cases of connection re use  the timings would have resulted in  NaN s or negative numbers.  This is resolved by assuming any events  such as  lookup   that did not happen  due to re use  are  filled in  using the timestamp of the previous phase  such as  socket    resulting in a  0  ms delta.  11. Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/2575 by not re adding event listeners to Keep Alive sockets  resulting in EventEmitter leak     Here is an example of the current properties:               elapsedTime: 143                  // deprecated    responseStartTime: 1488424737161  // deprecated    timingStart: 1488424737018        // Unix Epoch ms    timings:                          // relative to timingStart       socket: 6.410719000000002        lookup: 7.299280000000001        connect: 46.287758000000004        response: 105.45501300000001        end: 142.975414           timingPhases:                     // durations       wait: 6.410719000000002        dns: 0.8885609999999993        tcp: 38.988478        firstByte: 59.167255000000004        download: 37.52040099999999        total: 142.975414                  Tests have been added.

title: Correctly format the Host header for IPv6 addresses
body: Fixes  2292       PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [x] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [  N/A    or add link to issue here]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description    When using IPv6 addresses in URLs  the address must be enclosed in brackets  e.g. https://[::1]:3000/headers.json     Likewise  when using IPv6 addresses in  Host  header values  the address again must be enclosed in brackets  e.g.  Host: [::1]:3000     When the   request   module adds the  Host  header value  it does so using the  hostname  and  port   if needed  parts of the parsed URL.  However  this approach does not correctly format IPv6 addresses with the necessary enclosing brackets as  hostname  does not include them.    If you were instead to utilize the  host  portion of the parsed URL instead  you would automatically get the correctly bracketed value  potentially plus the port.  My testing has not shown any case where the port was unnecessarily included in the  host  value so I have also avoided adding extra code to remove the port if deemed unnecessary by   request    though I d be happy to add such if anyone can prove it is needed.

title: EventEmitter leak in 2.80
body: After upgrading to 2.80  I was getting this error in production:     MaxListenersExceededWarning: Possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 connect listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners   to increase limit     The node.js processes quickly grew to 1 2 GB of resident memory  normally 300 MB  and then CPU load started spiking.    Rolled back to 2.79 and the issue went away.

title: Allow to set main content type header with form/formData
body: When sending a form  you can control the boundary  similarly to the advanced use case of forms from the  README.md :       js  var r = request  uri:  http://service.com/upload   method:  post    function optionalCallback err  httpResponse  body   ...    var form = r.form  ;  form._boundary =  MY BOUNDARY ;  form.append  my_field    my_value  ;  ...         The content type header of the request will be set to   multipart/form data; boundary=MY BOUNDARY  .     However  I need to control the content type  e.g.   multipart/MY TYPE; boundary=MY BOUNDARY  .    This is not possible  although the  form data  package allows for this. Reason is that when the  getHeaders    method of the form object is invoked with an empty/undefined  userHeaders  argument.      form data/lib/form_data  ll. 281ff.       js  FormData.prototype.getHeaders = function userHeaders       var header;    var formHeaders =         content type :  multipart/form data; boundary=    this.getBoundary       ;      for  header in userHeaders         if  userHeaders.hasOwnProperty header            formHeaders[header.toLowerCase  ] = userHeaders[header];                  return formHeaders;   ;           request.js  ll. 571ff       js  if  self._form     self.hasHeader  content length         // Before ending the request  we had to compute the length of the whole form  asyncly    self.setHeader self._form.getHeaders    true     self._form.getLength function  err  length         if   err     isNaN length            self.setHeader  content length   length              end            else      end              A simple solution would be to pass  self.headers  as  usedMembers  argument. I will submit a pull request for this.

title: Allow to set main content type header with form/formData
body: Request headers are passed to the  form data   getHeaders    method  so it is possible to override the default header for  content type   generated by  form data .  For detailed description  see issue [Allow to set main content type header with form/formData] https://github.com/request/request/issues/2582

title: v2.80.0 is broken with browserify
body: It seems that the change introduced in  2480  upgrade  har validator@2  to  har validator@4   pulled in some unintended side effects.     har validator@4  depends on  ajv@4  which appears to internally use  regenerator  without listing it as a dependency. I haven t dug down far enough to figure out if/how/why this is so I don t know if it is a bug or by design.    I m still trying to come up with a reduced test case so that this can be added as a regression test.    In the meantime  pinning request to   2.79.0  seems to resolve the issue.

title: Any way to get server IP address from response?
body: Is there any practical way of getting the remote server IP address from the response object?    I m looking for something akin to curls PRIMARY_IP info field  which gives the actual IP address of the server that handled the request.    I ve been digging through the response object but I m unable to find any way to access anything other than the hostname from the URL object or headers.    Any help or suggestion on how to solve this would be much appreciated  as it is currently the only thing holding me back from replacing curl.

title: Inconsistency in  time  documentation
body: Running request v2.80.0 with  time: true   the timing members do not match those in the documentation.    According to the documentation  there should be a  timingPhases  object  this does not exist.    The  timings  object contains   socket  connect  response  end  dns  tcp  firstByte  download  total   which is a mixture of what the documentation details between the  timings  and  timingPhases  objects.    Why am I seeing this inconsistency between documented objects and actual returned objects in my project?

title: Update codecov to version 2.0.2
body:
Hello lovely humans [codecov] https://www.npmjs.com/package/codecov just published its new version 2.0.2.
State Update :rocket:
Dependency codecov
New version 2.0.2
Type devDependency
This version is not covered by your current version range . Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of codecov. Given that you have a decent test suite a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. Do you have any ideas how I could improve these pull requests? Did I report anything you think isn t right? Are you unsure about how things are supposed to work? title: Servers that respond with  Upgrade: h2c  makes  the world end   Node v4
body: Summary  This issue describes something that is not a problem in your lib  the cause is a bug in Node  but I thought you might like to know  more?  about this issue so that you can possibly decide to document it  maybe it will save a few other people from banging their heads again the wall          Simplest Example to Reproduce     js  var request       = require  request  ;    request .get  http://www.grozette.com/images/pdf/industrie/industriecopackingnew.jpg            .on   error   console.error           .on   response   function response                 console.log response.statusCode               console.log response.headers[ content type ]                            More Involved Example to Reproduce  using Promise.map      js  var bb            = require  bluebird  ; // assuming v3.5.0  var request       = require  request  ;    // promisified deps  var requestP      = bb.promisify request.defaults   jar : true       multiArgs : true   ;    var files = [          src:  https://www.google.nl/logos/doodles/2017/first day of spring 2017 northern hemisphere 5171021979058176.2 s.png     // 200          src:  file:///C:/some/path/to/a/file.png     // Error          src:  http://www.grozette.com/images/pdf/industrie/industriecopackingnew.jpg     // death by Upgrade header          src:  http://www.example.com/some/fake.jpg    // 404  ];    function download_image img          return requestP img.src    encoding : null   .spread function resp             console.log  req RESP   resp.statusCode  img.src ;            return bb.resolve true ;        .catch function e             console.log  req ERR   e  img.src ;            return bb.resolve true ;        .finally function               console.log  req FINALLY   img.src ;         ;         function download_images images          return bb.map images  download_image    concurrency : 1   ;       download_images files       .then    function      console.log  MAP DONE  ;             .catch   function e    console.log  MAP ERR   e ;           .finally function      console.log  MAP FINALLY  ;          ;             Expected Behavior  I expect to see a response or error output  and in the case of the promise based code I additionally expect to see the  FINALLY  output in all cases.        Current Behavior  I see nothing  in the case of the single request example  and do not see the  FINALLY   in the case of the promise based example          Possible Solution  The solution is upgrading to node v6   the problem stems from [this node bug] https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/4844   which is [fixed here] https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/4337          Context  this drove me mad  no errors  no output  promise chain broken  process just  ends   without so much as an error exit code  :          Your Environment      software           version                                  request            v2.81.0    node               v4.x    npm                v2.x    Operating System   MacOS / Ubuntu              thanks for reading   thanks for the lib

title: Failing to get the SSL details when sending multiple requests to same URL
body: Hi     I m trying to grab the SSL details of URLs and it works when requesting for multiple unique hosts.    Yet  when requesting for the same host  for some reason  only the certificate for the 1st request returns but not others.    It feels like there is a cache/session that keeps the SSL handshake and doesn t perform.    Here is a code to replicate it:         var request       = require  request      var r = request      url:  https://google.com/      method:  HEAD      gzip: true     followRedirect: false    followAllRedirects: false    ;    r.on  response   function res       certDetails =  res.req.connection.getPeerCertificate       console.log           1st Request            ;    console.log certDetails ;            setTimeout  function        var r = request        url:  https://google.com/        method:  HEAD        gzip: true       followRedirect: false      followAllRedirects: false      ;      r.on  response   function res         certDetails =  res.req.connection.getPeerCertificate    // works      console.log           2nd Request            ;      console.log certDetails ;           5000          The 2nd request is sent 5 seconds later to the same host and it fails to get the certificate details.    Yet  if we keep the 1st host as google.com and the 2nd one as yahoo.com  both are retrieved  as they are unique and possibly not cached .

title: Improvemts in digest auth implementation
body: PR Checklist:    [x ] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [ x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [x ] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: https://github.com/request/request/issues/2546         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  As described in issue 2546  this PR tries to address a couple of limitations of current implementation of digest authentication in request:    1.  There is no way to ensure that digest authentication is the only authentication mechanism that can be used. It is possible for an attacker to do a MitM and  downgrade  teh authentication to basic and thus capturing user credentials.  To address this problem I have added an additional  optional  field to the auth parametrer that can disable specifc authentication mechanisms when setting the immediate parameter to false. Thus  the client app can disable basic  and bearer  authentication. When the server responds with the authenticate header  if the authentication requested is disabled by the client  the request fails with an error.    2.  Reusing cnonces and handling nc  When issuing a request with digest auth  the previous cnonce was not used. The consequence is that every request with digest auth had to perform two http requests  one to get the cnonce  and another to send teh digest authentication data using the new cnonce .   I have improved this keeping the last cnonce and trying to reuse it when a request  to the same server  with immediate set to false is performed. This can reduce the number of http requests actually sent in teh case that several accesses to the same server are perfomed consecutively. This improvement also required ensuring that a different nc is sent with each request containg digest auth.

Promises will only get more and more popular as async/await gains support.    /cc @mikeal

title: Improvements in digest auth implementation
body: PR Checklist:    [ ] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [ ] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [ ] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A  or add link to issue here]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  <    Describe Your PR Here    >  As described in issue 2546  this PR tries to address a couple of limitations of current implementation of digest authentication in request:    1.  There is no way to ensure that digest authentication is the only authentication mechanism that can be used. It is possible for an attacker to do a MitM and  downgrade  teh authentication to basic and thus capturing user credentials.  To address this problem I have added an additional  optional  field to the auth parametrer that can disable specifc authentication mechanisms when setting the immediate parameter to false. Thus  the client app can disable basic  and bearer  authentication. When the server responds with the authenticate header  if the authentication requested is disabled by the client  the request fails with an error.    2.  Reusing cnonces and handling nc  When issuing a request with digest auth  the previous cnonce was not used. The consequence is that every request with digest auth had to perform two http requests  one to get the cnonce  and another to send teh digest authentication data using the new cnonce .  I have improved this keeping the last cnonce and trying to reuse it when a request  to the same server  with immediate set to false is performed. This can reduce the number of http requests actually sent in teh case that several accesses to the same server are perfomed consecutively. This improvement also required ensuring that a different nc is sent with each request containg digest auth.

title: Redirect with followOriginalHttpMethod:true does not mantain the original body
body: Summary  Hi there  I m currently working with  Cisco Meraki  web APIs and they return a redirect for each request. During my test I noticed that the request s body is not propagated in the redirected requests.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  I created a simple express server to test it easily  it s online so you can use it for testing      js  app.use bodyParser.json   ;    app.post  /    req  res  =>      res.writeHead 308          location :  https://body redirect.stamplayapp.com/api/codeblock/v1/run/redirect/show body       ;    res.end  ;    ;    app.post  /show body    req  res  =>      res.send 200  req.body ;    ;         and this is a simple request snippet to prove that behavior:     js  const request = require  request  ;    const settings =       method:  POST      followAllRedirects: true     followOriginalHttpMethod: true     url:  https://body redirect.stamplayapp.com/api/codeblock/v1/run/redirect      json: true     body:        test:  redirect             request settings   err  response  body  =>      console.log response.statusCode     console.log body  // this is empty instead of return the body that has been sent             This is the output running the snippet with request in debugging mode:       REQUEST   method:  POST      followAllRedirects: true     followOriginalHttpMethod: true     url:  https://body access control allow methods :  GET  PUT  POST  DELETE  PATCH  OPTIONS       access control allow headers :  Content Type  Authorization  stamplay app  x stamplay jwt  X Requested With       access control expose headers :  Content Type  Link  X total page  X total elements  x stamplay jwt     REQUEST reading response s body  REQUEST finish init function https://body redirect.stamplayapp.com/api/codeblock/v1/run/redirect/show body  REQUEST response end https://body redirect.stamplayapp.com/api/codeblock/v1/run/redirect/show body 200   server:  openresty      date:  Fri  24 Mar 2017 14:34:50 GMT       content type :  application/json; charset=utf 8       content length :  2      connection:  close       cache control :  no cache  no store  must revalidate      pragma:  no cache      expires:  0       x frame options :  DENY       x powered by :  Express      etag:  W/ 2 a3a6bf43        access control allow origin :  https://body redirect.stamplayapp.com https://body redirect.stamplayapp.com/api/codeblock/v1/run/redirect/show body               Expected Behavior  The expected behavior is that the original body is propagated about the redirects        Current Behavior  In the current behavior the redirected requests do not contain the original body        Possible Solution  Probably if the  followOriginalHttpMethod  is true and the method is title: Case sensitive header Strings
body: Hi     I have found an embedded web server in one of my  IoT  devices  which does not authenticate while using the  request  module inside iobroker.javascript.    The problem is  that request sends the Authorization header field in all lower case letters. I don t know  if it is defined in RFC if the header has to be case sensitive.    Is it possible to change the auth.js file  and maybe also others  to have the Header fields starting with uppercase letters and continuing with lowercase as    Authorization    for example. There are some other examples for this behaviour like the host header and so on.       software           version                                  request            2.79.0    node               4.5.0    npm                3.10.8    Operating System   Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS with kernel 3.16.0 44 generic  59 14.04.1 Ubuntu    Kind regards Uwe

title: OAuth 1.0 requests failing when using POST  form object and transport_method=body
body: Simplest Example to Reproduce  Look at tests/test oauth.json:506  test  body transport_method   form option   url params   The body of such request will be actually truncated to the length of the object supplied as  form  parameter.  To catch it you need to send it to the actual server or mock  which implements OAuth 1.0 and check the response.        Expected Behavior  Content length should be calculated properly        Current Behavior  Content length is truncated in one specific case        Possible Solution  PR: https://github.com/request/request/pull/2615        Context  This issue failed one of my own tests when I tried to start using this project

title: Fixed  2614. Content length of the body of the Post request is calcul
body: ated properly when using OAuth 1.0 and  form  object and transport_method=body       PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.       PR Description  Fixes https://github.com/request/request/issues/2614 and possibly https://github.com/request/request/issues/2599  <    Describe Your PR Here    >  Content length of the body is calculated after OAuth because OAuth can update body if transport_method=body.

title: Need to upload [post] gzipped file along json data
body: I need to send a POST request containing a gzipped file along with some json data. Here is what I tried and it didn t work. I get the following error: Uncaught Error: write after end           var inp2 = fs.createReadStream  ./myFile.tar  ;  var gzip = inp2.pipe zlib.createGzip   ;  gzip.pipe request.post   url:  http://localhost/saveData.php  form: srvAuth: slskjk  tables: tables     ;       I tried replacing  form  with  formData  but it didn t make a difference. If I remove the form data and make a simple post request with nothing but the url  the file gzipped file gets uploaded successfully. How can resolve the above issue? Is this a bug within  request  ?

title: Added promises library
body: PR Checklist:    Simple doc change       PR Description    Added a tiny promises library I made to follow the official  request  API  as per Node.js convention . Because passing  resolveWithFullResponse: true  to every single of the tests I had in my project didn t make sense  nor making a small library only for my project .    With my library you can do:       js  const request = require  request promises  ;    request ... .then res =>      // ...    ;         I made it to be able to natively retrieve the  response  as per the official  request  interface. Node.js unwritten?  I couldn t find a reference  convention is that the first parameter in callbacks is the error and will be  .catch     and the second parameter is the value and will be passed to  .then   . So passing the third parameter to  .then    IMHO doesn t follow what we are used to.    By using this library  the tests become much simpler:       js  const request = require  request promises  ;    it  works   async    =>      const res = await request  http://localhost:3000/  ;    expect res.statusCode .toBe 200 ;    expect res.body .toBe  Hello     ;    ;         And of course with ES7 you aren t really bothered if what you want is the body  just add a small destruct:       js  const request = require  request promises  ;    it  works   async    =>      const   body   = await request  http://localhost:3000/  ;    expect res.statusCode .toBe 200 ;    expect res.body .toBe  Hello     ;    ;

Ps: express req.body object is such objects.       js  const request = require  request  ;    const formData = Object.create null ;  formData.test =  test ;    request.post   url:  http://localhost:3000   formData: formData    function err  res  body       if  err         return console.error  upload failed:   err ;         console.log  Upload successful   Server responded with:   body ;    ;              sh    node app.js  /Users/cik/Desktop/bug/node_modules/request/request.js:330        if  formData.hasOwnProperty formKey                         ^    TypeError: formData.hasOwnProperty is not a function      at Request.init  /Users/cik/Desktop/bug/node_modules/request/request.js:330:20       at new Request  /Users/cik/Desktop/bug/node_modules/request/request.js:130:8       at request  /Users/cik/Desktop/bug/node_modules/request/index.js:54:10       at Function.post  /Users/cik/Desktop/bug/node_modules/request/index.js:62:12       at Object.<anonymous>  /Users/cik/Desktop/bug/app.js:6:9       at Module._compile  module.js:570:32       at Object.Module._extensions..js  module.js:579:10       at Module.load  module.js:487:32       at tryModuleLoad  module.js:446:12       at Function.Module._load  module.js:438:3

title: request module should follow SemVer   breaking change in 2.76
body: Summary  The release v2.75 declared that the  request  is gonna stop supporting node.js v0.10. This should have been released as v3 instead of v2.75. Why?  Because the next release v2.76 introduced [the breaking change] https://github.com/request/request/pull/2431/files diff ccc0734f65dd7a299409ff07d35be095R742  which breaks in node.js v0.10    Our applications  dependencies in package.json:        request :  ^2.58.0     Meaning  that npm will install any  request  module which starts with  2. .    Suddenly  servers started to fall over when a remote host becomes unavailable...        Simplest Example to Reproduce    node.js v0.10  UPD:   any   node.js version      npm i nock request      js  const assert = require  assert  ;  const request = require  request  ;  const nock = require  nock  ;    nock  http://localhost:8080  .get  /  .delayConnection 1000 .reply 200 ;  request  url:  http://localhost:8080/   timeout: 10   function  err         assert.ok err ;      assert.equal err.code   ETIMEDOUT  ;    ;             Expected Behavior  The code does not error. Exit code is 0.  This is confirmed on versions <=2.75        Current Behavior  Since v2.76 and forward the test fails.         AssertionError: null == true      at Request._callback  /Users/koresar/code/client/tmp.js:7:12       at Request.self.callback  /Users/koresar/code/client/node_modules/request/request.js:186:22       at Request.emit  events.js:98:17       at Request.<anonymous>  /Users/koresar/code/client/node_modules/request/request.js:1060:10       at Request.emit  events.js:95:17       at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  /Users/koresar/code/client/node_modules/request/request.js:980:12       at IncomingMessage.g  events.js:180:16       at IncomingMessage.emit  events.js:117:20       at _stream_readable.js:944:16      at process._tickCallback  node.js:458:13              Possible Solution  Re release as v3. Start strictly following SemVer.  Implement the  timeout  feature back  only for <=0.10 node.js environments .        Your Environment  OS X Sierra

title: HEAD with empty Buffer throws error  HTTP HEAD requests MUST NOT include a request body.
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js  request      method:  HEAD      url:  http://example.com   // a public URL that we can hit to reproduce  if possible    body: Buffer.alloc 0                  Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  The HEAD request is done  with an empty body        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  Throws error:  HTTP HEAD requests MUST NOT include a request body.         Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >   paramsHaveRequestBody  in helpers.js:11 should return  false  if  params.body  is set  but  params.body.length  is  0   empty buffer or string         Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >  This crashes npm proxy cache because it proxies all incoming requests with whatever it received in the body  no matter if the buffer is empty or the method is HEAD. https://github.com/runk/npm proxy cache/issues/50        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               7.7.0    npm                4.4.4    Operating System   macOS

title: OAuth 1.0 Support for HMAC SHA256
body: Summary  I would like to ass OAuth support for HMAC SHA256 added. Currently request only supports HMAC SHA1 and RSA SHA1.        Current Behavior  Currently using HMAC SHA256 causes the following exception to be thrown:  Signature method not supported: HMAC SHA256    This should be a supported workflow such that this additional signature method can be used without any errors following the existing process.        Context  I am trying to integrate with an OAuth 1.0a one leg provider who can optionally support HMAC SHA256. They recommend that any integrating partner move towards that since they intend to stop supporting HMAC SHA1 in the future.        References  There is an open issue in the oauth sign repo  [Issue 13] https://github.com/request/oauth sign/issues/13   that looks like it might solve this issue.

title: TypeError: The header content contains invalid characters
body: Summary  I recently added a method to the Object prototype and a day later spent a couple of hours fighting with uploads that mysteriously stopped working        Simplest Example to Reproduce  the following works fine:       js  const fs = require  fs  ;  const request = require  request  ;    var url =  http://localhost:8000/ ;  var formData =   script: fs.createReadStream  t.txt    ;  request.post  url  formData    err  resp  body  =>            console.log err     ok  ;    ;         however  this fails:       js  const fs = require  fs  ;  const request = require  request  ;    Object.prototype.XYZ = function          return 0;     var url =  http://localhost:8000/ ;  var formData =   script: fs.createReadStream  t.txt    ;  request.post  url  formData    err  resp  body  =>            console.log err     ok  ;    ;         interestingly  it seems to be the newlines in the body of the method that break the code i.e. defining the method this way does not express the problem:     Object.prototype.XYZ = function     return 0;           Expected Behavior  what I would expect happen is that any methods described in the prototype are not considered as headers        Current Behavior  the call fails with the following stack trace:       TypeError: The header content contains invalid characters      at ClientRequest.setHeader  _http_outgoing.js:374:11       at new ClientRequest  _http_client.js:131:14       at Object.request  http.js:26:10       at Request.start  /Users/ekkis/dev/node_modules/request/request.js:748:32       at Request.write  /Users/ekkis/dev/node_modules/request/request.js:1466:10       at FormData.ondata  internal/streams/legacy.js:16:26       at emitOne  events.js:96:13       at FormData.emit  events.js:191:7       at FormData.CombinedStream.write  /Users/ekkis/dev/node_modules/combined stream/lib/combined_stream.js:118:8       at FormData.CombinedStream._pipeNext  /Users/ekkis/dev/node_modules/combined stream/lib/combined_stream.js:106:8              Possible Solution  I m guessing somewhere the code is doing a  for  k in o   when it should be doing something like  Object.keys o .forEach function k       and that needs fixing        Context  I m unable to post a form to a listening server.  I believe it may be related to this issue https://github.com/request/request/issues/2367 but different in its genesis        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.27.0    node               7.7.2    npm                4.1.2    Operating System   OSX 10.11.6

title: fix logic

title: Error is thrown even when a handler/listener was set
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >  When making a request to a site with https through a proxy  under some circumstances an error is thrown even when an error handler was set        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js  var request = require  request  ;  var concurrency = 1;  var requestOptions =     uri:  https://google.com     proxy:      hostname:  138.68.129.67      port: 8118     protocol:  http:        ;    for var i=0; i<concurrency; i         request.get requestOptions  function error  response  body         if error  console.log error ;     if body  console.log body ;      ;          Definitely not the best way to reproduce it  I know. Will update when I get the time to write a failing proxy        Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  If an error occurs  it should be printed without crashing the app        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  The app crashes with the following error:         Error: tunneling socket could not be established  statusCode=503      at ClientRequest.onConnect  D: projects test node_modules request node_modules tunnel agent index.js:166:19       at Object.onceWrapper  events.js:293:19       at emitThree  events.js:116:13       at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:197:7       at Socket.socketOnData  _http_client.js:443:11       at emitOne  events.js:96:13       at Socket.emit  events.js:191:7       at readableAddChunk  _stream_readable.js:178:18       at Socket.Readable.push  _stream_readable.js:136:10       at TCP.onread  net.js:560:20  code:  ECONNRESET     events.js:163        throw er; // Unhandled  error  event        ^    Error: read ECONNRESET      at exports._errnoException  util.js:1050:11       at TCP.onread  net.js:581:26              Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >  If this is a bug  seems like its related to the proxy closing the connection when its overloaded. The particular proxy in the example above is overloaded most of the time  it does not produce the error when its not  thats why the  concurrency  var is there for heheh . If you can t reproduce the problem with 1 request  I ve been successfully reproducing it with 100        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               7.9.0    npm                4.2.0    Operating System   Windows 10 and Ubuntu 16.04

It was not made clear that  ca  can be an array  and that in fact this is necessary  AFAICT  when you want to accept a certificate that has been signed by multiple issuers  common in internal environments.

title: Support asynchronous followRedirect filter  callback or Promise
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.       PR Description    This can be needed for hostname to ip resolution  which can be used to disallow redirection to internal network addresses for protection against SSRF attacks. This PR also allows the  followRedirect  result to be a string  which overrides the redirect location. This can be used translate the target hostname to a ip  locking it .       js  // using a callback  followRedirect: function response  callback         callback null  result ;       // using a promise  followRedirect: function response         return new Promise ... ;            After writing this I ended up just using [ paranoid request ] https://github.com/uber common/paranoid request  for my use case   so take this PR with a grain of salt. That said  implementing this sort of behavior with normal  request  would be non trivial / not possible without this PR or something similar  unless I m missing something obvious .

title: A specific URL can not be requested/loaded  although it works on browsers
body: Summary  Hi      We have experienced a URL where we can not get a response via request  and Nodejs http .        Simplest Example to Reproduce     js  var request = require  request  ;  request  https://desktop.dev.qtc.com.au/    timeout: 20000   function  error  response  body       console.log  error:   error ;    console.log  statusCode:   response    response.statusCode ;     ;             Expected Behavior  I m normally expecting this request to return HTTP 200.         Current Behavior  It just timeouts.        Your Environment  Tested with:  request   2.81.1  latest  and 2.74.0  node   v4.4.2  Windows 10  x64     And  when tested with request debug  I can see that the request redirects successfully to https://desktop.dev.qtc.com.au/index.action but hangs there.    Any opinions are appreciated.

title: request returns corrupted data
body: request   url: url  headers:   Accept:   /         err  res  body  =>            // error here. body is bad        ;    I m sure it s very well known  but it was driving me nuts and I have no clue why request doesn t put that upfront to make it clear. I get content type application/zip and request  conveniently  decides that I may perhaps want body as a string. Strangely enough  it took quite a bit of googling to find that I need  encoding: null  to prevent request from doing that.    Your [first example] https://github.com/request/request  on your page should clearly state that the body will be converted to a string.

Le meilleur de la musique urban rap rnb reggae ragga         icy genre :  rap       icy name :  RadioGansta       icy pub :  1       icy url :  http://www.radiogansta.fr      server:  Icecast 2.3.3 kh8       cache control :  no cache  no store      pragma:  no cache       access control allow origin :          access control allow headers :  Origin  Accept  X Requested With  Content Type       access control allow methods :  GET  OPTIONS  HEAD      connection:  close      expires:  Mon  26 Jul 1997 05:00:00 GMT     REQUEST reading response s body  REQUEST finish init function http://streaming.radionomy.com/RadioGansta         It feels to me like a bug  as I would expect at least to get a call to my callback function and then handle the response or even to throw an exception. title: Extract OAuth Authorization header generation
body: This module does a very good job of generating the  Authorization  header for OAuth requests. However  it is coupled with the request handling.    I have written a small wrapper around the [ lib/oauth.js ] https://github.com/request/request/blob/e8fca511ba2800a809c7759a1c09ea33a440e4fb/lib/oauth.js  to expose this functionality: https://github.com/OliverJAsh/oauth authorization header    Would it be possible to extract  lib/oauth  so I can deprecate my wrapper module?

title: Lazy loading tough cookie
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.       PR Description  I m currently working on a device with low memory and while going through heapdumps  one of Request s deps  [tough cookie] https://www.npmjs.com/package/tough cookie   uses a lot of memory by [loading a large array] https://github.com/salesforce/tough cookie/blob/master/lib/pubsuffix.js  of domain name suffices when using  require . This PR lazy loads the  tough cookies  module and components for handling cookies. Now modules using Request that do not use cookies will not load  tough cookies  into memory.

title: Host header is not replaced if explicitly specified on 307 responses
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  If a  Host  header is provided to  request   and if the response is a 307 with a _different_ host  the old host is reused  which causes a maxRedirects error. The test case below reproduces the issue.  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js   use strict     var http = require  http    var request = require  ../index    var tape = require  tape      // test data  var redirecter =  test1.local.omg  // always resolves to 127.0.0.1  var responder =  test2.local.omg   // this too.    var server = http.createServer function  req  res       if  req.headers.host.indexOf redirecter  === 0         res.setHeader  location    http://  responder :  port /foo        res.statusCode = 307      return res.end  try again        else if  req.headers.host.indexOf responder  === 0         res.statusCode = 200      return res.end  ok             res.statusCode = 404    return res.end  not found          var port    tape  setup   function  t       server.listen 0  function           port = this.address  .port      t.end                tape  307 redirect should work when host is set explicitly  but changes on redirect   function  t       var redirects = 0      request        url:  http://  redirecter :  port /foo        headers:          Host: redirecter              followAllRedirects: true       followRedirect: true       encoding: null       lookup: function  hostname  options  callback           callback null   127.0.0.1   4   // All hosts will resolve to 127.0.0.1              function  err  res  body         t.equal err  null       t.equal body.toString     ok        t.equal redirects  1       t.end        .on  redirect   function           redirects                tape  cleanup   function  t       server.close function           t.end                         Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  The module should replace the host header with the new one.        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  We see an error   Exceeded maxRedirects. Probably stuck in a redirect loop .        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >  Add this code in redirect.js  right after computing  uriPrev  :         // remove the host header if the response is a 307   the host has changed.    //  the new host will be populated auto magically .    // For other types of redirects  it s removed automatically  see code below     if  response.statusCode === 307    request.headers    uriPrev.host  == request.uri.host         request.removeHeader  host                    Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request                 node                    npm                     Operating System

title: Add an option to keep querystring on redirection
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >  When following redirects  add an option to append to the redirected location the QueryString passed in options.             Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >    When requesting an URL with certain parameters and the webserver returns 301 to a new location  it happens that the webserver does not include the query string parameters from the original request.    With an option we could configure request to call the new location appending the original query string parameters.
