title: The  transfer closed with outstanding read data remaining  error is not thrown when abort stream connection
body: I try to handle HTTP stream errors.        Steps to Reproduce  When some error occurred I want to abort response stream using:     js  res.connection.destroy new Error  INVALID_END_OF_STREAM   ;         Below is a simple stream source example.     js  const express = require  express  ;   function           const app0 = express  ;        app0.get  /errdata    req  res  next  =>            let i = 0;          res.setHeader  Transfer Encoding    chunked  ;          res.setHeader  Content type    application/json; charset=utf 8  ;          res.write  [  ;          const descriptor = setInterval                  =>                    if    i > 3                         clearInterval descriptor ;                      console.log new Date     close connection  ;                      // when some error occurred I want to abort response stream                      res.connection.destroy new Error  INVALID_END_OF_STREAM   ;                      return;                                       res.write JSON.stringify  i: i  item: i   ;                  res.write     ;                              1000 ;        ;        app0.listen 1000     => console.log  app0:   1000  ;      ;         The stream consumer is another node process which uses the request library to handle the stream:     js  const xSrc = request  url:  http://localhost:1000/errdata   method:  GET   timeout: 10000  ;  xSrc.on  error    err  =>            console.log  ERROR:    err ;              .on  data    chunk  =>            console.log  CHUNK:    chunk.toString  .length ;              .on  end      =>            console.log  END  ;        ;             Expected Behavior  I expect to see something like below since response stream is not closed properly:       > CHUNK: xx  > ...  > CHUNK: xx  > ERROR: NET::ERR_INCOMPLETE_CHUNKED_ENCODING           Current Behavior  Currently I don t see any error. Request just ends without any marker of incomplete stream.       > CHUNK: xx  > ...  > END       While requesting URL from Chrome I ve got request status:        failed  NET::ERR_INCOMPLETE_CHUNKED_ENCODING       Request from CURL also gives an error:       >curl  i   raw http://localhost:1000/errdata  HTTP/1.1 200 OK  X Powered By: Express  Transfer Encoding: chunked  Date: Tue  30 May 2017 08:35:10 GMT  Connection: keep alive    1  [  10    i :1  item :1   1     10    i :2  item :2   1     10    i :3  item :3   1     curl:  18  transfer closed with outstanding read data remaining             Workaround  At the moment I found a workaround to raise an error on client side by violating HTTP chunked transfer encoding. It is handled properly but I dislike this approach as a dirty hack.       js  res.write  [  ;  res.write    i : 1   item : 1   ;  ...  // when error   violate chunked transfer by writing size less chunk directly to connection  res.connection.write  INVALID_END_OF_STREAM  ;  res.end  ;             Summary  Do you think it should be considered as a bug? Let me know if I missed something.  Thanks in advance.

title: request should provide a custom util.promisified   version
body: Code like       js  request  https://example.com    error  response  body  =>      ...    ;         can t be promisified through the usual [ util.promisify   ] https://nodejs.org/api/util.html util_util_promisify_original  function in Node 8.x because it goes beyond the standard   error  result  =>    callback pattern. It should be pretty easy to fix that by providing a [custom implementation] https://nodejs.org/api/util.html util_custom_promisified_functions  that gives e.g. a Promise for a   response  body   object.    I know there s  request promise   and I can t really tell how much of  request  this affects  but it would be awesome if a library that is this popular had even just very simple support for it.

title: Unix socket can t work with HTTPS
body: This code runs well:       js  let options =        key: fs.readFileSync  key.pem         cert: fs.readFileSync  cert.pem     ;    https.createServer options   req  res  =>        console.log  Request received  ;      res.writeHead 200 ;      res.end  hello world n  ;    .listen 50000   127.0.0.1  ;  console.log  HTTPS server started.  ;    setTimeout    =>        request            url:  https://127.0.0.1:50000/            strictSSL: false        ;     1000 ;         But if I use Unix socket  then it will fail  saying self signed cert error:       js  let options =        key: fs.readFileSync  key.pem         cert: fs.readFileSync  cert.pem     ;    https.createServer options   req  res  =>        console.log  Request received  ;      res.writeHead 200 ;      res.end  hello world n  ;    .listen  /Users/zzz/test unix socket/socket.sock  ;  console.log  HTTPS server started.  ;    setTimeout    =>        request            url:  https://unix:/Users/zzz/test unix socket/socket.sock:/            strictSSL: false        ;     1000 ;         Is this a bug  or am I missing something?

title: Set multipart/form data request encoding
body: Hello     Thank you all for the awesome lib.    Here s the problem: currently  any multipart/form data POST request will reset content type to:   multipart/form data; boundary=  THE BOUNDARY    and will use utf 8 as the form charset  without specifying the charset in the content type field .    So  2 questions here:  1  How can i manage to post my form  multipart/form data  with files  with a charset encoding that is NOT set to UTF 8 ?  I don t own/control the server .  2  Why not giving a  charset  options  that would encode all strings from the form to the specified charset  based on iconv lite or something   then do the POST request with the appropriate charset header ?

title: Failure to set proxy during redirects
body: Summary  I have a scenario where a request is being made to an internal company server  no proxy  which redirects to an external server  proxy needed . The consecutive request is also being done without a proxy.        Expected Behavior  The redirect request should validate if a proxy is needed  based on the url        Current Behavior  No additional proxy information is added to the request        Possible Solution  https://github.com/request/request/compare/master...atti187:master         Context  An example is how Microsoft TFS handles npm feeds  see https://www.visualstudio.com/en us/docs/package/npm/upstream sources caching  Internet requirements . Normally  TFS is installed on prem  no proxy needed  but will redirect to npmjs.org  proxy needed .        Your Environment    npm   4.6.1                                  request            2.81.1    node              v6.10.0    Windows   Windows 7 Enterprise

title: Can t do SSL verification through proxy
body: Summary  Once proxy is set up   request  is not passing through the HTTPS SSL details  such as certificates and settings  further        Simplest Example to Reproduce  Unfortunately  I could not find a free proxy and example HTTPS with certificate server to include in this demo code for reproduction. So the links are dummy     js  var options =        proxy:  http://myuser:mypass@my proxy server:9393      method:  POST      url:  https://mysecuresite.com      headers:   content type :  application/x www form urlencoded         ca: fs.readFileSync my_certificate_path   utf8       passphrase: my_passphrase     // secureProtocol:  TLSv1_method        form:       example:  for detail              request options  function  err  response  body             The issue is not with the certificates or the servers  as I do the same thing  SSL through proxy in Ruby code with HTTParty and it works.        Expected Behavior  The SSL request should be verified and successful.        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  The SSL fails with       Error: write EPROTO 139621169032064:error:14094410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:sslv3 alert handshake failure:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s3_pkt.c:1493:SSL alert number 40  139621169032064:error:1409E0E5:SSL routines:ssl3_write_bytes:ssl handshake failure:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s3_pkt.c:659:         And this error is consistent  regardless of trying other secure protocols with  secureProtocol  attribute. The handshake failure is always SSL v3  which made me speculate that through proxy it ignores the SSL settings for some reason        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.79.0    node               6.11.0    npm                4    Operating System   Ubuntu 17.04

title: digest auth broke by a 301 response
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >    when request a digest authed uri  auth succeed  by looking the debug log   but the response is 301  so request continue to fetch the redirected uri  but 401  and then 400. same call tested with chrome and curl found no problem.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >    a server configured with digest auth  and a handler response 301 to a specific uri redirecting to another uri which also use the same digest auth.    my case:     js  function validateSVNAccount repoURL  username  password       request.Request.debug = true    return new Promise  resolve  reject  =>        request.get repoURL            auth :             user : username            pass : password            sendImmediately : false                   error  response  body  =>          if  error             reject error                  if  response.statusCode  == 200             error = new Error JSON.stringify body            error.status = response.statusCode          reject error           else            resolve body                                        Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >    if the user/pass is correct should response 200.        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >    400 was responsed.        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >    it may caused by the server responding 301 without a  WWW Authenticate  header  so in  Auth.prototype.onResponse   didn t hit any case in switch. i think the auth header already generated could be stored somewhere.        Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request           2.81.0    node              7.2.1    npm               2.15.11    Operating System  windows 10 x64 pro           debug log:    REQUEST   auth:   user:  admin   pass:  Dream008   sendImmediately: false       uri:  https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala      callback: [Function]     method:  GET     REQUEST make request https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala  REQUEST onRequestResponse https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala 401   date:  Tue  13 Jun 2017 10:15:39 GMT      server:  Apache       www authenticate :  Digest realm= Subversion   nonce= J6ijt9RRBQA=72f784d7cb9e46b66843bd0f12a476c248632964   algorithm=MD5  qop= auth        content length :  381      connection:  close       content type :  text/html; charset=iso 8859 1     REQUEST reauth digest  REQUEST redirect to Url      protocol:  https:      slashes: true     auth: null     host:  192.168.0.3:10443      port:  10443      hostname:  192.168.0.3      hash: null     search: null     query: null     pathname:  /svn/lalala      path:  /svn/lalala      href:  https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala     REQUEST     REQUEST response end https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala 401   date:  Tue  13 Jun 2017 10:15:39 GMT      server:  Apache       www authenticate :  Digest realm= Subversion   nonce= J6ijt9RRBQA=72f784d7cb9e46b66843bd0f12a476c248632964   algorithm=MD5  qop= auth        content length :  381      connection:  close       content type :  text/html; charset=iso 8859 1     REQUEST make request https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala  REQUEST onRequestResponse https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala 301   date:  Tue  13 Jun 2017 10:15:39 GMT      server:  Apache      location:  https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala/       content length :  245      connection:  close       content type :  text/html; charset=iso 8859 1     REQUEST redirect https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala/  REQUEST redirect to https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala/  REQUEST     REQUEST response end https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala/ 301   date:  Tue  13 Jun 2017 10:15:39 GMT      server:  Apache      location:  https://192.168.0.3:10443/svn/lalala/       content length :  245      connection:  close       content type :  text/html; title: request timeout is ignored when try to get an unreach url through a proxy
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  request timeout is ignored when try to get an unreach url through a proxy.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  Use request to get any unreach url with a small timeout:     js  request       timeout: 100     url:  https://github.com      err  res  => console.log err  res             Set your proxy  github.com must be unreach through this proxy :       export HTTP_PROXY=<your proxy here>  export HTTPS_PROXY=<your proxy here>        Run the code. You will note that the console will responds only after SO timeout  around 120s           Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  The code should throws a timeout error after 100ms    <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >          Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  The code throws a timeout error after 120 seconds  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >        Context  <     How has this issue affected you? title: Feature Request: Enable JSON serialization in Request and JSON parsing in Response separately
body: Summary       Note: This is a Feature Request. I m willing to discuss the 2 solutions I suggest  and already implemented both of them with success; I will submit the PR as soon as discussion on this Feature Request is able to settle on one of the 2 solutions       I think that it would be useful to be able to enable separately the   JSON serialization of a Request s data    and the   JSON parsing of the Response s data  . Currently  both of this parts are handled by the same  json  param which makes it a pain for people who might want one and not the other.        Simplest Example to Reproduce    This example will be based on <https://hellojson.horgix.eu> is the most simple API of the world and will just answer this with  application/json  Content Type wether you GET or POST on  /  :               hello :  world             So  let s send a simple POST to it:       js    cat test.js  var request = require  request  ;  request                        method:  POST              url:  https://hellojson.horgix.eu              body:   feature request               json: true                      function err  httpResponse  body              console.log body             console.log  hello  in body                        and the result:           node test.js    hello:  world     true         This is fine. Now just switch the  json: true  to  json: false  in order to   not   encode the   request   body    feature request    in JSON  and we get this:       js    node test.js        hello :  world        ./test.js:12            console.log  hello  in body                                 ^    TypeError: Cannot use  in  operator to search for  hello  in       hello :  world            at Request._callback  ./test.js:12:31       at Request.self.callback  ./node_modules/request/request.js:188:22       at emitTwo  events.js:106:13       at Request.emit  events.js:194:7       at Request.<anonymous>  ./node_modules/request/request.js:1171:10       at emitOne  events.js:96:13       at Request.emit  events.js:191:7       at IncomingMessage.<anonymous>  ./node_modules/request/request.js:1091:12       at Object.onceWrapper  events.js:293:19       at emitNone  events.js:91:20          And this is what I want to talk about.        Current Behavior    This  request  lib exposes the  json  parameter for requests  allowing the user to enable a set of things:    From https://github.com/request/request requestoptions callback :  >  body    entity body for PATCH  POST and PUT requests. Must be a  Buffer    >  String  or  ReadStream . If  json  is  true   then  body  must be a  > JSON serializable object.  >   > [...]  >   >  json    sets  body  to JSON representation of value and adds  Content type:  > application/json  header. Additionally  parses the response body as JSON.    The usecase that I m concerned with is the case where we need to do a request that is   not   a JSON request  but where the expected response   is   a JSON response  so where we want to be able to use the   Additionally  parses the response body as JSON    part despite this  json  param being set to  false .    Actually  as told in the documentation quoted some lines ago  the JSON parsing of the response is only enabled if the request itself is declared as  json :    From https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L1152 :     javascript  if  self._json       try        response.body = JSON.parse response.body  self._jsonReviver              Expected Behavior    I m feeling like it would make sense to be able to   enable this response parsing without depending on the  json  parameter  ; this is actually a need that I find myself with  and which is described in details below.        Possible Solution    I see 2 possibles solutions:    1. Add a  json_response  parameter that enables response parsing even if  json  is set to  false         Advantages: quite simple  just implies adding a new parameter and documenting it        Disadvantages: it would have to be clear what the default behavior is in case it s not defined  2. Add something a bit smarter  which parses the JSON in the Response body if the Response comes with  application/json  as  Content Type   which would totally make sense        Advantages: cleaner  imho        Disadvantages: might be a breaking change for people who are relying on response not being parsed right now        Context    I m using chakram  [site] http://dareid.github.io/chakram/   [github] https://github.com/dareid/chakram/   to test a REST API. This is just an extension for chai  [site] http://chaijs.com/   [github] https://github.com/chaijs/chai   that uses  request  for requests  and which is run by mocha  [site] http://mochajs.org/   [github] https://github.com/mochajs/mocha  .    Among my tests  I would like to test the edge case where I POST an   invalid   JSON to the API on purpose  but with a  Content Type  set correctly to  application/json ; the goal being to ensure that my API correctly detects the invalid JSON data and handles it propertly by sending back an   HTTP 400  error.    Concretely  this result in the following test: <https://gist.github.com/Horgix/6a612f2a86c7507663012f530ed66c59 file test_invalid_json js>    The   json : false  is here to disable the JSON serialization of my data by request lib  it is automatically enabled by chakram   and the manual definition of the  Content Type  header is here due to the fact that this is usually done by the  json  param  which I just explicitely set to  false .    My API returns an error looking like this:       json  HTTP/1.0 400 BAD REQUEST  Content Type: application/json          error :  400 Bad Request: Failed to decode JSON object: Unterminated string starting at: line 1 column 9  char 8              Until this point  everything is fine.    Except that  as explained in the  Current Behavior  part  I m setting the  json  param to  false   since I explicitely want to   avoid   my request s body from being serialized into JSON   so I don t benefit from the   Additionally  parses the response body as JSON.   part  despite the fact that I really want to use it since I m going to verify this response against a JSON schema  see test linked above . This is actually on this part that my test fails  since   the response body is no longer parsed   and is only a plain string  which obviously doesn t match whatever JSON schema that expects a dict  which would be got from parsing the reponse body .    That s at this point that I took a look at how this  json  think is handled and that I felt the need of this Feature Request.  Of course I could parse the response afterward by myself in a single line  but this is something I would expect  request  being able to do.        Your Environment    Not really relevant. Anyway I m using nodejs  v7.10.0  with request v 2.81.0 .

title: Setting statusMessage in pipeDest
body: Summary  Hi     Is there a reason statusMessage can t also be set in the pipeDest function:  https://github.com/request/request/blob/e8fca511ba2800a809c7759a1c09ea33a440e4fb/request.js L1211     dest.statusMessage = response.statusMessage    I understand statusMessage can be retrieved as answered here : https://github.com/request/request/issues/2591    But  can it just be set along with statusCode? I m using a library that uses requestjs and am setting custom statusMessages that aren t passed along.     Thank you very much         Simplest Example to Reproduce  Use express request proxy and proxy to a server that returns a status message > 400 with a custom statusMessage.         Expected Behavior  Expect the statusCode and custom statusMessage to be returned.        Current Behavior  When running this  the statusCode will be returned  without the message.        Possible Solution     dest.statusMessage = response.statusMessage // Line 1212 request.js        Context  We are using express request proxy and response is setting a custom statusMessage  which is not being returned.

title: Callback never called when file stream fails in formData
body:
Summary When sending multipart data via formData if there is request stream that errors the request is never made and the callback is never executed. There is no indication of what happened Simplest Example to Reproduce js const fileStream = request.get http://doesnt.exist/file.test.png .once error err => console.error Attachment failed to download request method: POST uri: http://localhost:3000 json: true formData: from: test@test.com to: customername@test.com subject: test attachments html:

hello world

inline: [ value: fileStream options: filename: test.png contentType: image/png ] err res body => console.log never called if err return console.error err console.log res.statusCode body Expected Behavior The request should be made with out the failed attachments or the callback should executed with some indication of what happened. Current Behavior If the attachment stream encounters a net work error ECONNREFUSED the url doesn t exist . the request is never actually made and/or the callback is never executed indicating that there was a problem with the request. This works ok if the server returns an error code 500 . Context We are trying to send multi part email messages with attachment file. We are creating an array of request streams in the formData objects. We get the error events for the streams when they fail but the actual request callback is never called. More importantly the request is never actually made software version request 2.73.0 node 6.10.0 npm 3.10.3 Operating System Arch / Debian jessie

title: Violates streams flowing mode contract  losing  data  callbacks
body: Hi   This library is currently causing me some trouble due to an idiosyncrasy in streams handling. This is essentially the same as  2565 and  2567   the  response  stream begins in flowing mode  even though it is expected of Readable Streams in the Node.js world to start as  non flowing :  https://nodejs.org/api/stream.html stream_two_modes    I am passing the Response object to some other part of code via a Promise  and it effectively causes a part of the data to be lost  because  data  events are fired too soon  before the first listener is registered.    Additionally  since  response  emulates a ReadableStream  or so the README leads the user to believe   one would expect  response.pause    to stop the flow and mitigate the quirk. Alas  it does nothing   on the other hand  a  Request.prototype.pause  is implemented which does the same thing  but is outside the readable stream.    An effort should be taken to make the response object s stream API adhere to what the user normally expects of Readable Streams.    The root cause of this behaviour is probably this line: https://github.com/request/request/blob/b12a6245d9acdb1e13c6486d427801e123fdafae/request.js L1082    It looks like it proxies  data  events   only doing this immediately switches the underlying stream into flowing mode.    Another questionable operation in the code is https://github.com/request/request/blob/b12a6245d9acdb1e13c6486d427801e123fdafae/request.js L1114   even if we fix the flowing mode issue  it will be of no use if the response registers a  data  handler on itself. As an aside  registering event handlers on  this  is considered an anti pattern  and this is one case where it can be seen.

title: The secureProtocol requestOption is ignored: can not use TLSv1.2
body: I m on macOS trying to make a single rest call over https in an Electron app. Our servers currently accept TLSv1 requests  but soon will switch to TLSv1.2 exclusively. I m unable to set request options to make this happen. It always sends TLSv1. In fact I ve tried other options like SSL3  but it always sends TLSv1. It seems like the securityProtocol option is being ignored.    In order to see the request details  I m using Charles Proxy on macOS. This does not block TLSv1.2. The Electron web views make TLSv1.2 calls through the  proxy without any problem.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  Note: Some values are private for our usage and they are listed as private. The actual rest call requires an OAuth2 token which you can t get  so you can t try to reproduce the problem. But you can give me suggestions and I can try them     const requestOptions =      method:  GET      url:  https:// private host/path      headers:         Host :  private host         Connection :  keep alive         User Agent : theSession.getUserAgent          Upgrade Insecure Requests :  1         Authorization :  private OAuth token         Accept :  text/html application/xhtml xml application/xml;q=0.9 image/webp  / ;q=0.8         Accept Encoding :  gzip  deflate         Accept Language :  en US            proxy:  http://127.0.0.1:8888      secureProtocol:  TLSv1_2_method     tunnel: false     followRedirect: false   ;    request requestOptions   error  response  body  =>     < our code to handle the response >    ;        Expected Behavior  1. Charles proxy shows the request being sent using TLSv1.2.  2. The request is sent  and response received  without error and containing expected values.         Current Behavior  1. Charles proxy shows the request being sent using TLSv1 instead of TLSv1.2  2. The request/response works  because our servers still accept TLSv1 for now.         Your Environment      software           version                                  request              2.81.0    node                6.10.0    npm                 5.0.1    Operating System    macOS 10.11.6

Current Behavior  There is no such assertion. Meaning that if no data gets piped  the test passes. title: Crash after  Argument error  options.body
body: Summary  If incorrect body is given  object without the json flag   error is poorly handled  causing entire app to crash with  TypeError: First argument must be a string or Buffer  thrown from within node s http module.        Simplest Example to Reproduce     js  request.post  url:  http://example.com   body:       err  res  body  =>     console.log  Err will be printed  but then we will crash   err ;    ;             Expected Behavior  We get  Error: Argument error  options.body  in callback  and the app continues working.        Current Behavior  We get  Error: Argument error  options.body  in callback  but then node s http module emits an uncaught  TypeError: First argument must be a string or Buffer  error  causing the app to crash.        Possible Solution  After you emit the argument error  you need to stop executing the request.    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L434    You should probably add a  return  to that line.       javascript  return self.emit  error   new Error  Argument error  options.body.                Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               6.5.0    npm                3.10.8    Operating System   Linux  Debian Jessie

title: S3 signature version 4:  x amz content sha256  header missing
body: Summary  When using  sign_version : 4 when using S3  the following error is returned by AWS:  HTTP 400  Missing required header for this request: x amz content sha256 .        Simplest Example to Reproduce     js  request      url:  https://<bucketname>.s3.eu central 1.amazonaws.com      aws:        bucket:  bucketname        key:  s3 key        secret:  s3 secret        sign_version: 4          qs:        prefix:  filename          ;             Expected Behavior  HTTP 200 is returned  containing an XML response.        Current Behavior  HTTP 400 Bad Request containing the following error:   Missing required header for this request: x amz content sha256         Possible Solution  In request.js  > Request.prototype.aws method  add the following after line 1395:     js  self.setHeader  x amz content sha256   signRes.headers[ X Amz Content Sha256 ]        We would also need to update the  aws4  module to the latest version.  I ve tested with 1.6.0.    See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/bucket policy s3 sigv4 conditions.html and https://github.com/aws/aws sdk go/issues/743.        Context  Connect to S3 by using signature version 4.        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               6.9.1    Operating System   Windows

title: Unhandled  error  event due to DNS problem
body: We currently have a docker container on test environment running a nodeJS application using the request library  v. 2.81.0 . Some network problems leave the container unable to resolve a URL through DNS.    When we try to make a post request to the URL  then the application complains about an unhandled  error  event and crashes.    Here s the output of the application with request set on debug level:       bash  [18 07 2017 @ 16:01] [database] Connected to mongoDB  [18 07 2017 @ 16:01] [server] Started on port 3001  REQUEST   url:  xxx      timeout: 3000     headers:    content type :  application/json        json:        color:  red         message:  error message         notify: true        message_format:  text        method:  POST      callback: undefined    REQUEST make request xxx  REQUEST make request xxx  events.js:182        throw er; // Unhandled  error  event        ^  2017 07 18T16:02:00.844071639Z   Error: ETIMEDOUT      at Timeout._onTimeout  /srv/gii handler/node_modules/request/request.js:852:19       at ontimeout  timers.js:488:11       at tryOnTimeout  timers.js:323:5       at Timer.listOnTimeout  timers.js:283:5          I was able to reproduce the issue on my local machine creating the docker container with an invalid DNS server so the URL doesn t get resolved.    We ve tried setting the on  error   callback  and even a try catch before making the actual request but we get the same result.    We re using the latest version of node.    Any idea on how to avoid the application from crashing? Thanks

title: How to set up   get flag?

I also tried appending it to the end of the URL with  ?  as a separator and trying both POST and GET. Any idea?          G    get    When used  this option will make all data specified with  d    data    data binary or   data urlencode to be used in an HTTP GET request instead of the POST request that otherwise would be used. The data will be appended to the URL with a  ?  separator.

title: Disable URL encoding for request
Follow Meta Refresh redirects?

When requesting http://domain.com/url 1 which has a meta tag of  <meta http equiv= refresh  content= 0; url=http://domain.com/url 2 >  the ideal solution would be that request ends on /url 2 without having to capture the initial response  check the body for a Meta Refresh redirect and then firing off a second request for that Meta Refresh url. title: Do not delete  agent  without asking
body: When using an agent that is able to handle both HTTP and HTTPS  and  request  is configured for following HTTP redirects  the agent is deleted  and there is no control over it: [check here] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/redirect.js L110 L113 . A practical example happens when using  node socks proxy agent .    I can implement a fix for that by adding an additional flag; I just need the right name for it :

title: handling a bad statusCode in a stream causing Error: write after end
body: Couldn t find anything about bailing out of a response in the event of a bad  statusCode .    I have an express web server that s sits between an API server and the client  so I m piping responses from the API server  through the web server  and down to the client. I want to have  statusCode  error handling.  863 seems similar  but I don t have access to the  req0  object to call  end  on. Node seems to have this  end  [function as well] https://nodejs.org/api/http.html http_request_end_data_encoding_callback .       js  module.exports = function req  res       request.get options     .on  response   apiRes =>        if  apiRes.statusCode >= 400           console.error  API request failed with code     apiRes.statusCode ;        // this causes the Error: write after end        return res.status 500 .send  ;                 .on  error   err =>        console.error err ;      return res.status 500 .send  ;          .pipe res ;   ;         So  is there a recommended way of bailing out of a stream in the event of a bad status code?

title: Expose net.Socket.localPort and net.Socket.localAddress for debugging purpose when error occurred
body: For example  when we send a request and get a  ESOCKETTIMEDOUT   error  there is no extra information to help debugging:       js  request  http://xxxx.com   function  err  res  body        console.log err       // All information is an error name and an error message:     // Error: ESOCKETTIMEDOUT:     // <stack trace>     console.log res  body      // undefined  undefined             Or Is there already someway to get the  net.Socket.localPort  and  net.Socket.localAddress  under this situation?

title: OAuth signing with nested query strings
body: Summary  OAuth failure with  Invalid Signature  in the case of query strings with nested objects  using the default library  qs .        Simplest Example to Reproduce  Attempt to make an OAuth request with a query string containing nested objects.       js  request.get     url:  /orders     json: true    oauth:      consumer_key:        consumer_secret:        token:        token_secret:            qs:       searchCriteria :        filterGroups : [        filters : [         field :  key          value :  val        ]                                Expected Behavior  The query string passed on to sign is being stringified correctly but then is re parsed by the default qs library which turns it back in to a nested object before being parsed back on to the signing function.        Current Behavior  The signing function expects key/values and will treat it like so resulting in an invalid signature.        Possible Solution  When re parsing the query string simply use the default  querystring  module instead of qs which will keep the object keys nested  i.e. searchCriteria[filterGroups][0][filters][0][field][key]  and will produce a valid signature.

title: Multiple calls to  .defaults    does not merge with previous  .defaults    calls
body:
Summary < Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above > Simplest Example to Reproduce javascript let request = require request let req = request.defaults baseUrl: https://httpbin.org method: GET req.defaults method: POST json: true body: hello : world req uri: /post err resp body => console.log body Output is: < DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC //W3C//DTD HTML 3.2 Final//EN > 405 Method Not Allowed

Method Not Allowed

The method is not allowed for the requested URL.

Expected Behavior Multiple calls to .defaults should merge with options that was previously set with .defaults: Current Behavior Second and all future calls to .defaults does not merge with options that was passed first Context Trying to write a class that will be a builder for my requests: typescript import request = require request import requestPromise = require request promise import URL from url class WebApiRequest private client = requestPromise constructor private completeRelativeUri: string this.client = requestPromise.defaults baseUrl: https://httpbin.org json: true headers: Content Type : application/json; charset=utf 8 Accept : application/json text/plain / x site id : uk x site language : en resolveWithFullResponse: true //TODO: Add types validation for method string public method method: string : WebApiRequest this.client.defaults method return this public headers headers: request.Headers : WebApiRequest this.client.defaults headers return this public cookies jar: request.CookieJar : WebApiRequest this.client.defaults jar return this public body body: string Object : WebApiRequest this.client.defaults body return this public send return this.client uri: this.completeRelativeUri Your Environment software version request request : ^2.78.0 node 7.8 npm 4.x Operating System OSX

title: Wrong encoding on POST with options
body: Summary  When trying to send a POST request with an accented character in the URL it gets reencoded  but only when there is a non empty  options  object. In the example  I m trying to send a POST request to  http://localhost:3000/    where     gets converted to     .        Simplest Example to Reproduce  The backend server:     js  let express = require  express  ;  let app = express  ;  app.post  /:id   function req  res        let id = req.params.id;      console.log id ;      res.send id ;    ;  app.listen 3000 ;       The request:     js  let request = require  request  ;  require  request debug   request ;  let url= http://localhost:3000/  ;  let options1 =        body:   test: 0         json: true   ;  let options2 =        body: JSON.stringify   test: 0      ;  let options3 =        body: JSON.stringify   test: 0          json: false   ;  let options4 =   ;  request.post url  options1  function error  response         console.log response.body ;    ;             Expected Behavior  All requests should be logged and returned as     by the server.        Current Behavior  Only  options4  and not using  options  at all returns      where  options1    options2  and  options3  return     .        Possible Solution  It seems that when the options are being handled the URL gets reencoded. For this specific transformation to happen  the URL seems to be recognized as  latin 1  before.        Context  I m using it to test all the routes in the backend of an app and accented characters can be used in user s ids  resulting in routes like  /user/m rio/phone . The app itself sends the request correctly  this problem only happens when using this request library.        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               7.10.0    npm                4.2.0    Operating System   Linux Mint 18.1

title: Post with empty array in form removes the property

This is bad for me  it removes properties from the form.  I m trying to send an object with a property holding an array which could be empty.   Every time the array is empty an MissingPropertyError is being returned which is incorrect as the empty array actually holds value over not having the property at all.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >     js  const request = require   request     const bodyParser = require  body parser    const app = require  express        app.use  bodyParser.json      app.use  bodyParser.urlencoded    extended: true          app.post  /   function  req  res      console.log urlencoded         form:      emptyArray: []     filledArray: [ something:[] ]         console.log   sending:   req    request  req   function  err  httpResponse  body      process.exit 0 requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  I expected the send object to be received  as it is valid json      shell    node index.js  sending:   url:  http://localhost:53153      method:  POST      headers:    Content Type :  application/x www form urlencoded        form:   emptyArray: [] title: Should not set content length header if the request doesn t contain a body
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >  According to [rfc7230] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230 section 3.3.2 :   > A user agent SHOULD NOT send a     Content Length header field when the request message does not contain     a payload body and the method semantics do not anticipate such a     body.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js  request      method:  OPTIONS    // any method other than GET    url:  http://example.com                  Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  http headers:       OPTIONS /v2/flush HTTP/1.1 r n  // other headers... except content length           Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  http headers:       OPTIONS /v2/flush HTTP/1.1 r n  content length: 0  // other headers...              Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >  check body before set content length header  other than only check the method  https://github.com/request/request/blob/643c43ab7be269a1efaa080ff05a18fff3f64cd7/request.js L558 L560

title: Cannot find module aws sign2

title: Paraquire
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >  The new behavior does not contain API changes or improvements  it is only about security  so   no new tests needed      [x] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  <    Describe Your PR Here    >  NPM ecosystem is [quite unresistant] https://github.com/ChALkeR/notes/blob/master/Gathering weak npm credentials.md  against dependency attacks. It means that if a hacker gets control over one small abandoned package  the hacker gets control over all it s dependents  dependents of dependents  etc.   request  is a very popular dependency and  on the other side  has some dependencies. So  hijacking only one of  request  s dependencies will be very crucial for whole NPM ecosystem. This PR improves  request  security by jailing most dependencies into  paraquire    secure [alternative] https://github.com/nickkolok/paraquire  for standard  require . I did my best  however  I couldn t manage to define the rights needed by some libraries  so that sides remain unprotected.    I realise that this PR probably will not be merged  but I hope for having a productive discussion. I could not open an issue first  because only PR can show my suggestion clearly enough.

title: ugghhh bug   validation needed for options object properties
body: I have been using this package to much delight for several years. I have the following promise wrapping code. The fact that it s a wrapper isn t important. Do you see what might be wrong with the code below?       js   let requestp = function  method  url  headers =     query =     body =            return new Promise function  resolve  reject           request  method  url  headers  query  json: true  body   function  err  response  body             err ? reject err  : resolve  response  body  ;          ;        ;     ;         If you thought query should be  qs   then you d be right.    This is correct:       js   let requestp = function  method  url  headers =     query =     body =            return new Promise function  resolve  reject           request  method  url  headers  qs: query   json: true  body   function  err  response  body             err ? reject err  : resolve  response  body  ;          ;        ;     ;         how hard would it be to include validation in the request library  so that an error is thrown  or at least a warning logged  when a property is passed to the request options object that does not belong?     for example  if I pass foo to request  I d hope to get a warning:      request  method  url  headers  foo: query   json: true  body   fn ;

title: Cannot upload multiple files without  []
body: Summary  I tried to upload multiple files using requestjs but only the last file in the array was uploaded unless I added  []  after the key.        Simplest Example to Reproduce       js  var formData =      attachments: [      fs.createReadStream __dirname    /attachment1.jpg         fs.createReadStream __dirname    /attachment2.jpg      ]   ;  request.post  url: http://service.com/upload   formData: formData   function optionalCallback err  httpResponse  body       if  err         return console.error  upload failed:   err ;         console.log  Upload successful   Server responded with:   body ;    ;             Expected Behavior  Server should receive two files.        Current Behavior  Only the last file in the array was uploaded.        Possible Solution  Now I could only change the key from  attachments  to  attachments[]  to avoid this problem. But I think this is a bug because the doc says it is ok to use  attachment  as the key to upload multiple files.        software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               6.11.2    npm                3.10.10    Operating System   macOS

title: agent: false without pool: false uses globalAgent?
body: Summary    It looks common to get the  ESOCKETTIMEDOUT  error and some solutions say to use  agent: false .  This might lead one to believe that a new agent is being created  per request  as noted in the Node.js docs: https://nodejs.org/dist/latest v6.x/docs/api/http.html http_class_http_agent        Expected Behavior     agent: false  should create a new agent instance for each request?        Current Behavior    1. If the  pool  option is unset then the  globalPool  is used: https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L172  2. This means the  agent  is set to the return value of  self.getNewAgent   : https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L487  3. Which is the  globalAgent : https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L687        Possible Solution    Not saying this is a bug  but perhaps I didn t understand the options.  The docs say:    > pool   an object describing which agents to use for the request. If this option is omitted the request will use the global agent  as long as your options allow for it . Otherwise  request will search the pool for your custom agent. If no custom agent is found  a new agent will be created and added to the pool. Note: pool is used only when the agent option is not specified.    In this case  agent  is specified but I am not sure what  as long as your options allow for it  means.  Assuming the issue brought up here is accurate  solutions could be:    1. Be explicit in the documentation that  agent: false  does not mean  pool: false   2. If  agent: false  and  pool  is unset  then default  pool  to  false  and document it.        Context    Possibly related to  ESOCKETTIMEDOUT  errors.           If the above looks accurate and a PR is desired  please let me know and I can certainly create one.

title: Proxy with self signed cert not accepted  rejectUnauthorized=false not being passed to tunnel agent
body: Summary  When using request to CONNECT to an explicit proxy that had a self signed cert  the request produced this error:         Error: tunneling socket could not be established  cause=self signed certificate      at ClientRequest.onError  /nodeApp/node_modules/tunnel agent/index.js:178:17       at ClientRequest.g  events.js:292:16       at emitOne  events.js:96:13       at ClientRequest.emit  events.js:188:7       at TLSSocket.socketErrorListener  _http_client.js:310:9       at emitOne  events.js:96:13       at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:188:7       at emitErrorNT  net.js:1277:8       at _combinedTickCallback  internal/process/next_tick.js:80:11       at process._tickCallback  internal/process/next_tick.js:104:9  code:  ECONNRESET            I traced the problem to the code below at line 134 in tunnel agent/index.js       debug  making CONNECT request      var connectReq = self.request connectOptions     connectReq.useChunkedEncodingByDefault = false // for v0.6    connectReq.once  response   onResponse  // for v0.6    connectReq.once  upgrade   onUpgrade    // for v0.6    connectReq.once  connect   onConnect    // for v0.7 or later    connectReq.once  error   onError     connectReq.end         The connectOptions at that point in the code did not contain the properties rejectUnauthorized or requestCert which were set to false in the request options object  even though headers set at the request object like Proxy Authorization were passed all the way through ;    Modifying the tunnel agent module to hardcode the rejectUnauthorized and requestCert properties at this point in the code resolved the error.     version of request used was latest  2.81.1      So  it appears that somewhere the rejectUnauthorized and requestCert properties are being removed  or not copied over  such that they do not make there way down to the tunnel agent module

title: Sending  Connection: Close  header when using https proxy with NTLM auth
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >  My Company is using Squid as an https proxy together with a NTLMv2 authentication. I use px  https://github.com/genotrance/px  to handle the NTLM part. Basicaly  px creates a local proxy responsible for NTLM authentication.  But when I use Bower or Npm which use this  request  module  the connection is closed by the proxy  whereas the same GET request works fine with Firefox  using px as proxy too .        Simplest Example to Reproduce    Use a Squid proxy with NTLM authentication    Install px and set the proxy host in the ini file    launch  px   debug     try to install something with bower :  bower install jquery         Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  Bower  which uses this request module  should download any package flawlessly        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  Bower fail to download packages. Example with jquery :    bower not cached    https://github.com/jquery/jquery dist.git    bower resolve       https://github.com/jquery/jquery dist.git    bower download      https://github.com/jquery/jquery dist/archive/3.2.1.tar.gz  bower retry         Download of https://github.com/jquery/jquery dist/archive/3.2.1.tar.gz failed with   ECONNRESET    retrying in 1.5s        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >  With some analysis of px logs  it seems that the request module send the http header  Connection: Close  while asking the proxy to connect to the target url. So with such a header in the request  the squid proxy simply close the connection as asked.    By forcing the Connection header to  Keep Alive   the problem disapear.  For example  I added the line  self.headers[ Connection ] =  Keep Alive   right after  self.headers = self.headers ? copy self.headers  :     in request.js  Request.prototype.init    But this is quite an ugly fix  and it would be interesting to find out why a connection close is issued.        Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >  My company  pretty big  use a proxy with authentication for all HTTP and HTTPS queries. We use Npm and Bower in automated build as well as on our developpement machines.  For now  we did the above modification.        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.67.0    node               6.11.3    npm                3.10.10    Operating System   Windows 8.1 Version 6.3  Build 9600     px                   0.2.1

title: Error object contains certificate in text
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js  const auth =        cert :  THESE ARE THE CONTENTS OF THE CERT        key :  THESE ARE THE CONTENTS OF THE KEY        ca :  THESE ARE THE CONTENTS OF THE CA     ;    const options =      url:  https://www.aurl.that/doesntexist/really      cert: auth.cert     key: auth.key    ;    request options   .catch  err  =>      console.log err ;    ;             Expected Behavior  The error object should not include the cert  key or ca information  unless there is a very good reason why these should be part of the error  and I can t thing of one  they should be silenced  as error objects generally are supposed to be caught and thrown in different layers. Error objects are also supposed to be logged. I understand that a solution is to only take the secure info from the error object and log these  leaving the insecure. But I still don t understand why the error object needs to contain the whole cert/ket/ca.         Current Behavior  When making an SSL request  with a cert/ca/key  any error object returned contains the cert/ca/key information.        Possible Solution  Take out any sensitive information from the options object of the error object          Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.81.0    node               v6.11.3    npm                5.4.2    Operating System   Centos7

title: Release @2.82.0 broke semver minor version
body: Hi sorry to be a pain  but upgrading the Hawk dep broke the semver minor version. This is a breaking change as the new hoek uses const instead of var. Hawk uses Hoek  which uses  const . This release should be major version @3.         const Hoek = require  hoek  ;  ^^^^^  SyntaxError: Use of const in strict mode.

title: Timeout even before the HTTP request is triggered when timeout set
body: Because of single threaded nature of NodeJS event loop  even before the HTTP request is triggered to downstream application  NodeJS is self timing out resulting in HTTP request not reaching to downstream application at all. i.e by the time main thread is picking up this task the timeout has already occurred  30ms have already elapsed    the request to downstream application never got triggered.    Ideally the timer should have started after the request is triggered but in this case it seems like the timer starts immediately which is causing this issue.    Meanwhile  I increased the timeout to 120ms from 30ms  the self timeouts have reduced from  2.5K per hour to 2 8 per hour.        js  let options =                url: Url  //URL to hit              qs: params  //Query string data              method:  GET   //Specify the method              timeout: 30           ;          request options   error  response  body  =>                if  error                     return callback new ErrorResponse 500   error: error   ;                else                    return callback null  response  body ;                           ;           Environment details  node 5.9.1  npm 3.7.x  request  2.67.0  OS details below  Distributor ID: Ubuntu  Description: Ubuntu 14.04.4 LTS  Release: 14.04  Codename: trusty    Can someone from the authors/contributors look into this ASAP   help me figure out what is the exact issue here.

title: last release should be major version   breaks compatibility with pre ECMAScript 2015
body: Summary  https://github.com/request/request/pull/2751 breaks compatibility  the resulting hawk version should have incremented the major version number  not the patch number  2.82.0 to 2.82.1  in https://github.com/request/request/commit/6f1b51ed43309128487739f20f9df0699a043124    > I updated hawk from 3.1.3 to 6.0.2  still a   for version managing     This jump in versions changed the which version s  of NodeJS it is compatible with and should have resulted in a major version change. Only the patch version was updated  not even the minor version    consequently libraries which depend on version 2.x of request automatically pick up a breaking change.         Simplest Example to Reproduce  run/compile in code that requires/uses pre  ECMAScript 2015         Expected Behavior  compiling an application that has transitive dependencies on request 5 days ago and today should continue to work  especially when the transitive dependency specifies a locked major version.        Current Behavior  building a project fails due to the new patch version.       .  /node_modules/grunt juice email/node_modules/juice/node_modules/jsdom/node_modules/request/node_modules/hawk/node_modules/boom/lib/index.js:5  const Hoek = require  hoek  ;  ^^^^^    Loading  juice.js  tasks...ERROR  >> SyntaxError: Use of const in strict mode.             Possible Solution  remove version 2.82.1  update to 3.0.0 to account for the breaking change        Context  Builds that worked on the 15th no longer work  code work  deploys that are in progress are halted. We re looking at having to create a snowflake fork of this library just to keep our application working  since upgrading our NodeJS across the board is not a short term option.        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.x  via jsdom      node               0.10.26    npm                   Operating System   Debian 7.11

title: Updating tough cookie due to security fix.
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [x] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A  or add link to issue here]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  This addresses:       The tough cookie module is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service. Input of around 50k characters is required for a slow down of around 2 seconds.    Unless node was compiled using the  DHTTPMAXHEADER_SIZE= option the default header max length is 80kb so the impact of the ReDoS is limited to around 7.3 seconds of blocking.    At the time of writing all version <=2.3.2 are vulnerable           See: https://www.versioneye.com/Node.JS/tough cookie/2.3.2      Also tough cookie:        https://github.com/salesforce/tough cookie/pull/97        https://github.com/salesforce/tough cookie/pull/92

title: HTTP Digest Authentication over POST
body: Summary  I am   unable to use Digest Authentication over a simple POST request        Simplest Example to Reproduce     javascript  request.post            url:  URL to digest server            auth:              user:  username              pass:  password              sendImmediately: false                      form:   lvalue: value               oError   oResponse   sBody  =>    ... whatever you neeed ....          ;           Expected Behavior  I expect to see two requests: the first should fail with error 401 and the second should be able to handle the original request        Current Behavior  For some reasons I haven t understood the  sendImmediately  set to false is ignored.    When the request is launched  the method  basic  of  auth.js  is called twice; the first is using the  sendImmediately  option to  false ; the second one is set to  true .  The second internal call to the method seems to be the problem; it seems it doesn t receive the arguments set by the user.        Possible Solution  I had to force  sendImmediately  to  false  before the following line: https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/lib/auth.js L29 to see the library work correctly with HTTP Digetst        Your Environment    software           version                                  request            ^2.81.0    node               6.10.0    npm                3.10.10    Operating System   Windows 10

title: Using Request to Automate Filling Forms
body: At the moment I have used Selenium to automate the completion of a form   however I have come to realise that the npm package request can do the same   as well as submit the request with a proxy which is what I need.    However I have a few questions/need help with:    So at basic I see I can use some code like this:         var request = require  request  ;    let options =              url:  https://theURLToForm            form:                email:  me@example.com                email2:  me@example.com                fname:  firstname                lname:  surname               ;    request.post options  function err httpResponse body             console.log body     ;         My questions:    1   The URL to the form   the page itself contains 3 forms   the one I want to use has the attribute name=Regi1Form   so do I need to specify that in my options  if so how?    2   The fields I want to enter text into  in the options block above I m using keys like email and email2 because in the code the input has a name attribute with that value. Is the correct way to enter into the field?    3   The first page of the form contains the input fields themselves. However once I feel in the fields and click Submit   it goes to a second page where I have to click I Agree   then finally a 3rd page with a submit field. Can this be handled with request?    4   With Selenium I can actually see what it is doing   however with request how do i actually verify that its completing the form?    Thanks.

When using request debug:       REQUEST make request http://ltiapps.net/test/tc outcomes.php    request:        ...        headers:           ...            content length : 12           Authorization:  OAuth oauth_body_hash= MmVmN2JkZTYwOGNlNTQwNGU5N2Q1ZjA0MmY5NWY4OWYxYzIzMjg3MQ 3D 3D  oauth_signature_method= HMAC SHA1  ...            body:  Hello World                   Possible Solution  PR is linked        Context  This issue fails my requests to IMS LTI Outcome service which requires POST requests and body hashes.    @simov FYI

title: Form data throws  ReferenceError: window is not defined  in Webpack bundle
body: Summary      UPDATE: The problem is caused by [this form data issue/commit] https://github.com/form data/form data/issues/252 issuecomment 249051882 .       The form data entry point is throwing this exception.      ORIGINAL:      Request 2.83.0 is not compatible with Webpack 3.7.1 due to an issue with the form data dependency. I am able to bundle everything using Webpack  but upon running my bundle I encounter a  ReferenceError: window is not defined  exception.     It appears to be caused by importing this function:         /  459  /  /   /  function module  exports       /  eslint env browser  /  module.exports = typeof self ==  object  ? self.FormData : window.FormData;         I tracked this function to form data:         var FormData = __webpack_require__ 459          And then I tracked form data to request. Commenting out the  module.exports  line above causes the exception to no longer occur.        Expected Behavior    My Webpack bundle should run without any exceptions caused by modules.        Current Behavior    Form data throws an exception  breaking my Webpack bundle.        Possible Solution    [Require form data on demand  so it doesn t throw an exception when it is not in use.] https://github.com/visionmedia/superagent/commit/f80e1473cb0e1c1ce5d24919c4b5abc469e4fb06         Context    Webpack is obviously one of the most popular build tools out there  and request/request promise should be compatible.     Here is the full stacktrace:                  The  request  library is not installed automatically anymore.      But required by  request promise .           npm install request   save         /my project/build/main.bundle.js:41913      throw err;      ^    ReferenceError: window is not defined      at Object.module.exports  /my project/build/main.bundle.js:72538:60   ...         Here is my Webpack configuration:         const path = require  path  ;  const webpack = require  webpack  ;    module.exports =      entry:  ./main.js      output:        path: path.resolve __dirname   build         filename:  main.bundle.js           module:        rules: [                   test: / .js /           exclude: path.resolve __dirname   node_modules             use:               loader:  babel loader              options:                presets: [  env  ]               plugins: [  transform runtime  ]                                       ]          stats:        colors: true          devtool:  source map      // https://github.com/webpack contrib/css loader/issues/447    node:        fs:  empty        tls:  empty        net:  empty         ;             Your Environment      software           version                                  request             2.83.0    node               v6.10.2    webpack        3.7.1    npm                3.10.10    Operating System   OSX Yosemite

title: request.defaults and event handlers
body: Is there anyway to add generic event handlers to a request instance?    My use case is that I have a requirement to log a few events on downstream requests  namely:    request start    request end    request error    request response with status >= 400    we re already using request.defaults so this seems like a natural place to do it.    I have a temporary solution  but this involves some  nasty wrapping of request methods  and I m keen to just expose a request instance.

title: Query string encoded incorrectly

I was testing these 2 urls:       http://localhost:9002/unicodeq/?q= o  test  http://localhost:9002/unicodeq/?q=              test         But on the server they are received as       q: 1o1 test  converted from latin letters to ascii   q: @CAA:89 B5:AB test         The request code is rather basic:     js    request.get       url: uri      maxRedirects: 5      timeout: 5000      headers:         User Agent :  Mozilla/5.0             ;         How would I fix this issue so that the URL is requested correctly?

title: Cannot pipe s3 object readstream to PUT request
body: [StackOverflow Link] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42877791/cannot pipe s3 object readstream to put request .  Reason for asking it here is because I suspect there might be a bug while piping an external read stream to  put/post  methods. The boundary of multipart data may not be set properly.    I have a simple scenario. I need to read an object from S3 and pipe its output to  PUT  request. Here is my  client.js  code using request module.     javascript  // client.js  let AWS = require  aws sdk    let request = require  request      let bucket =  my_bucket   let filename =  path/to/file.zip     let host =  localhost   let port = 8080    let s3 = new AWS.S3      . . .        let readStream = s3.getObject      Bucket: bucket     Key: filename    .createReadStream      let formData =      applicationType:  my_app_type      applicationName:  my_app_name      upload:        value: readStream       options:          filename:  my_file_name.zip          contentType:  application/zip                    request.put      url:  http://    host    :    port    /bootstrap      formData: formData     function  error  response  body       if  error  throw error    console.log body              And  here is my  server.js  code.     javascript  // server.js  let http = require  http    let Busboy = require  busboy    let events = require  events    let fs = require  fs      let host =  localhost   let port = 8080    let compressedCodeLocation =  ./code.zip     let handleRequest = function  request  response       let eventEmitter = new events.EventEmitter      let inputStreamWriter = fs.createWriteStream compressedCodeLocation     inputStreamWriter.on  finish   function           eventEmitter.emit  input.stream.saved            let busboy = new Busboy        headers: request.headers            busboy.on  file   function  field  file         file.pipe inputStreamWriter           busboy.on  field   function  field  val         console.log field    :     val           eventEmitter.on  input.stream.saved   function           let stats = fs.statSync compressedCodeLocation       response.statusCode = 200      response.end JSON.stringify stats              request.pipe busboy        let server = http.createServer handleRequest   server.listen port  host  function         console.log  Server started on     host    :    port         let handleShutdown = function         server.close function           console.log  Server stopped on     host    :    port            process.on  SIGTERM   handleShutdown   process.on  SIGINT   handleShutdown          I am getting this error:        File [upload] got 58 bytes      events.js:160            throw er; // Unhandled  error  event            ^            Error: Unexpected end of multipart data          at /pots/cnc/node_modules/dicer/lib/Dicer.js:62:28          at _combinedTickCallback  internal/process/next_tick.js:67:7           at process._tickCallback  internal/process/next_tick.js:98:9     The funny thing is  if I save the file locally first and then  createReadStream  for that local file  it works:        let formData =          ...        upload:            value: fs.createReadStream localPath    /    filename            options:              ...                           ;

title: How to serialize and deserialize a cookieJar ?
body: I check the code about cookie of request           use strict   var tough = require  tough cookie      var Cookie = tough.Cookie  var CookieJar = tough.CookieJar    exports.parse = function  str       if  str    str.uri         str = str.uri         if  typeof str  ==  string          throw new Error  The cookie function only accepts STRING as param           return Cookie.parse str   loose: true         // Adapt the sometimes Async api of tough.CookieJar to our requirements  function RequestJar  store       var self = this    self._jar = new CookieJar store   looseMode: true       RequestJar.prototype.setCookie = function  cookieOrStr  uri  options       var self = this    return self._jar.setCookieSync cookieOrStr  uri  options            RequestJar.prototype.getCookieString = function  uri       var self = this    return self._jar.getCookieStringSync uri      RequestJar.prototype.getCookies = function  uri       var self = this    return self._jar.getCookiesSync uri        exports.jar = function  store       return new RequestJar store               It don t have serialize and deserialize method   I need a way to send the cookieJar to another progress  so I need serialize and deserialize the cookieJar.    I know that the cookie of request is another project https://github.com/salesforce/tough cookie.  but I can t use those API because the cookieJar of request has been encapsulated as  RequestJar  and I can t access it directly.  Maybe I can do it as follow code:     jar._jar.xxxx  ;     But access a member with  _  prefix is not a good way.
