title: [Feature] Route like format for URI
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >  I want to have an alternative to concatenation and string interpolation for dynamic URIs.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >     js  request      baseUrl:  https://github.com      uri:  /:user/:name/search?q=uriData      uriData:        user:  request        name:  request                    Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >   request  should find parameters  :user  and  :name  in the URI and replace them with provided values from  uriData  object. Values should be encoded if needed.        Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >   uriData  is ignored and URI will be used as provided        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >   koa  and  express  use  path to regexp  library to handle routes. The library also provides methods to [combine an URL from route and data] https://github.com/pillarjs/path to regexp compile reverse path to regexp . Same syntax  colon prefixed parameter  is used by  ui router . So front end and back end developers are familiar with this syntax.    I will provide a PR.        Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >  It is a common situation  when URI is not static but depends on some data. For example  I have a github repository model:     js  const githubRepo =      user:  request      name:  request    ;       To get an URI for search request I need to use concatenation     js  request  https://github.com/    githubRepo.user    /    githubRepo.name    /search?q=uriData  ;       or may to use string interpolation     js  request  https://github.com/  githubRepo.user /  githubRepo.name /search?q=uriData  ;       which is better  but still is hard to read.  Route syntax is much clear:     js  request  https://github.com/:user/:name/search?q=uriData     uriData: githubRepo   ;         URL encoding is also an issue when developer manually combines an URI.

title: npm install fails intermittently due to race condition in Redirect.prototype.onResponse
body: Summary  We spent the past 3 months investigating an issue where  npm install  would fail intermittently.    NPM 4 shows an error like this:         npm ERR  tar.unpack unzip error C: example project temp npm tmp npm 13780 b27f9707 onedrive.pkgs.visualstudio.com _packaging team npm registry cldrjs   cldrjs 0.4.8.tgz         When we inspected the NPM cache  we found that the downloaded tarball was truncated.  This mostly seems to happen in repos that have lots of multi megabyte dependencies  and in configurations where the NPM registry redirects the HTTP request for the tarball.  It was extremely difficult to investigate because it s a race condition that will stop happening if you change any number of things  the computer  the time of day  the proxy settings  etc .    The issue also occurs with the NPM 5 client  but the error message is different  although still ultimately due to a corrupted tarball :         npm ERR  code EINTEGRITY  npm ERR  sha1 20E D1MrUwyeZvYOmVLkQnQ o1Y= integrity checksum failed when using sha1: wanted sha1 20E D1MrUwyeZvYOmVLkQnQ o1Y= but got sha1 ygU0cyjTuZdxezDk6ofWXCGJbqI=.  867808 bytes          The issue also occurs with the [PNPM client] https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm   which relies on the   Request   library as well.      >    UPDATE:   PNPM is no longer affected by this issue.  See comments.     In this case  the symptom is an unhandled stream error:                       events.js:160                                 throw er; // Unhandled  error  event                                 ^                   Error: read ECONNRESET                               at exports._errnoException  util.js:1018:11                                at TLSWrap.onread  net.js:572:26          Wireshark and the VSTS server logs show that the server is correctly streaming the tarball.  In fact  we can repro the issue using [Fiddler] https://www.telerik.com/fiddler  on the local machine  and Fiddler downloads the full tarball  even though NPM still fails.  The explanation is that the NPM client is aborting the connection due to a bug in the   Request   library.        Simplest Example to Reproduce    We ultimately debugged this using a physical PC that consistently repros the problem.  Unfortunately we cannot find any other environment that consistently encounters the errors  even though 10 or more people have reported these issues to us over the past few months.  In some cases it fails consistently on the person s computer for a day or so  then suddenly starts working again.  It was really difficult to pin down.        Problem Analysis    The problem happens when the request for a tarball encounters an HTTP redirect to an Azure blob storage URL.  It goes like this:       Request.init    initializes a bunch of data structures     Request.start    creates a connection  obtains a socket  wires up event handlers    Stream events are fired such as  socket  and  request   and processed by the calling application    An HTTP response is received and passed to  Request.onRequestResponse       At this point  the [lib/redirect.js] https://github.com/request/request/blob/253c5e507ddb95dd88622087b6387655bd0ff935/lib/redirect.js L79  module kicks in with a kind of hacky way of handling this:      It tries to carefully delete all the state that was set up so far:     javascript    delete request.src    delete request.req    delete request._started    if  response.statusCode  == 401    response.statusCode  == 307         // Remove parameters from the previous response  unless this is the second request      // for a server that requires digest authentication.      delete request.body      delete request._form      if  request.headers           request.removeHeader  host          request.removeHeader  content type          request.removeHeader  content length          if  request.uri.hostname  == request.originalHost.split  :  [0]             // Remove authorization if changing hostnames  but not if just          // changing ports or protocols .  This matches the behavior of curl:          // https://github.com/bagder/curl/blob/6beb0eee/lib/http.c L710          request.removeHeader  authorization                                ...but note that it doesn t unwire any event handlers  and it obviously cannot undo any stream events that were already processed by the caller    Then it calls  Request.init    again on the same object    Which causes  Request.start    to create a new connection and a new a socket  and wire up the same event handlers to these new objects    Stream events are fired such as  socket  and  request  are fired a second time    The second HTTP response is received and passed to  Request.onRequestResponse     which starts streaming bytes to the calling application    Even though this design seems super brittle  it does work most of the time.  In most cases  the tarball is successfully streamed and unzipped.    But every once in a while  [onRequestError  ] https://github.com/request/request/blob/253c5e507ddb95dd88622087b6387655bd0ff935/request.js L862  will get called with an ECONNRESET error that crashes the install.  Here s the details:      The error occurs after the above sequence  and always on the second socket for that   Request   instance    Inside  onRequestError     we find that  self.req.socket.destroyed  is true.  It seems to be an old socket that was supposed to be returned to the connection pool.    The Wireshark timings show that this ECONNRESET error is for an unused HTTP connection that has been idle for a while  and is now timing out due to keepalive    But we never find a socket in that state [where it s first obtained] https://github.com/request/request/blob/253c5e507ddb95dd88622087b6387655bd0ff935/request.js L778     seems like something is destroying the socket later    For the PNPM repro  the application s error handler is missing because it s a  once  handler that has already fired once before.  We tried working around this by attaching a second handler  but it just crashes later because [npm registry client] https://github.com/npm/npm registry client/blob/c03a77aba3e86e191b4025e34da47afb452c684a/lib/fetch.js L40  tries to push the error back down onto the response s stream  creating an infinite loop        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >    I believe the ideal solution would be to rethink the design of   lib/redirect.js    to avoid trying to reconstruct the Request instance  and to avoid mixing together stream events from two different HTTP requests.  That s probably a lot of work.    For PNPM  which we are using now   we found a workaround which simply ignores the error and prevents it from tripping up the installation:       javascript  Request.prototype.onRequestError = function  error       var self = this    if  self._aborted         return         if  self.req    self.req._reusedSocket    error.code ===  ECONNRESET          self.agent.addRequestNoreuse         self.agent =   addRequest: self.agent.addRequestNoreuse.bind self.agent         self.start        self.req.end        return         if  self.timeout    self.timeoutTimer         clearTimeout self.timeoutTimer       self.timeoutTimer = null           // PROPOSED WORKAROUND:    if  self.req    self.req.socket    self.req.socket.destroyed         return;           self.emit  error   error             It s interesting that a few lines above  someone else had written some logic that seems to be handling a similar issue for the [ForeverAgent] https://github.com/request/forever agent  case.  However that code was disabled [forever ago] https://github.com/request/request/blob/253c5e507ddb95dd88622087b6387655bd0ff935/request.js L471 .    This workaround unfortunately does not fix NPM  even though the  self.req.socket.destroyed  condition does get executed many times during the install.          Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >  I m not sure why the race condition suddenly became so frequent this summer.  We ve tried upgrading/downgrading NodeJS and NPM and   request   and   npm registry client   and it has no effect.  8 different experts from various teams  including Azure and Visual Studio Team Services  all worked together on this investigation.    It s been a huge headache for us. I just received another problem report from someone   as I was typing up this issue  .  : P  It would be awesome if it could get some attention.  You can find [lots] https://github.com/facebookincubator/create react app/issues/1427  and [lots] https://github.com/cncjs/cncjs/issues/172  of [examples] https://github.com/mithunsatheesh/node rules/issues/32  of people struggling with these symptoms.  Like our experiences  people figure out a black magic  solution  that merely shuffles the race condition around  and seems to work  but then another person hits the same issue.        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               6.10.2    npm                5.5.1    Operating System   Windows 10

title: Nodejs Hangs up on Receiving 202 statusCode and retries automatically after 2 mins
body: Context  I am creating a nodejs client server for my angular app. Request is sent to process large data  while data is being processed we send back 202 status Code. I use same handler Callback for all requests which basically Emails me request log details on call back and options are as follows . It is working for many requests which doesn t send back 202 but only 200. But at this particular request the nodejs server itself stops responding to further requests. From main server logs we know that the request from nodejs server is going through but response is not handled at nodejs. And whole nodejs is stuck up and no further requests to the nodejs server are entertained. I have to restart server for everything to work again. And there are no error in logs available. For some reason nodejs server sends a request 2 min after first request which got 202  and that gets resolved to 200 as processing is over by then. This part of retry is not programmed by me but for some reason done by request Library itself         var options =        url: process.env.REQUEST_URL       method:  GET        json: true         headers:             Content Type :  application/json             Accept :  application/json             Authorization :  Token     process.env.TOKEN          ;            request options  handleResponse.bind  res  options   ;            function handleResponse error  response  body         if  error    parseInt response.statusCode  > 399             Email error  response  body  this.options ;          this.res.status response.statusCode .json   response :  Error    message :  Something bad happened   ;        else            this.res.status response.statusCode .json body .end  ;                     software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               v8.4.0    npm                v5.3.0    Operating System   16.04 LTS

title: request.put hangs
body: Summary  <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >    I have a nodejs server using express and I want to echo an icoming put request to another service. By echoing I mean that I send the same headers and body  on a different url.    The problem is that the request.put method is hanging and I can t even see the request on the other service.        Simplest Example to Reproduce     js  app.put  /beta/tenants/:tenant_id/wallets/:wallet_id   function  req  res         tenant_id = req.params.tenant_id    wallet_id = req.params.wallet_id      request.put  url: http://0.0.0.0:3002/beta/ws/tenants/    tenant_id    /wallets/    wallet_id  headers: req.headers  body: req.body  json: true        function optionalCallback err  httpResponse  body           if  err             console.error  request failed:   err ;          res.status 500 ;          res.send                     res.status httpResponse.statusCode         res.set httpResponse.headers         res.write body         res.end          ;    ;         I m using the body parser like this in order to get my request s body:       js  var bodyParser = require  body parser    app.use bodyParser.json   ;         And the console.log req.body  prints the following:       js    encrypted_private_key:  private key   iv:  iv   salt:  salt                Expected Behavior  The expected behavior would be to make the put request with the provided headers and body.         Current Behavior  request.put hangs        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request           2.83.0    node              v8.2.1    npm               5.3.0    Operating System

title: Request options.json and options.form inconsistencies
body: The Problem  There s two ways to send JSON  as stated in the docs  readme :    1. .json = object  2. .json = true AND .body = object    In the json function  when using the  pair method   .json = true AND body = object   there is a check to see if there isn t already a form urlencoded content type header already set before trying to send JSON  if there is  it actually treats the request as a .form request  and encodes body right in the JSON function  without the various checks the .form function provides to ensure the body is encoded correctly  for example  in cases where it s an object .    However  with the .json = object method  it doesn t care about existing headers that may or may not be there  and goes ahead and stringify s the object to send JSON regardless. One flaw with this  is that if there IS a form urlencoded content type header present  this is maintained despite that it s sending a stringify ied object.    There s actually a heap of issues that come up because of this that are really hard to articulate without writing a book  because what we have now is that neither .json or .form behave in a consistent fashion. I can see why the JSON stuff was done this way  but when you re a user using this library  chasing some of these seemingly random variances in output is really tricky and time consuming.    The actual root problem here that I originally wanted to fix  which I think causes all this weirdness  is that .json is used both as a flag to  Accept: application/json   and as a mechanism to actually send a JSON payload where it ultimately becomes  Content Type: application/json . However the two aren t mutually inclusive and this is where the issues come in. This seems like a design issue. These potentially should be separated into two different flags  or perhaps the convenience functionality should be removed  or people should be unable to add what fits the requirements for both a form and json request simultaneously.    This problem is compounded by the various combinations you can have of options.form  options.json  options.body  and options.headers.        Potential Solution and Step in the Right Direction    Trying to fix what I deem as the root issue above  seemed to be a tangled mess that wasn t going to be very backwards compatible  so in the pull request to follow  I instead opted to achieve:    1. If .form and .json functions worry about content type headers  they should worry about them in all use cases.    2. Because request worries about the content type headers  looking at the options flags .form and .json isn t enough to determine if the request should be a form or JSON request. Since headers can be manually injected into the options parameter.    3. Unify the form processing logic  don t have the .json function do what work that the .form function should have already performed  since it runs first.    4. Ultimate goal is to have  .json = object  ==  .json = true AND body = object  be equivalent  and on the flipside form requests with a body be equivalent.    5. By making the functionality consistent and more readable  hopefully   the consistency will help users will not fall into the trap of trying various combinations and seeing differing results while debugging  and contributors maintaining request will easily grasp the intentions of the software.        Example to Reproduce       js  var requestOptions = [    // Test 1  happy case     //  content type :  application/x www form urlencoded     // request.body:  some=url encoded=data            url:  http://127.0.0.1:1337        headers:   content type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=UTF 8         form:  some:  url   encoded:  data         json: true          // Test 2  happy case     //  content type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=UTF 8     // request.body:  some=url encoded=data            url:  http://127.0.0.1:1337        headers:   content type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=UTF 8         body:  some=url encoded=data        json: true          // Test 3  happy case     //  content type :  application/json     // request.body:    foo : bar              url:  http://127.0.0.1:1337        json:  foo:  bar            // Test 4  happy case     //  content type :  application/json     // request.body:    foo : bar              url:  http://127.0.0.1:1337        body:  foo:  bar         json: true          // Test 5  issue case     //  content type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=UTF 8     // request.body:    foo : bar              url:  http://127.0.0.1:1337        headers:   content type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=UTF 8         body:  some=url encoded=data        json:  foo:  bar            // Test 6  issue case     // TypeError: str.replace is not a function           url:  http://127.0.0.1:1337        headers:   content type :  application/x www form urlencoded; charset=UTF 8         body:  foo:  bar         json: true       ];    requestOptions.forEach function options       try        request.post options ;      catch e         console.log e ;         ;           Related Issues    https://github.com/request/request/issues/1759   This is a related issue that was never completely addressed  the change was quickly reverted  it was a pretty blunt change .        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            v2.58.0 and v2.83.0    node               v6.9.2    npm                3.10.9    Operating System   Mac OS X 10.11.6

title: Describe casing for method option
body: PR Checklist: [x] I have run npm test locally and all tests are passing. [n/a] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior. < Request is a complex project there are VERY FEW exceptions where a new test is not required for new behavior. > [n/a] If this is a significant change an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A or add link to issue here] < If you d like to suggest a significant change to request please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather feedback BEFORE submitting your PR. > PR Description The code base is treating HTTP method casing inconsistently. For example [request.js:1389] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L1389 converts the method to all uppercase while [index.js:L49] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/index.js L49 is only checking against all upper case. In this specific case if head is the method it could still by pass all the checks. Thus IMO the easiest way to solve this is to document the casing. Personally I d prefer to make HTTP method case insensitive as a feature however due to lack of knowledge about the code base I m not able to create an PR for that. < Reviewable:start > This change is [] https://reviewable.io/reviews/request/request/2827 < Reviewable:end >

title: Remove hawk dependency
body: I can t take this any more.    Request has a dependency on [hawk] https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk  even though no one uses that feature. It was added because @mikeal was using it a few years ago. People who use hawk are more likely to be using other hapi ecosystem modules like wreck and no hawk user needs it integrated like this. I wrote hawk and am its main user and I don t want it integrated in wreck  the module I use instead of request.    Every other week some request user opens an issue on hawk  hoek  boom  or the other dependencies with shitty attitude and a sense of entitlement  even if they think they are being nice about it  demanding changes  asking to support older versions of node  removing dependencies that annoy their build system  complain about how it s not working well with yarn  and other issues I don t care about.    NONE of these people USE hawk  or give a crap about the way I do things. I am not asking them to. These are developers that have not chosen to work within my ecosystem and my way of doing things. This was forced on them as much as on me.    It is also absurd that every month  hawk is downloaded 24 million times  hoek 26 millions times  boom 36 million times  cryptiles 24 million times  and sntp 24 million times FOR NO REASON  That s over 100 millions monthly download of code NO ONE uses.    I am always happy to try and solve real issues people have with my code. I take pride of my work and go out of my way to support people who honored me with building their product using it. But this is not part of the deal. You don t get to waste my time if you don t use my work in a meaningful way.    Please find the less disruptive way to remove this or make it optional in some way. For example  joi has a dependency on isemail that is structured in a way that the module is only loaded when needed which allows people to not require they don t want it.    At some point  I am going to take one sided actions that will force this move. I am not going to break anything but I sure can annoy the fuck out of everyone with colorful console logs...    We are like a couple who finds out a year later that when got drunk one night and got married. Time for a quick annulment   we are already seeing other people.

title: Some exceptions ignore  error  event listener
body: Summary  Current  request  version fires some exceptions synchronously  not letting users to handle them with an   error   event listener.  Those exceptions could still be handled with a  callback .  But since using  callback  causes  request  to buffer incoming data  it may not be an option.        Simplest Example to Reproduce       js  request  invalid_uri      .on  error      => console.log  error       .on  complete      => console.log  complete                Expected Behavior    Since   error   handler was attached to request object synchronously  it s expected to catch all exceptions  including  Invalid URI  exception.        Current Behavior    Right now   error   event with  Invalid URI  exception is fired synchronously inside a  request ...   call before any   error   handler could be attached.  As a result  this exception is thrown into an event loop.        Possible Solution  One possible solution is to wrap all synchronous  .emit  error   ...   calls with [process.nextTick] https://nodejs.org/api/process.html process_process_nexttick_callback_args .  It should deffer   error   events firing enough to let users register their error handlers.        Context  I ve encountered this issue while downloading huge files from a remote server using  request .  Since those files are very large  their content is piped into an appropriate consumer immediately.  In other circumstances I could ve used  callback  to handle all exceptions. But registering a  callback  causes  request  to buffer an entire response  which is absolutely unacceptable in my case.        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               8.4.0    npm                5.5.1    Operating System   Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS  kernel 4.4.0 101 generic

title: Webpack bundle includes every feature whether it s used or not
body: This makes the library ill suited for universal javascript.  There are many features that blow up the size of the bundle that should be opt in.  There should be a core for the library that could be bundled for the browser leaving off features such as HAR for example.

title: Request is not redirected due to encoded location header
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary  Hi guys  I m having trouble with sending request to URL which precedes redirection to another one after receiving  301 .        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js  request  http://www.tanitbar.ru/menu.aspx?cat=6   function  error  response  body       console.log  error:   error ;    console.log  response   response ;    ;        1  First response contains status code equals to 301  that means that we should redirect to URL from  location  header  but it contains encoded Russian letters:                   2  Since this URL   http://www.tanitbar.ru/               doesn t exist  I m getting  404  error        Expected Behavior  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >  Expect to get html body of page  with status code equals to  200       Current Behavior  <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >  I m getting  404  for now      Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >   curl  works fine and redirects to another URL after receiving 301   curl  http://www.tanitbar.ru/menu.aspx?cat=6   L    curl doesn t redirect by default  therefore we need to pass   L  option     I guess we should decode location header somehow before redirection  By the way I could not decode it by hand       Context  <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >  Couldn t receive content of the page from JS. title: JSON.parse failing because of BOM char
body: Summary  BOM not stripped from response body when body filled with buffer        Simplest Example to Reproduce     js      request            url: url           json: true           strictSSL: false           error  response  data  =>            if  error                 throw error;                       if  response.statusCode === 200                 // data is string instead of json deserialized object                                 Expected Behavior  BOM char stripped and json response deserialized        Current Behavior  JSON.parse fails and a string is returned        Possible Solution     js      if  bufferLength           debug  has body   self.uri.href  bufferLength         response.body = Buffer.concat buffers  bufferLength         if  self.encoding  == null             response.body = response.body.toString self.encoding                  //  buffer  is defined in the parent scope and used in a closure it exists for the life of the Request.        // This can lead to leaky behavior if the user retains a reference to the request object.        buffers = []        bufferLength = 0        else if  strings.length           // The UTF8 BOM [0xEF 0xBB 0xBF] is converted to [0xFE 0xFF] in the JS UTC16/UCS2 representation.        // Strip this value out when the encoding is set to  utf8   as upstream consumers won t expect it and it breaks JSON.parse  .        if  self.encoding ===  utf8     strings[0].length > 0    strings[0][0] ===   uFEFF              strings[0] = strings[0].substring 1                  response.body = strings.join                  As we can see the BOM char is stripped when strings are used instead of buffer  Extract the code outside of the else if  strings.length  to always clean the response body.        Context  Reading json response from a company custom swagger based on swashbuckle        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               9.3.0    npm                5.5.1    Operating System   Windows 10

title: gspread.exceptions.RequestError: 401  Invalid token: Crypto credential expired
body:
Hi I know this issue has already been mentionned [here] https://github.com/burnash/gspread/issues/333 [here] https://github.com/burnash/gspread/issues/272 or [here] https://github.com/burnash/gspread/issues/373 but none of these solutions worked for me. I m trying to fill a google spreadsheet in python3 using request and ServiceAccountCredentials of oauth2client.service_account module. The script is the following: import json import pandas as pd import requests import gspread from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials def open_spreadsheet : print Opening Spreadsheet... scope = [ https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds ] credentials = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name Apps Script Execution API Quic 0d5369b6757b.json scope try: gc = gspread.authorize credentials sheet = gc.open myspreadsheet .get_worksheet 0 print Opening of Spreadsheet: OK except gspread.exceptions.RequestError: print Cannot open Google Spreadsheet. Retry one more time in 10 seconds to access it. time.sleep 10 gc = gspread.authorize credentials sheet = gc.open mysheet .get_worksheet 0 return sheet sheet = open_spreadsheet ... while 1 : ... try: sheet.update_cell index_ligne 2 arg1 except gspread.exceptions.HTTPError gspread.exceptions.requests gspread.exceptions.RequestError as e: sheet = open_spreadsheet sheet.update_cell index_ligne 2 arg1 After launching the script the program runs approximately for 1 hour before the following error shows up: File /home/Maggle/.local/lib/python3.6/site packages/gspread/models.py line 512 in update_cell self._cell_addr row col File /home/Maggle/.local/lib/python3.6/site packages/gspread/client.py line 210 in get_cells_cell_id_feed r = self.session.get url File /home/Maggle/.local/lib/python3.6/site packages/gspread/httpsession.py line 73 in get return self.request GET url params=params kwargs File /home/Maggle/.local/lib/python3.6/site packages/gspread/httpsession.py line 69 in request response.status_code response.content gspread.exceptions.RequestError: 401 401: b n nToken invalid Invalid token: Crypto credential expired. n n n

Token invalid Invalid token: Crypto credential expired.

n

Error 401 n n n It seems that I can t use or get a refresh token. So to tackle this I tried request.login method: def login_spreadsheet : scope = [ https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds ] credentials = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name Apps Script Execution API Quic 0d5369b6757b.json scope gc = gspread.authorize credentials gc.login sheet = gc.open mysheet .get_worksheet 0 print Successfully logged in return sheet ... try: sheet.update_cell index_ligne 2 arg1 except gspread.exceptions.HTTPError gspread.exceptions.requests gspread.exceptions.RequestError as e: sheet = login_spreadsheet sheet_update_cell index_ligne 2 arg1 It didn t work either and I still got the same error.Then I tried to add some lines indicated [here] https://github.com/burnash/gspread/issues/333 but it didn t work either: def login_spreadsheet : scope = [ https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds ] credentials = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name Apps Script Execution API Quic 0d5369b6757b.json scope gc = gspread.authorize credentials gc.login http = httplib2.Http http = credentials.authorize http credentials.refresh http gc = gspread.authorize credentials sheet = gc.open mysheet .get_worksheet 0 print Successfully logged in return sheet Finally I unsuccessfully attempted to create a new class as developed [here] https://github.com/burnash/gspread/issues/373 which looks like: class WKS: def __init__ self : scope = [ https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds ] self.credentials = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name Apps Script Execution API Quic 0d5369b6757b.json scope self._refresh_auth def _refresh_auth self : gc = gspread.authorize self.credentials self.wks = gc.open_by_key 11EroRI36SeERHisr50ZE0OE9Nxg9OZ9FnUh1X1BTu3M .sheet1 def _decorate self method : def safe_method args kwargs : try: method args kwargs except gspread.exceptions.HTTPError as e: getattr is needed to get a new instance of self.wks getattr self.wks method.__name__ args kwargs return safe_method def __getattr__ self attr : doesn t shadow _refresh_auth and _decorate return self._decorate getattr self.wks attr sheet = WKS sheet = sheet.wks val = sheet.cell 2 1 .value But I got again and again the same gspread.exceptions.RequestError: 401 Invalid token after one hour of peaceful run. I work on PyCharm CE 2017.2.3 for OS X and on pythonanywhere.com and the issue is the same for both environments. My version of request is 2.18.4 and oauth2client is 4.1.2 any ideas or suggestions will be gratefully welcomed :

title: persistent jar between session with to/fromJSON
body: I need to store the cookies between two sessions.  For this  all it takes is adding the following to lib/cookies.js:         RequestJar.prototype.toJSON = function         var self = this    return self._jar.toJSON       RequestJar.prototype.fromJSON = function         var self = this    return self._jar.fromJSON              I hope this is agreeable to you and that such change can be merged into the official distribution.

title: AWS options should support region and service name for non standard SigV4 endpoints
body: Summary  aws option in requests not sufficient for non standard AWS URLs.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >       js  request      method:  POST      url:  https://a39m6bjbcdlsl4.iot.us east 1.amazonaws.com       aws:        key:  foo        secret:  bar                       Expected Behavior  The user needs a way to provide a region and service name so that aws4 will calculate the correct signature in the case that the user is using a non standard SigV4 signed endpoint.        Current Behavior  Currently a user attempting to make a call to a non standard endpoint will receive an error that an incorrect signature has been calculated.        Possible Solution  The simplest thing to do here seems to be to modify request.js and add region and service as new fields in the options object that gets passed to aws4 for signing.        Context  This problem has forced me to locally modify request in order to workaround this issue and be able to correctly sign requests to my IoT endpoint.

title: Remove request.prototype.getHeader  .
body: [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [ ] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [ ] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A  or add link to issue here]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  With the addition of  caseless  in v2.41.0   1006   getHeader  is now set on a request instance inside  caseless.httpify .  https://github.com/request/request/blob/253c5e507ddb95dd88622087b6387655bd0ff935/request.js L160    https://github.com/request/caseless/blob/a3edd69b68c014a1599bd095ca19a944a355d013/index.js L59 L61    It seems this definition was simply missed during the cleanup and left behind. A single instance of the legacy call signature  providing a second arg  was in  httpSignature  which is always called after  caseless.httpify  is run on the request.

title: First request hangs while using followAllRedirects
body: I have a electron app interacting with a remote express server with passport authentication. The login route looks somewhat like        js  app.post  /login   passport.authenticate  local           successRedirect:  /loginSuccess         failureRedirect:  /loginFailure       ;       In the electron app I am using request module in the following way        js  var options =        jar: j       followAllRedirects: true       url:  http://localhost:5050/login        method:  POST        request  option   err  resp  body  =>        if  err  throw err      console.log body              When the request is made for the first time the callback does not trigger. Nor is log generated for  /loginSuccess  path access on the express server. But when I make the request a second time  it works. And the access logs on webserver look something like  after two requests         js  POST /login  GET /loginSuccess  POST /login         The route works perfectly when used with postman or the HTML form and the access logs look like  after two requests         js  POST /login  GET /loginSuccess  POST /login  GET /loginSuccess       If I set followAllRedirects to false  the callback is triggered on the first request.

title: Unwanted behavior of request on some linux distros.
body: Summary  So far this issue is reproducible on Ubuntu and Fedora 27.    The problem is that when you send another instance of    request    inside the callback of a previous    request     the second request is somewhat swallowed or hiding somewhere and will just come up if there is another instance of request is send.  And this also will prevent the use of promise chaining.    I already post it on SO [Unable to send request from request callback] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48135641/unable to send request from request callbackl .        Simple Example to Reproduce  I did a sample project https://github.com/zer09/request_test  It include the express server and a electron app.  There is the 3 menus to test  Get Request    Post Request    Post Promise Request .  The result can be seen on console.        Expected Behavior  You should see the result of the second request.        Current Behavior  The second request is somewhat swallowed.        Possible Solution  Hmmm  sorry  I don t have any idea for now  I don t have depth understanding how request works at the moment  basically I just starting studying JS since last year.        Context  Actually this works on MS Windows  tested on vm  but using on Fedora the problem exists. If you create app using electron  then possibly this wont work on some distro of linux.        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               8.9.3    npm                5.6.0    express           4.15.5    Operating System   Fedora 27

title: Set Cookie header not being respected
body: Summary  When a cookie jar has been set in the options and the set cookie header has been returned in a response the cookie is not set into the cookie jar and the header is not listed properly in the response.        Simplest Example to Reproduce  Run a server on 3001 using NodeJS   Express   PassportJS with a local strategy for authentication.     js  // Express configuration  var app = express  ;  app.use bodyParser.urlencoded   extended: false  type:  application/x www form urlencoded     ;  app.use cors   ;  app.use require  cookie parser     ;  app.use session   secret:  cats     ;  app.use passport.initialize   ;  app.use passport.session   ;    // Passport  authentication  setup  passport.use new LocalStrategy users.authenticate  ;  passport.deserializeUser users.authDeserializeUser ;  passport.serializeUser users.authSerializeUser ;    app.post  /login   passport.authenticate  local    function req  res         res.send  ;    ;         Create client code to perform login against server     js  var cookieJar = request.jar  ;  var url =  http://localhost:3001/login ;  var options =      method:  POST      form:        username:  jsmith2        password:  password           jar: cookieJar   ;    request url  options   error  response  body  =>        ...    ;             Expected Behavior  Inspecting the response parameter should show a header like the following:       set cookie: connect.sid=s 3A7Lf02SOfm_b6oQh1lR9LgDeQxWwtG3HC.9tPr9ymv 2BLVJl5yo54vsEk3H9 2FQpcgmApMizTuo6yTs; Path=/; HttpOnly         The cookie jar should have one cookie set.        Current Behavior  Response parameter includes no set cookie header and no cookie stored in the jar.    Debug Console shows:     js  request:      body:  username=jsmith2 password=password      debugId: 5     headers:        content length: 34       content type:  application/x www form urlencoded        host:  localhost:3001          method:  POST      uri:  http://localhost:3001/login      response:      body:        debugId: 5     headers:        statusCode: 200            However running Fiddler shows the following:       POST http://localhost:3001/login HTTP/1.1  Host: localhost:3001  Connection: keep alive  Content Length: 34  Origin: http://localhost:3000  User Agent: Mozilla/5.0  Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64  AppleWebKit/537.36  KHTML  like Gecko  Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36  content type: application/x www form urlencoded  Accept:  /   Referer: http://localhost:3000/login  Accept Encoding: gzip  deflate  br  Accept Language: en US en;q=0.9    username=jsmith2 password=password    HTTP/1.1 200 OK  X Powered By: Express  Access Control Allow Origin:    set cookie: connect.sid=s 3A7Lf02SOfm_b6oQh1lR9LgDeQxWwtG3HC.9tPr9ymv 2BLVJl5yo54vsEk3H9 2FQpcgmApMizTuo6yTs; Path=/; HttpOnly  Date: Thu  25 Jan 2018 22:05:01 GMT  Connection: keep alive  Content Length: 0             Your Environment    software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               8.2.1    npm                5.5.1    Operating System   Windows 10  Version 1709  Build 16299.125

title: Request used as a streaming proxy breaks when query string parameters contain URLs
body: We use request to proxy using the stream API  so we can t really control what query strings people will pass. We noticed this error in our logs:        Error: options.uri must be a path when using options.baseUrl    When a client requests the path:        /item/detail/395691820/? deeplink_path=item/detail/395691820/  fallback_url=https://offerup.com/item/detail/395691820/ button=item_view user_id=36953831 event_id=2018 01 26_LosAngeles_CA_5 _branch_match_id=459093596557993047    After some tinkering it seems to be the URL that s the problem. Here s the stack trace:         Error: options.uri must be a path when using options.baseUrl      at Request.init  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/request/request.js:212:33       at new Request  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/request/request.js:130:8       at request  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/request/index.js:54:10       at /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/request_test.js:18:25      at Layer.handle [as handle_request]  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:95:5       at trim_prefix  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:317:13       at /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:284:7      at Function.process_params  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:335:12       at next  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:275:10       at expressInit  /Users/john.simons/repos/webapp/monorepo/services/web/src/node_modules/express/lib/middleware/init.js:40:5          Also I boiled it down to as simple of a repro case as I could  but it still depends on Express:    That code is below. If you request any path on localhost:8080 you ll repro the error.           const request = require  request  ;  const express = require  express  ;    let baseUrl =  https://www.google.com ;    // Breaks with  Error: options.uri must be a path when using options.baseUrl   // if you use this URL.   let uri =  /movies/about/?x=https://foo.com ;    // It seems to be something about an unescaped URL as a query string  // parameter. This works fine:  // let url =  /movies/about/?x=https 3A//foo.com ;  //   // But colons themselves aren t the problem because this works also:  // let url =  /movies/about/?x=y:z ;      const app = express  ;    app.use function req  res  next           var remoteRequest = request            baseUrl: baseUrl           uri: uri           headers: req.headers           followRedirect: false         ;        req.pipe remoteRequest           .on  error   next           .pipe res ;    ;    app.listen 8080 ;         Workaround we re currently using is to escape colons with  s/:/ 3A/

title: Feature Request: Option to disable automatic URLEncode of URL
body: Summary  Add an option to the  RequestPromiseOptions  for disabling automatic URLEncoding of characters in Urls        Context  I know this is an odd feature request.  I am working with Azure Media Services API. I need to make a request to a URL like        https://media.windows.net/API/Locators  nb:lid:UUID:5bfcb65d 843d 4d5e bf71 9306ecb08203          See their API documentation at https://docs.microsoft.com/en us/rest/api/media/operations/locator and yes  I didn t believe it worked this way either.     Sending the request with request  the single quotes get replaced by   27 s and the request fails with  401   undefined  in the message.  Inspecting the error object reporting the error shows something like this under  request/uri/href .        ...    href : https://blob.restv2.location.media.azure.net/api/Locators  27nb:lid:UUID:f4db7680 45b4 404c 91e9 abcdefabcdef 27     ...         I can make valid requests using Postman and request libraries in other languages where I can force the  correct  behavior  unescaped single quotes .  Also  endpoints other than ones that expect the singlequotes work properly  so I know I have the correct host and authorization information.    There are options for the query string  but those options do not apply to the rest of the URL.    I have searched deeply for documentation  and searched existing issues extensively  but nothing covers this use case.  If there is already support or a workaround for this  please let me know how.        Your Environment    software           version                                  request            2.83.0    node               8.8.1    npm                5.5.1    Operating System   Win10 x64    Thank you for your time and consideration.

title: Support proxy basic auth in URL without password
body: [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [x] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.    According to [RFC 2617] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2617 section 2   Basic authentication must have a  :  between the username and password  and according to [RFC 3986] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986 section 3.2.1   the  userinfo  component doesn t require the  :  character to be present.    The usual interpretation of that is that if an URI defines authentication with just an username  e.g.  http://user@host   when this is translated to Basic authentication  the password is considered empty and  user:  is sent  sending just  user  would be invalid .    This is currently supported for the main request URI  but it s not tested for  maybe it s a side effect of the way the code is written   but not supported for proxy with authentication in the URL.    This PR:    1. Adds test for the main request URI to make sure it supports the username being defined in the URI without a  :  and a password  and that it translates to a valid Basic authentication.  2. Adds test for both proxy and proxy connect to ensure this behaviour.  3. Fix the proxy authentication code to ensure the  :  is present in the Basic authorization header.  4. Fix the proxy connect code to support this case. I m unsure if this should be fixed here in directly in tunnel agent but I m assuming the latter is more low level and maybe shouldn t care about that.      Note:   tests pass locally  not sure why it does not on CI but seems unrelated.

title: Request with method: HEAD returns body in response
body: Summary  I m trying to get the headers for a url without waiting for the entire body. It seems I should be able to do that by setting the  method  option to  HEAD :            Simplest Example to Reproduce       var requestOpts =        url:  http://www.google.com        method:  HEAD     ;  request.get requestOpts  function  error  response  body         console.log error  response ;    ;             Expected Behavior  According to the spec of HTTP methods  HEAD should get the headers  not the body:    > Same as GET but returns only HTTP headers and no document body  > https://www.w3schools.com/tags/ref_httpmethods.asp        Current Behavior  The response object contains a  body  property that contains  in this examples  case  html output.        Possible Solution  N/A        Context  I m trying to figure out what the  final  redirect url is for an Icecast stream. The problem is that if I use GET the request keeps going because it s a never ending radio stream:  http://playerservices.streamtheworld.com/api/livestream redirect/VERONICA.mp3        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            ^2.83.0    node               8.2.1    npm                5.6.0    Operating System   Windows 10 x64

title: No compatible version found: request@ 2.79.0
body: I had an earlier version of  node sass  and I am trying to install the latest version of  node sass    4.7.2 and I get the error below. I removed the earlier to check if that would help me installing node sass correctly  even now installing the new version does not work.    NPM Error when trying to install  node sass       npm ERR  Windows_NT 10.0.14393  npm ERR  argv  C:  Program Files  nodejs  node.exe   C:  Program Files  nodejs  node_modules  npm  bin  npm cli.js   install   node sass   npm ERR  node v6.11.4  npm ERR  npm  v3.10.10  npm ERR  code ETARGET    npm ERR  notarget No compatible version found: request@ 2.79.0  npm ERR  notarget Valid install targets:  npm ERR  notarget 2.83.0  2.81.0  2.76.0  2.75.0  2.74.0  2.55.0  2.16.6  npm ERR  notarget  npm ERR  notarget This is most likely not a problem with npm itself.  npm ERR  notarget In most cases you or one of your dependencies are requesting  npm ERR  notarget a package version that doesn t exist.  npm ERR  notarget  npm ERR  notarget It was specified as a dependency of  node sass   npm ERR  notarget

title: put stream fails with larger files >64kB
body: this is hopefully not an issue   just a  understanding  problem on my side.    BTW:  I first asked at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48776919/node js request module put stream fails with larger files 64kb  but probably its better here.     I use a small node.js express server to test/simulate a file upload download server with HTTP put/get:       app.use express.static SERVER_DIR    app.put  /put/:filename    req  res  =>      req.pipe fs.createWriteStream  SERVER_DIR   req.params.filename  ;    res.send  OK             the above server works fine if tested with  shell  curl put/get:       curl  http://localhost:8765/put/   T 100MB.file  curl  http://localhost:8765/100MB.file   o 100MB.get        tested up to 1GB   check if uploaded /downloaded files are equal with cmp     My problem ist to upload  put  the files with a node.js client using the request module:       fs.createReadStream filename .pipe request.put SERVER_URL  put/  filename           this upload works fine with small files > 64kB but it fails for larger. uploading file with 65400Byte is working / file with 65450Byte is not working   it stops after 65410Byte / EOF error.      How can I change this limit ?      BTW: download  get  with the node.js request client app:     request SERVER_URL filename .pipe fs.createWriteStream filename         works with large 1GB files.

title: TLS Check Server Identity callback silently dropped
body: Summary    NodeJS provides a [checkServerIdentity] https://nodejs.org/api/tls.html tls_tls_checkserveridentity_host_cert  callback function which is generally used by userland to add extra validation for the server certificate  such as pinning the certificate fingerprint.    This works very well in all cases  except for the tunneling agent.  When the TLS options are being copied over from the standard  options  argument  there is a [whitelist of options] https://github.com/request/request/blob/v2.83.1/lib/tunnel.js L70 L87   which unfortunately does not include the  checkServerIdentity  callback.    This results in a security accident where certificate pinning works in environment without proxy  while the check is silently skipped when being proxied.          Simplest Example to Reproduce       js  var request = require  request  ;    var options =        url:  https://www.google.com/        checkServerIdentity:  servername  peer  =>            const good =  77:53:28:AD:42:B1:04:F7:49:2B:C7:C7:7B:2A:84:64:EA:0B:1F:CE ;          const bad =  mismatch           if  peer.fingerprint  == bad                 return new Error   Fingerprint mismatch  ;                     console.log  Woohoo  www.google.com is using our pinned fingerprint            ;    request options  function  error  response  body       console.log  error:   error ;    ;         Currently  when the script is execute with     shell    node poc.js       it correctly rejects the certificate and returns the  Fingerprint mismatch  error.  However  when running behind proxy:     shell    https_proxy=http://localhost:3128 node poc.js       The script will erroneously continue  never calling the checkServerIdentity function at all.        Expected Behavior         error: Error: Fingerprint mismatch      at Object.checkServerIdentity  /var/www/git repos/tunnel/poc.js:9:20       at TLSSocket.onConnectSecure  _tls_wrap.js:1051:27       at TLSSocket.emit  events.js:160:13       at TLSSocket._finishInit  _tls_wrap.js:638:8              Current Behavior         error: null             Possible Solution      Easiest fix is to add  checkServerIdentity  to the whitelist    IMHO the best fix would be removing the whitelist and simply forward all the options over again

title: Hawk dependency causes security risk
body: I recently ran a Node Security scan on a project that uses Request and found a security issue related to the version of Hawk  and subsequently Hoek  that Request is using.    request@2.83.0 > hawk@6.0.2 > hoek@4.2.0    https://nodesecurity.io/advisories/566  https://hackerone.com/reports/310439

title: Update hawk version
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [ ] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [ ] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A  or add link to issue here]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  <    Describe Your PR Here    >  Update hawk version in order to avoid a known vulnerability in hoek.  request@2.83.0 > hawk@6.0.2 > hoek@4.2.0    https://nodesecurity.io/advisories/566  https://hackerone.com/reports/310439    Closes  2874

title: Adding redirectLocationTrusted option to retain authorization header on redirect domain change
body: PR Checklist:    [Y] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [Y] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.      new tests added into tests/test redirect auth.js    [Y] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed:      Not a significant change  but has been mentioned a few times in the issues:        https://github.com/request/request/issues/2606        https://github.com/request/request/issues/2278         PR Description  If a redirect location has a different domain than the original request  excluding port and protocol changes  then any authorization header is removed from the request. This is a deliberate choice in the code  to do the same as curl  for security reasons     Curl does have an option   location trusted for overriding that behaviour though:  https://curl.haxx.se/docs/manpage.html   location trusted  so this pull request is to add an equivalent option  redirectLocationTrusted  to request. If not supplied this option defaults to false  keeping the original behaviour.    In this change I ve kept  redirectLocationTrusted  as the simple boolean that curl has. It _could_ be overloaded for finer grained options  e.g. a domain matching regex  if it was felt that would be of more value.

title: Tests consistently failing in Travis CI
body: Summary  Since the end of 2017 all Pull requests are all failing at the test headers test; this appears to be because of two issues  1. The  catch invalid characters error  test works on node v4   v6  but fails on v8.  2. The  IPv6 Host Header  test fails in all builds        Simplest Example to Reproduce  These are test bugs rather than functional bugs   compare the CI builds for the recent pull requests and see they all fail in the same way.        Current Behavior       1. Headers characters tests fails on node v8  The  catch invalid characters error  test works on node v4   v6  but fails on v8.  This test appears to be asserting _node_ functionality; there isn t anything in the request code that actually throws the error message the test looks for. The error message that node throws has changed between versions:    v6   https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/v6.x/lib/_http_outgoing.js L359  v8   https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/lib/_http_outgoing.js L496    So what s the best solution here?    1. Remove the test  since it is checking node functionality rather than the library functionality?  Or if the test needs to exist to check that  request  properly rethrows the error  2. Change request to catch the error and throw it s own consistent error?  3. Change the test to check accept either error message?    I d prefer 3. here I think.         2. The  IPv6 Host Header  test fails in all builds  There are a number of pages on this e.g.  https://github.com/travis ci/travis ci/issues/4964 issuecomment 159748141  https://github.com/travis ci/travis ci/issues/9207  https://github.com/njh/travis ipv6 test    Basically it appears that IPv6 is not supported on travis ci  and only worked previously as  a by product of where we ve been hosting   first link above . The second link above suggests it stopped working around the end of October  which would match when the pull requests started failing.    So what s the best solution here? I ve only got one solution  so others are welcome...    1. Since the environments don t support IPv6  then don t run the IPv6 test. Pass some environment flag that allows that particular test to be skipped.        Context  Blocking pull requests :         Your Environment  travis ci

Read this for more info: [https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:hoek:20180212] https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:hoek:20180212

title: Allow for custom headers in aws signature
body: Summary  On line 1367 of request.js when signing for the aws 4 signature  request only uses the  content type  header and doesn t allow for other headers to be passed in. This unfortunately produces an invalid signature when making a request to aws.    Code issue occurs here         if  opts.sign_version === 4    opts.sign_version ===  4          // use aws4      var options =          host: self.uri.host         path: self.uri.path         method: self.method           headers:             content type : self.getHeader  content type                            body: self.body             var signRes = aws4.sign options           accessKeyId: opts.key         secretAccessKey: opts.secret         sessionToken: opts.session                     Simplest Example to Reproduce  To reproduce this call a more specific aws instance  for example aws cloudwatch  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatchLogs/latest/APIReference/API_DescribeLogStreams.html    A sample request from aws docs looks like this:       POST / HTTP/1.1  Host: logs.<region>.<domain>  X Amz Date: <DATE>  Authorization: AWS4 HMAC SHA256 Credential=<Credential>  SignedHeaders=content type;date;host;user agent;x amz date;x amz target;x amzn requestid  Signature=<Signature>  User Agent: <UserAgentString>  Accept: application/json  Content Type: application/x amz json 1.1  Content Length: <PayloadSizeBytes>  Connection: Keep Alive  X Amz Target: Logs_20140328.DescribeLogStreams        logGroupName :  my log group           Sample request using request would look like this:             method :  POST       timeout : 10000      url :  https://logs.us east 1.amazonaws.com       body :    logGroupName : my log group         aws :         key : <access key>        secret : <secret key>        sign_version : 4           headers :         Accept :  application/json         Content Type :  application/x amz json 1.1         Connection :  Keep Alive         X Amz Target :  Logs_20140328.PutLogEvents                    With this sample request we would need to include  X Amz Target  in the signature and  Accept  as the others are already auto generated through aws4 signing.        Expected Behavior  Custom headers set through the request api  should be part of the signature. At the moment the example request would generate a Sign header that looks like this:       SignedHeaders=content length;content type;content type;host;x amz date       When it should look like this:       SignedHeaders=accept;connection;content length;content type;host;x amz date;x amz target       Notice that the accept  connection  x amz target headers are still there. With incorrect Sign headers it is indicative of an incorrect signature for aws.        Current Behavior  Incorrect signatures lead to an error message that looks like this:       <InvalidSignatureException> n  <Message>The request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided. Check your AWS Secret Access Key and signing method. Consult the service documentation for details. n nThe Canonical String for this request should have been n POST n/ n ncontent length:193 ncontent type: nhost:logs.us east 1.amazonaws.com nx amz date:20180222T181935Z n ncontent length;content type;host;x amz date na47e08f5b41b9ac4a0d4c93a909fb90f956c6f047513dfcc8caa3dde945ed206  n nThe String to Sign should have been n AWS4 HMAC SHA256 n20180222T181935Z n20180222/us east 1/logs/aws4_request nb4c68f9a051329634cf5086aa1ed6fc3c710a27d8aaf3cfe0b18e1288ac53ce2  n</Message> n</InvalidSignatureException> n             Possible Solution  This could be fixed by passing in options into the aws function  and calling options.headers       headers:         content type : options.headers           Not sure if there are any side effects with this but this should allow developers to get the correct signature when settings custom headers.        Context  Prevents me from making any specific action call to my aws services.    Currently a work around   I think that will work although not tested as of writing this  will be simply call request and the aws4 library. And creating the authorization header my self manually for this.         Edit   Tested the work around and it works smoothly  simply call        var aws = require  aws4  ;  aws.sign requestOptions  credentials ;        note requestOptions and credentials are parameters from here  https://github.com/mhart/aws4 api      Your Environment      software           version                                  request            2.72.0    node               8.2.1    npm                5.3    Operating System   Linux

title: request always removes header called  cookie
body: <      BEFORE YOU SUBMIT please read the following:    Please search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before     If you have a support request or question please submit them to one of this resources:      Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/request node.js using the tags  node.js     request     Gitter community: https://gitter.im/request/request?utm_source=newissue    Also have a look at the Readme for more information on how to get support:    https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/README.md    Issues on GitHub are only related to problems of request itself and we cannot answer  support questions here.    >        Summary    Request always strips headers called  cookie  as it s a reserved word. This seems to make it incompatible with the express session module which always reads cookies from the  cookie  header.    <     Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above   >        Simplest Example to Reproduce  say you had your request configured like so:      js   const options =        method:  POST        uri:    dev_api history/logs        jar: true       headers:          monkey:  hello monkey          authCookie: document.cookie              json:   scanner_execution_id: id       ;  request options        when adding the headers request silently removes reserved words  including  cookie . Below you can see the header  monkey  is preserved but cookie is removed.       js    host:  localhost:8000      connection:  keep alive       content length :  26      pragma:  no cache       cache control :  no cache      monkey:  hello monkey      origin:  http://localhost:8081       user agent :  Mozilla/5.0  Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_6  AppleWebKit/537.36  KHTML  like Gecko  Chrome/64.0.3282.167 Safari/537.36       content type :  application/json      accept:  application/json      referer:  http://localhost:8081/dashboard/history       accept encoding :  gzip  deflate  br       accept language :  en GB en US;q=0.9 en;q=0.8              <     If describing a bug  tell us what request options we can use to reproduce the same bug/behavior   >        Expected Behavior  I d expect any custom headers to be respected  or at least throw an error if you re trying to set a header with a reserved word.  <     If you re describing a bug  tell us what should happen   >  <     If you re suggesting a change/improvement  tell us how it should work   >  <     If request is handling requests/responses incorrectly  please include a link to the spec or documentation that supports that your expected behavior is correct.   >        Current Behavior  custom headers are not respected if they contain a reserved word and there is no error thrown.    <     If describing a bug  tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior   >  <     If suggesting a change/improvement  explain the difference from current behavior   >        Possible Solution  <     Not obligatory  but suggest a fix/reason for the bug    >  <     or ideas how to implement the addition or change   >        Context  I m using request in conjunction with axios. I only use request for streaming http because i prefer the streaming api.    express session reads the cookie from the  cookie  header and has not option to alter this behaviour.     Setting jar to true doesn t seem to work for cookies set by axios.    The end result seems to be that request and express session are incompatible if your attaching cookies set by another http client library.    <     How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish?   >  <     Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world   >        Your Environment  <     Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in   >      software           version                                  request            2.83    node              8.21    npm               5.3.0    Operating System   OSX 10.12.16

title: Piping with gzip leads to inconsistent response
body: If I use request with  gzip: true  and pipe it directly to the response  that response does not contain the  Content Encoding  header. Also  the  Content Length  header is set to the length of the compressed data  but the data is sent uncompressed. This causes my client to read a partial response.    I would expect either one of the two:    Data is piped uncompressed  and headers are set accordingly    Data is piped compressed  with the right headers  preferred

title: Timeout error handling
body: Read [Timeouts] https://www.npmjs.com/package/request timeouts  section of documentation.  After glancing the related code [here] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L846  as well as [here] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L813  and [here] https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/request.js L867   I was left with a few questions.    1. Are  README  suggestions still correct? Looks more like ETIMEDOUT error is exclusively connection related  and ESOCKETTIMEDOUT read related.  1. Should client side code also be checking for ESOCKETTIMEDOUT and ECONNRESET?  1. Could you change the Error messages to something useful to user?    For 3  the  errno  based names are already included as  error.code . As such  could  error.message  be made more human readable [e.g.  ETIMEDOUT >  new Error  server took too long to connect   ]?

title: Chunked FormData should not appear content length header.
body: Summary  Should  NOT  send content length header while sending chunked formData.        Simplest Example to Reproduce       nc  l localhost 3000            js  request.postAsync      url:  http://localhost:3000      formData:        box       steps       cache       env: JSON.stringify env        workspace: tar.c          gzip: true          [workspace]          ;    OR    request.postAsync      url:  http://localhost:3000      headers:          transfer encoding :  chunked           formData:        box       steps       cache       env: JSON.stringify env        workspace: tar.c          gzip: true          [workspace]          ;             Expected Behavior  Send request with  transfer encoding: chunked .        Current Behavior  While upload with readstream  it should use  transfer encoding: chunked  but doesn t  and still call setContentLength function cause socket hang up.    If set header   transfer encoding: chunked  manually  the content length didn t disappear.  And still socket hang up.        Possible Solution  Detect if transfer encoding header equal to chunk    OR    Detect if formData contain with stream.    Use chunked without content length.        Your Environment      software           version                                  request            ^2.85.0    node               v8.9.4    npm                5.6.0    Operating System   macOS 10.13.3

title: Tor Request
body: PR Checklist:    [x] I have run  npm test  locally and all tests are passing.    [ ] I have added/updated tests for any new behavior.         <    Request is a complex project  there are VERY FEW exceptions                 where a new test is not required for new behavior.   >    [ ] If this is a significant change  an issue has already been created where the problem / solution was discussed: [N/A  or add link to issue here]         <    If you d like to suggest a significant change to request                  please create an issue to discuss those changes and gather                 feedback BEFORE submitting your PR.   >         PR Description  <    Describe Your PR Here    >
